Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Black River At Black Rock affecting Independence...Jackson and
Lawrence Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The National Weather Service in Little Rock has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Black River At Black Rock.
* from Sunday evening until further notice...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 12:00 PM Friday the stage was 10.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Sunday evening and continue to
rise to near 19.0 feet by early Tuesday morning.
* Impacts at 20.0 feet...Agricultural land is flooding along both
banks of the river in Lawrence, Independence, and Jackson counties.
Minor flooding in Powhatan Community and Courthouse State Park.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.
Alert:

The Flood Warning continues for
The White River At Clarendon.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 12:00 PM Friday the stage was 27.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 27.5 feet by
Sunday morning.
* Impacts at 28.0 feet...Flooding of cropland and timber is occurring.
Roads to homes and cabins in lower Maddox Bay area off Highway 146
south of Clarendon impassible.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Sunday evening.

boaters should be very cautious. Access to many oil and gas rigs

* Flood Warning for
The Cache River Near Patterson.

is cancelled.
* At 11:00 AM Friday the stage was 6.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday early afternoon and
continue to rise to near 9.5 feet by Friday morning.
* Impacts at 10.0 feet...Pastureland and cropland not protected by
levees in Jackson and Woodruff counties affected. Water is over
portions of State Highway 37 and deep along the shoulders of State
Highway 18 near Grubbs. Water over portions of Woodruff County Road
775 north of State Highway 260.

Alert:
The areas affected include...
Northern Biscayne Bay...
Coastal waters from Aventura to South Beach FL out 10 NM...

At 1259 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated a shower capable of
producing waterspouts. This shower was located just offshore of
Surfside, moving north northwest at 10 to 15 knots.

The shower will be near...
North Bay Village, Bal Harbour, Bay Harbor Islands, Sunny Isles,
and Golden Beach.
Instruction:
Waterspouts are possible with this activity. Remain on the alert in
case warnings are issued for waterspout development.

Report severe weather to the coast guard or nearest law enforcement
agency. They will relay your report to the National Weather Service
forecast office.

Alert:
Mermentau River Near Mermentau

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Calcasieu River Near Oakdale
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Texas..

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River Near Glenmora.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:45 AM Friday the stage was 14.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 14.2 feet
by tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At stages near 15.0 feet...Flooding of secondary roads
near the river and its tributaries begins, including Ashmore Road.
Strothers Crossing Road near Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near
Hineston have several feet of water over them and subject to
washouts.
* Impact...At stages near 14.0 feet...Some roads upstream from
Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the community of
Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have two to three
feet of water over the road and are subject to being closed.
Flooding of forested areas near the river will also occur.
* Impact...At stages near 12.0 feet...When the river is rising and
the gauge reading is forecast to reach 12 feet or higher. Roads
upstream from Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the
community of Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have
water on them and are subject to being closed. Also, flooding of
forested areas near the river will occur.
Instruction:

Mermentau River Near Mermentau

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Calcasieu River Near Oakdale
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Texas..

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Atchafalaya River At Morgan City.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 11:00 AM Friday the stage was 7.7 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 7.8 feet by
tomorrow evening then begin falling.
* Impact...At stages near 7.0 feet...Buildings at the foot of Ann
Street on the river side of the flood wall will flood as water
overtops the Rio Oil Company dock. Buildings on the river side of
the Berwick floodwall will flood. River traffic restrictions will
be strictly enforced. In addition, backwater flooding could
potentially impact portions areas around Lake Palourde and
Stephensville.
* Impact...At stages near 6.0 feet...Flood stage. The city dock will
be under water. Water will cover the lower end of Belleview Front
Street in Berwick. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger
river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly
enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 5.0 feet...Floodwall gates will be closed
to protect against higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected
by stronger river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be
strictly enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Action stage. Water will move
up the bank and across access roads below the city dock. Floodwall
gates should be closed by the 5 foot stage to protect against
higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger river
current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly enforced
by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Instruction:

Alert:
* Wind: South 15 to 20 knots, with gusts to 25 knots.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots over
the Currituck Sound are expected to produce hazardous boating
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels...should avoid navigating in
these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.
Alert:
* Wind: South 15 to 20 knots, with gusts to 25 knots.

* Waves: 2 to 3 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots over
the rivers of eastern Virginia are expected to produce hazardous
boating conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.
Alert:
* Wind: South 15 to 25 knots, with gusts to 30 knots.

* Waves: 3 to 4 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots and/or
waves of 4 feet or greater over the Chesapeake Bay waters are
expected to produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.
Alert:
* Wind: South 15 to 20 knots, with gusts to 25 knots.

* Seas: 4 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots and/or
seas of 5 feet or greater over the coastal waters are expected to
produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

Alert:
At 1244 PM EDT, radar indicated showers were located along a line
extending from 6 miles south of Mineralwells to near Marmet. Movement
was northeast at 40 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph are possible with these showers.

Locations impacted include...
Charleston, Spencer, Elizabeth, Sissonville, Chesapeake, Marmet,
Belle, Clendenin, Pinch, Glen, North Bend State Park, Coal Fork,
Elkview, Amma, Mineralwells, Cairo, Reedy, Cherry, Procious and
Maxwell.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 79 between mile markers 1 and 32.
Interstate 77 in West Virginia between mile markers 96 and 111, near
mile marker 117, and between mile markers 160 and 166.
West Virginia Turnpike between mile markers 89 and 95.
Route 119 near mile marker 80.
Route 50 in West Virginia between mile markers 17 and 35.

Alert:
A strong storm system will move across Minnesota and Wisconsin
today bringing very windy conditions to the area. Winds will
increase to 25 to 35 mph by mid to late morning with gusts to
45 mph possible.
* Winds...Southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* Timing...Now through sunset.

* Impacts...Driving will be difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 mph or greater are
expected, which can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles.  Use extra caution if you are traveling.

Alert:
Wolf River near Shiocton affecting Outagamie...Shawano and Waupaca
Counties

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Wisconsin...Michigan...

Menominee River near McAllister affecting Marinette and Menominee
Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wolf River near Shiocton.
* At 7:30 AM Friday the stage was 11.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 11.7 feet by this
afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage Tuesday evening.
* Impacts at 11.5 feet. There is minor flooding at the city park
along with lowland and adjacent agricultural land.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Alert:
* HAZARDS...Dangerous rip currents and breaking waves are
expected due to elevated surf of 3 to 5 feet.

* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip
currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large
breaking waves can cause injury...wash people off beaches and
rocks...and capsize small boats near shore.
Instruction:
A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Swim near a
lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and float. Don't
swim against the current. If able, swim in a direction following
the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or
wave for help.
Alert:
* SURF...Breakers of 8 to 12 feet will linger into this evening,
then diminish overnight into early Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...Dangerous rip currents and breaking waves are
expected.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area...producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions. Swim near a lifeguard. If caught
in a rip current, relax and float. Don't swim against the
current. If able, swim in a direction following the shoreline. If
unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.
Alert:
* SURF...Breakers of 5 to 8 feet will linger into this evening,
then diminish overnight into early Saturday morning.

* Impacts...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip
currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large
breaking waves can cause injury...wash people off beaches and
rocks...and capsize small boats near shore.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area...producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions. Swim near a lifeguard. If caught
in a rip current, relax and float. Don't swim against the
current. If able, swim in a direction following the shoreline. If
unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

flooding. 416th Avenue and 257th Street are flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not drive cars through flooded areas. the water
depth and road condition may be unsafe.

Additional information is available at

http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=fsd

or your local radio and TV stations.

Alert:
At 1219 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9
miles southeast of Shelby, or near Grover, moving northeast at 35
mph.

Locations to be impacted include...
Gastonia, Kings Mountain, Cherryville, Bessemer City, Dallas, Grover,
Crowders Mountain State Park and Crouse.

Wind gusts up to 45 mph and very heavy rainfall rates up to 2 inches
per hour will be possible in these areas.
Instruction:
Gusty winds can blow down trees that are dead, or that have weakened
root systems. Outdoor furniture and similar items can be tossed
around if not anchored. Seek shelter indoors.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio and tv
stations, as well as local cable tv outlets for additional
information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bayou Dorcheat At Dixie Inn, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 11:00 AM Friday The stage was 19.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14 feet.
* Forecast...The bayou will continue to fall to a stage of 18.9 feet
by Saturday morning.  Also the Bayou Dorcheat at Dixie Inn
crested at 20.4 feet during yesterday, Thursday morning.
* Impact...at 20.0 feet...Expect moderate to severe flooding of bayou
bottoms. The boat ramp park at Dixie Inn is completely flooded at
this point.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

extending from 6 miles northeast of Buffalo to 6 miles northwest of
Julian. Movement was northeast at 55 mph.

Charleston, Nitro, Ripley, Spencer, Winfield, Elizabeth, Jefferson,

Eleanor, Marmet, Belle, Clendenin, Poca, Pinch, Sandyville and Cross
Lanes.

Interstate 79 between mile markers 1 and 19.
Interstate 77 in West Virginia between mile markers 96 and 142.
Interstate 64 in West Virginia between mile markers 38 and 57.
West Virginia Turnpike between mile markers 86 and 95.
Route 119 between mile markers 54 and 80.

The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Louisiana
* until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Friday the stage was 22.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue rising to near 22.1 feet by this
afternoon. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

* The river is forecast to continue rising to near 20.8 feet by this
afternoon. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

Advisory, which is in effect until 8 PM CDT this evening.

* TIMING...Late this morning through early evening.

* WINDS...Southwest winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Driving will be difficult. Unsecured outdoor objects
may be blown around.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 30 mph and/or wind
gusts of 45 mph are expected. Winds this strong can make driving
difficult...especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra
caution.

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 48 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

10 PM.
Alert:
* WINDS...NW to N increasing to 15 to 25 kt with local gusts to 35
kt between Cape Mendocino and Pt Arena.

* WAVES...NW building to 5 to 7 ft at 7 seconds and NW swell
building to 8 to 10 ft at 13 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous wave conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:

building to 8 to 10 ft at 13 seconds.
Instruction:

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
At 1157 AM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 11
miles east of Union, or near Lockhart, moving northeast at 30 mph.

Locations to be impacted include...
Sharon, Mcconnells and Bullock Creek.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph and very heavy rainfall rates up to 2 inches
per hour will be possible in these areas.
Instruction:
Gusty winds can blow down trees that are dead, or that have weakened
root systems. Outdoor furniture and similar items can be tossed
around if not anchored. Seek shelter indoors.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio and tv
stations, as well as local cable tv outlets for additional
information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
At 955 AM MDT, an area of heavy snow was slowly moving southward
through Meagher County.

This area of heavy snow will affect locations along the following
highways...Highway 89 between White Sulphur Springs and Kings Hill,
and Highway 12 from White Sulphur Springs to Deep Creek Pass.

Visibilities will drop quickly to less than a quarter of a mile in
this area of heavy snow. This band of snow could produce up to an
inch of snow before Noon today.

Conditions can deteriorate rapidly in winter weather situations. Be
prepared for snow or ice covered roads. Slow down and allow extra
time when traveling.
Instruction:

Alert:
* LOCATIONS...Including the cities of Grand Junction, Fruita,
Palisade, De Beque, New Castle, Mesa, Parachute, Rifle, Silt,
Montrose, Hotchkiss, Delta, Gateway, Nucla, Moab, Castle
Valley, Canyonlands National Park, Dead Horse Point State
Park, and Fry Canyon.

* TEMPERATURES...27 to 32.

* TIMING...The coldest temperatures are expected early Saturday
morning shortly after sunrise .

* IMPACTS...Sensitive vegetation and swamp coolers will be
impacted by sub-freezing temperatures.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are imminent or
highly likely. These conditions will kill crops and other
sensitive vegetation.
Alert:
Temperatures have risen above freezing across southeast Utah and
as a result, temperature effects on sensitive vegetation and
outdoor plumbing is no longer a concern. Therefore, the Freeze
Warning for southeast Utah has been allowed to expire.
Instruction:

Alert:
* LOCATIONS...Including the cities of Grand Junction, Fruita,
Palisade, De Beque, New Castle, Mesa, Parachute, Rifle, Silt,
Montrose, Hotchkiss, Delta, Gateway, Nucla, Moab, Castle
Valley, Canyonlands National Park, Dead Horse Point State
Park, and Fry Canyon.

* TEMPERATURES...27 to 32.

* TIMING...The coldest temperatures are expected early Saturday
morning shortly after sunrise .

* IMPACTS...Sensitive vegetation and swamp coolers will be
impacted by sub-freezing temperatures.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are imminent or
highly likely. These conditions will kill crops and other
sensitive vegetation.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...
Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather radio.
Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton

Alert:
* WINDS...Southwest winds will increase to 15 to 25 knots, with
gusts over 30 knots expected this afternoon and tonight. A few
gale force gusts are possible along the Lake Michigan shoreline.

* WAVES...Building to 4 to 7 feet on Lake Michigan. Waves should
only be 1 to 3 feet in ice free areas on the northern bay.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind gusts over 25 knots or
waves greater than 4 feet are expected to produce hazardous
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

* until further notice.

* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to a stage of 31.6 feet
by tomorrow morning.

higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor

conditions or forecasts change.

Alert:
At 950 AM, an area of heavy snow was located along a line from Heart
Butte to Augusta to Craig, with this area of snow moving southeast
at 10 mph.

Expect this line of snow to affect areas near Bowmans Corner, Wolf
Creek and portions of Interstate 15 from Hardy Creek to Helena,
along with portions of Highway 200 from Rogers Pass to Simms.

Visibilities will drop quickly to less than a quarter of a mile in
this area of heavy snow. This band of snow could produce up to an
inch of snow before Noon today.

Conditions can deteriorate rapidly in winter weather situations. Be
prepared for snow or ice covered roads. Slow down and allow extra
time when traveling.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Building to 5 to 8 feet by Sunday.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the northwest Florida
panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm.  Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Building to 5 to 8 feet by Sunday.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the northwest Florida

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-

Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to

float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:
* WINDS...Southeast 10 to 20 kt.

* SEAS...4 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and or seas of 6 ft or greater are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and West
Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes

...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Friday the stage was 57.4 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 57.4 feet by
Friday April 12. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

* Impact, At  21.0 feet, Water affects many homes in Camanche and is
at the base of the Camanche water treatment plant.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an
alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Wabash River...White River...


.Lowland flooding will develop along the Wabash and White Rivers in
western, central, and southern Indiana this weekend and the upcoming
week. Significant flooding is not expected.

On Thursday night and Friday morning most locations in Indiana saw
less than half an inch of rain.  Higher amounts, in some cases
between one inch and about one and three quarter inches, fell in a
swath across far southwestern, west central, and north central
Indiana.  This rainfall alone should be enough to take the Wabash
back into flood.  With more rain coming Saturday afternoon through
much of the day Sunday, the White river is expected to go into flood
as well.

Flood water is expected to affect local and state roads,
agricultural land, river parks, and river cabins.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Hazleton.
* from Monday evening until further notice.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 19.5 feet Saturday April 20
and will rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon.
* At 20.0 feet...Most of the low bottomlands flood. Flooding begins in
higher bottomlands. High water affects any residents in Pottsville
river cabins. Pottsville Road...North C Street on river side of
railroad tracks and Catt Street near U. S. Highway 41 are flooded.
Water is near or starting on Giro Road in the vicinity of submerged
Pottsville Road. Oil stripped fields flood. Flood gates must be
installed at Hazleton.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday morning and continue to
rise to near 9.9 feet by Saturday afternoon  and will rise later to
12.2 by Monday evening. It will fall below flood stage by late
Tuesday night.
* At 12.0 feet...High water affects a few low river cabins and county
roads.

another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and

click on rivers and lakes.

The Wabash River at Terre Haute.
* from Saturday evening to Sunday April 21.
* At 10:30 AM Friday the stage was 13.0 feet. This is 2.0 to 2.5 feet
higher than the observations from the old legacy gauge.
* Flood stage is 16.5 feet. This is 2.5 feet higher than flood stage
from the old legacy gauge.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Saturday evening and continue
to rise to near 20.8 feet by Wednesday afternoon.  It will fall
below flood stage by Saturday April 20.
* At 21.0 feet...The Wabash River extends to Interstate 70 Mile Marker
Number 4 from its west bank in the Terre Haute and West Terre Haute
area. All lakes in this area are affected by seep water and reach
capacity with some minor flooding.

will rise above flood stage by Saturday afternoon.
* At 20.0 feet...Leaverton Park in Palestine and park in Hutsonville
begin to flood.  Agricultural flooding spreads to higher land.

cottages are surrounded by water.  Several county or township roads
east of Lincoln Heritage Trail between Palestine and Hutsonville in
Crawford County Illinois are impassable.

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following streams in Kansas..
Big Blue River near Blue Rapids affecting Marshall County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At 10:15 AM Friday the stage was 40.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 40.9 feet by
early Sunday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
The river is forecast to remain above flood stage for the next
several weeks due to backwater from Tuttle Creek Lake.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

Stay tuned to later developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio
and local media.
Alert:
* WINDS...Southerly at 20 to 25 knots on Saturday shifting to
westerly at 20 to 25 knots in the wake of the front Sunday.

* WAVES/SEAS...Building to 5 to 8 feet near shore and 7 to 10
feet well offshore. Wave heights increasing to 2 to 3 feet
over most inland bays and sounds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds or frequent gusts
of 20 to 33 knots and/or seas of 7 feet or higher are expected to
produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners, especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Melbourne has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Sebastian Inlet to Jupiter Inlet 0-20 nm...

* Until 1215 PM EDT.

* At 1132 AM EDT, a thunderstorm producing waterspouts was located 7
nm northeast of Sewall's Point, or 8 nm east of Jensen Beach,
moving north at 15 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts 34 knots or greater.

SOURCE...Public.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can can quickly form and capsize boats,
damage vessels and create locally hazardous seas. Make
sure all on board are wearing life jackets. Expect wind
gusts in excess of 34 knots...suddenly higher
waves...lightning and heavy downpours. Make sure all on
board are wearing life jackets. Return to safe harbor if
possible.

* Locations impacted include...
Waveland, Sewall's Point, Nettles Island, Ocean Breeze Park and
Jensen Beach.
Instruction:

Alert:
Kaskaskia River at Carlyle TW

.This Flood Warning is a result of releases from Carlyle Dam...
The Flood Warning continues for
the Kaskaskia River at Carlyle TW
* until late Wednesday night.
* At 10:00 AM Friday the stage was 425.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 423.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to below flood stage by
Wednesday morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Los Angeles/Oxnard has issued a
Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect until 3 AM PDT Saturday.
The Gale Warning has been cancelled.

SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous sea conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous sea conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
The Gale Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous sea conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
* Winds...Northwest winds 20 to 30 kt with gusts to 40 kt are
expected when winds are strongest.

* Seas...Combined seas of 9 to 12 feet with periods around 10
seconds are expected when waves are largest.

SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.
Alert:
SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous sea conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous sea conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
Mississippi River at Red Wing  affecting Goodhue and Pierce
Counties
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...Wisconsin...

Minnesota River at Henderson MN19 affecting Le Sueur...Scott and
Sibley Counties
Mississippi River at St. Paul affecting Dakota...Ramsey and
Washington Counties
Mississippi River at Red Wing L/D 3 affecting Goodhue and Pierce
Counties
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...Wisconsin..
Cottonwood River at New Ulm affecting Brown County
Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County
Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Chippewa...Lac qui Parle
and Yellow Medicine Counties
Minnesota River At Morton  affecting Renville County
Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown and Nicollet Counties
Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver and Scott Counties
Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota...Hennepin and Scott
Counties
Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota...
Washington and Pierce Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...The precipitation that has fallen the past two days,
and that is forecast to fall through tomorrow, will stop the falls
that are occuring on area rivers and lead to rises over the next
several days.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At Morton .
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 24.9 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 25.7 feet by
Friday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Numerous roads flooded and impassable
between the Minnesota River and Redwood Falls.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Fleischer Rd flooded in North Redwood; storm
sewers closed off and bypass pumping begins.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in
North Redwood.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Water reaches flood mitigation culverts on
Riverside Road
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Cottonwood River at New Ulm.
* until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Friday the stage was 10.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday evening and continue
to rise to near 13.4 feet by Friday morning. additional rises are
possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 11.0 feet...Flood waters begin to impact low lying
areas...and some roads along the river.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Montevideo.
* until further notice.
* For Montevideo, no observed stage value is available.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is forecast to have a maximum value of 17.7
feet early Friday morning.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Sanitary sewers begin to be affected at this
level.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Storm sewers may need to be plugged to
prevent water from backing up into streets.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along the
river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 6.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 7.8 feet by
Friday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 6.0 feet...Low lying areas, mainly farmland, and some
roads along the river begin to experience flooding; bottom of
Swayback bridge

The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Savage.
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Friday the stage was 707.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 702.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 706.9 feet
by tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At 705.0 feet...Flood waters begin to impact the park road
at Fort Snelling State Park.
* Impact...At 702.0 feet...Barge loading stops at Port Cargill, and
other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact
Black Dog Road in Burnsville.
* Impact...At 700.0 feet...Flood waters begin to cover trails at Fort
Snelling State Park as well as low parts on the Bloomington Ferry
Bridge trail just east of US 169.

The Minnesota River near Jordan.
* until further notice.

* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 27.1 feet
by tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At 26.7 feet...The bridge at Scott County Road 9 and Carver
County Road 11/Jonathan Carver Parkway will be closed.
* Impact...At 25.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin to flood and private sanitary sewers may experience
problems.

The Minnesota River At New Ulm.

* At  9:45 AM Friday the stage was 803.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 800.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 803.1 feet by
Friday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 796.0 feet...Water impacts park land and boat launch
access road is closed.
* Impact...At 795.0 feet...Water begins to impact the access roads in
the floodplain.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bayou Dorcheat Near Springhill, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Friday The stage was 13.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 11 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 14.0 feet by
Wednesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...at 13.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding of private boat
ramps. Move livestock to higher ground.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bayou Dorcheat At Dixie Inn, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Friday The stage was 19.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14 feet.
* Forecast...The bayou will continue to fall to a stage of 18.9 feet
by Saturday morning.  Also the Bayou Dorcheat crested at 20.4 feet
during yesterday, midday of Thursday.
* Impact...at 20.0 feet...Expect moderate to severe flooding of bayou
bottoms. The boat ramp park at Dixie Inn is completely flooded at
this point.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bayou Dorcheat At Lake Bistineau, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Friday The pool stage was 143.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 142.5 feet.
* Forecast...The lake will continue rising to near 143.5 feet by
Sunday morning.  Additional rises remain possible thereafter.
* Impact...at 144.0 feet...Most camps across the lake begin to flood.
Some homes will also face flooding especially homes that are not
stilted. Preparations for flooding should be rushed to completion.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
Missouri River at Atchison affecting Atchison...Buchanan and Platte
Counties.

Missouri River at St Joseph affecting Doniphan...Andrew and
Buchanan Counties.

Missouri River at Napoleon affecting Jackson...Lafayette and Ray
Counties.

Missouri River at Waverly affecting Carroll...Lafayette and Saline
Counties.

Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline
Counties.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River at Waverly.
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 21.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will remain nearly steady through next
week.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.
Alert:
Missouri River at Atchison affecting Atchison...Buchanan and Platte
Counties.

Missouri River at St Joseph affecting Doniphan...Andrew and
Buchanan Counties.

Missouri River at Napoleon affecting Jackson...Lafayette and Ray
Counties.

Missouri River at Waverly affecting Carroll...Lafayette and Saline
Counties.

Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline
Counties.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River at Napoleon.
* until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Friday the stage was 18.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 18.6 feet by
Thursday April 18th then begin falling.
* At 17.0 feet...Low-lying areas unprotected by levees begin to
flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.
Alert:
Missouri River at Atchison affecting Atchison...Buchanan and Platte
Counties.

Missouri River at St Joseph affecting Doniphan...Andrew and
Buchanan Counties.

Missouri River at Napoleon affecting Jackson...Lafayette and Ray
Counties.

Missouri River at Waverly affecting Carroll...Lafayette and Saline
Counties.

Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline
Counties.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River at Atchison.
* from late Wednesday night to Friday April 19.
* At 10:01 AM Friday the stage was 20.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is expected to rise to near flood stage
Thursday April 18th.
* At 22.0 feet...Low-lying areas on the Missouri side of the river
begin to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

Counties.

Counties.

Counties.

* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.

Joseph occurs.

Minor to moderate flooding continues along the Mississippi River.

precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at La Crosse.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:15 AM Friday the stage was 13.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.5 feet by
Saturday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 13.5 feet...Water goes over the road in the 600 block of
Shore Acres Road. Many La Crosse River Marsh trails are under
water.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bodcau Bayou At Bayou Bodcau Lake, Louisiana.
* from late Saturday night until further notice...or until the
warning is cancelled.
* At 9:00 AM Friday The pool stage was 171.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage pool is 172 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by early Sunday morning and
continue to rise to near 173.5 feet by Wednesday morning.
Additional rises remain possible thereafter.
* Impact...at 172.0 feet...Expect bankfull conditions on Red Chute
Bayou.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

Alert:
The Winter Weather Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow ongoing. Additional snow accumulations of up to
one inch.

* WHERE...Wells county.

* WHEN...Until 1 PM CDT this afternoon.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Patchy
blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

Alert:
At 1113 AM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8
miles south of Union, or over Rose Hill State Park, moving northeast
at 25 mph.

Locations to be impacted include...
Union, Monarch Mill, Buffalo, Jonesville, Lockhart, Rose Hill State
Park, Sedalia, Adamsburg, Santuc and Cross Keys.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph will be possible in these areas.
Instruction:
This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio and tv
stations, as well as local cable tv outlets for additional
information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

Big Black River At West affecting Attala and Holmes Counties
Big Black River Near Bentonia affecting Madison and Yazoo Counties
Big Black River Near Bovina affecting Hinds and Warren Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Black River At West
* until further notice.
* At  9:45 AM Friday the stage was 19.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 20.5 feet on Sunday
evening.
* Impact...At 21.0 feet...Extensive flooding of agricultural land.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 48 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Alert:
Affecting the following counties in Iowa...Palo Alto...Pocahontas

...The Flood Warning continues for all or portions of the following
rivers in Iowa...West Fork Des Moines River...

Affecting the following counties in Iowa...Emmet...Humboldt

River forecasts include observed precipitation, as well as expected
precipitation over the next 24 hours.

Due to the expected slow changing nature of the flooding along the West Fork
of the Des Moines River, regularly scheduled forecast statements will only
be issued once per week. The next scheduled update will be Thursday, April
18. Additional statements will be issued if conditions or forecasts change.
The Flood Warning continues for
The West Fork Des Moines River at Estherville, or From the
Iowa-Minnesota border...to near Wallingford.
* Until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Friday the stage was 12.0 feet, or 4.0 feet above Flood
Stage.
* Flood Stage is 8.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast...rise to 12.1 feet, or 4.1 feet above Flood Stage, this
evening. Then hold nearly steady with minor flucuations through
next week.
* Impact...At 12.0 feet, Water affects the low areas of West 1st
Street south of Iowa 9. Residences on Valley Drive along School
Creek are affected.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, do not drown.

More information--including impact statements and crest
histories--is available on the Web at...  www.weather.gov/desmoines.
Click on the Rivers and Lakes link.
Alert:
Affecting the following counties in Iowa...Palo Alto...Pocahontas

...The Flood Warning continues for all or portions of the following
rivers in Iowa...West Fork Des Moines River...

Affecting the following counties in Iowa...Emmet...Humboldt

River forecasts include observed precipitation, as well as expected
precipitation over the next 24 hours.

Due to the expected slow changing nature of the flooding along the West Fork
of the Des Moines River, regularly scheduled forecast statements will only
be issued once per week. The next scheduled update will be Thursday, April
18. Additional statements will be issued if conditions or forecasts change.
The Flood Warning continues for
The West Fork Des Moines River at Humboldt, or From Joe Reasoner
Dam...to the East Fork Des Moines River.
* Until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Friday the stage was 10.9 feet, or 0.9 feet above Flood
Stage.
* Flood Stage is 10.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast...rise to 11.2 feet, or 1.2 feet above Flood Stage, Sunday
evening. Then slowly begin falling.
* Impact...At 10.0 feet, Water impacts some homes along Country Club
Drive. Sandbagging occurs at the water treatment plant.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, do not drown.

More information--including impact statements and crest
histories--is available on the Web at...  www.weather.gov/desmoines.
Click on the Rivers and Lakes link.
Alert:
Affecting the following counties in Iowa...Palo Alto...Pocahontas

...The Flood Warning continues for all or portions of the following

The Flood Warning continues for
The West Fork Des Moines River at Emmetsburg, or From near
Graettinger...to Cylinder Creek near West Bend.
* Until Thursday afternoon.
* At  9:15 AM Friday the stage was 11.3 feet, or 0.3 feet above Flood
Stage.
* Flood Stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast...rise to 11.6 feet, or 0.6 feet above Flood Stage,
Saturday morning. Then slowly begin falling and go below Flood Stage
Thursday afternoon.
* Impact...At 11.5 feet, Southern portions of the airport field are
affected including approaches to the primary runway. Grass
airstrips are affected near hangars along the east side of the
airfield.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, do not drown.

More information--including impact statements and crest
histories--is available on the Web at...  www.weather.gov/desmoines.
Click on the Rivers and Lakes link.
Alert:
* WINDS...West 10 to 20 kt with gusts up to 25 kt.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
West Fork Des Moines River at Jackson

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...

Redwood River Near Marshall
West Fork Des Moines River near Avoca
West Fork Des Moines River Near Windom

.The following river forecasts include forecast precipitation through
tonight. Any additional future rains could affect the crest
forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The West Fork Des Moines River Near Windom.
* until further notice.
* At 09AM Friday the stage was 20.00 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.00 feet.
* At stages near 21.0 feet...Island Park in Windom begins to flood,
along with some agricultural lands outside of Windom.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not drive cars through flooded areas. the water
depth and road condition may be unsafe.

Additional information is available at

http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=fsd

Stay tuned for further updates by listening to NOAA weather radio...
or your local radio and TV stations.

The next scheduled statement will be issued tomorrow morning.

Alert:
West Fork Des Moines River at Jackson

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...

Redwood River Near Marshall
West Fork Des Moines River near Avoca
West Fork Des Moines River Near Windom

.The following river forecasts include forecast precipitation through
tonight. Any additional future rains could affect the crest
forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Redwood River Near Marshall.
* from late Wednesday night to Saturday April 20.
* At 07AM Friday the stage was 10.44 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.00 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Thursday April 18 and crest
near 14.3 feet by Thursday April 18. The river will fall below flood
stage by Friday April 19.
* At stages near 14.0 feet...There will be minor flooding of low
lying areas outside of Marshall.

Alert:
Big Black River At West affecting Attala and Holmes Counties
Big Black River Near Bentonia affecting Madison and Yazoo Counties
Big Black River Near Bovina affecting Hinds and Warren Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Black River Near Bentonia
* until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Friday the stage was 23.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 26.0 feet on Tuesday
morning.
* Impact...At 25.0 feet...Extensive flooding of agricultural land is
occurring.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

* from late Saturday night until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Friday the stage was 26.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 28.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage Sunday morning and
will continue to rise to near 31.0 feet by next Friday morning.

Alert:
Areas of dense fog and freezing drizzle over the higher terrain,
with visibility less than one-half mile at times, will gradually
diminish into early this afternoon. Temperatures remaining around
freezing will result in slippery conditions on untreated roads.
Instruction:

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Tightening pressure gradients between high pressure centered to
the northeast and a frontal boundary slowly approaching from the
west will bring southeast winds around 15 to 25 knots with higher
gusts through tonight. Seas will continue around 5 to 8 feet
today, then slowly subside late tonight into Saturday morning.
* WINDS...Southeast 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* SEAS...5 to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
Big Muddy River near Murphysboro

.Minor flooding continues along the Big Muddy River near Murphysboro.
Water levels continue to fall, and the river is now forecast to fall
below flood stage by Wednesday morning.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Big Muddy River near Murphysboro.
* until Wednesday afternoon.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 23.5 feet.
* Flood Stage is 22.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 24.0 Feet...Some minor flooding in S 3rd & Division /
Plum Street area.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Nearshore and Open waters from Willowick OH to Geneva-on-the-lake
OH...

The showers have weakened and no longer pose a significant threat to
boaters.
Instruction:

Alert:
Strong east to northeast winds will subside today as the center
of low pressure of the storm system moves into the western Lake
Superior region.

* Waves...10 to 14 feet.

* Wind Gusts...Up to 25 knots.
Instruction:

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
White River...Wabash River...

.Lowland flooding will develop along the Wabash and White Rivers in
western, central, and southern Indiana this weekend and the upcoming
week. Significant flooding is not expected.

On Thursday night and Friday morning most locations in Indiana saw
less than half an inch of rain.  Higher amounts, in some cases
between one inch and about one and three quarter inches, fell in a
swath across far southwestern, west central, and north central
Indiana.  This rainfall alone should be enough to take the Wabash
back into flood.  With more rain coming Saturday afternoon through
much of the day Sunday, the White river is expected to go into flood
as well.

Flood water is expected to affect local and state roads, agricultural
land, river parks, and river cabins.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River at Spencer.
* from late Monday night until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 6.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late Monday night and continue
to rise to near 15.3 feet by late Tuesday night. Additional rises
are possible thereafter.
* At 15.5 feet...Gosport Road, also known as County Line Road in Owen
County, begins to flood on north side of river.  Romona Road west
of Gosport begins to flood.  Flooding of low agricultural land is
noticeable.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
White River...Wabash River...

.Lowland flooding will develop along the Wabash and White Rivers in
western, central, and southern Indiana this weekend and the upcoming
week. Significant flooding is not expected.

On Thursday night and Friday morning most locations in Indiana saw

back into flood.  With more rain coming Saturday afternoon through
much of the day Sunday, the White river is expected to go into flood
as well.

Flood water is expected to affect local and state roads, agricultural
land, river parks, and river cabins.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River at Elliston.
* from Monday morning to Saturday April 20.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...It is forecast to rise above flood stage Monday morning,
crest at 21.2 feet Wednesday morning and then fall below flood
stage by Friday April 19.
* At 21.0 feet...Eastern portion of CR 100 S in Greene County floods
leading to Plummer. Flooding covers all low bottomlands.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River at Edwardsport.
* from Monday afternoon to Sunday April 21.
* At  7:00 AM Friday the stage was 11.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 18.5 feet by Thursday morning.  It will fall below
flood stage by Sunday April 21.
* At 18.6 feet...During June 2010 and March 2011 high water...INDOT
closed SR 358 between SR 67 at Edwardsport to SR 57 at Plainville.
SR 358 floods on the east side of the river between the levees.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

* Flood Warning for
the Wabash River at Mount Carmel.
* from late Monday night until further notice.
* At  7:45 AM Friday the stage was 15.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late Monday night and continue
to rise to near 21.4 feet by Sunday April 21.
* At 21.0 feet...River Road in the Mount Carmel, Illinois area begins
to flood.  Lowland flooding in progress.  A few local river roads
are closed by high water.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

much of the day Sunday, the White river is expected to go into flood
as well.

Flood water is expected to affect local and state roads, agricultural
land, river parks, and river cabins.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River at Petersburg.
* from Monday afternoon to Monday April 22.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 11.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 18.7 feet by Saturday April 20.  It will fall below
flood stage by Monday April 22.
* At 19.0 feet...Low bottomlands flood and flooding begins on higher
bottomlands.  State Road 257 may begin to flood if Shoals gage
reading is over 17 feet.  Private levees may be overtopped in many
cases.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
White River...Wabash River...

.Lowland flooding will develop along the Wabash and White Rivers in
western, central, and southern Indiana this weekend and the upcoming
week. Significant flooding is not expected.

On Thursday night and Friday morning most locations in Indiana saw
less than half an inch of rain.  Higher amounts, in some cases
between one inch and about one and three quarter inches, fell in a
swath across far southwestern, west central, and north central
Indiana.  This rainfall alone should be enough to take the Wabash
back into flood.  With more rain coming Saturday afternoon through
much of the day Sunday, the White river is expected to go into flood
as well.

Flood water is expected to affect local and state roads, agricultural
land, river parks, and river cabins.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the Wabash River at Clinton.
* from Sunday evening to Friday April 19.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...It is forecast to rise above flood stage Sunday evening,
crest at 20.2 feet Tuesday evening and then fall below flood stage
by Thursday afternoon.
* At 20.0 feet...Low bottomlands flood.  Water begins to back up local
tributaries.  River road near Mecca is impassable.  Higher county
roads and bottomlands begin to flood.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

the White River at Hazleton.
* from Monday evening until further notice.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 19.5 feet Saturday April 20
and will rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon.
* At 20.0 feet...Most of the low bottomlands flood. Flooding begins in
higher bottomlands. High water affects any residents in Pottsville
river cabins. Pottsville Road...North C Street on river side of
railroad tracks and Catt Street near U. S. Highway 41 are flooded.
Water is near or starting on Giro Road in the vicinity of submerged
Pottsville Road. Oil stripped fields flood. Flood gates must be
installed at Hazleton.

click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River Near Blair.
* until Monday April 29.
* At  9:00 AM Friday the stage was 25.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.5 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 25.9 feet early Sunday
morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.

Alert:
* Wahpeton...on the Red River ...in Wilkin and Richland Counties
* Fargo...on the Red River ...in Clay and Cass Counties
* Halstad...on the Red River ...in Norman and Traill Counties
* Oslo...on the Red River ...in Marshall...Polk...Grand Forks and
Walsh Counties
* Drayton...on the Red River ...in Kittson...Marshall...Pembina and
Walsh Counties
* Pembina...on the Red River ...in Kittson and Pembina Counties
* Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND) ...in Richland County

.   Along the mainstem Red River and Abercrombie rivers are cresting
or falling from Grand Forks and to the south. The river continues to
rise north of Grand Forks with crests expected this weekend at Oslo.
Crests late next week or later north of Oslo. A second rise is
expected, mainly in the southern Red River Valley, next week as the
snow from this last winter storm melts and enters the river system.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND).
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:15 AM Friday the stage was 18.3 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue to fall to a stage of 17.8 feet
by Saturday mid-morning.
* The river is forecast to crest at 17.9 on early Thursday morning
during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 18.0 feet, MAJOR FLOOD. Bridge near the
gage is inaccessible due to agricultural flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks
