Alert:
The Flood Watch has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
The risk of strong rip currents will persist through Saturday.
Swim near a lifeguard and stay away from rocks, piers and
jetties where they are particularly strong. In addition, with
increasing winds and seas, water levels will become 1 to 2 feet
above normal on Saturday. Near times of high tide, minor overwash
of low lying coastal roads will be a possibility. This includes
portions of the Bolivar Peninsula, Blue Water Highway and Surfside.
The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston has issued a
Beach Hazards Statement for a high risk of rip currents, elevated surf
and above normal water levels. It is in effect through Saturday evening.

* HAZARDS...Strong rip currents, elevated surf, minor coastal flooding.

* TIMING...through Saturday.

* LOCATION...Gulf facing shoreline along the upper Texas coast.

* POTENTIAL IMPACTS...Rip currents can become life threatening to anyone
entering the surf and can even sweep the strongest swimmer out
to sea. Minor coastal flooding on Saturday could make travel difficult
along low lying coastal roads, particularly between Surfside and the
Bolivar Peninsula.
Instruction:
A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution
should be used when in or near the water.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore...which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins...
jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol...
flags and signs. Swim near a lifeguard.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
The Flood Watch has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Small Craft Advisory is now in effect until 8 AM EDT
Saturday.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY...Expect
sustained winds of up to 27 knots from the southwest, with
gusts up to 32 knots. The largest expected significant waves
will be 5 feet with a maximum wave height of up to 7 feet
possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 6 PM EDT Friday
with the largest waves expected around 7 PM EDT Friday.

Please see the latest marine forecasts for more detailed
information.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 22 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The Gale Warning will expire at 11 AM EDT /10 AM CDT/ this
morning.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE GALE WARNING...Expect sustained
winds of up to 29 knots from the east, with gusts up to 35
knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 14 feet
with a maximum wave height of up to 20 feet possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 10 AM EDT
Friday with the largest waves expected around 10 AM EDT
Friday.
Instruction:

Alert:
A Small Craft Advisory remains in effect until 8 AM EDT Saturday.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY...Expect
sustained winds of up to 28 knots from the southwest, with
gusts up to 31 knots. The largest expected significant waves
will be 5 feet with a maximum wave height of up to 7 feet
possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 12 AM EDT
Saturday with the largest waves expected around 12 AM EDT
Saturday.

Please see the latest marine forecasts for more detailed
information.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 22 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
A Small Craft Advisory remains in effect until 5 PM EDT this
afternoon.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY...Expect
sustained winds of up to 22 knots from the east, with gusts up
to 27 knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 10
feet with a maximum wave height of up to 15 feet possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 10 AM EDT
Friday with the largest waves expected around 10 AM EDT
Friday.

Please see the latest marine forecasts for more detailed
information.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 22 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Marquette has issued a Gale
Watch...which is in effect from 6 PM EDT this evening through
late tonight.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE GALE WATCH...Expect sustained winds
of up to 28 knots from the southwest, with gusts up to 35
knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 9 feet
with a maximum wave height of up to 14 feet possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 11 PM EDT
Friday with the largest waves expected around 5 AM EDT
Saturday.

The Small Craft Advisory is now in effect until 6 PM EDT this
evening.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY...Expect
sustained winds of up to 23 knots from the southwest, with
gusts up to 31 knots. The largest expected significant waves
will be 5 feet with a maximum wave height of up to 8 feet
possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 5 PM EDT Friday
with the largest waves expected around 5 PM EDT Friday.

Please see the latest marine forecasts for more detailed
information.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 22 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased, but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.
Alert:

CDT/ this afternoon.

feet with a maximum wave height of up to 9 feet possible.

Friday with the largest waves expected around 10 AM EDT
Friday.

information.

Alert:
At 1047 AM EDT...National Weather Service doppler radar indicated a
strong thunderstorm near Joanna, or 10 miles northwest of Newberry,
moving northeast at 20 mph.

HAZARD...gusty winds 40 to 50 mph.

IMPACT...expect minor damage to tree limbs and blowing around of
light, unsecured objects.

Some locations in the path of this storm include...
Whitmire, Kinards, and Bush River Fire Station.
Instruction:
This storm may intensify. Monitor NOAA Weather Radio, local radio and
television stations for additional information and possible warnings
from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
At 743 AM PDT, reporting gauges indicated high water levels and
flooding continue on many creeks and streams across the area.
Additional rainfall of 0.50 to one inch occurred overnight with the
high water levels persisting through the day. Water levels are
expected to decrease later today and tonight.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.
Alert:
* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
At 1045 AM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 13
miles northwest of Newberry, or near Joanna, moving northeast at 20
mph.

Locations to be impacted include...
Union, Joanna, Carlisle, Rose Hill State Park, Clinton, Buffalo,
Monarch Mill, Sedalia, Kinards and Tuckertown.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph will be possible in these areas.
Instruction:
This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio and tv
stations, as well as local cable tv outlets for additional
information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River At Omaha.
* until Tuesday evening.
* At  9:30 AM Friday the stage was 26.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 29.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 27.8 feet early Monday
morning.
* Impact...at 29.0 feet...At this level water nears the base of the
Council Bluffs levee. Significant lowland flooding occurs in NP
Dodge Park, Freedom Park, Tom Hanafan Park, Fontenelle Forest and
Haworth Park.
* Impact...at 28.0 feet...At this level most of the flood gates for
the city of Council Bluffs are closed.
* Impact...at 27.0 feet...NP Dodge Park, Freedom Park, Tom Hanafan
Park and Fontenelle Forest begin to flood.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...A casino parking lot begins to flood along
the Iowa side of the river.  In addition, Haworth Park located in
Bellevue begins to flood.
* Impact...at 21.0 feet...At this level the City of Council Bluffs
begins closing flood gates.
* Impact...at 19.0 feet...At this level, the City of Council Bluffs
begins to close drainage gates that discharge into the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.
Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River Near Blair.
* until Monday evening.
* At  9:00 AM Friday the stage was 25.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.5 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 25.9 feet early Sunday
morning.
* Impact...at 26.5 feet...Flooding is occurring in the Fort Calhoun
area.  This flooding affects several homes and includes County
Roads 34, 47 and 51.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...Minor flooding occurs at the Fort Calhoun
trailer park.
* Impact...at 23.5 feet...Flooding begins to occur at Wilson Island
State Park.

Alert:
* Shelly...on the Marsh River...in Norman County
* Upstream of Warren...on the Snake River...in Marshall County
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County

.   The Minnesota tributaries with the exception of Climax are
falling. Climax has started to crest and little additional rise
expected. Many points near the mainstem Red River remain high due to
backflow from the Red River.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Crookston...on the Red Lake River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:45 AM Friday the stage was 17.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 20.2 feet by
Friday mid-morning.  Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 20.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
* Kindred...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass and Richland Counties
* West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Harwood...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Mapleton...on the Maple River ...in Cass County

.   River levels continue to fall on the North Dakota tributaries.
Slow falls expected on the Sheyenne at West Fargo and Harwood as
this is dependent on falls on the mainstem Red River. Faster falls
at Kindred and Mapleton with re-rises next week as the snow melts
and adds water into the river system.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:15 AM Friday the stage was 22.2 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue to fall to a stage of 22.1 feet
by Saturday mid-morning.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 21.0 feet, MAJOR FLOOD. Approximate stage
where flooding begins in areas along the Sheyenne River north of
the diversion channel to Harwood, ND.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

Alert:
At 820 AM, an area of heavy snow was located 10 miles southeast of
Belt, moving southeast at 20 mph.

This area of heavy snow will affect areas near Stanford, Belt,
Geyser, Neihart, Raynesford, Sluice Boxes State Park and Utica.

This also includes portions of the the following highways...
Highway 200 between mile markers 0 and 46.
Highway 89 between mile markers 22 and 74

This area of heavy snow could produce snowfall rates near 1 inch per
hour, with visibilities quickly dropping to less than a quarter of a
mile at times.

Those driving through this region should be prepared for quickly
changing road conditions.

cancelled.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to trees and power lines.

Locations impacted include...

Amherst, Grafton, Wellington, Lodi, Loudonville, Shreve, West Salem,
Hayesville, Polk, Avon, Sheffield Lake, Olmsted Falls, Eaton and
Oberlin.
Instruction:
Wind damage with these storms will occur before any lightning. Do
not wait for the sound of thunder before taking cover.

windows.

conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially

conditions.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Eastern Huron County in north central Ohio...
Eastern Richland County in north central Ohio...
Erie County in north central Ohio...
Western Medina County in northeastern Ohio...
Ashland County in north central Ohio...
Western Wayne County in northeastern Ohio...
Lorain County in north central Ohio...

* Until 1045 AM EDT.

* At 953 AM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from Vermilion to near Bellville, moving northeast at 60
mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to trees and power lines.

* Locations impacted include...
Lorain, Elyria, Mansfield, Wooster, Ashland, Vermilion, Western
Vermilion, North Ridgeville, Avon Lake, Amherst, Grafton,
Wellington, Lodi, Loudonville, New London, Bellville, Shreve, West
Salem, Wakeman and Hayesville.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Wind damage with these storms will occur before any lightning. Do
not wait for the sound of thunder before taking cover.
SEEK SHELTER IMMEDIATELY inside a sturdy structure and stay away from
windows.

Alert:
Deep moisture wrapping around a broad upper level low to the east
of the Big Island will bring periods of snow to the higher
elevations of Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa today and tonight.
* WHAT...Periods of snow will affect the summits today and
tonight. Plan on slippery road conditions. Additional snow
accumulations of 1 to 3 inches are expected.

* WHERE...Big Island Summits above 11500 feet.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM HST Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times in snow, along with blowing and drifting snow.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause travel difficulties. Be prepared for snow covered roads and
limited visibilities, and use extreme caution while driving.
Alert:
Surface temperatures have warmed to above freezing values for
the affected areas and will continue to warm to the lower to mid
50s by the afternoon hours. Therefore, the Freeze Warning will be
allowed to expire at 9 AM.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Flash Flood Watch continues for

* Maui and the Big Island.

* Through 6 PM HST this evening.

* Moisture wrapping around a broad upper level low to the east of
the state will bring frequent showers and isolated thunderstorms
to Maui and the Big Island today. Rainfall will be heavy at
times, potentially leading to flash flooding. Although most of
the heavy rain will focus over windward areas due to the strong
trade winds in place, heavy showers and thunderstorms will also
remain possible across leeward areas. The threat for flash
flooding is expected to diminish this evening.
Instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions are favorable for flash
flooding. Flash flooding is LIFE THREATENING. Do not cross fast
flowing water in your vehicle or on foot.

Monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action if a Flash
Flood Warning is issued. If you experience heavy rain or rising
water, head to higher ground immediately.
Alert:
* WINDS...East to northeast 20 to 30 mph with localized gusts over
50 mph are expected across Lanai, Kahoolawe, the Maui central
valley and leeward West Maui, as well as the South Kohala
district of the Big Island.

* TIMING...Through 6 PM HST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Winds this strong could down tree branches and cause
localized power outages. Motorists, especially those in high
profile vehicles, are urged to drive with caution.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of at least 30 mph, or
gusts of at least 50 mph, are expected. Motorists should use
extra caution.
Alert:
Contentnea Creek Near Hookerton affecting Greene...Lenoir and Pitt
Counties
The National Weather Service in Newport has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Contentnea Creek Near Hookerton.
* from late tonight until further notice...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 9 AM Friday the stage was 12.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by after midnight tonight and
continue to rise to near 13.4 feet by Tuesday morning.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...Minor flooding of low lying areas adjacent
to creek can be expected. Several homes threatened by water in
northwest Greene County near HWY 58.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive vehicles through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur
in automobiles when people try to drive through flooded areas.

Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Flood waters will
weaken the banks making them dangerous.

A followup product will be issued by the National Weather Service a
little later.
Alert:
* WINDS: Southwest gales 35 to 40 knots.

* WAVES: 6 to 9 feet occasionally to 10 feet building to 8 to 12
feet occasionally to 14 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased...but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.
Alert:
* WINDS: Southwest winds increasing to 20 to 30 knots with
frequent gusts to 35 knots developing this morning and afternoon.

* WAVES: 2 to 5 feet with the highest waves toward the open
waters.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
The Frost Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
A sprawling low pressure system located across the northern Plains
will slowly weaken today into tonight as it tracks northeast across
Lake Superior and eventually towards James Bay. Showers and possibly
a few rumbles of thunder will accompany this system this morning as
a cold front sweeps through the region. A tight pressure gradient
will continue to lead gusty easterly winds that will gradually veer
south/southeasterly this morning, and then southwest this afternoon.
Gusts across much of the local waters will be as high as 30 knots at
times, with a few sporadic gusts to gales possible over the Lake
Huron open waters early this morning, and across western Lake Erie
this afternoon. The sporadic nature of the gust potential will
preclude any gale headlines at this time. However, the combination
of gusty winds and continued elevated wave action will result in
hazardous conditions for small craft across all of the Lake Huron
nearshore waters, Saginaw Bay, Lake St. Clair, and western Lake
Erie.

A lingering pressure gradient will result in southwest winds
remaining gusty into Saturday as high pressure ridges eastward into
the central Great Lakes, but with gusts generally limited to around
20 knots for most of the local waters outside of Saginaw Bay where
gusts of 25-30 knots will be possible. Nearshore conditions will
improve with offshore flow and decreasing waves, with the exception
being Saginaw Bay where hazardous small craft conditions will likely
persist through much of Saturday. Winds will weaken briefly Saturday
night as they veer northwesterly. Another low pressure system will
then track northeast towards the region from the lower Mississippi
Valley Sunday, with strengthening and veering northeasterly flow
leading to another round of potential gales and hazardous conditions
for small craft.
* WIND AND WAVES: During the Small Craft Advisory, expect
sustained winds up to 20 knots from the south with gusts up
to 27 knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 7
feet with a potential maximum wave height of 10 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 11 AM EDT Friday
with the largest waves expected around 9 AM EDT Friday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
Noxubee River At Macon affecting Noxubee County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Noxubee River At Macon
* until Saturday evening.
* At  8:00 AM Friday the stage was 28.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 28.7 feet this
afternoon.
* Impact...At 28.0 feet...Farm land near the river begins to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Cape Fear At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3 affecting Bladen County NC
Lumber Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County NC
Great Pee Dee At Pee Dee affecting Marion and Florence Counties SC
The Flood Warning continues for
The Great Pee Dee At Pee Dee.
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Friday the stage was 20.72 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 21.3 feet by early tomorrow
afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Flooding will affect swamp and timberlands while also
disrupting logging operations. Operations will likely cease and equipment not
previously moved will remain trapped. Some farmland will have minor flooding
especially around Britton Neck.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

People with interests along the river should take the necessary precautions to
protect life and property from the flood waters.

Additional information is available on our website at weather.gov/ilm under the
"Rivers and Lakes" link.

The Cape Fear At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3.

* Flood stage is 42.0 feet.

Alert:
Sturgeon River near Chassell affecting Houghton County

.The Sturgeon River near Chassell fell only slightly over
the past 24 hours. In addition, 5 to 7 inches of snow and
about 1 inch of new water equivalent fell in the basin.
Will continue to extend this warning 24 hours at a time
due to the once daily morning observation.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Even 6 inches of fast moving flood water can knock
you off your feet...and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never
try to walk...swim...or drive through such swift water. If you come
upon flood waters...stop...turn around and go another way.

additional weather and river information is available at
www.weather.gov/mqt

The next statement will be issued by 11 AM EDT 4/13.

today, then slowly subside late tonight into Saturday morning.
* WINDS...South 10 to 20 kt with gusts up to 25 kt.

* SEAS...4 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
Tightening pressure gradients between high pressure centered to
the northeast and a frontal boundary slowly approaching from the
west will bring southeast winds around 15 to 25 knots with higher
gusts through tonight. Seas will continue around 5 to 8 feet
today, then slowly subside late tonight into Saturday morning.

difficult and dangerous.

Instruction:

Alert:
Occasional freezing drizzle is expected to persist across northern
Iowa through mid morning with road surface and air temperatures
hovering near the freezing mark. A few accidents have already
occurred early this morning and roads are slick in spots.

Conditions should improve by late morning when air and road
surface temperatures should rises further above freezing. In the
mean time, motorists are advised to slow down, allow for extra
distance between vehicles, and be prepared for variable road
conditions and slick spots.
Instruction:

Alert:
* East Grand Forks...on the Red River ...in Polk and Grand Forks
Counties

.  The Red River at East Grand Forks appears to be cresting. With
upstream points on the mainstem Red River still rising slowly change
in river level will be slow today. A slow fall in river level is
forecast for the next few days into next week.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...East Grand Forks...on the Red River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:45 AM Friday the stage was 46.7 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 46.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue to fall to a stage of 46.5 feet
by Saturday mid-morning.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 48.5 feet, Second Ave NE at 2nd St NE
closure to be constructed. Bygland Rd at Murray Bridge closure to
be assembled. Murray Bridge closes. (East Grand Forks)
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
* WINDS: Potential for southwest gales 35 to 40 knots.

* WAVES: 6 to 9 feet occasionally to 10 feet building to 8 to 12
feet occasionally to 14 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased...but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Milwaukee/Sullivan has issued a
Gale Warning...which is in effect until 8 PM CDT this evening.
The Small Craft Advisory is no longer in effect.

* WINDS: Southwest winds increasing to 20 to 30 knots with
frequent gusts to 35 knots developing this morning and
continuing this afternoon.

* WAVES: 2 to 4 feet with the highest waves toward the open
waters.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
Willamette Tributaries Bulletin

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon...

Middle Fk Willamette R at Jasper affecting Lane County
S Santiam River at Waterloo affecting Linn County
Pudding River at Aurora affecting Clackamas and Marion Counties

River forecasts are based on observed and forecast rainfall and
temperatures, and include current and planned reservoir releases.

For the latest river stages and forecasts, visit
weather.gov/portland.

The next update for these locations will be issued by 1 pm today.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pudding River at Aurora.
* At 5 AM Friday the stage was...22.3 feet / 7400 cfs.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet and flood flow is 7000 cfs.
* Forecast...This river will hold rather steady at 22.3 feet
today. The river will slowly recede tonight, dropping
below flood stage later Saturday morning.
* Impact...Above 22 ft, expect minor flooding of low-lying
agricultural lands and access roads along the river.

expected to crest between 12.0 to 12.1 feet this morning.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Middle Fk Willamette R at Jasper.
* At 5 AM Friday the stage was...10.4 feet / 24200 cfs.
* Flood stage is 10.0 feet and flood flow is 22100 cfs.
* Forecast...This river is near its forecast crest of 10.5 feet,
and will change little this morning. River will recede this
afternoon and tonight. It is expected to drop below flood stage
around 7 AM Saturday, and continue falling for the next couple days.
* Impact...Above 10.0 ft, expect minor flooding of agricultural land
and low-lying areas along the Middle Fork from Jasper downstream to
Springfield.

Alert:
At 839 AM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Mechanicsburg, moving northeast at 65 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Brighton, South Vienna, Catawba and Plattsburg.

This includes I-70 in Ohio between mile markers 63 and 70.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

To report severe weather, go to our website at weather.gov/iln and
submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Willamette River at Corvallis.
* At 5 AM Friday the stage was...29.5 feet / 76400 cfs.
* Flood stage is 30.0 feet and flood flow is 83000 cfs.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...This river will remain below flood stage
today, but start rising again this evening. The river is
expected to rise above flood state late Friday night,
and crest near 30.3 ft around noon Saturday.
* Impact...Above 30 ft, expect extensive flooding of
low-lying agricultural land east and south of Corvallis.

* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 30 kt with gusts up to 35 kt.

* SEAS...8 to 12 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:

Instruction:

Alert:
Until 1230 AM EDT.

At 1143 PM EDT, strong thunderstorms extended from near
Burnsville... through Warm Springs...to Sweet Springs. Movement was
east at 35 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph...dime size hail...and very heavy rainfall
are possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Covington...
Clifton Forge...
Goshen...
Millboro...
and Rockbridge Baths.

These storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Instruction:

Alert:
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Shelly...on the Marsh River ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County


.The above Minnesota tributaries with the exception of Climax are
falling. Climax was near crest and little additional rise
expected and then will slowly fall. Many points near the
mainstem Red River remain high due to backflow from the Red River.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Alvarado...on the Snake River.
* until Monday evening...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:30 PM Friday the stage was 107.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 106.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will fall below Flood Stage Sunday.
* The river is forecast to crest at 107.9 on Saturday
during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 108.0 feet, Moderate Flood Stage and
overland sheet flooding of local agricultural land.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at: www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
Strong onshore flow and a large tidal cycle will lead to higher
than normal tides Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
The National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued a Coastal
Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 1 PM Saturday to 1 AM CDT
Sunday.

* COASTAL FLOODING...1 to 1.5 feet above normal.

* TIMING...Highest tide will occur during the late afternoon and
early evening hours.

* IMPACTS...Minor inundation of low lying areas around bays and
the lower reaches of rivers and bayous. A few mainly secondary
roadways could become covered in water.
Instruction:
A Coastal Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds and tides
will combine to generate flooding of low areas along the shore.
Alert:
Walla Walla River near Touchet affecting Walla Walla County


...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon..
John Day River at Service Creek affecting Wheeler County
Umatilla River at Pendleton affecting Umatilla County
Umatilla River near Gibbon affecting Umatilla County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Walla Walla River near Touchet.
* until late Saturday night.
* At 7:30 PM Friday, the stage was 13.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.5 feet by
tomorrow late morning. The river will fall below flood stage
tomorrow late evening.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton

Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building to 5 to 8 feet Saturday
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents beginning
late tonight continuing through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm.  Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:

escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.

Alert:
At 1037 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Como, or 10 miles east of Sulphur Springs, moving northeast at 30
mph.

Half inch hail will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Como.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WINDS...NW to N 15 to 25 kt, with local gusts to 35 kt.

* WAVES...NW building to 6 to 8 ft at 8 seconds and NW swell
around 8 to 9 ft at 16 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:

35 kt.

* WAVES...NW building to 6 to 8 ft at 8 seconds and NW swell
around 7 to 8 ft at 15 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous wave conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

* WAVES...NW 5 to 6 ft at 7 seconds and NW swell building to 8 to

Alert:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions occurring. Travel will be very
difficult to impossible.

* WHERE...Central Beaufort Sea Coast.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 50 mph will
cause whiteout conditions in blowing snow. Significant
drifting of the snow is likely.
Instruction:
A Blizzard Warning means severe winter weather conditions are
expected or occurring. Falling and blowing snow with strong winds
and poor visibilities are likely. This will lead to whiteout
conditions, making travel extremely difficult. The latest road
conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
* WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Plan on areas of poor
visibilities and slick roadways to create difficult travel
conditions at times. Winds gusting as high as 25 mph will
cause areas of blowing and drifting snow.

* WHERE...Northeastern Brooks Range.

* WHEN...Until midnight.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 25 mph will
cause areas of blowing and drifting snow.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for blowing snow means periods of
blowing snow will cause travel difficulties. The latest road
conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
* WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Plan on areas of poor
visibilities and slick roadways to create difficult travel
conditions at times. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph will
cause areas of blowing and drifting snow.

* WHERE...Western Arctic Coast.

* WHEN...Until midnight.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 35 mph will
cause areas of blowing and drifting snow.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for blowing snow means periods of
blowing snow will cause travel difficulties. The latest road
conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions occurring. Travel will be very
difficult to impossible.

* WHERE...Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 50 mph will
cause whiteout conditions in blowing snow. Significant
drifting of the snow is likely.
Instruction:
A Blizzard Warning means severe winter weather conditions are
expected or occurring. Falling and blowing snow with strong winds
and poor visibilities are likely. This will lead to whiteout
conditions, making travel extremely difficult. The latest road
conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
At 1033 PM CDT, Meteorologists were tracking a strong thunderstorm
over Sibley, or 11 miles south of Natchez, moving northeast at 60
mph.

Nickel size hail and winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with
this storm.

This strong thunderstorm will be near...
Kingston around 1040 PM CDT.
Cranfield around 1050 PM CDT.
Stanton around 1055 PM CDT.
Hamburg and Stampley around 1100 PM CDT.
Fayette and Mcnair around 1105 PM CDT.
Red Lick around 1115 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this storm include Roxie and Ridgecrest.
Instruction:
High winds can bring down trees and large limbs resulting in serious
injury or property damage. Exercise extreme caution when outdoors
during such strong winds...and be especially aware of older trees.

Alert:
* WINDS...Southerly at 20 to 25 knots on Saturday shifting to
westerly at 20 to 25 knots in the wake of the front Sunday.

* WAVES/SEAS...Building to 5 to 8 feet near shore and 7 to 10
feet well offshore. Wave heights increasing to 2 to 3 feet
over most inland bays and sounds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds or frequent gusts
of 20 to 33 knots and/or seas of 7 feet or higher are expected to
produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners, especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
* SEAS...Westerly swell 10 ft.

* WIND...south wind 15 to 25 kt Saturday becoming southwest
Saturday night.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:

Saturday night.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased, but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.

Alert:
An area of low pressure and an associated cold front will
approach and move through the area Saturday. Southerly wnds over
the coastal waters will increase in advance of the front
beginning early Saturday morning and continuing through much of
the day. Behind the front, winds will turn out of the north but
remain strong through Sunday. Wave heights of 8 to 10 feet can be
expected across the outer coastal waters and 5 to 7 feet over the
nearshore waters.

Saturday.

Alert:
At 1029 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over
Votaw, or near Thicket, moving northeast at 45 mph.

Half inch hail and winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Woodville, Colmesneil, Chester, Saratoga, Ebenezer, Rockland,
Wildwood, Warren, Thicket, Votaw, Honey Island, Batson, Village
Mills, Ivanhoe, Sam Rayburn Dam and Hillister.
Instruction:
Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building to 5 to 8 feet Saturday
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents beginning
late tonight continuing through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm.  Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building to 5 to 8 feet Saturday

A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm.  Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:
* Kindred...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass and Richland Counties
* West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Harwood...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Mapleton...on the Maple River ...in Cass County


.River levels continue to fall on the North Dakota tributaries.
Slow falls expected on the Sheyenne at West Fargo and Harwood as
this is dependent on falls on the mainstem Red River. Faster falls
at Kindred and Mapleton with a return to rising next week as the
recent snowfall melts.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Mapleton...on the Maple River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:15 PM Friday the stage was 18.0 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...fall then rise above Flood Stage by Tuesday and
continue to rise to near 20.4 feet by Thursday.
Additional rises are possible thereafter.
* The river is forecast to crest at 20.4 on Thursday
during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 20.0 feet, Flooding begins on high ground
near gage.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at: www.weather.gov/grandforks

Walsh Counties

.Along the mainstem Red River and Abercrombie rivers are falling
from Grand Forks and south. North of Grand Forks the mainstem
was rising. Oslo is expected to crest this weekend.
North of Oslo the mainstem Red is expected to crest late next week.
In the south, Wahpeton was beginning a slow rise from melting
snow from the latest winter storm. Wahpeton will continue to rise
for the next week.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Oslo...on the Red River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:15 PM Friday the stage was 37.7 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 36.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 37.8 feet by
Saturday.  Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* The river is forecast to crest at 37.8 on Saturday
during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 37.5 feet, State Highway 1 overtops (MN
DOT).
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at: www.weather.gov/grandforks

.Along the mainstem Red River and Abercrombie rivers are falling
from Grand Forks and south. North of Grand Forks the mainstem
was rising. Oslo is expected to crest this weekend.
North of Oslo the mainstem Red is expected to crest late next week.
In the south, Wahpeton was beginning a slow rise from melting
snow from the latest winter storm. Wahpeton will continue to rise
for the next week.

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected between 8 and 10 AM.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on slippery road conditions. Total
snow accumulations of up to one to two inches are expected.
Isolated higher amounts may be possible as well.

* WHERE...Portions of the Texas Panhandle.

* WHEN...From 7 AM to 10 PM CDT Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Be prepared for snow covered
roads and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.
The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* FLOOD WARNING FOR
the Attoyac Bayou Near Chireno.
* until Sunday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.
* AT  8:30 PM Friday The stage was 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tonight and continue to rise
to near 14.2 feet by tomorrow morning. The river will fall below
flood stage by tomorrow evening.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Portland has issued a Small Craft
Advisory for rough bar, which is in effect from 7 AM Saturday to
5 AM PDT Sunday.



* IN THE MAIN CHANNEL...

* GENERAL SEAS...7 to 9 ft this evening increasing to 9 to 11 ft
later tonight and Saturday.

* FIRST EBB...Around 1145 PM Friday. Seas near 10 ft.

* SECOND EBB...Around Noon Saturday. Seas near 14 ft with
breakers likely.

* THIRD EBB...Around 1 AM Sunday. Seas near 15 ft with breakers
possible.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for rough bar means that wave conditions
are expected to be hazardous to small craft in or near harbor
entrances.
Alert:
* WINDS...Becoming southwest at 15 to 20 kt with gusts of 25 to 30
kt mid to late Saturday morning and Saturday afternoon.

* SEAS...9 to 11 ft tonight building to 11 to 13 ft Saturday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 21 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Streets in Princeton. There is widespread flooding of lowland and
wooded land.

Haw River Near Bynum affecting Chatham County
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flood Warning for  The Haw River Near Bynum.
* until Sunday morning, or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:16 PM Friday the stage was 10.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is expected to rise above flood stage by after
midnight tomorrow and continue to rise to near 12.4 feet by
tomorrow morning.The river will fall below flood stage by tomorrow
late evening.
* At 11.0 feet, The river widens up to 400 feet across. It
floods pasturelands on the right bank and woodlands on the left.
Instruction:

attempt to drive through. Turn around, dont drown.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Carbon County in northeastern Pennsylvania...
Monroe County in northeastern Pennsylvania...

* Until 230 AM EDT.

* At 1026 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
heavy rain which will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. Up
to one inch of rain has already fallen.

* Some locations that could experience flooding include...
Lehighton, Mount Pocono, East Stroudsburg, Tobyhanna, Palmerton,
Jim Thorpe, Nesquehoning, Weatherly, Stormville, Pocono Pines, Lake
Harmony, Tannersville, Long Pond, Kresgeville, Sun Valley, Reeders,
Beltzville State Park, Saylorsburg, McMichael and Blakeslee.

Additional rainfall of up to one inch is expected over the area.
This additional rain will result in minor flooding.
Instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.
Alert:
Corrected for addition of potential hazardous conditions on
Falcon Lake

...Strong Winds expected across the Western Ranchlands and the
Upper Rio Grande Valley Saturday...

.A developing low pressure system over West Texas tonight,
intensifies Saturday as it tracks across the Southern Plains. A
strong pressure gradient is expected to set up across the Western
Ranchlands behind a dry cold front associated with the intense
low pressure area. Higher then normal winds across Falcon Lake are
likely to produce rough waters.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 11 AM to 7 PM CDT Saturday.

* TIMING...11 AM to 7 PM.

* WINDS...25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph possible.

* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions, especially for high
profile vehicles. Boaters on Falcon Lake may experience rough
waters. Unsecured light weight objects may be easily blown by
strong winds. Potential for sporadic power outages or power
surges.
Instruction:

The Missouri River at Napoleon.
* until further notice.

* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

intensifies Saturday as it tracks across the Southern Plains. A
strong pressure gradient is expected to set up across the Western
Ranchlands behind a dry cold front associated with the intense
low pressure area.

the Tombigbee River at Bigbee
* from Sunday April 14 until Monday April 15.

* Minor flooding is forecast.

extensive agricultural flooding is occurring.

latest river information.

Alert:
A low pressure system centered over western Lake Superior will track
northeastward reaching James Bay by Saturday morning. A trailing
trough will keep the gusty southwest flow going into Saturday
before high pressure starts building across the region allowing
winds to relax later in the afternoon. Small craft advisory has
been extended through Saturday afternoon for Saginaw Bay and
around the tip of the Thumb to account for the sustained southwest
flow and elevated waves. High pressure will be short lived as the
next strong low lifts northeast out of the lower Mississippi
Valley reaching Lake Erie Sunday evening. Increased easterly
gradient on the north side of the low will result in gusts to near
gales Sunday evening and overnight. Small craft advisories may be
needed at a minimum for increased wave heights building along the
shoreline with winds around 25 knots.
* WIND AND WAVES: During the Small Craft Advisory, expect
sustained winds up to 21 knots from the southwest with gusts
up to 28 knots. The largest expected significant waves will
be 5 feet with a potential maximum wave height of 7 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 10 AM EDT
Saturday with the largest waves expected around 10 AM EDT
Saturday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

the Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow

Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

* At  8:00 PM Friday the stage was 20.0 feet and falling.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast, Fall to 19.5 feet Sunday morning.
* Impact, At  20.0 feet, Water affects Buffalos Front Street at
Franklin and on Iowa Highway 22 west of town. Water affects
Illinois Highway 92 west of Andalusia.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an
alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
Updated flood information for the Mississippi River.

River forecasts include past precipitation and forecast rainfall for
the next 24 hours.

Alert:
* WINDS...East winds between 15 to 20 knots with higher gusts.

* SEAS...5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or more are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

The Flood Warning continues for
the Meramec River near Arnold
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 PM Friday the stage was 30.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to a stage of 30.0 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact:  At 30.0 feet...Wells Road below Suson Woods begins flooding
at this height.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Berks County in eastern Pennsylvania...
Lehigh County in eastern Pennsylvania...
Northampton County in eastern Pennsylvania...

* Until 145 AM EDT.

* At 945 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
heavy rain which will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. Up
to one inch of rain has already fallen.

* Some locations that could experience flooding include...
Allentown, Reading, Easton, Bethlehem, Forks, Emmaus, Wyomissing,
Northampton, Wilson, Hellertown, Nazareth, Bangor, Birdsboro,
Kutztown, Hamburg, Slatington, Fleetwood, Sinking Spring,
Laureldale and Pen Argyl.

Additional rainfall of up to one inch is expected over the area.
This additional rain will result in minor flooding.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Find an alternate route.
Alert:
Ohio River at Cairo

.Minor flooding continues along the Ohio River at Cairo. The river
continues to fall slowly. Due to heavy rain forecast over the next
few days, the river is now expected to fall below flood stage on
Saturday, April 20. Check back often for possible adjustments to
the forecast.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Ohio River at Cairo
* until Saturday April 20.
* At  8:00 PM Friday the stage was 43.6 feet.
* Flood Stage is 40.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Saturday morning April 20.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/
Alert:
* Winds and Seas...East winds 15 to 25 kt with higher gusts. Seas
8 to 13 feet.
Instruction:
means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots and/or seas 10 feet or
greater are expected to produce conditions hazardous to small
craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
White River At Augusta affecting White and Woodruff Counties

White River At Clarendon affecting Arkansas and Monroe Counties

Cache River Near Patterson affecting Jackson and Woodruff Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River At Augusta.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 8:00 PM Friday the stage was 29.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river continue rising to near 30.2 feet by
Monday morning.
* Impacts at 30.0 feet...Thousands of acres of farm ground flooded.
County roads on both sides of the river are flooded, including
County Road 871 and 899.


Fld     Observed        Forecast 6 AM        Crest
Location     Stg   Stg  Day Time   Sat   Sun   Mon  Crest Time  Date

Lower White River
Augusta     26  29.6 Fri 08 PM  29.6  29.7  30.2   31.0 07 AM 04/18
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Cache River Near Patterson.
* from Monday afternoon until further notice...Or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At 8:00 PM Friday the stage was 6.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain steady through Saturday afternoon
before beginning to rise. The river will rise above flood stage by
Monday afternoon and continue to rise to near 9.3 feet by
Tuesday morning.
* Impacts at 9.0 feet...Low swampy timberland along the river begins to
flood. Flood gates should be closed and equipment moved out of the low
grounds along the river and tributaries.

Alert:
Large surf will continue along exposed east facing shores
through the weekend due to strong trade winds locally and over a
large area east of the islands.
* SURF...8 to 12 feet along east facing shores of Kauai, Oahu,
Molokai, Maui and the Big Island, lowering to 7 to 10 feet
Sunday.

* TIMING...Through 6 PM HST Sunday.

* IMPACTS...Moderate...Expect strong breaking waves, shore
break, and strong longshore and rip currents making swimming
difficult and dangerous.
Instruction:
surfers should heed all advice given by ocean safety officials
and exercise caution.

* Impact:  At 23.0 feet...Area south of Collier Street and along
Sycamore Street outside the Hannibal flood wall floods.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

Alert:
A storm system passing over central and southern New Mexico
tonight and Saturday combined with favorable east winds will
bring accumulating snow to the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Raton
Ridge and Johnson Mesa as well as the Northeast Highlands.
Although snow is expected to begin over the higher elevations of
the Sangre de Cristo mountains late today, the snow level will
lower and snow will become heavier and more widespread over the
region tonight. For the latest New Mexico road conditions visit
nmroads.com or call 511.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5
inches expected.

* WHERE...West Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Far Northeast
Highlands and Northeast Highlands.

* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 9 PM MDT Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
Visibility may be reduced below one mile at times in snow and
areas of fog.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by
calling 5 1 1 or 1-800-432-4269.
Alert:
A storm system passing over central and southern New Mexico
tonight and Saturday combined with favorable east winds will
bring accumulating snow to the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Raton
Ridge and Johnson Mesa as well as the Northeast Highlands.
Although snow is expected to begin over the higher elevations of
the Sangre de Cristo mountains late today, the snow level will
lower and snow will become heavier and more widespread over the
region tonight. For the latest New Mexico road conditions visit
nmroads.com or call 511.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to
12 inches expected.

* WHERE...Northern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet including
Red River, Southern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet, East
Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Raton Ridge and Johnson
Mesa.

* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 9 PM MDT Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Travel could be very difficult,
especially through mountain passes. Visibility may be reduced
below one half mile at times in heavy snow and fog. The weight
of wet snow on trees and power lines may lead to local power
outages.
Instruction:
A Winter Storm Warning for snow means severe winter weather
conditions will make travel very hazardous or impossible. If you
must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food and water in your
vehicle in case of an emergency.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by
calling 5 1 1 or 1-800-432-4269.

the Mississippi River at Caruthersville
* until Monday April 15.
* At 8 PM Friday the stage was 32.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring AND Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 32.0 feet.
* At 33.0 feet...In Tennessee, Barr Road in Chickasaw National
Wildlife Refuge is flooding, cutting off evacuations from the
Wardlews Pocket Area. In Arkansas, docks useed by the steel plant
at Hickman are mostly flooded. Numerous roads and fields inside the
levee between Gayoso and Kennedy, Missouri are covered.

www.weather.gov and click near Memphis on the map, then select Rivers
and Lakes.

Stay tuned to your weather radio and your local news media for the
latest river information.

The Yockanookany River Near Ofahoma
* Until late Tuesday night.
* At  7:45 PM Friday the stage was 18.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage tomorrow evening
and will continue to rise to near 19.5 feet Sunday evening.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Minor overbank flooding of farmland along
the river is occurring.
Instruction:

water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

* At  7:15 PM Friday the stage was 13.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 13.5 feet into Sunday
morning, then begin falling.

Shore Acres Road. Many La Crosse River Marsh trails are under
water.

feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!
