Alert:
Minor to moderate flooding continues along the Mississippi River.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Lake City.
* until Sunday afternoon...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:15 PM Friday the stage was 16.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall...Dropping below flood
stage by Saturday evening.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs and some
residential sections near the river are evacuated. Water and Sewer
service is turned off along Central Point Road.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .
Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...Southwest winds 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to
30 kt. Seas 5 to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The heavy rain has ended. The street and road flooding has receded
for the most part; however, streams and creeks continue running
high. The flash flood warning will be allowed to expire at 930 PM.
Any additional heavy rain may prompt additional Warnings tonight or
Saturday due to saturated ground and high water levels in area
streams. Be prepared to move to higher ground if additional
warnings are issued.
Instruction:

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana..

Boeuf River Near Fort Necessity affecting Franklin Parish
The Flood Warning continues for
The Boeuf River Near Fort Necessity
* Until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 54.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 50.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 55.0 feet early
Tuesday morning.
* Impact...At 55.0 feet...Several thousand acres of farm and
agricultural land are inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected between 8 and 10 AM.
Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Mississippi..

Big Black River At West affecting Attala and Holmes Counties

Big Black River Near Bentonia affecting Madison and Yazoo Counties

Big Black River Near Bovina affecting Hinds and Warren Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Black River At West
* Until further notice.
* At  7:45 PM Friday the stage was 19.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 20.5 feet Sunday
evening.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Thousands of acres of agricultural land are
under water.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

Big Black River Near Bentonia affecting Madison and Yazoo Counties

Big Black River Near Bovina affecting Hinds and Warren Counties
The Flood Warning continues for

* From late Saturday night until further notice.
* At  8:15 PM Friday the stage was 26.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 28.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage Sunday morning and
will continue to rise to near 31.0 feet Friday morning.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The

Alert:
Deep moisture wrapping around a broad upper level low to the
east of the Big Island will bring periods of snow and ice to the
higher elevations of Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa through tonight.
* WHAT...Snow and ice accumulation occurring. Plan on slippery
road conditions. Additional snow accumulations of up to 1 inch
is expected.

* WHERE...Big Island Summits above 12000 feet.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory means that periods of snow, sleet, or
freezing rain will cause travel difficulties. Be prepared for
slippery roads and limited visibilities and use caution while
driving.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northeast 20 to 30 mph with localized gusts over 50 mph.

* TIMING...Through 6 PM HST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Winds this strong could down tree branches and cause
localized power outages. Motorists, especially those in high
profile vehicles, are urged to drive with caution.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of at least 30 mph, or
gusts of at least 50 mph, are expected. Motorists should use
extra caution.
Alert:
The Flash Flood Watch has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Counties
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...

Washington Counties

Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County
Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Chippewa...Lac qui Parle
and Yellow Medicine Counties

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Savage.
* until further notice.
* At 8:15 PM Friday the stage was 707.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 702.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is forecast to have a maximum value of 707.1
feet after midnight tonight.
* Impact...At 705.0 feet...Flood waters begin to impact the park road
at Fort Snelling State Park.
* Impact...At 702.0 feet...Barge loading stops at Port Cargill, and
other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact
Black Dog Road in Burnsville.
* Impact...At 700.0 feet...Flood waters begin to cover trails at Fort
Snelling State Park as well as low parts on the Bloomington Ferry
Bridge trail just east of US 169.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Montevideo.
* until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 17.4 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 17.9 feet by
Friday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Sanitary sewers begin to be affected at this
level.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Storm sewers may need to be plugged to
prevent water from backing up into streets.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along the
river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

for the latest information concerning this flood event.

* until further notice.

problems.

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Henderson MN19.
* until further notice.
* At  7:30 PM Friday the stage was 732.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 732.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 732.9 feet by
Friday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 733.7 feet...The floodwall gates will be closed when
Henderson reaches 733.7 and the river is still rising at Mankato.
* Impact...At 733.5 feet...Highway 93 may be closed between Henderson
and Hwy 169.
* Impact...At 732.5 feet...Water begins encroaching on highway 19 east
of Henderson.
* Impact...At 732.0 feet...Water begins impacting residences and
agricultural buildings north and south of Henderson.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At Morton .
* until further notice.
* At  7:30 PM Friday the stage was 24.8 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 25.8 feet by
Friday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Numerous roads flooded and impassable
between the Minnesota River and Redwood Falls.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Fleischer Rd flooded in North Redwood; storm
sewers closed off and bypass pumping begins.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in
North Redwood.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Water reaches flood mitigation culverts on
Riverside Road
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Redwood River near Redwood Falls.
* until further notice.
* At  7:30 PM Friday the stage was 6.8 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 8.3 feet by
Friday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 8.5 feet...Swayback bridge in Redwood Falls overtopped.
* Impact...At 6.0 feet...Low lying areas, mainly farmland, and some
roads along the river begin to experience flooding; bottom of
Swayback bridge
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.
Alert:
Saline River At Benton affecting Saline County


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Saline River At Benton.
* from Sunday afternoon to Tuesday morning...Or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 7:30 PM Friday the stage was 4.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by Sunday afternoon
and continue to rise to near 18.5 feet by Sunday evening. The river
will fall below flood stage by Monday morning.
* Impacts at 18.0 feet...Minor flooding begins at 18 feet, flooding of
low lying pastures along the west bank.


Fld     Observed        Forecast 6 AM        Crest
Location     Stg   Stg  Day Time   Sat   Sun   Mon  Crest Time  Date

Saline River
Benton      18   4.6 Fri 07 PM   4.4  15.1  16.0   18.5 07 PM 04/14
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
the Cuivre River at Old Monroe
* until further notice.
* At  7:30 PM Friday the stage was 27.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to a stage of 27.8 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact:  At 28.1 feet...Dyer Road upstream from the gage begins
flooding just downstream of the new Highway 79 bridge.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in State College PA has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for Poor Drainage Areas
for...
Central Dauphin County in south central Pennsylvania...
Lebanon County in south central Pennsylvania...

* Until 1215 AM EDT.

* At 918 PM EDT, emergency management reported heavy rain and water
covering roads in poor drainage areas in Swatara Township. The
heavy rain will cause urban and small stream flooding. Overflowing
poor drainage areas will result in minor flooding.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Lebanon, Hershey, Colonial Park, Progress, Middletown, Palmyra,
Linglestown, Annville, Hummelstown, Cornwall, Myerstown, Paxtonia,
Rutherford, Skyline View, Lawnton, Campbelltown, Penbrook, Pleasant
Hill, Sand Hill and Newmanstown.
Instruction:

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Sturgeon River near Chassell affecting Houghton County

.Water levels on the Sturgeon River near Chassell remain above flood stage.
Significant precipitation, mainly in the form of snow and sleet, fell across the
basin yesterday. While additional runoff was limited, it has kept water levels
from receeding and so the warning continues.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Sturgeon River near Chassell.
* until Saturday afternoon.
* At  8:10 AM Friday the stage was 10.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.5 feet.
* At 10.5 feet...The river begins to overflow onto Sturgeon River
Road...Rajala Road...and Aho Road.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Even 6 inches of fast moving flood water can knock
you off your feet...and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never
try to walk...swim...or drive through such swift water. If you come
upon flood waters...stop...turn around and go another way.

additional weather and river information is available at
www.weather.gov/mqt

The next statement will be issued by 11AM EDT Saturday.
Alert:
Cape Fear At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3 affecting Bladen County NC
Lumber Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County NC
Great Pee Dee At Pee Dee affecting Marion and Florence Counties SC
The Flood Warning continues for
The Lumber Near Lumberton.
* until further notice.
* At  7:50 PM Friday the stage was 14.12 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 14.3 feet by Monday morning
then begin falling.
* Impact...At 15.0 feet...Flood waters will affect yards in the Pines area, Coxs
Pond area, and along River Road. Additional residential property will be
affected between the Pepsi plant and the river on the east side of Lumberton.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

People with interests along the river should take the necessary precautions to
protect life and property from the flood waters.

"Rivers and Lakes" link.

Saturday.

* WAVES...4 to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that winds or waves are expected to
produce hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels should
avoid navigating in these conditions.

at La Grange Lock and Dam
at Valley City
at Hardin

the past 24 hours and zero precipitation forecast in the next

The Flood Warning continues for
the Illinois River at Valley City
* until further notice.
* At  7:30 PM Friday the stage was 17.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to a stage of 16.9 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact:  At 14.0 feet...The road to Norbut Fish and Wildlife area is
flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

forecasts.

in rises along the Trempealeau River near Dodge, with minor
flooding expected.

precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trempealeau River at Dodge.
* from late Monday night to Saturday April 20...Or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At  7:45 PM Friday the stage was 7.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 9.8 feet by Thursday morning. The river will fall
below flood stage by Friday morning.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...The entrance road to the Trempealeau National
Wildlife Refuge is flooded.

feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility

St. John The Baptist Parishes

The Mississippi River At Reserve.
* Until Sunday, April 28.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 22.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Sunday, April 28.
* Impact...At 22.0 feet...Marine and industrial interests along the
river, upstream barge operators, and facilities are impacted.
Navigation will become difficult for smaller river craft. Safety

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Baton Rouge.
* Until Monday, May 06.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 40.4 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 35.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Monday, May 06.
* Impact...At 40.0 feet...The grounds of the older part of Louisiana
State University's campus become soggy. This includes the area
around the Veterinary Medicine building, the Veterinary Medicine
Annex, the stadium and ball fields. The city of Baton Rouge and the
main LSU campus are protected by levees at this level.
* Impact...At 38.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 36.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 35.0 feet...River islands from Red River Landing
downstream to Baton Rouge will be inundated.

Alert:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes
Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes
Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 57.4 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 57.1 feet
by Sunday, April 14.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,

* WAVES: Waves 8 to 12 ft occasionally to 16 ft.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
At 530 PM PDT, Bureau of Reclamation in conjunction with Pendleton
City Officials and Umatilla County Emergency Management are going to
speed up the higher releases from McKay Dam.

The flow from McKay Dam will increase to 2500 cubic feet per second
around 8 AM Saturday morning.

The City of Pendleton has confirmed that the Quinney Street Bridge
is capable of passing 4000 cubic feet per second.  People in this
area should take action now to move property items that may be
impacted by the high water. People not directly impacted are
encourage to stay away from this area.  Stay away from the creek as
the banks may be unstable and could collapse.

deaths occur in vehicles.

Alert:
At 815 PM EDT, National Weather Service doppler radar indicated
strong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Rocky Ford to
near Aline, and moving northeast at 10 mph.

HAZARD...strong winds 45 to 55 mph, up to penny sized hail and
excessive cloud to ground lightning.

IMPACT...Expect minor damage to tree limbs and blowing around of
light, unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to plants,
trees and crops is possible. Damage to windshields is
unlikely. All outdoor activities should cease. Move
indoors immediately.

Some locations in the path of these storms include...
Metter, Sylvania, Portal, Rocky Ford, Woodcliff and Scarboro.

1-888-383-2024 when it is safe to do so. You can also email your
report to nws.charlestonsc@noaa.gov.

away from windows.

calling toll free, 800 401 9535, when you can do so safely.

Charleston West Virginia National Weather Service Facebook Page, or
by using the Twitter Hashtag, NWSRLX.

Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect from 6 AM EDT Saturday through
Saturday evening.

* LOCATIONS...Coastal Pender and Coastal New Hanover.

* TIMING...From 6 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.

* SURF ZONE IMPACTS...Very strong rip currents will be dangerous
to anyone who enters the surf.
Instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect from 6 AM EDT Saturday through
Saturday evening.

* LOCATIONS...Coastal Pender and Coastal New Hanover.

* TIMING...From 6 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.

* SURF ZONE IMPACTS...Very strong rip currents will be dangerous
to anyone who enters the surf.
Instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.
Alert:
Decreasing SE swell will lower the rip current risk at Coastal
Brunswick, Horry and Georgetown counties to a moderate risk for
tomorrow.

* THIS IS A TEST MESSAGE. THIS TEST TORNADO WARNING INITIATES THE
SEVERE WEATHER AWARENESS WEEK TORNADO DRILL FOR THE STATE OF
WISCONSIN...REPEAT...THIS IS A TORNADO DRILL. THIS ANNUAL DRILL IS
THE HIGHLIGHT OF THE WISCONSIN AND MINNESOTA SEVERE WEATHER AND
TORNADO AWARENESS WEEK. ALL SCHOOLS...BUSINESSES...HOSPITALS AND
OTHER PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS ARE URGED TO TREAT THIS AS IF IT WERE A
REAL EMERGENCY AND PRACTICE YOUR SEVERE WEATHER EMERGENCY PLANS.

* THIS IS A TEST MESSAGE. THE SAFEST PLACE TO BE DURING A TORNADO IS
IN A BASEMENT. GET UNDER A WORKBENCH OR OTHER PIECE OF STURDY
FURNITURE. IF NO BASEMENT IS AVAILABLE...SEEK SHELTER ON THE
LOWEST FLOOR OF THE BUILDING IN AN INTERIOR HALLWAY OR SMALL ROOM.
USE BLANKETS OR PILLOWS TO COVER YOUR BODY. NEVER TRY TO OUTRUN A
TORNADO IN A VEHICLE.

THIS IS A TEST MESSAGE. DO NOT TAKE ACTION BASED ON THIS MESSAGE.

Alert:
At 737 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9
miles east of Fayetteville, moving northeast at 25 mph.

Pea size hail, heavy rain, and wind gusts up to 50 mph will be
possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Stedman, Falcon, Autryville, Hobbton, Vander, Spivey's Corner and
Cedar Creek.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Doppler radar has indicated weak rotation with this storm. If the
storm intensifies and rotation strengthens, a warning may need to be
issued.
Alert:

limits, and no longer poses an immediate threat to life or property.
Therefore the warning will be allowed to expire.  However heavy rain
is still possible with this thunderstorm.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 930 PM EDT

* At 730 PM EDT, Radar indicated heavy rain continuing over Durham.
Radar estimated 2 to locally 3 inches of rain had fallen around
Durham. Any additional heavy rain will likely produce flash
flooding.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Rougemont, Lake Michie, Gorman, Parkwood, Bahama, Bethesda,
Rollingview Marina, Research Triangle and Eno River State Park.
Instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many
roads and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When
encountering flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
* LOCATIONS...Including the cities of Grand Junction, Fruita,
Palisade, De Beque, New Castle, Mesa, Parachute, Rifle, Silt,
Montrose, Hotchkiss, Delta, Gateway, Nucla, Moab, Castle
Valley, Canyonlands National Park, Dead Horse Point State
Park, and Fry Canyon.

* TEMPERATURES...27 to 32 degrees.

* TIMING...The coldest temperatures are expected early Saturday
morning shortly after sunrise.

* IMPACTS...Sensitive vegetation and swamp coolers will be
impacted by sub-freezing temperatures.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are imminent or
highly likely. These conditions will kill crops and other
sensitive vegetation.

The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Cumberland County in central North Carolina...

* Until 930 PM EDT

* At 725 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated showers and isolated
thunderstorms with very heavy rain over the city of Fayetteville.
The heavy rain extended from near the Fayetteville Airport
northeast across the city of Fayetteville and extended to
Eastover. The heaviest rain was training over the urban area and
that will cause urban and small stream flooding in the advisory
area. Up to one inch of rain has already fallen, an additional
inch will fall through 800 PM.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Fayetteville, Godwin, Hope Mills, Eastover, Stedman, Wade, Falcon,
Autryville, Linden and Vander.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

A Flood Advisory means river or stream flows are elevated, or ponding
of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.

Nighttime flooding is impossible to recognize. Be extra cautious and
turn around, don't drown.

extending from near Lyons to near Altamaha...and moving northeast at
15 mph.

HAZARD...Up to 40 mph wind...frequent cloud to ground lightning
and heavy rain.

street flooding especially in poor drainage areas.

Ohoopee, New Branch, Ponderosa and Johnson Corner.
Instruction:
People outdoors should seek shelter immediately. If you can hear
thunder...you are close enough to be struck by lightning. Motorists
should slow down and be prepared for possible loss of control due to
hydroplaning.

At 659 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a line of strong
thunderstorms along a line extending from Fuquay-Varina to 8 miles
west of Godwin. Movement was northeast at 30 mph.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph will be possible with these storms.

Heavy rain and minor flooding will also be possible with these
storms.

Locations impacted include...
Smithfield, Lillington, Garner, Fuquay-Varina, Clayton, Dunn,
Zebulon, Angier, Benson and Selma.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
40 mph are capable of knocking down tree limbs and blowing around
trash cans, and other light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

Alert:
At 654 PM EDT, a confirmed tornado was located near Fuquay-Varina, or
13 miles north of Lillington, moving north at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Fuquay-Varina, Holly Springs, Duncan, New Hill, Harris Lake Boat
Launch and Shearon Harris Reservoir.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a
basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

This cluster of thunderstorms is capable of producing tornadoes and
widespread significant wind damage. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest
floor of a building.
Alert:

and Dietrich through 550 PM MDT.

Locations impacted include...
Northern Idaho Falls, Carey, Little Wood Reservoir, Picabo,

Butte, Osgood and Kettle Butte.
Instruction:

Alert:
Web cameras and observation platforms indicate that areas of
dense sea fog are developing rapidly across the near shore Gulf
waters and starting to spread over portions of the Laguna Madre.
The combination of high dew point air over relatively cool shelf
waters is producing the dense sea fog. Conditions are expected to
remain conducive for the fog to persist through at least mid
morning Saturday before a cold front moves through the Gulf waters
Saturday afternoon.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Dense
Fog Advisory, which is in effect until 10 AM CDT Saturday.

* VISIBILITY...one mile or less.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
At 645 PM EDT, a confirmed tornado was located 8 miles southwest of
Fuquay-Varina, or 10 miles northwest of Lillington, moving northeast
at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Fuquay-Varina, Holly Springs, New Hill, Harris Lake Boat Launch,
Shearon Harris Reservoir, Duncan, Raven Rock State Park and Lake
Jordan.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a
basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

This cluster of thunderstorms is capable of producing tornadoes and
widespread significant wind damage. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest
floor of a building.

Alert:
At 319 PM PDT, Bureau of Reclamation in conjunction with Pendleton
City Officials and Umatilla County Emergency Management are going to
speed up the higher releases from McKay Dam.

The flow from McKay Dam will increase to 2000 cubic feet per second
at 4 pm.

The City of Pendleton has confirmed that the Quinney Street Bridge
is capable of passing 4000 cubic feet per second.  People in this
area should take action now to move property items that may be
impacted by the high water. People not directly impacted are
encourage to stay away from this area.  Stay away from the creek as
the banks may be unstable and could collapse.
Instruction:

deaths occur in vehicles.

Big Blue River near Blue Rapids affecting Marshall County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At  4:15 PM Friday the stage was 40.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 40.9 feet by
early Sunday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
The river is forecast to remain above flood stage for the next
several weeks due to backwater from Tuttle Creek Lake.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

Stay tuned to later developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio
and local media.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 800 PM EDT

* At 556 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated showers and thunderstorms
with very heavy rain extending from Fearrington and Chapel Hill to
Durham, moving east at 10 mph. Training of the more intense cores
of the thunderstorms to the north along the line will cause urban
and small stream flooding in the advisory area. Up to two inches
of rain have already fallen. An additional 1 to 2 inches of rain
through 700 PM may produce flash flooding.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Hillsborough, Carrboro, Rougemont, Carr,
Efland, Lake Michie, Eno River State Park and Gorman.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

Do not drive your vehicle into areas where the water covers the
roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross
safely. Move to higher ground.

Umatilla River at Pendleton affecting Umatilla County
The National Weather Service in Pendleton has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Umatilla River at Pendleton.
* until late tonight...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 2:00 PM Friday, the stage was 12.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late this afternoon and
continue to rise to near 12.4 feet by this evening.  The
river will fall below flood stage overnight.  Even as the river
falls at Pendleton, flooding will continue along Umatilla through
Echo and Hermiston to the confluence of the Columbia River
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.

Alert:
At 546 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a line of strong
thunderstorms extending from 11 miles south of Sanford to 7 miles
northeast of Raeford to Antioch. Movement was northeast at 25 mph.
Periods of weak rotation have been witnessed in a few of these
storms.

Nickel size hail, heavy rain, and wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph will be
possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Fayetteville, Raeford, Lillington, Fort Bragg, Dunn, Angier, Benson,
Godwin, Pope AFB and Antioch.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a Small Craft
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 PM Saturday to 2 PM AST
Sunday.

* WINDS...East winds between 15 to 20 knots with higher gusts.

* SEAS...5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or more are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Portland has issued a Small Craft
Advisory for winds, which is in effect from 10 AM to 3 PM PDT
Saturday.

* WINDS...Saturday, SW 15-20 kt with gusts to 25 kt.

* SEAS...Around 10 ft through tonight building to around 12 ft
Saturday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.
Alert:
* WINDS...Saturday, SW 15-20 kt with gusts 25 to 30 kt.

* SEAS...Around 10 ft through tonight building to around 12 ft
Saturday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 21 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Lee County in central North Carolina...
Eastern Chatham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 715 PM EDT

* At 519 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms with very
heavy rain extending from Sanford to Pittsboro, moving east at 10
mph. Training of the individual thunderstorms to the north at 30
mph along the line will cause urban and small stream flooding in
the advisory area. Up to two inches of rain have already fallen.
An additional 1 to 2 inches through 630 PM can be expected from
near Sanford to Jordan Lake and Pittsboro.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Sanford, Pittsboro, Broadway, Crosswinds Boating Center, Lemon
Springs, Crosswinds Campground, Gum Springs, Jordan Lake State Rec
Area, Bynum and Seaforth Boat Dock.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

A Flood Advisory means river or stream flows are elevated, or ponding
of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.

Alert:
At 518 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated a strong thunderstorm over
Monument, moving northeast at 55 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph are possible.

Locations impacted include...
Lock Haven, Jersey Shore, Avis, Dunnstown, Flemington, McElhattan,
Monument, Waterville, Little Pine State Park, Salladasburg and Lock
Haven University.
Instruction:

Alert:
At 417 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over
Grant, or near Sugartown, moving northeast at 25 mph.

Pea size hail and winds in excess of 30 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Elizabeth, Pitkin, Sugartown, Grant and Union Hill.
Instruction:
Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.
Alert:
At 515 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 7 miles west of
Rougemont, or 8 miles east of Prospect Hill, moving northeast at 25
mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and nickel size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Chapel Hill, Hillsborough, Carrboro, Mebane, Carr, Efland, Eno River
State Park, Cane Creek Reservoir and Schley.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Straight line winds can blow down trees, power lines, and damage
mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.
Alert:
The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected above 4000 feet. Total snow accumulations
of up to 12 inches are expected. Southwest winds gusting as
high as 40 to 50 mph can be expected Saturday on exposed ridges.

* WHERE...Cascade mountains of Whatcom and Skagit Counties,
including the Mount Baker Ski Area, Cascade mountains Snohomish
and King Counties including Stevens Pass, and Cascade mountains
of Pierce and Lewis Counties, including the Crystal Mountain Ski
Area, and Paradise on Mount Rainier.

* WHEN...From 6 AM Saturday to midnight PDT Saturday night.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions on higher
passes and on the higher elevation roadways of Mt. Baker and Mt.
Rainier.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

For the latest road conditions in Washington state, call 5 1 1.

* Until 600 PM EDT.

* At 516 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Fort Ashby,
or near Bel Air, moving northeast at 60 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Damaging winds will cause some trees and large branches
to fall. This could injure those outdoors, as well as
damage homes and vehicles. Roadways may become blocked by
downed trees. Localized power outages are possible.
Unsecured light objects may become projectiles.

* Locations impacted include...
Cumberland, Keyser, Hancock, Bel Air, La Vale, Fort Ashby,
Lonaconing, Berkeley Springs, Ridgeley, Cresaptown, Potomac Park,
Wiley Ford, Rawlings, Springfield, Midland, Great Cacapon, Green
Spring, Flintstone, Oldtown and Spring Gap.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.

Alert:
Willamette Tributaries Bulletin


...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in
Oregon...

Pudding River at Aurora affecting Clackamas and Marion Counties

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon...

Middle Fk Willamette R at Jasper affecting Lane County


River forecasts are based on observed and forecast rainfall and
temperatures, and they include current and planned reservoir
releases.

For the latest river stages and forecasts, visit
weather.gov/portland.

The next update for these locations will be issued by 5 AM Saturday.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Middle Fk Willamette R at Jasper.
* At 8 PM Friday the stage was...10.2 feet / 23413 cfs.
* Flood stage is 10.0 feet and flood flow is 22100 cfs.
* Forecast...This river crested at 10.5 feet at 5 AM Friday. It is
expected to fall below flood stage around 6 AM Saturday and
continue falling for the next couple days.
* Impact...Above 10.0 ft, expect minor flooding of agricultural land
and low-lying areas along the Middle Fork from Jasper downstream to
Springfield.

Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots and/or
seas of 5 feet or greater over the coastal waters are expected to
produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

* Until 1130 PM CDT.

* At 1051 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Hamburg, or
21 miles east of Natchez, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...Half dollar size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Damage to vehicles is expected.

Mcbride around 1115 PM CDT.
Pleasant Hill around 1120 PM CDT.
Allen around 1125 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this severe thunderstorm include Roxie.

building.

Alert:
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Shelly...on the Marsh River ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County


.The above Minnesota tributaries with the exception of Climax are
falling. Climax was near crest and little additional rise
expected and then will slowly fall. Many points near the
mainstem Red River remain high due to backflow from the Red River.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Alvarado...on the Snake River.
* until Monday evening...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:30 PM Friday the stage was 107.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 106.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will fall below Flood Stage Sunday.
* The river is forecast to crest at 107.9 on Saturday
during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 108.0 feet, Moderate Flood Stage and
overland sheet flooding of local agricultural land.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at: www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
Strong onshore flow and a large tidal cycle will lead to higher
than normal tides Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
The National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued a Coastal
Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 1 PM Saturday to 1 AM CDT
Sunday.

* COASTAL FLOODING...1 to 1.5 feet above normal.

* TIMING...Highest tide will occur during the late afternoon and
early evening hours.

* IMPACTS...Minor inundation of low lying areas around bays and
the lower reaches of rivers and bayous. A few mainly secondary
roadways could become covered in water.
Instruction:
A Coastal Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds and tides
will combine to generate flooding of low areas along the shore.
Alert:
Walla Walla River near Touchet affecting Walla Walla County


...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon..
John Day River at Service Creek affecting Wheeler County
Umatilla River at Pendleton affecting Umatilla County
Umatilla River near Gibbon affecting Umatilla County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Umatilla River near Gibbon.
* until Sunday morning.
* At 8:15 PM Friday, the stage was 7.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 7.2 feet by
tomorrow late evening. The river will fall below flood stage Sunday
morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton

Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building to 5 to 8 feet Saturday
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents beginning
late tonight continuing through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm.  Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building to 5 to 8 feet Saturday
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents beginning
late tonight continuing through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm.  Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline.  If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

difficult to impossible.

* WHERE...Central Beaufort Sea Coast.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds gusting as high as 50 mph will
cause whiteout conditions in blowing snow. Significant
drifting of the snow is likely.
Instruction:
A Blizzard Warning means severe winter weather conditions are
expected or occurring. Falling and blowing snow with strong winds
and poor visibilities are likely. This will lead to whiteout
conditions, making travel extremely difficult. The latest road
conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

Instruction:

injury or property damage. Exercise extreme caution when outdoors

A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased, but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.

* SEAS...Westerly swell 10 ft.

* WIND...south wind 15 to 25 kt Saturday becoming southwest
Saturday night.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
An area of low pressure and an associated cold front will
approach and move through the area Saturday. Southerly wnds over
the coastal waters will increase in advance of the front
beginning early Saturday morning and continuing through much of
the day. Behind the front, winds will turn out of the north but
remain strong through Sunday. Wave heights of 8 to 10 feet can be
expected across the outer coastal waters and 5 to 7 feet over the
nearshore waters.

Alert:
At 1029 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over
Votaw, or near Thicket, moving northeast at 45 mph.

Half inch hail and winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Woodville, Colmesneil, Chester, Saratoga, Ebenezer, Rockland,
Wildwood, Warren, Thicket, Votaw, Honey Island, Batson, Village
Mills, Ivanhoe, Sam Rayburn Dam and Hillister.
Instruction:
Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building to 5 to 8 feet Saturday
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents beginning
late tonight continuing through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Tonight through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.  Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf.  Swim near a lifeguard.

escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.  If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current.

Alert:
* Kindred...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass and Richland Counties
* West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Harwood...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Mapleton...on the Maple River ...in Cass County


.River levels continue to fall on the North Dakota tributaries.
Slow falls expected on the Sheyenne at West Fargo and Harwood as
this is dependent on falls on the mainstem Red River. Faster falls
at Kindred and Mapleton with a return to rising next week as the
recent snowfall melts.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:15 PM Friday the stage was 22.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue to fall to a stage of 21.6 feet
by Sunday.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 21.0 feet, MAJOR FLOOD. Approximate stage
where flooding begins in areas along the Sheyenne River north of
the diversion channel to Harwood, ND.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at: www.weather.gov/grandforks

Walsh Counties

.Along the mainstem Red River and Abercrombie rivers are falling
from Grand Forks and south. North of Grand Forks the mainstem
was rising. Oslo is expected to crest this weekend.
North of Oslo the mainstem Red is expected to crest late next week.
In the south, Wahpeton was beginning a slow rise from melting
snow from the latest winter storm. Wahpeton will continue to rise
for the next week.

from Grand Forks and south. North of Grand Forks the mainstem
was rising. Oslo is expected to crest this weekend.
North of Oslo the mainstem Red is expected to crest late next week.
In the south, Wahpeton was beginning a slow rise from melting
snow from the latest winter storm. Wahpeton will continue to rise
for the next week.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Oslo...on the Red River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:15 PM Friday the stage was 37.7 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 36.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 37.8 feet by
Saturday.  Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* The river is forecast to crest at 37.8 on Saturday
during this 7-day period.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 37.5 feet, State Highway 1 overtops (MN
DOT).
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

on our web page at: www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected between 8 and 10 AM.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on slippery road conditions. Total
snow accumulations of up to one to two inches are expected.
Isolated higher amounts may be possible as well.

* WHERE...Portions of the Texas Panhandle.

* WHEN...From 7 AM to 10 PM CDT Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Be prepared for snow covered
roads and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.
The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* FLOOD WARNING FOR
the Attoyac Bayou Near Chireno.
* until Sunday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.
* AT  8:30 PM Friday The stage was 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tonight and continue to rise
to near 14.2 feet by tomorrow morning. The river will fall below
flood stage by tomorrow evening.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Portland has issued a Small Craft
Advisory for rough bar, which is in effect from 7 AM Saturday to
5 AM PDT Sunday.



* IN THE MAIN CHANNEL...

* GENERAL SEAS...7 to 9 ft this evening increasing to 9 to 11 ft
later tonight and Saturday.

* FIRST EBB...Around 1145 PM Friday. Seas near 10 ft.

* SECOND EBB...Around Noon Saturday. Seas near 14 ft with
breakers likely.

* THIRD EBB...Around 1 AM Sunday. Seas near 15 ft with breakers
possible.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for rough bar means that wave conditions
are expected to be hazardous to small craft in or near harbor
entrances.
Alert:
* WINDS...Becoming southwest at 15 to 20 kt with gusts of 25 to 30
kt mid to late Saturday morning and Saturday afternoon.

* SEAS...9 to 11 ft tonight building to 11 to 13 ft Saturday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 21 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.8 feet by
Wednesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 13.8 feet...Floodwaters are over the banks in the
Berlin area and affect the road in Riverside Park in Berlin.
Floodwaters are into Webster Street Park in Berlin.
Instruction:

Alert:
Haw River Near Bynum affecting Chatham County
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flood Warning for  The Haw River Near Bynum.
* until Sunday morning, or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:16 PM Friday the stage was 10.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is expected to rise above flood stage by after
midnight tomorrow and continue to rise to near 12.4 feet by
tomorrow morning.The river will fall below flood stage by tomorrow
late evening.
* At 11.0 feet, The river widens up to 400 feet across. It
floods pasturelands on the right bank and woodlands on the left.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message. If you encounter deep water while driving, do not
attempt to drive through. Turn around, dont drown.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Carbon County in northeastern Pennsylvania...
Monroe County in northeastern Pennsylvania...

* Until 230 AM EDT.

* At 1026 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
heavy rain which will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. Up
to one inch of rain has already fallen.

* Some locations that could experience flooding include...
Lehighton, Mount Pocono, East Stroudsburg, Tobyhanna, Palmerton,
Jim Thorpe, Nesquehoning, Weatherly, Stormville, Pocono Pines, Lake
Harmony, Tannersville, Long Pond, Kresgeville, Sun Valley, Reeders,
Beltzville State Park, Saylorsburg, McMichael and Blakeslee.

Additional rainfall of up to one inch is expected over the area.
This additional rain will result in minor flooding.
Instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.
Alert:
Corrected for addition of potential hazardous conditions on
Falcon Lake

...Strong Winds expected across the Western Ranchlands and the
Upper Rio Grande Valley Saturday...

.A developing low pressure system over West Texas tonight,
intensifies Saturday as it tracks across the Southern Plains. A
strong pressure gradient is expected to set up across the Western
Ranchlands behind a dry cold front associated with the intense
low pressure area. Higher then normal winds across Falcon Lake are
likely to produce rough waters.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 11 AM to 7 PM CDT Saturday.

* TIMING...11 AM to 7 PM.

* WINDS...25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph possible.

* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions, especially for high
profile vehicles. Boaters on Falcon Lake may experience rough
waters. Unsecured light weight objects may be easily blown by
strong winds. Potential for sporadic power outages or power
surges.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 to 39 MPH are expected.
Winds this strong can make driving difficult...especially for
high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
Missouri River at Atchison affecting Atchison...Buchanan and Platte
Counties.
Missouri River at Napoleon affecting Jackson...Lafayette and Ray
Counties.
Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline
Counties.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River at Napoleon.
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 PM Friday the stage was 18.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 18.6 feet by
Thursday evening.
* At 17.0 feet...Low-lying areas unprotected by levees begin to
flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

The Flood Warning continues for
the Tombigbee River at Bigbee
* from Sunday April 14 until Monday April 15.
* At 7 PM Friday the stage was 11.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 16.7 feet on Monday April 15.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.

to rise to near 16.7 feet by Monday April 15. The river will
likely fall below flood stage by later Monday April 15.

extensive agricultural flooding is occurring.

and Lakes.

latest river information.

occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:

Alert:
A low pressure system centered over western Lake Superior will track
northeastward reaching James Bay by Saturday morning. A trailing
trough will keep the gusty southwest flow going into Saturday
before high pressure starts building across the region allowing
winds to relax later in the afternoon. Small craft advisory has
been extended through Saturday afternoon for Saginaw Bay and
around the tip of the Thumb to account for the sustained southwest
flow and elevated waves. High pressure will be short lived as the
next strong low lifts northeast out of the lower Mississippi
Valley reaching Lake Erie Sunday evening. Increased easterly
gradient on the north side of the low will result in gusts to near
gales Sunday evening and overnight. Small craft advisories may be
needed at a minimum for increased wave heights building along the
shoreline with winds around 25 knots.
* WIND AND WAVES: During the Small Craft Advisory, expect
sustained winds up to 21 knots from the southwest with gusts
up to 28 knots. The largest expected significant waves will
be 5 feet with a potential maximum wave height of 7 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 10 AM EDT
Saturday with the largest waves expected around 10 AM EDT
Saturday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau and Thebes

.Moderate flooding continues along the Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau
and Thebes. The river will continue to fall slowly, and flood warnings
will continue until further notice.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 PM Friday the stage was 38.9 feet.
* Flood Stage is 32.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The River will continue to fall to a stage of 38.2 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 38.0 Feet...The flood gate at Broadway closes.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

consider wind and sea conditions in planning.
Alert:
* Wind: South 15 to 20 knots, with gusts to 25 knots.

* Waves: 2 to 3 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots over
the rivers of eastern Virginia are expected to produce hazardous
boating conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

Alert:
* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 25 knots dropping to 10 to 15 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...Waves 3 to 5 feet subsiding to 2 to 3 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory is issued when waves of 4 feet or more are
expected or wind speeds reach 21 to 33 knots which may produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should stay in port
during these conditions.

* Forecast, Fall to 20.8 feet Sunday morning.
* Impact, At  21.0 feet, Riverside Park is entirely under water.

alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.
