Alert:
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Berks County in eastern Pennsylvania...
Lehigh County in eastern Pennsylvania...
Northampton County in eastern Pennsylvania...

* Until 145 AM EDT.

* At 945 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
heavy rain which will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. Up
to one inch of rain has already fallen.

* Some locations that could experience flooding include...
Allentown, Reading, Easton, Bethlehem, Forks, Emmaus, Wyomissing,
Northampton, Wilson, Hellertown, Nazareth, Bangor, Birdsboro,
Kutztown, Hamburg, Slatington, Fleetwood, Sinking Spring,
Laureldale and Pen Argyl.

Additional rainfall of up to one inch is expected over the area.
This additional rain will result in minor flooding.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Find an alternate route.
Alert:
Ohio River at Cairo

.Minor flooding continues along the Ohio River at Cairo. The river
continues to fall slowly. Due to heavy rain forecast over the next
few days, the river is now expected to fall below flood stage on
Saturday, April 20. Check back often for possible adjustments to
the forecast.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Ohio River at Cairo
* until Saturday April 20.
* At  8:00 PM Friday the stage was 43.6 feet.
* Flood Stage is 40.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Saturday morning April 20.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Cache River Near Patterson affecting Jackson and Woodruff Counties

forecasts.

* from Monday afternoon until further notice...Or until the warning
is cancelled.

Alert:
Large surf will continue along exposed east facing shores
through the weekend due to strong trade winds locally and over a
large area east of the islands.
* SURF...8 to 12 feet along east facing shores of Kauai, Oahu,
Molokai, Maui and the Big Island, lowering to 7 to 10 feet
Sunday.

* TIMING...Through 6 PM HST Sunday.

* IMPACTS...Moderate...Expect strong breaking waves, shore
break, and strong longshore and rip currents making swimming
difficult and dangerous.
Instruction:
surfers should heed all advice given by ocean safety officials
and exercise caution.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

Alert:
A storm system passing over central and southern New Mexico
tonight and Saturday combined with favorable east winds will
bring accumulating snow to the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Raton
Ridge and Johnson Mesa as well as the Northeast Highlands.
Although snow is expected to begin over the higher elevations of
the Sangre de Cristo mountains late today, the snow level will
lower and snow will become heavier and more widespread over the
region tonight. For the latest New Mexico road conditions visit
nmroads.com or call 511.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5
inches expected.

* WHERE...West Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Far Northeast
Highlands and Northeast Highlands.

* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 9 PM MDT Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
Visibility may be reduced below one mile at times in snow and
areas of fog.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by
calling 5 1 1 or 1-800-432-4269.
Alert:
A storm system passing over central and southern New Mexico
tonight and Saturday combined with favorable east winds will
bring accumulating snow to the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Raton
Ridge and Johnson Mesa as well as the Northeast Highlands.
Although snow is expected to begin over the higher elevations of
the Sangre de Cristo mountains late today, the snow level will
lower and snow will become heavier and more widespread over the
region tonight. For the latest New Mexico road conditions visit
nmroads.com or call 511.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to
12 inches expected.

* WHERE...Northern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet including
Red River, Southern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet, East
Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Raton Ridge and Johnson
Mesa.

* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 9 PM MDT Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Travel could be very difficult,
especially through mountain passes. Visibility may be reduced
below one half mile at times in heavy snow and fog. The weight
of wet snow on trees and power lines may lead to local power
outages.
Instruction:
A Winter Storm Warning for snow means severe winter weather
conditions will make travel very hazardous or impossible. If you
must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food and water in your
vehicle in case of an emergency.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by
calling 5 1 1 or 1-800-432-4269.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Yockanookany River Near Ofahoma
* Until late Tuesday night.
* At  7:45 PM Friday the stage was 18.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage tomorrow evening
and will continue to rise to near 19.5 feet Sunday evening.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Minor overbank flooding of farmland along
the river is occurring.

water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .
Alert:
Minor to moderate flooding continues along the Mississippi River.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Wabasha.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:15 PM Friday the stage was 14.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 13.9 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Wisconsin Highway 35 between Maiden Rock and
Stockholm may experience flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

* Impact...At 15.5 feet...The water is over Marina Road.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast

The Mississippi River at Winona.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:45 PM Friday the stage was 15.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 15.4 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...Prairie Island Park begins to flood. Pumping
operations are underway by the city of Winona, and dike patrols are
started.

Alert:
Minor to moderate flooding continues along the Mississippi River.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Lake City.
* until Sunday afternoon...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:15 PM Friday the stage was 16.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall...Dropping below flood
stage by Saturday evening.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs and some
residential sections near the river are evacuated. Water and Sewer
service is turned off along Central Point Road.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .
Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...Southwest winds 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to
30 kt. Seas 5 to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The heavy rain has ended. The street and road flooding has receded
for the most part; however, streams and creeks continue running
high. The flash flood warning will be allowed to expire at 930 PM.
Any additional heavy rain may prompt additional Warnings tonight or
Saturday due to saturated ground and high water levels in area
streams. Be prepared to move to higher ground if additional
warnings are issued.
Instruction:

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana..

Boeuf River Near Fort Necessity affecting Franklin Parish
The Flood Warning continues for
The Boeuf River Near Fort Necessity
* Until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 54.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 50.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 55.0 feet early
Tuesday morning.
* Impact...At 55.0 feet...Several thousand acres of farm and
agricultural land are inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected between 8 and 10 AM.

Alert:
Deep moisture wrapping around a broad upper level low to the
east of the Big Island will bring periods of snow and ice to the
higher elevations of Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa through tonight.
* WHAT...Snow and ice accumulation occurring. Plan on slippery
road conditions. Additional snow accumulations of up to 1 inch
is expected.

* WHERE...Big Island Summits above 12000 feet.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Saturday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory means that periods of snow, sleet, or
freezing rain will cause travel difficulties. Be prepared for
slippery roads and limited visibilities and use caution while
driving.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northeast 20 to 30 mph with localized gusts over 50 mph.

* TIMING...Through 6 PM HST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Winds this strong could down tree branches and cause
localized power outages. Motorists, especially those in high
profile vehicles, are urged to drive with caution.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of at least 30 mph, or
gusts of at least 50 mph, are expected. Motorists should use
extra caution.
Alert:
The Flash Flood Watch has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Savage.
* until further notice.
* At 8:15 PM Friday the stage was 707.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 702.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is forecast to have a maximum value of 707.1
feet after midnight tonight.
* Impact...At 705.0 feet...Flood waters begin to impact the park road
at Fort Snelling State Park.
* Impact...At 702.0 feet...Barge loading stops at Port Cargill, and
other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact
Black Dog Road in Burnsville.
* Impact...At 700.0 feet...Flood waters begin to cover trails at Fort
Snelling State Park as well as low parts on the Bloomington Ferry
Bridge trail just east of US 169.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

.Overview...
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Montevideo.
* until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 17.4 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 17.9 feet by
Friday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Sanitary sewers begin to be affected at this
level.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Storm sewers may need to be plugged to
prevent water from backing up into streets.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along the
river.

and Hwy 169.

of Henderson.

agricultural buildings north and south of Henderson.

* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 8.3 feet by

* Impact...At 8.5 feet...Swayback bridge in Redwood Falls overtopped.
* Impact...At 6.0 feet...Low lying areas, mainly farmland, and some
roads along the river begin to experience flooding; bottom of
Swayback bridge
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

forecasts.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Saline River At Benton.
* from Sunday afternoon to Tuesday morning...Or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 7:30 PM Friday the stage was 4.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by Sunday afternoon
and continue to rise to near 18.5 feet by Sunday evening. The river
will fall below flood stage by Monday morning.
* Impacts at 18.0 feet...Minor flooding begins at 18 feet, flooding of
low lying pastures along the west bank.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in State College PA has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for Poor Drainage Areas
for...
Central Dauphin County in south central Pennsylvania...
Lebanon County in south central Pennsylvania...

* Until 1215 AM EDT.

* At 918 PM EDT, emergency management reported heavy rain and water
covering roads in poor drainage areas in Swatara Township. The
heavy rain will cause urban and small stream flooding. Overflowing
poor drainage areas will result in minor flooding.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Lebanon, Hershey, Colonial Park, Progress, Middletown, Palmyra,
Linglestown, Annville, Hummelstown, Cornwall, Myerstown, Paxtonia,
Rutherford, Skyline View, Lawnton, Campbelltown, Penbrook, Pleasant
Hill, Sand Hill and Newmanstown.
Instruction:

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Sturgeon River near Chassell affecting Houghton County

.Water levels on the Sturgeon River near Chassell remain above flood stage.
Significant precipitation, mainly in the form of snow and sleet, fell across the
basin yesterday. While additional runoff was limited, it has kept water levels
from receeding and so the warning continues.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Sturgeon River near Chassell.
* until Saturday afternoon.
* At  8:10 AM Friday the stage was 10.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.5 feet.
* At 10.5 feet...The river begins to overflow onto Sturgeon River
Road...Rajala Road...and Aho Road.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Even 6 inches of fast moving flood water can knock
you off your feet...and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never
try to walk...swim...or drive through such swift water. If you come
upon flood waters...stop...turn around and go another way.

additional weather and river information is available at
www.weather.gov/mqt

The next statement will be issued by 11AM EDT Saturday.

Alert:
* WINDS...Southwest to 25 knots diminishing to 10 to 20 knots
Saturday.

* WAVES...4 to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that winds or waves are expected to
produce hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels should
avoid navigating in these conditions.

is cancelled.

* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.

to rise to near 9.8 feet by Thursday morning. The river will fall

Alert:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes
Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes
Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Baton Rouge.
* Until Monday, May 06.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 40.4 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 35.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Monday, May 06.
* Impact...At 40.0 feet...The grounds of the older part of Louisiana
State University's campus become soggy. This includes the area
around the Veterinary Medicine building, the Veterinary Medicine
Annex, the stadium and ball fields. The city of Baton Rouge and the
main LSU campus are protected by levees at this level.
* Impact...At 38.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 36.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 35.0 feet...River islands from Red River Landing
downstream to Baton Rouge will be inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

around and don't drown!

Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton

West Baton Rouge Parishes
Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Friday the stage was 57.4 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 57.1 feet
by Sunday, April 14.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

Alert:
* WINDS: Southwest gales 35 to 40 knots.

* WAVES: Waves 8 to 12 ft occasionally to 16 ft.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
At 530 PM PDT, Bureau of Reclamation in conjunction with Pendleton
City Officials and Umatilla County Emergency Management are going to
speed up the higher releases from McKay Dam.

The flow from McKay Dam will increase to 2500 cubic feet per second
around 8 AM Saturday morning.

The City of Pendleton has confirmed that the Quinney Street Bridge
is capable of passing 4000 cubic feet per second.  People in this
area should take action now to move property items that may be
impacted by the high water. People not directly impacted are
encourage to stay away from this area.  Stay away from the creek as
the banks may be unstable and could collapse.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Alert:
At 815 PM EDT, National Weather Service doppler radar indicated
strong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Rocky Ford to
near Aline, and moving northeast at 10 mph.

HAZARD...strong winds 45 to 55 mph, up to penny sized hail and
excessive cloud to ground lightning.

IMPACT...Expect minor damage to tree limbs and blowing around of
light, unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to plants,
trees and crops is possible. Damage to windshields is
unlikely. All outdoor activities should cease. Move
indoors immediately.

Some locations in the path of these storms include...
Metter, Sylvania, Portal, Rocky Ford, Woodcliff and Scarboro.
Instruction:
Report damage directly to the Charleston National Weather Service at
1-888-383-2024 when it is safe to do so. You can also email your
report to nws.charlestonsc@noaa.gov.

The National Weather Service in Charleston West Virginia has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
East central Nicholas County in southeastern West Virginia...
Southwestern Webster County in northeastern West Virginia...

* Until 830 PM EDT.

* At 803 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Craigsville,
or 8 miles northwest of Richwood, moving east at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...

Glade.
Instruction:
Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds. People outside
should move immediately to shelter inside a strong building. Stay
away from windows.

Please report severe weather to the National Weather Service by
calling toll free, 800 401 9535, when you can do so safely.

You may also report severe weather by posting your report to the
Charleston West Virginia National Weather Service Facebook Page, or
by using the Twitter Hashtag, NWSRLX.

watch for all counties in Wisconsin expired at 7 PM CDT.

THIS IS A TEST MESSAGE. Do not take action based on this message.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect from 6 AM EDT Saturday through
Saturday evening.

* LOCATIONS...Coastal Pender and Coastal New Hanover.

* TIMING...From 6 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.

* SURF ZONE IMPACTS...Very strong rip currents will be dangerous
to anyone who enters the surf.
Instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect from 6 AM EDT Saturday through
Saturday evening.

* LOCATIONS...Coastal Pender and Coastal New Hanover.

* TIMING...From 6 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.

* SURF ZONE IMPACTS...Very strong rip currents will be dangerous
to anyone who enters the surf.
Instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.
Alert:
Decreasing SE swell will lower the rip current risk at Coastal
Brunswick, Horry and Georgetown counties to a moderate risk for
tomorrow.

* THIS IS A TEST MESSAGE. THE SAFEST PLACE TO BE DURING A TORNADO IS
IN A BASEMENT. GET UNDER A WORKBENCH OR OTHER PIECE OF STURDY
FURNITURE. IF NO BASEMENT IS AVAILABLE...SEEK SHELTER ON THE
LOWEST FLOOR OF THE BUILDING IN AN INTERIOR HALLWAY OR SMALL ROOM.
USE BLANKETS OR PILLOWS TO COVER YOUR BODY. NEVER TRY TO OUTRUN A
TORNADO IN A VEHICLE.

At 737 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9
miles east of Fayetteville, moving northeast at 25 mph.

Pea size hail, heavy rain, and wind gusts up to 50 mph will be
possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Stedman, Falcon, Autryville, Hobbton, Vander, Spivey's Corner and
Cedar Creek.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Doppler radar has indicated weak rotation with this storm. If the
storm intensifies and rotation strengthens, a warning may need to be
issued.

Therefore the warning will be allowed to expire.  However heavy rain
is still possible with this thunderstorm.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 930 PM EDT

* At 730 PM EDT, Radar indicated heavy rain continuing over Durham.
Radar estimated 2 to locally 3 inches of rain had fallen around
Durham. Any additional heavy rain will likely produce flash
flooding.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Rougemont, Lake Michie, Gorman, Parkwood, Bahama, Bethesda,
Rollingview Marina, Research Triangle and Eno River State Park.
Instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many
roads and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When
encountering flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
* LOCATIONS...Including the cities of Grand Junction, Fruita,
Palisade, De Beque, New Castle, Mesa, Parachute, Rifle, Silt,
Montrose, Hotchkiss, Delta, Gateway, Nucla, Moab, Castle
Valley, Canyonlands National Park, Dead Horse Point State
Park, and Fry Canyon.

* TEMPERATURES...27 to 32 degrees.

* TIMING...The coldest temperatures are expected early Saturday
morning shortly after sunrise.

* IMPACTS...Sensitive vegetation and swamp coolers will be
impacted by sub-freezing temperatures.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are imminent or
highly likely. These conditions will kill crops and other
sensitive vegetation.
Alert:
* WINDS...South 15 to 20 knots.

* WAVES...1 to 3 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 18 to 33 knots
and/or waves averaging 4 feet or more are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels...should
avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Cumberland County in central North Carolina...

* Until 930 PM EDT

* At 725 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated showers and isolated
thunderstorms with very heavy rain over the city of Fayetteville.
The heavy rain extended from near the Fayetteville Airport
northeast across the city of Fayetteville and extended to
Eastover. The heaviest rain was training over the urban area and
that will cause urban and small stream flooding in the advisory
area. Up to one inch of rain has already fallen, an additional
inch will fall through 800 PM.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Fayetteville, Godwin, Hope Mills, Eastover, Stedman, Wade, Falcon,
Autryville, Linden and Vander.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

A Flood Advisory means river or stream flows are elevated, or ponding
of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.

Nighttime flooding is impossible to recognize. Be extra cautious and
turn around, don't drown.

extending from near Lyons to near Altamaha...and moving northeast at
15 mph.

HAZARD...Up to 40 mph wind...frequent cloud to ground lightning
and heavy rain.

street flooding especially in poor drainage areas.

Some locations in the path of these storms include

Ohoopee, New Branch, Ponderosa and Johnson Corner.
Instruction:
People outdoors should seek shelter immediately. If you can hear
thunder...you are close enough to be struck by lightning. Motorists
should slow down and be prepared for possible loss of control due to
hydroplaning.

Alert:
At 659 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a line of strong
thunderstorms along a line extending from Fuquay-Varina to 8 miles
west of Godwin. Movement was northeast at 30 mph.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph will be possible with these storms.

Heavy rain and minor flooding will also be possible with these
storms.

Locations impacted include...
Smithfield, Lillington, Garner, Fuquay-Varina, Clayton, Dunn,
Zebulon, Angier, Benson and Selma.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
40 mph are capable of knocking down tree limbs and blowing around
trash cans, and other light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

Instruction:

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

these conditions.

Alert:

Instruction:

Alert:
At 654 PM EDT, a confirmed tornado was located near Fuquay-Varina, or
13 miles north of Lillington, moving north at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Fuquay-Varina, Holly Springs, Duncan, New Hill, Harris Lake Boat
Launch and Shearon Harris Reservoir.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a
basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

This cluster of thunderstorms is capable of producing tornadoes and
widespread significant wind damage. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest
floor of a building.

Locations impacted include...

Instruction:

Alert:
Web cameras and observation platforms indicate that areas of
dense sea fog are developing rapidly across the near shore Gulf
waters and starting to spread over portions of the Laguna Madre.
The combination of high dew point air over relatively cool shelf
waters is producing the dense sea fog. Conditions are expected to
remain conducive for the fog to persist through at least mid
morning Saturday before a cold front moves through the Gulf waters
Saturday afternoon.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Dense
Fog Advisory, which is in effect until 10 AM CDT Saturday.

* VISIBILITY...one mile or less.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
At 319 PM PDT, Bureau of Reclamation in conjunction with Pendleton
City Officials and Umatilla County Emergency Management are going to
speed up the higher releases from McKay Dam.

The flow from McKay Dam will increase to 2000 cubic feet per second
at 4 pm.

The City of Pendleton has confirmed that the Quinney Street Bridge
is capable of passing 4000 cubic feet per second.  People in this
area should take action now to move property items that may be
impacted by the high water. People not directly impacted are
encourage to stay away from this area.  Stay away from the creek as
the banks may be unstable and could collapse.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following streams in Kansas..
Big Blue River near Blue Rapids affecting Marshall County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At  4:15 PM Friday the stage was 40.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 40.9 feet by
early Sunday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
The river is forecast to remain above flood stage for the next
several weeks due to backwater from Tuttle Creek Lake.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

Stay tuned to later developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio
and local media.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 800 PM EDT

* At 556 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated showers and thunderstorms
with very heavy rain extending from Fearrington and Chapel Hill to
Durham, moving east at 10 mph. Training of the more intense cores
of the thunderstorms to the north along the line will cause urban
and small stream flooding in the advisory area. Up to two inches
of rain have already fallen. An additional 1 to 2 inches of rain
through 700 PM may produce flash flooding.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Hillsborough, Carrboro, Rougemont, Carr,
Efland, Lake Michie, Eno River State Park and Gorman.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

Do not drive your vehicle into areas where the water covers the
roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross
safely. Move to higher ground.

Alert:
Umatilla River at Pendleton affecting Umatilla County
The National Weather Service in Pendleton has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Umatilla River at Pendleton.
* until late tonight...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 2:00 PM Friday, the stage was 12.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late this afternoon and
continue to rise to near 12.4 feet by this evening.  The
river will fall below flood stage overnight.  Even as the river
falls at Pendleton, flooding will continue along Umatilla through
Echo and Hermiston to the confluence of the Columbia River
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.

Alert:
At 546 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a line of strong
thunderstorms extending from 11 miles south of Sanford to 7 miles
northeast of Raeford to Antioch. Movement was northeast at 25 mph.
Periods of weak rotation have been witnessed in a few of these
storms.

Nickel size hail, heavy rain, and wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph will be
possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Fayetteville, Raeford, Lillington, Fort Bragg, Dunn, Angier, Benson,
Godwin, Pope AFB and Antioch.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a Small Craft
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 PM Saturday to 2 PM AST
Sunday.

* WINDS...East winds between 15 to 20 knots with higher gusts.

* SEAS...5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9 feet.
Instruction:

and/or seas of 7 feet or more are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

* WINDS...Saturday, SW 15-20 kt with gusts to 25 kt.

* SEAS...Around 10 ft through tonight building to around 12 ft

Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

* At 519 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms with very
heavy rain extending from Sanford to Pittsboro, moving east at 10

near Sanford to Jordan Lake and Pittsboro.

Springs, Crosswinds Campground, Gum Springs, Jordan Lake State Rec
Area, Bynum and Seaforth Boat Dock.

well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

Locations impacted include...

Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Straight line winds can blow down trees, power lines, and damage
mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.

passes and on the higher elevation roadways of Mt. Baker and Mt.
Rainier.

Alert:
A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the region
from tonight through early Sunday morning. As temperatures drop
into the mid 30s overnight, snow is expected to mix with rain for
locations along and north of route 6. Snow accumulations of 1 to
2 inches are possible primarily on grassy areas and elevated,
cooler surfaces. Given that overnight low temperatures will remain
above freezing, no accumulation is expected on roadways. Motorist
should slow down if traveling overnight as roads will be wet.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
East central Nacogdoches County in eastern Texas...
Southwestern Shelby County in eastern Texas...
Northwestern San Augustine County in eastern Texas...

* Until 300 PM CDT.

* At 237 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Melrose, or 15 miles east of Nacogdoches, moving
northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
east central Nacogdoches, southwestern Shelby and northwestern San
Augustine Counties, including the following locations... Chireno.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

* WINDS...Southerly wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph.

* IMPACTS...Compromised trees or limbs may fall, possibly blocking
roadways and downing power lines. Strong winds could compromise
tarps, particularly those used to supplement damaged roofs.

this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of northern New York and Vermont, including the
following areas, in northern New York, Eastern Clinton,
Eastern Essex, Northern Franklin, Northern St. Lawrence,
Southeastern St. Lawrence, Southern Franklin, Southwestern St.
Lawrence, Western Clinton, and Western Essex. In Vermont,
Caledonia, Eastern Addison, Eastern Chittenden, Eastern
Franklin, Eastern Rutland, Essex, Lamoille, Orange, Orleans,
Washington, Western Addison, Western Chittenden, Western
Franklin, Western Rutland, and Windsor.

* From Sunday evening through Tuesday morning

* A moisture-laden frontal system will bring widespread rainfall
Sunday afternoon through Monday morning, with rainfall amounts
from 0.75 to 1.25 inches expected. This will combine with
increasing snow melt due to warm temperatures through Sunday
morning to produce significant runoff into area rivers and
streams. Main stem rivers most at risk for minor category
flooding include the Ausable, Missisquoi, Passumpsic, Otter
Creek, Winooski, Lamoille, and possibly the Mad river. Sharp
river rises are likely beginning Sunday night. Most main stem
rivers are expected to crest during the day Monday based on
current indications.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the weekend and
into Monday.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:

through Monday will have the rivers rising over the next few days.
Low pressure will move through central new Hampshire and into
Maine Monday. It is expected that 0.75 to 1 inch of rain will
fall through Tuesday morning. This may lead to minor river
flooding.

A strong cold front will approach the waters Sunday and push
through early Monday. Strong south to southwest winds 20 to 30
knots will develop. Gale force winds are likely to develop south
of Oregon Inlet Sunday night and continue through mid day Monday.

subside late Monday and Monday night.
The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 11 PM Sunday to
8 PM EDT Monday.

* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* WAVES...2 to 3 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

At 232 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 10 miles southeast of Jonesboro, moving northeast at 45
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Brownsville-Bawcomville, Chatham, Fondale, Vixen, Bosco, Luna and
Lapine.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Alert:
In the wake of a strong cold front that moved across the area
earlier, strong northwest to north winds behind the front will
lower humidities into the lower 20s while gusting up to 40 MPH at
times. These breezy and dry conditions will result in favorable
conditions for the spread of fires through this evening.
* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 19 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches
expected. The snow will start by 7 am over western sections then
spread north and east to the rest of the advisory area by late
morning. This snow will be wet and may fall at a rate of up to 1
inch per hour at times.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...From 7 AM Sunday to 4 AM EDT Monday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

Alert:

Instruction:

Alert:
A strong storm system will move across the Tennessee Valley and
southern Appalachians Sunday, producing two rounds of showers and
thunderstorms - one in the morning and one in the late afternoon
and evening. There is an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms
area wide, with the highest severe threat coming with the late
day storms. The main concern will be damaging winds, but isolated
tornadoes and hail up to quarter size will also be possible.

Windy conditions will develop tonight and Sunday morning.
Southerly winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 45 mph is possible
across most of the area, with gusts up to 60 mph possible in the
mountains.

Please keep abreast of the latest forecast updates from the
National Weather Service.
Instruction:

Alert:
A strong storm system will move across the Tennessee Valley and
southern Appalachians Sunday, producing two rounds of showers and
thunderstorms - one in the morning and one in the late afternoon
and evening. There is an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms
area wide, with the highest severe threat coming with the late
day storms. The main concern will be damaging winds, but isolated
tornadoes and hail up to quarter size will also be possible.

Windy conditions will develop tonight and Sunday morning.
Southerly winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 45 mph is possible
across most of the area, with gusts up to 60 mph possible in the
mountains.

Please keep abreast of the latest forecast updates from the
National Weather Service.
Instruction:

Alert:
Gusty southerly to southwesterly winds around a strong surface
low associated with large upper storm system will likely affect
higher elevations tonight and most of the day on Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued
a High Wind Warning above 3500 feet, which is in effect from
midnight tonight to 10 PM EDT Sunday.

* LOCATIONS...Higher elevations of the Southern Appalachians of
Western North Carolina and Northeast Georgia.

* HAZARDS...Very windy conditions.

* TIMING...From Midnight tonight to Sunday evening.

* WINDS...South 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph.

* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power
lines. Widespread power outages are possible. Travel could be
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.

Please report damaging winds by calling the National Weather
Service toll free at...1...800...2 6 7...8 1 0 1. Leave a message
with your observation and the specific location where it
occurred. You can also post your report to National Weather
Service Greenville Spartanburg Facebook or tweet your report
using hashtag nwsgsp.

* Until 300 PM CDT.

* At 215 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 11 miles south of Jonesboro, moving northeast at 45
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
northwestern Caldwell, southeastern Jackson, southwestern Ouachita
and northern Winn Parishes, including the following locations...
Fondale, Sikes, Vixen, Bosco, Hudson, Luna, Chatham, Dodson, Lapine
and Calvin.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

by early Sunday morning for portions of southeastern New Mexico
and northwest Permian Basin. These conditions may affect

* From late Sunday night through Tuesday morning

* The Upper Hudson River, Sacandaga River, Black River, Mohawk
River, Hoosic River, Deerfield River, West River and their
tributaries are at risk for flooding.

* The combination of runoff from snowmelt over the weekend and
rainfall Sunday afternoon into early Monday morning will
result in significant rises on rivers and their tributaries
with flooding possible.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.

Lidgerwood.

This includes Interstate 29 between mile markers 0 and 48.

deaths occur in vehicles.

Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 4 PM Sunday to 5 PM EDT
Monday.

* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 kt. Gusts to 35 kt possible Sunday
night.

* SEAS...5 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and or seas of 6 ft or greater are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

If on or near Lake Conroe, get away from the water and move indoors
or inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 15 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now!  Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

Monday.

feet. Sunday night, Southwest winds 20 to 25 knots becoming west
in the morning. Seas 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
* TIMING...This afternoon and evening.

* WINDS...West to northwest near 25 MPH with gusts to around 40
MPH.

* IMPACTS...Loose and unsecured outdoor articles may be blown
about in the wind. Driving will become difficult for vehicles
on east-west oriented roadways.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult...especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
One storm which prompted the warning has weakened below severe
limits, and the other storm has exited the warned area, and is now
covered by Severe Thunderstorm Warning 45. Therefore, this warning
will be allowed to expire. However heavy rain is still possible.

A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.

To report severe weather, contact your nearest law enforcement
agency. They will relay your report to the National Weather Service
League City.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has extended the

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Alamance County in central North Carolina...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 615 PM EDT

* At 259 PM EDT, local law enforcement officials reported flash
flooding occurring. A portion of Johnson Road in Durham County
remains closed due to flooding. Additionally, the Eno River in
Hillsboro has risen above flood stage, with subsequent rises
occurring along the Eno River eastward into Durham County.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Burlington, Graham, Hillsborough, Carrboro,
Mebane, Elon College, Rougemont and Gibsonville.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many roads
and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When encountering
flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
At 302 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Morganton,
moving east at 25 mph.

HAZARD...70 mph wind gusts and ping pong ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
considerable tree damage. Wind damage is also likely to
mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings.

Locations impacted include...
Morganton, Valdese, Gamewell, Cajah's Mountain, Drexel, Connelly
Springs, Rutherford College, Glen Alpine, Lake Rhodhiss and Oak Hill.
Instruction:
Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

Large hail can cause major property damage, especially to vehicles.
Strong winds may blow down a few trees and power lines. Seek shelter
inside an interior room.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.
Alert:

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...

Northeastern Richmond County in central North Carolina...

* Until 345 PM EDT

* At 301 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles northwest
of Hoffman, or 11 miles northeast of Rockingham, moving northeast
at 25 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Southern Pines, Carthage, Pinehurst, Aberdeen, Whispering Pines,
Pinebluff, Ellerbe, Foxfire, Taylortown and Norman.
Instruction:
Straight line winds can blow down trees, power lines, and damage
mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.

Alert:
Scattered to numerous snow showers have developed across south
central and southeast Wyoming this afternoon. This activity will
persist for the next several hours. The heaviest showers will be
accompanied by visibilities as low as one half mile and possibly
slick road conditions. Those traveling across southeast Wyoming
today should be prepared for rapidly changing weather and road
conditions. If you encounter inclement weather, slow down and
allow extra time to reach your destination.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 8 AM to 8 PM EDT Sunday.

* WINDS...Northeast 15 to 25 knots with gusts up to 30 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...Waves 3 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory is issued when waves of 4 feet or more are
expected or wind speeds reach 21 to 33 knots which may produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should stay in port
during these conditions.

* At 157 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Sacul, or 15 miles east of Rusk, moving northeast
at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without

damage is likely.

* This dangerous storm will be near...
Minden around 225 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include
Laneville, Brachfield and Glenfawn.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Topeka has issued a Freeze
Warning, which is in effect from 3 AM to 9 AM CDT Sunday.

* TEMPERATURES...Are expected to fall into the upper 20s to low
30s during the early morning hours on Sunday. There is some
uncertainty in how far east these freezing temperatures will
spread, which will depend heavily on how fast clouds and winds
can lessen before sunrise.

* IMPACTS...Sub-freezing temperatures will cause damage to
plants. Outdoor plants will need to be covered or brought
indoors.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are highly
likely. These conditions will kill crops and other sensitive
vegetation.

vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
At 253 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 11
miles north of Rockingham, moving northeast at 25 mph. A Severe
Thunderstorm Warning may be needed if this storm continues to
strengthen.

Nickel size hail, heavy downpours, and wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph
will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Southern Pines, Carthage, Pinehurst, Aberdeen, Whispering Pines,
Pinebluff, Ellerbe, Foxfire, Taylortown and Norman.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.
Alert:
At 153 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located north of Lake
Conroe Dam. A new storm, 8 miles east of New Waverly, or 11 miles
northeast of Willis, has also developed, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...

Instruction:
A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Continuous cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Move indoors immediately. Lightning is one of nature's leading
killers. Remember, if you can hear thunder, you are close enough to
be struck by lightning.

If on or near area lakes, get away from the water and move indoors
or inside a vehicle. remember, lightning can strike out to 15 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now!  Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.
Alert:
Strong northeast winds will develop Sunday on the lake causing a
seiche to develop. This will result in high water levels on the
western end of Lake Erie. Higher than normal water levels may cause
lakeshore flooding Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a Lakeshore
Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday morning through
Sunday afternoon.

* LAKE SHORE FLOODING...A northeasterly flow Sunday may cause
higher than normal water levels on the western basin of Lake
Erie. This may result in flooding along the lakeshore. The
combination of rising water levels and waves may result in the
flooding of the lakeshore.

* TIMING...Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon

* IMPACTS...Flooding along the immediate lakeshore and beach and
shoreline erosion may be possible. Rising water levels in
marinas and waterways into the lake could submerge dockage and
shoreline structures.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Watch is issued when conditions are favorable
for lakeshore flooding to develop. Residents on or near the shore
should begin to take action to protect property. Listen for later
statements or warnings.
Alert:
* TIMING...Through 1 AM CDT Sunday.

* WINDS...Sustained north to northwest winds at 25 to 35 MPH with
gusts as high as 45 MPH.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. High profile vehicles will see more difficult driving
conditions on east and west oriented roadways. Any boaters
heading out on area lakes will see choppy conditions.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult...especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
A low pressure system remains on track to travel across the Ohio
Valley northeast into New England Sunday into early Monday, which
will bring unsettled weather and lake conditions to start off the
week. As the low pressure system nears the Ohio Valley, the pressure
gradient will strengthen across the open waters and will aid in
quickly ramping up winds speeds and gusts through Sunday morning.
Gusts will peak in excess of 22 knots by late Sunday morning which
will result in the initial issuance of small craft advisories across
Lake Erie, St. Clair, and far southern Lake Huron. Gale warnings to
then go in effect for nearly all of southern and central Lake Huron
and Saginaw Bay by Sunday afternoon as northeasterly gusts continue
to climb to 35 - 40 knots. Long fetch across Lake Huron will also
result in waves to or in excess of 9-10 ft across Lake Huron into
the outer Saginaw Bay. Strong gusts to continue through early Monday
morning before a ridge of high pressure acts to relax the pressure
gradient.
* WIND AND WAVES: During the Gale Warning, expect sustained
winds up to 35 knots from the northeast with gusts up to 40
knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 13 feet
with a potential maximum wave height of 19 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 8 PM EDT Sunday
with the largest waves expected around 10 PM EDT Sunday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.
Alert:
A low pressure system remains on track to travel across the Ohio
Valley northeast into New England Sunday into early Monday, which
will bring unsettled weather and lake conditions to start off the
week. As the low pressure system nears the Ohio Valley, the pressure
gradient will strengthen across the open waters and will aid in
quickly ramping up winds speeds and gusts through Sunday morning.
Gusts will peak in excess of 22 knots by late Sunday morning which
will result in the initial issuance of small craft advisories across
Lake Erie, St. Clair, and far southern Lake Huron. Gale warnings to
then go in effect for nearly all of southern and central Lake Huron
and Saginaw Bay by Sunday afternoon as northeasterly gusts continue
to climb to 35 - 40 knots. Long fetch across Lake Huron will also
result in waves to or in excess of 9-10 ft across Lake Huron into
the outer Saginaw Bay. Strong gusts to continue through early Monday
morning before a ridge of high pressure acts to relax the pressure
gradient.
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Small Craft Advisory which is in effect from 8 AM Sunday to 4 PM
EDT Monday.

* WIND AND WAVES: During the Small Craft Advisory, expect
sustained winds up to 26 knots from the northwest with gusts
up to 30 knots. The largest expected significant waves will
be 9 feet with a potential maximum wave height of 13 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 7 AM EDT Monday
with the largest waves expected around 8 AM EDT Monday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:

Alert:
White Rock Creek at Greenville Ave affecting Dallas County
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Flood Warning for
White Rock Creek at Greenville Ave.
* until late tonight...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 115 PM Saturday the stage was 82.02 feet.
* Flood stage is 84.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river should rise above flood stage by Saturday
afternoon and continue to rise to a crest near 86 feet by Saturday
afternoon. The river should fall below flood stage by late Saturday
afternoon.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.
Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Stay tuned to NOAA All Hazards Radio for the latest river forecasts.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Southwestern Rusk County in northeastern Texas...
Northwestern Nacogdoches County in eastern Texas...
East central Cherokee County in northeastern Texas...

* Until 215 PM CDT.

* At 139 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Alto, or 8 miles southeast of Rusk, moving
northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This dangerous storm will be near...
Sacul around 155 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include
Reklaw, Lilbert and Cushing.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,

specific location where it occurred.

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Even 6 inches of fast moving flood water can knock
you off your feet...and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never
try to walk...swim...or drive through such swift water. If you come
upon flood waters...stop...turn around and go another way.

additional weather and river information is available at
www.weather.gov/mqt

Alert:
Sturgeon River near Chassell affecting Houghton County

.An afternoon observation has shown that the river has fallen
below flood stage and is now in action stage prompting the advisory.
The river is expected to continue to fall through the day, however
a warm this week may cause river to rise back into flood stage.
The National Weather Service in Marquette has issued a
* Flood Advisory for
The Sturgeon River near Chassell.
* until Sunday afternoon.
* At 12 PM Saturday the stage was 10.3 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.5 feet.
* At 10.5 feet...The river begins to overflow onto Sturgeon River
Road...Rajala Road...and Aho Road.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Residents along these rivers should remain alert and
exercise caution when walking near riverbanks.

A Flood Advisory means minor flooding is possible and rivers are
forecast to exceed bankfull. If you are in the advisory area remain
alert to possible flooding...or the possibility of the advisory being
upgraded to a warning. Report observed flooding to local emergency
services or law enforcement and request they pass this information on
to the National Weather Service.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your favorite media outlet for
further developments and information from the National Weather
Service.
Alert:
At 125 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong
thunderstorms, including one near Huntsville that has produced
winds of 40 mph, moving northeast at 45 mph.

Pea size hail and winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Conroe, Huntsville, Willis, Livingston, Pinehurst, Trinity, Panorama
Village, Onalaska, Corrigan, Magnolia, Groveton, New Waverly,
Coldspring, Point Blank, Montgomery, Riverside, Seven Oaks,
Sebastopol, Lake Livingston State Park and West Livingston.
Instruction:
This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

If on or near Lake Livingston, get out of the water and move indoors
or inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 10 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now! Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

At 123 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 16 miles west of
Jonesboro, moving northeast at 30 mph.

This is a very dangerous storm.

HAZARD...80 mph wind gusts and half dollar size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be heavily damaged. Expect
considerable damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles.
Extensive tree damage and power outages are likely.

Locations impacted include...
Ruston, Grambling, Arcadia, Gibsland, Dubach, Simsboro, Goldonna,
Vienna, Saline, Lucky, Ashland, Athens, Bienville, Bryceland, Mount
Lebanon, Brice, Mount Zion, Aycock, Friendship and Liberty Hill.
Instruction:
A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for north central
and northwestern Louisiana.

This is an EXTREMELY DANGEROUS SITUATION with tornado like wind
speeds expected. Mobile homes and high profile vehicles are
especially susceptible to winds of this magnitude and may be
overturned. For your protection move to an interior room on the
lowest floor of a building. This storm has the potential to cause
serious injury and significant property damage.
