Alert:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Southwestern Cabarrus County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...
Southern Mecklenburg County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...
Northwestern Union County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...
Southeastern York County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 600 PM EDT Saturday.

* At 1155 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. This will cause minor flooding in the advisory area.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Rock Hill, South Charlotte, Southwest Charlotte, East Charlotte,
Matthews, Mint Hill, Indian Trail, Weddington, Fort Mill and
Stallings.
Instruction:
Heavy rainfall will cause ponding of water in urban areas, streets
and underpasses, as well as other poor drainage areas and low lying
spots. Rapid rises on small creeks and streams will also occur,
possibly flooding low water crossings and farmland. Do not attempt to
travel across flooded roads. Turn around, dont drown.

If heavy rainfall continues, the advisory may be upgraded to a Flash
Flood Warning. People in flood prone areas, especially along creeks
and small streams, should prepare to move to higher ground quickly if
a Flash Flood Warning is issued.
Alert:
Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D affecting Bradley...Calhoun and
Union Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:30 AM Saturday the stage was 85.8 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 79.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 87.0 feet by
Saturday early afternoon.
* Impacts at 88.0 feet...River is high enough to stop drainage from
Calion Lake. Heavy rainfall in the area could cause the lake to
rise towards several homes along the shore. Downstream, water
rising into undeveloped areas of the State Park at Moro Bay.
Widespread flooding of timber, with access to many oil and gas rigs
flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.
Alert:
* Wahpeton...on the Red River ...in Wilkin and Richland Counties
* Hickson...on the Red River ...in Cass County
* Fargo...on the Red River ...in Clay and Cass Counties
* Halstad...on the Red River ...in Norman and Traill Counties
* East Grand Forks...on the Red River ...in Polk and Grand Forks
Counties
* Oslo...on the Red River ...in Marshall...Polk...Grand Forks and
Walsh Counties
* Drayton...on the Red River ...in Kittson...Marshall...Pembina and
Walsh Counties
* Pembina...on the Red River ...in Kittson and Pembina Counties
* Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND) ...in Richland County

.Recent snowfall across the region is expected to begin melting in
the coming days as temperatures climb, and remain, above freezing.
This will drive either an increase in water levels or will slow down
water level decline at most points along the mainstem Red River.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND).
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:15 AM Saturday the stage was 17.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...
Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Moderate Flood Stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 17.7 feet by
Wednesday evening.  Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 18.0 feet, MAJOR FLOOD. Bridge near the
gage is inaccessible due to agricultural flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:

Instruction:

Alert:
Cache River Near Patterson affecting Jackson and Woodruff Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Cache River Near Patterson.
* from Monday afternoon until further notice...or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Saturday the stage was 6.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday early afternoon and
continue to rise to near 9.5 feet by Wednesday early afternoon.
* Impacts at 10.0 feet...Pastureland and cropland not protected by
levees in Jackson and Woodruff counties affected. Water is over
portions of State Highway 37 and deep along the shoulders of State
Highway 18 near Grubbs. Water over portions of Woodruff County Road
775 north of State Highway 260.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southeastern Cass County in northeastern Texas...
Northeastern Marion County in northeastern Texas...

* Until 1130 AM CDT.

* At 1053 AM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Lodi, or 17
miles south of Atlanta, moving north at 65 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Linden, Bivins, Smithland, McLeod, Lodi, Kildare and Pruett.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.
Alert:
* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 20 knots with gusts 25 to 30 knots
veering to West late in the afternoon.

* SEAS...Generally 11 to 13 feet through Sunday. Dominant period
17 seconds today, then 14 to 15 seconds tonight and Sunday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 21 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
At 1053 AM CDT, Meteorologists were tracking a strong thunderstorm
near Goodwill, or 15 miles east of Bastrop, moving northeast at 45
mph.

Nickel size hail will be possible with this storm.

This strong thunderstorm will be near...
Jones around 1105 AM CDT.
Wilmot around 1115 AM CDT.
Parkdale around 1120 AM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this storm include Bonita.
Instruction:
This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
Noxubee River At Macon affecting Noxubee County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Noxubee River At Macon
* until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Saturday the stage was 29.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 31.0 feet Tuesday
evening.
* Impact...At 31.0 feet...Agriculture flooding is occurring near the
river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.
Alert:
At 1051 AM CDT, a confirmed tornado was located near Hearne, moving
northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Hearne, Franklin and Calvert.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! If you are
outdoors, in a mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest
substantial shelter now!  Get to an interior room on the lowest floor
of a sturdy building and avoid windows.
Alert:
At 553 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8
miles west of Samantha, or 13 miles northeast of Gordo, moving north
at 35 mph.

Pea size hail and winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Winfield, Fayette, Berry, Glen Allen, Bankston, Bevill State College
Fayette, Stone Wall, Hubbertville, Bazemore, Fowlers Crossroads,
Richard Arthur Field and Fayette County Public Lake.
Instruction:
Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.

Alert:
At 545 PM CDT, a confirmed tornado was located over Little Yazoo, or
10 miles south of Yazoo City, moving northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado and golf ball size hail.

SOURCE...Weather spotters confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornado will be near...
Myrleville around 555 PM CDT.
Yazoo City and Benton around 610 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include
Satartia, Bentonia and Eden.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a
basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

flooding is already occurring.

Helena, Lake Bruin, Youngton, Oak Ridge, Somerset and Bovina.

deaths occur in vehicles.

Alert:
At 530 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms
along a line extending from near Claiborne to 15 miles northwest of
Columbia to 11 miles west of Olla to 6 miles north of Timber Trails.
Movement was east northeast at 50 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Monroe, Alexandria, Claiborne, West Monroe, Columbia, Swartz,
Brownsville-Bawcom, Brownsville-Bawcomville, Jena, Richwood, Olla,
Clarks, Grayson, Midway, Urania, Chatham, Pollock, Dry Prong, Tullos
and Georgetown.
Instruction:
Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

These storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:

* Flood advisory for...
The island of Hawaii in Hawaii County

* Until 345 PM HST.

* At 1223 PM HST, radar indicated heavy rain near Pahoa and a band
of heavy rain approaching Hilo from the northeast. Rain was
falling at a rate of up to an inch per hour.

* Locations in the advisory include but are not limited to...
Hilo, Hawaiian Acres, Paauilo, Waipio Valley, Glenwood, Pepeekeo,
Keaau, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park and Honokaa.
Instruction:
Stay away from streams, drainage ditches and low lying areas prone to
flooding.

Rainfall and runoff will also cause hazardous driving conditions due
to ponding, reduced visibility and poor braking action.

Do not cross fast flowing or rising water in your vehicle, or on
foot. Turn around, don't drown.

Alert:
Sister Grove Creek near Blue Ridge affecting Collin County
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Flood Warning for
Sister Grove Creek near Blue Ridge.
* until Sunday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 500 PM Saturday the stage was 23.48 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river should rise above flood stage by Saturday
evening and continue to rise to a crest near 24 feet by Saturday
evening. The river should fall below flood stage by Sunday after
midnight.
* At 24 feet, minor out of bank flooding along the creek is expected.
Rural roads, along with farm and ranch land near the creek, will
begin to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.
Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Stay tuned to NOAA All Hazards Radio for the latest river forecasts.

Alert:
Minor to moderate flooding continues along portions of the
Mississippi River.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Winona.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  4:45 PM Saturday the stage was 15.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 15.4 feet
by Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...Prairie Island Park begins to flood. Pumping
operations are underway by the city of Winona, and dike patrols are
started.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Alamance County in central North Carolina...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 1215 AM EDT Sunday

* At 610 PM EDT, emergency management officials and local river
guages confirm flooding continuing across portions of Alamance,
Orange, and Durham Counties. Several roads remain closed, and
multiple creeks, streams, and rivers remain out of their banks.
This includes the Eno River at Huckelberry Springs and Hillsboro
along with portions of the Little River. Even though rainfall has
ended, water runoff continues to remain slow. Use caution,
especially if traveling in these areas.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Burlington, Graham, Hillsborough, Carrboro,
Mebane, Elon College, Rougemont and Gibsonville.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...Southwest winds 10 to 15 kt with gusts up to
20 kt. Seas 3 to 5 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots,
or seas 5 feet or greater, are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

THE FOLLOWING AREAS

IN LOUISIANA THIS WATCH INCLUDES 7 PARISHES

IN CENTRAL LOUISIANA

AVOYELLES             EVANGELINE            RAPIDES

THIS INCLUDES THE CITIES OF ALEXANDRIA, BEAVER, BUNDICK LAKE,
BUNKIE, COTTONPORT, DE RIDDER, EFFIE, EUNICE, FIELDS, FORT POLK,
KINDER, LAWTELL, LEESVILLE, MAMOU, MANSURA, MARKSVILLE, OAKDALE,

SLAGLE, ST. LANDRY, AND VILLE PLATTE.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
East central Madison Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
Central Warren County in west central Mississippi...
Northwestern Hinds County in central Mississippi...
Southeastern Issaquena County in west central Mississippi...

* Until 530 PM CDT.

* At 505 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located over Vicksburg, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and ping pong ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This dangerous storm will be near...
Bovina around 515 PM CDT.
Redwood and Flowers around 520 PM CDT.
Youngton and Oak Ridge around 525 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include Delta.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected above 4000 feet. Additional accumulations
of 5-8 inches can be expected. This is on top of the 2-4 inches
that have already fallen since early this morning.

* WHERE...Cascade mountains of Whatcom and Skagit Counties,
including the Mount Baker Ski Area, Cascade mountains
Snohomish and King Counties including Stevens Pass, and
Cascade mountains of Pierce and Lewis Counties, including the
Crystal Mountain Ski Area, and Paradise on Mount Rainier.

* WHEN...Through Midnight PDT tonight.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions on
higher passes and on the higher elevation roadways of Mt.
Baker and Mt. Rainier.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

For the latest road conditions in Washington state, call 5 1 1.

Alert:
Recent precipitation and expected snowmelt in the next couple of days
is expected to lead to minor flooding along Trempealeau River at Dodge.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trempealeau River at Dodge.
* from late Monday night to Saturday April 20...Or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At  3:45 PM Saturday the stage was 7.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 9.8 feet by Thursday morning. The river will fall
below flood stage by Friday.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...The entrance road to the Trempealeau National
Wildlife Refuge is flooded.

Alert:
A strong spring storm system will likely bring an accumulation of
very wet and slushy snow to portions of northern Illinois and
extreme northwest Indiana on Sunday. The heaviest snowfall rates
are expected to occur from a bit prior to sunrise through mid day
or the early afternoon, with lower intensities during the
afternoon. The snow will end by early evening. There will likely
be a fairly narrow band where these heavy snowfall rates of up to
one inch per hour are most persistent. Exactly where this sets
up, two to four inches of accumulation are likely on colder or
elevated surfaces, with locally higher amounts possible.


With warm road temperatures and the strong April sun, roads will
likely be mainly wet most of the time. However, it's possible that
some slush may cover bridges or overpasses and less traveled
roadways during the heaviest snowfall. While overall lack of
accumulation on roads may limit the magnitude of travel impacts,
visibility will likely be sharply reduced at times. In addition,
northerly winds gusting up to 25 to 35 mph could plaster the very
wet and heavy snow onto elevated surfaces, including tree
branches, so minor tree damage is possible. Motorists are advised
to prepare for potentially adverse travel conditions on Sunday.
Continue to stay tuned for the latest forecast updates.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 5 PM Sunday to 8 AM EDT
Monday.

* Wind: South to southwest 15 to 20 knots with gusts to 25 knots.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots over
the Currituck Sound are expected to produce hazardous boating
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels...should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine
forecast...and consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

waves of 4 feet or greater over the Chesapeake Bay are expected to
produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels...should
avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Tensas Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
Madison Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
Northeastern Catahoula Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
East central Richland Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
Eastern Franklin Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
Warren County in west central Mississippi...
Central Claiborne County in southwestern Mississippi...

* Until 745 PM CDT.

* At 447 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing
heavy rain across the warned area. Up to three inches of rain have
already fallen. Flash flooding is expected to begin shortly.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Vicksburg, Tallulah, Redwood, Delhi, Newellton, St. Joseph, Wisner,
Waterproof, Mansford, Lee Bayou, Le Tourneau, Flowers, Omega,
Bakers, Helena, Lake Bruin, Youngton, Oak Ridge, Somerset and
Bovina.

Additional rainfall amounts of up to two inches are possible in the
warned area.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Alert:
At 445 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 8 miles northwest of Le Tourneau, or 9 miles west of
Vicksburg, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation. This tornado has a history of
producing tornadoes.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
east central Madison Parish in northeastern Louisiana and west
central Warren Counties, including the following locations... Mound
and Delta.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!
Alert:
At 545 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9
miles south of Shelby, or near Blacksburg, moving north at 10 mph.

Locations to be impacted include...
Shelby, Blacksburg, Grover, Patterson Springs and Earl.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph, pea size hail and very heavy rainfall rates
up to 2 inches per hour will be possible in these areas.
Instruction:
Gusty winds can blow down trees that are dead, or that have weakened
root systems. Outdoor furniture and similar items can be tossed
around if not anchored. Seek shelter indoors.

Torrential rainfall may flood areas with poor drainage, such as
ditches and underpasses. Avoid these areas and do not cross flooded
roads. Water levels of small streams may also rise rapidly. Seek
higher ground if threatened by flood waters.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Reno has issued a Lake Wind
Advisory for Pyramid Lake, which is in effect from 11 AM to 8 PM
PDT Sunday.

* Winds: Southwest 15 to 25 mph, gusts to 40 mph.

* Wave Heights: 2 to 4 feet.

* Small boats, kayaks and paddle boards will be prone to
capsizing and should remain off lake waters until conditions
improve.
Instruction:
Check lake conditions before heading out and be prepared for a
sudden increase in winds and wave heights. Consider postponing
boating activities on the lake until a day with less wind.

Washington Counties.
Tombigbee River Near Leroy affecting Choctaw...Clarke and Washington
Counties.

.Recent heavy rains have caused significant rises along the river.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Tombigbee River Near Coffeeville Dam
* until further notice.
* At 4 PM Saturday the stage was 29.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 29 feet.
* The river will continue rising to near 31.9 feet by Wednesday evening.
Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At 29 feet...Pastureland becomes flooded. Livestock should be moved to
higher ground. Old Ferry Road near the river begins to flood.

Alert:

Washington Counties.

Counties.

.Recent heavy rains have caused significant rises along the river.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Tombigbee River Near Leroy
* From after midnight tomorrow until further notice.
* At 4 PM Saturday the stage was 23.6 feet.
* No flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 24 feet.
* Forecast to rise above flood stage by after midnight tomorrow and continue to
rise near 25.6 feet by early Thursday morning. Additional rises are possible
thereafter.
* At 24 feet...Flooding of low lying farm and pasturelands begins. Cattle in
low lying areas should be moved to higher ground.

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following streams in Kansas..
Big Blue River near Blue Rapids affecting Marshall County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At  4:15 PM Saturday the stage was 40.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 41.0 feet by
Wednesday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
The river is forecast to remain above flood stage for the next
several weeks due to backwater from Tuttle Creek Lake.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

Stay tuned to later developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio
and local media.
Alert:
At 436 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along
a line extending from Hutton to Hackberry. Movement was northeast at
50 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Lake Charles, Alexandria, Sulphur, Westlake, Iowa, Kinder, Oberlin,
Boyce, Elizabeth, Fenton, Reeves, Moss Bluff, Sugartown, Hineston,
Lena, Mittie, Dry Creek, Alexandria International Airport, Ragley and
Lake Charles Regional Airport.
Instruction:
Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

These storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

Alert:
A Marine Weather Statement has been issued for the following areas...
Coastal waters from High Island to Freeport TX out 20 NM...
Galveston Bay...

At 429 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms, capable
of producing winds to around 30 knots. These thunderstorms were
located along a line extending from 21 nm north of Rollover Pass to
Trinity Bay to Galveston Bay to near Bastrop Bay, moving southeast
at 20 knots. The strongest winds may occur as outflow that can push
out well ahead of the thunderstorm.

Locations impacted include...
East Galveston Bay, Galveston Ship Channel, West Bay, Galveston Bay
Entrance, Galveston Bay, Offatts Bayou, North Jetty, Galveston Pier
21, Trinity Bay, Smith Point, San Luis Pass, Galveston Causeway,
Bastrop Bay, The Texas City Dike, Eagle Point and Christmas Bay.
Instruction:
Mariners can expect gusty winds to around 30 knots, locally higher
waves, and lightning strikes. Boaters should seek safe harbor
immediately until these storms pass.
Alert:
At 428 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from 15 miles southeast of Ringgold to near Campti to
Natchitoches to 8 miles north of Kurthwood, moving east at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Natchitoches, Campti, Provencal, Natchez, Martin, Clarence, Goldonna,
Saline, Lucky, Ashland, Powhatan, Kisatchie, Melrose, Grand Ecore,
Bellwood, Flora, Black Lake, Chestnut, Clear Lake and Creston.
Instruction:
A tornado watch remains in effect for the warned area. Tornadoes can
develop quickly from severe thunderstorms. Although a tornado is not
immediately likely, if one is spotted act quickly and move to a
place of safety inside a sturdy structure, such as a basement or
small interior room.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Never drive cars through flooded areas!! The water
may be too deep to allow safe passage. Most deaths that occur during
flooding are related to vehicles trying to cross flooded roadways.

and/or waves averaging 4 feet or more are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced

avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
* WINDS...Southwest to West 15 to 20 knots with gusts 25 to 30
knots. Wind decreasing during the evening.

* SEAS...Generally 11 to 13 feet through Sunday. Dominant period
17 seconds today, then 14 to 15 seconds tonight and Sunday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 21 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
At 425 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along
a line extending from League City to 8 miles southeast of Liverpool.
Movement was east at 35 mph.

Winds in excess of 30 mph will be possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
League City, Galveston Causeway, Galveston Island West End, Texas
City, Friendswood, Alvin, Dickinson, La Marque, Santa Fe, Webster,
Hitchcock, Kemah, Galveston Pier 21, Nassau Bay, Bayou Vista, Clear
Lake Shores, Jamaica Beach, Tiki Island, Hillcrest and Liverpool.
Instruction:
If on or near the water, get out of the water and move indoors or
inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 10 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now! Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.
Alert:
Another round of mountain snow is expected to fall on the Teton
and Gros Ventre Range after midnight tonight and will continue
through 12 noon sunday.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 5 to 8 inches
expected. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.

* WHERE...Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains.

* WHEN...From 6 PM Sunday to noon MDT Monday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Some
blowing and drifting snow could affect Teton Pass.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
At 424 PM CDT, a confirmed large and extremely dangerous tornado was
located over Somerset, or 16 miles south of Tallulah, moving
northeast at 40 mph.

This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. TAKE COVER NOW!

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Weather spotters confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...You are in a life-threatening situation. Flying debris may
be deadly to those caught without shelter. Mobile homes
will be destroyed. Considerable damage to homes,
businesses, and vehicles is likely and complete destruction
is possible.

The tornado will be near...
Afton around 435 PM CDT.
Tallulah around 445 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include Mound,
Delta and Richmond.
Instruction:
To repeat, a large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly
tornado is on the ground. To protect your life, TAKE COVER NOW! Move
to a basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

Delta and Richmond.

Alert:
At 513 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Benson, or 9 miles southwest of Smithfield, moving slowly east at 15
mph.

Half inch hail, heavy rain, and wind gusts up to 50 mph will be
possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Smithfield, Selma, Four Oaks, Pine Level and Princeton.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.
Alert:
..DUSTY CONDITIONS WILL PERSIST ACROSS PORTIONS OF THE SOUTHEAST
COASTAL BEND THROUGH THIS EVENING...

.Strong northwest winds in the wake of a cold front will persist
through this evening across most of South Texas. Areas of dust
lofted by these strong winds will primarily affect southeast
portions of the Coastal Bend.
The National Weather Service in Corpus Christi has issued a
Blowing Dust Advisory, which is in effect until 10 PM CDT this
evening. A Wind Advisory has also been issued. This Wind Advisory
is in effect until 10 PM CDT this evening.

* TIMING...This afternoon and early evening.

* WINDS...Northwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* VISIBILITY...As low as 1/2 to 1 mile at times.

* Impacts...Will make driving high profile vehicles difficult.
Outdoor furniture can be blown around.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 30 mph or greater...
or wind gusts around 40 mph or greater are expected. Winds this
strong can make driving difficult...especially for high profile
vehicles. Use extra caution.

A Blowing Dust Advisory means that blowing dust will restrict
visibilities. Travelers are urged to use caution.

Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 1 PM to 7 PM CDT
Sunday. A Gale Watch has also been issued. This Gale Watch is in

* BAY WATERS...rough.

* WAVES/SEAS...Nearshore 5 to 7 feet...offshore 7 to 9 feet with
occasional 11 foot significant wave heights.

occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

and/or seas 7 feet or higher...are expected to produce hazardous
conditions for small craft. Inexperienced boaters...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Sunday. A Gale Watch has also been issued. This Gale Watch is in
effect from late tonight through Sunday afternoon.

* WINDS...southeast 20 to 25 knots.

* BAY WATERS...rough.

* WAVES/SEAS...Nearshore 5 to 7 feet...offshore 7 to 9 feet with
occasional 11 foot significant wave heights.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots...
and/or seas 7 feet or higher...are expected to produce hazardous
conditions for small craft. Inexperienced boaters...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northwest 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* SEAS...7 to 10 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
At 408 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from 6 miles north of Montrose to near Oak Grove, moving
northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

These severe storms will be near...
Mcmillan Corner around 415 PM CDT.
Dermott around 420 PM CDT.
Eudora around 425 PM CDT.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with these storms, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.
Alert:
The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
At 408 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7
miles southeast of Plum Grove, or 8 miles northwest of Dayton, moving
northeast at 45 mph.

Pea size hail and winds in excess of 30 mph will be possible with
this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Dayton, Plum Grove, Kenefick, Dayton Lakes, Lake Houston, Moss Hill,
Romayor and Rye.

A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.
Instruction:

Alert:
At 408 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
New Llano, or near Leesville, moving northeast at 55 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Leesville, Fort Polk, Slagle, New Llano, Kurthwood, Hutton, Simpson
and Pickering.
Instruction:
Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Alert:
At 200 PM PDT, emergency management reported flooding across the
warned area. Flooding due to a dam floodgate release from the Mckay
reservoir will continue at least through Sunday. High water levels
are likely to continue into next due to the release from the dam.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles. People not helping or directly impacted
are encourage to stay away from this area.  Stay away from the creek
as the banks may be unstable and could collapse.
Alert:
The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
At 408 PM CDT, a confirmed large and extremely dangerous tornado was
located over Newlight, or 18 miles east of Winnsboro, moving
northeast at 50 mph.

This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. TAKE COVER NOW!

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...You are in a life-threatening situation. Flying debris may
be deadly to those caught without shelter. Mobile homes
will be destroyed. Considerable damage to homes,
businesses, and vehicles is likely and complete destruction
is possible.

The tornado will be near...
Newellton around 420 PM CDT.
Somerset around 425 PM CDT.
Afton around 430 PM CDT.
Tallulah around 440 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include Mound,
Delta and Richmond.
Instruction:
To repeat, a large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly
tornado is on the ground. To protect your life, TAKE COVER NOW! Move
to a basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!
Alert:

conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

conditions to small craft.  Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
An area of low pressure and an associated cold front will
approach and move through the area today and tonight. Southerly
winds over the coastal waters will increase in advance of the
front this morning and continue through much of the day. Behind
the front, winds will turn out of the north but remain strong
through Sunday. Wave heights of 8 to 10 feet can be expected
across the outer coastal waters and 5 to 7 feet over the
nearshore waters.

Alert:
A tightening pressure gradient in advance of an approaching cold
front will result in sustained winds of 25 to 30 MPH gusting to
35 MPH across the advisory area. Winds will moderate somewhat
after sunset before turning northerly behind the front early
Sunday morning.
* TIMING...Noon to 7 PM Saturday

* WINDS...25 to 30 MPH with gusts to 35 MPH.

* IMPACTS...Strong southerly winds will make driving difficult
for high profile vehicles along open east-west highways. Small
lawn furniture and garbage cans will be tossed around.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 20 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Grand Junction has issued a
Freeze Warning, which is in effect from 10 PM this evening to
10 AM MDT Sunday.

* LOCATIONS...Including the cities of De Beque, New Castle,
Mesa, Parachute, Rifle, Silt, Montrose, Hotchkiss, Delta,
Gateway, and Nucla.

* TEMPERATURES...28 to 32.

* TIMING...The coldest temperatures are expected early Sunday
morning around sunrise.

* IMPACTS...Sensitive vegetation and swamp coolers will be
impacted by sub-freezing temperatures.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are imminent or
highly likely. These conditions will kill crops and other
sensitive vegetation.
Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon..
Umatilla River at Pendleton affecting Umatilla County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Umatilla River at Pendleton.
* until late tonight.
* At 1:00 PM Saturday, the stage was 10.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.3 feet.
* Although the Umatilla River at Pendleton has fallen below flood
stage, flooding will continue along the Umatilla River downstream
of Pendleton due to the high outflow release from the Mckay
reservoir.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton

Watch, which is in effect from Sunday morning through Sunday
evening.

30 knots with gusts near 40 knots Sunday.

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

47 knots has significantly increased...but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.

extending from near Coushatta to 12 miles northeast of Zwolle to

small interior room.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton

Alert:
At 346 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 9 miles northwest of Warden, or 13 miles northeast of
Rayville, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This dangerous storm will be near...
Darnell and Goodwill around 355 PM CDT.
Oak Grove around 405 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include
Pioneer, Forest and Epps.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Eastern York County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 1030 PM EDT Saturday.

* At 440 PM EDT, the initial heavy rainfall that caused flash
flooding across eastern York County has ended, however residual
flooding impacts continue across the area and continued
runoff is still inducing rapid rises on the lower reaches of
area streams, especially Wildcat Creek between McConnells and
Rock Hill and Big Dutchman Creek in Rock Hill.  Additionally,
several roads were impacted and barricades are still in place
to ensure floodwaters fully recede and to give road crews
time to assess road stability.  Therefore, the Flash Flood
Warning has been cancelled and a Areal Flood Warning has been
issued in its place.

* The following streamgauge has exceeded Minor Flood Stage:
Wildcat Creek at Robertson Rd. 3 SW Rock Hill.

Current Stage: 14.07 feet and rising rapidly.
Forecast: Wildcat Creek will continue to rise to between 14.5
feet and 15.0 feet over the next 60 minutes before cresting
below 15.0 feet and beginning to recede early this evening.
Action Stage: 9.0 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 11.0 feet.
Impacts:  Minor flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to
Wildcat Creek from McConnells Hwy south to Ogden Rd,
Rambo Rd, and Auten Rd is likely. These roadways may be
impacted at these levels and some backyard home flooding
is possible.

* The following streamgauge has exceeded Minor Flood Stage:
Big Dutchman Creek 5 NNE Rock Hill.

Current Stage: 11.58 feet and falling rapidly.
Forecast: Big Dutchman Creek will continue to recede rapidly
over the next several hours and fall below Minor Flood
Stage within the next 2-4 hours.
Action Stage: 8.0 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 9.0 feet.
Moderate Flood Stage: 13.0 feet.
Impacts:  Minor flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to
Big Dutchman Creek near West Oak Rd. and Mt. Gallant Rd.
will continue through early evening.  Adjacent roadways
should no longer be impacted.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding
include...Rock Hill, Fort Mill, Tega Cay, Newport, Lesslie,
Mcconnells and Carowinds.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, highways, and underpasses. Additionally, country
roads and farmlands along the banks of creeks, streams, and other
low-lying areas are subject to flooding.

Numerous roads, parking lots and bridges will be threatened by heavy
rapidly rising streams and creeks. Please pay close
attention to road signs indicating a flood-prone area. Obey all
barricades, even if water is not currently over the road. Barricades
are in place for your protection and indicate areas where flooding
can occur rapidly and without warning.

Only when it is safe to do so, please report floodwaters or
landslides flowing over roads or threatening property to the National
Weather Service by calling toll-free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by
posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP.
Your message should describe the event and the specific location
where it occurred, including roadways, nearby cross streets, stream
names and other landmarks.

Alert:
Strong winds have developed across southeast Louisiana and
southern Mississippi in advance of a cold front.
* TIMING...Remainder of the afternoon and evening hours.

* WINDS...Sustained winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Winds of this strength can break numerous small tree
limbs and blow around loose objects such as trashcans and lawn
furniture. Additionally, gusty crosswinds can make driving
difficult, especially on elevated roadways and bridges.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 26 to 39 mph are expected.
Winds this strong can make driving difficult...especially for
high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
* WINDS...East winds between 15 to 20 knots with higher gusts.

* SEAS...Rising to 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or more are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building up to 5 to 8 feet this
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents continues
through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
Instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf. Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm. Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape,
face the shore and call or wave for help. If tired, float or
tread water until out of the rip current.

Alert:
Trinity River at Dallas affecting Dallas County
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Trinity River at Dallas.
* from this evening to Monday morning...Or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 300 PM Saturday the stage was 25.68 feet.
* Flood stage is 30.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river should rise above flood stage by Saturday
evening and continue to rise to a crest near 32 feet by early
Sunday morning. The river should fall below flood stage by Sunday
evening.
* At 32 feet, minor flooding of agricultural lands used for cattle
grazing will occur. Low water crossings near the river will begin
to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.
Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Stay tuned to NOAA All Hazards Radio for the latest river forecasts.

Center, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

* This dangerous storm will be near...
Zwolle around 335 PM CDT.
Converse around 340 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include

Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

If on or near Toledo Bend Reservoir, get away from the water and
move to safe shelter immediately. If you can hear thunder, you are
close enough to be struck by lightning. Severe thunderstorms can
produce large capsizing waves, even on small bodies of water. Move
into dock and seek safe shelter now! Do not be caught on the water
in a thunderstorm.

Alert:
At 315 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Milam, or 27 miles northwest of Toledo Bend Dam,
moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
west central Sabine Parish in northwestern Louisiana and north
central Sabine Counties.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.
Alert:
At 314 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from 6 miles northwest of Fountain Hill to Bastrop, moving
northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

These severe storms will be near...
Fountain Hill around 320 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by these severe thunderstorms include
Collinston and Mer Rouge.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with these storms, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Pocatello has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 9 AM to 9 PM MDT Sunday.

* IMPACTS/TIMING...Sunday afternoon through Sunday night. High
profile vehicles will encounter difficult driving conditions
through the Snake Plain and Arco Desert.

* WINDS...West to southwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45
mph. Localized gusts near 50 mph are possible across the Arco
Desert.

* LOCATIONS...Shoshone, Richfield, Craters of the Moon, Atomic
City, INL, Rexburg, Idaho Falls, Blackfoot, Fort Hall, Pocatello,
Aberdeen, American Falls, Rupert, and Burley.
Instruction:
A wind advisory means that winds of 30 mph are expected. Gusts
over 45 mph are possible. Winds this strong can make driving
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra
caution.

those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in
hazardous conditions.

to midnight MDT Sunday night.

* WINDS...West 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds and rough waves on area lakes will

Instruction:

Lake. For your personal safety, avoid the open waters. Stay close
to shore or around protected areas.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Northern Indiana has issued a
Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 5 AM Sunday to
11 AM EDT Monday.

* WINDS...Northeast wind increasing to 15 to 25 knots by daybreak.
Sunday. Wind backing north at 20 to 30 knots with a few gusts to
35 knots gales Sunday afternoon. Wind back to northwest Sunday
night and diminish to 10 to 15 knots.


* WAVES...Sunday morning 3 to 5 feet, building to 6 to 10 feet
occasionally to 13 feet Sunday night, then gradually subsiding
through Monday morning.
Instruction:
A small craft advisory means that sustained winds or frequent
gusts of 22 to 33 knots are likely...and/or waves greater than
4 feet are expected. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Instruction:

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 3
inches expected. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.

* WHERE...Bitterroot/Sapphire Mountains, Lolo Pass, and Lost
Trail Pass.

* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to noon MDT Sunday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Central Cabarrus County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...

* Until 945 PM EDT.

* At 349 PM EDT, runoff and high streamflows from this morning's
heavy rainfall across northwestern Cabarrus County has worked
its way downstream along the Rocky River, Coddle Creek, and
Irish Buffalo Creek watersheds between Concord, Harrisburg,
and Georgeville.  This will cause nuisance flooding of low-lying
areas adjacent to these streams and associated tributaries.
People are encouraged to avoid greenways, parks, and adjacent
areas until stream levels recede.

* The following streamgauge has exceeded Action Stage:
Rocky River above Irish Buffalo Creek Confluence, 5 W Georgeville

Current Stage: 13.49 feet and rising steadily.
Forecast: The Rocky River will continue to rise to 14-14.5 feet
over the next 60-90 minutes before cresting and beginning to
recede.
Action Stage: 12.0 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 16.5 feet.
Impacts: Flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to the river is
likely with backwater effects causing rises along Back Creek
and Reedy Creek.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding
include...West Concord, Harrisburg, Charlotte Motor Speedway,
Midland, Downtown Concord, and Mt Pleasant.
Instruction:
Heavy rainfall is causing ponding of water in urban areas, streets
and underpasses, as well as other poor drainage areas and low lying
spots. Rapid rises on small creeks and streams will also occur,
possibly flooding low water crossings and farmland. Do not attempt to
travel across flooded roads. Turn around, dont drown.
Alert:
The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
At 356 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking an area of showers and
strong thunderstorms near Jerome, or 15 miles southeast of
Fayetteville, moving northeast at 20 mph.

possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Godwin, Roseboro, Stedman, Salemburg, Falcon, Autryville, Vander,
Cedar Creek and Bushy Lake Natural Area.
Instruction:

40 mph are capable of knocking down tree limbs and blowing around
trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other light outdoor
objects.

Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Alert:
* TIMING...Through this evening.

* WINDS...Easterly winds from 25-30 mph with gusts as high as 40
mph possible.

* IMPACTS...High profile vehicles will need to take extra care.

Instruction:

Alert:
A cold front is moving through the region today. Drier air will
move into portions of deep south Texas this afternoon with winds
increasing from the west and northwest.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire weather zones 248, 249, and 252.

* WIND...Northwest 20 to 30 mph at the 20 foot level.

* HUMIDITY...Around 20 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means critical fire weather conditions are
occurring now...or will shortly. In general...these conditions
include sustained 20 foot winds of 25 MPH or greater...humidity
ranging from below 25 percent in Zapata County to below
45 percent along the coast...each lasting for 2 hours or longer...
and cured fuels. Humidity below 25 percent in most areas will
trigger fire danger at lower wind speeds. Detailed decision
tables are found at HTTP://WEATHER.GOV/RGV/?N=MAPCOLORS#FIRE.
Alert:
Surface low pressure across central Texas this afternoon will
move eastward through the evening. A strong pressure gradient
will develop across southwest Texas behind a cold front moving
through the region. Higher than normal winds across Falcon Lake
will produce rough waters.
* TIMING...Through 10 PM.

* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.

* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions, especially for high
profile vehicles. Unsecured light weight objects easily blown
by strong winds. Potential for sporadic power outages or power
surges. Boaters on Falcon Lake will experience rough waters.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 to 39 MPH are expected.

Alert:
Offshore flow in the wake of a cold front passage will
strengthen this afternoon through tonight and Sunday, creating
hazardous conditions for boaters.
* WINDS...West winds 15 to 20 knots becoming northwest 20 to 25
knots late this afternoon and this evening.

* WAVES/SEAS...Seas 6 to 8 feet with occasional seas up to 10
feet building to 7 to 9 feet with occasional seas up to 11
feet after midnight.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.

Alert:
At 242 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Martinsville, or 16 miles east of Nacogdoches,
moving northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
eastern Nacogdoches, southwestern Shelby and north central San
Augustine Counties.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Alert:
A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the region
from tonight through early Sunday morning. As temperatures drop
into the mid 30s overnight, snow is expected to mix with rain for
locations along and north of route 6. Snow accumulations of 1 to
2 inches are possible primarily on grassy areas and elevated,
cooler surfaces. Given that overnight low temperatures will remain
above freezing, no accumulation is expected on roadways. Motorist
should slow down if traveling overnight as roads will be wet.

* from Sunday afternoon to Tuesday morning...or until the warning is
cancelled.

* At  1:30 PM Saturday the stage was 3.0 feet.

* Minor flooding is forecast.

* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.

Sunday afternoon and crest near 22.3 feet mid Monday morning. The

streamlevels remain high and downstream rises are ongoing along
the Rocky River watershed.  Therefore the Flash Flood Warning

Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

Alert:
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of northern New York and Vermont, including the
following areas, in northern New York, Eastern Clinton,
Eastern Essex, Northern Franklin, Northern St. Lawrence,
Southeastern St. Lawrence, Southern Franklin, Southwestern St.
Lawrence, Western Clinton, and Western Essex. In Vermont,
Caledonia, Eastern Addison, Eastern Chittenden, Eastern
Franklin, Eastern Rutland, Essex, Lamoille, Orange, Orleans,
Washington, Western Addison, Western Chittenden, Western
Franklin, Western Rutland, and Windsor.

* From Sunday evening through Tuesday morning

* A moisture-laden frontal system will bring widespread rainfall
Sunday afternoon through Monday morning, with rainfall amounts
from 0.75 to 1.25 inches expected. This will combine with
increasing snow melt due to warm temperatures through Sunday
morning to produce significant runoff into area rivers and
streams. Main stem rivers most at risk for minor category
flooding include the Ausable, Missisquoi, Passumpsic, Otter
Creek, Winooski, Lamoille, and possibly the Mad river. Sharp
river rises are likely beginning Sunday night. Most main stem
rivers are expected to crest during the day Monday based on
current indications.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the weekend and
into Monday.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:

through Monday will have the rivers rising over the next few days.
Low pressure will move through central new Hampshire and into
Maine Monday. It is expected that 0.75 to 1 inch of rain will
fall through Tuesday morning. This may lead to minor river
flooding.

Alert:
A strong cold front will approach the waters Sunday and push
through early Monday. Strong south to southwest winds 20 to 30
knots will develop. Gale force winds are likely to develop south
of Oregon Inlet Sunday night and continue through mid day Monday.
Seas will peak at 6-12 ft Monday. Winds and seas will be slowly to
subside late Monday and Monday night.
The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 11 PM Sunday to
8 PM EDT Monday.

* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* WAVES...2 to 3 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

altering their plans.

Alert:
At 232 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 10 miles southeast of Jonesboro, moving northeast at 45
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Brownsville-Bawcomville, Chatham, Fondale, Vixen, Bosco, Luna and
Lapine.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Alert:
In the wake of a strong cold front that moved across the area
earlier, strong northwest to north winds behind the front will
lower humidities into the lower 20s while gusting up to 40 MPH at
times. These breezy and dry conditions will result in favorable
conditions for the spread of fires through this evening.
* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 19 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.
Alert:
The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

* Seas: 4 to 5 feet.
Instruction:

seas of 5 feet or greater over the coastal waters are expected to
produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

* Flood advisory for...
The island of Hawaii in Hawaii County

* Until 1245 PM HST.

* At 921 AM HST, radar indicated heavy rain along windward Big
Island from Laupahoehoe to Hilo to Pahoa. Rain was falling at a

* Locations in the advisory include but are not limited to...
Hilo, Hawaiian Acres, Paauilo, Waipio Valley, Glenwood, Pepeekeo,
Keaau, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park and Honokaa.
Instruction:

flooding.

Rainfall and runoff will also cause hazardous driving conditions due
to ponding, reduced visibility and poor braking action.

Do not cross fast flowing or rising water in your vehicle, or on
foot. Turn around, don't drown.

* At 219 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from near Hawkins to near Sacul, moving east at 40 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

Alert:
The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
A strong storm system will move across the Tennessee Valley and
southern Appalachians Sunday, producing two rounds of showers and
thunderstorms - one in the morning and one in the late afternoon
and evening. There is an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms
area wide, with the highest severe threat coming with the late
day storms. The main concern will be damaging winds, but isolated
tornadoes and hail up to quarter size will also be possible.

Windy conditions will develop tonight and Sunday morning.
Southerly winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 45 mph is possible
across most of the area, with gusts up to 60 mph possible in the
mountains.

Please keep abreast of the latest forecast updates from the
National Weather Service.
Instruction:

Alert:
A strong storm system will move across the Tennessee Valley and
southern Appalachians Sunday, producing two rounds of showers and
thunderstorms - one in the morning and one in the late afternoon
and evening. There is an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms
area wide, with the highest severe threat coming with the late
day storms. The main concern will be damaging winds, but isolated
tornadoes and hail up to quarter size will also be possible.

Windy conditions will develop tonight and Sunday morning.
Southerly winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 45 mph is possible
across most of the area, with gusts up to 60 mph possible in the
mountains.

Please keep abreast of the latest forecast updates from the
National Weather Service.
Instruction:

Alert:
Gusty southerly to southwesterly winds around a strong surface
low associated with large upper storm system will likely affect
higher elevations tonight and most of the day on Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued
a High Wind Warning above 3500 feet, which is in effect from
midnight tonight to 10 PM EDT Sunday.

* LOCATIONS...Higher elevations of the Southern Appalachians of
Western North Carolina and Northeast Georgia.

* HAZARDS...Very windy conditions.

* TIMING...From Midnight tonight to Sunday evening.

* WINDS...South 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph.

* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power
lines. Widespread power outages are possible. Travel could be
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.

Please report damaging winds by calling the National Weather
Service toll free at...1...800...2 6 7...8 1 0 1. Leave a message
with your observation and the specific location where it
occurred. You can also post your report to National Weather
Service Greenville Spartanburg Facebook or tweet your report
using hashtag nwsgsp.
