The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Northwestern Caldwell Parish in north central Louisiana...
Southeastern Jackson Parish in north central Louisiana...
Southwestern Ouachita Parish in north central Louisiana...
Northern Winn Parish in north central Louisiana...

* Until 300 PM CDT.

* At 215 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 11 miles south of Jonesboro, moving northeast at 45
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
northwestern Caldwell, southeastern Jackson, southwestern Ouachita
and northern Winn Parishes, including the following locations...
Fondale, Sikes, Vixen, Bosco, Hudson, Luna, Chatham, Dodson, Lapine
and Calvin.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.
Alert:
Temperatures are expected to drop to near or just below freezing
by early Sunday morning for portions of southeastern New Mexico
and northwest Permian Basin. These conditions may affect
temperature sensitive plants that have recently been planted so
special precautions to protect them may be needed.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of western Massachusetts, New York, and southern
Vermont, including the following areas, in western
Massachusetts, Northern Berkshire. In New York, Eastern
Rensselaer, Eastern Schenectady, Hamilton, Montgomery,
Northern Fulton, Northern Herkimer, Northern Saratoga,
Northern Warren, Northern Washington, Southeast Warren,
Southern Fulton, Southern Herkimer, Southern Saratoga,
Southern Washington, Western Rensselaer, and Western
Schenectady. In southern Vermont, Bennington, Eastern Windham,
and Western Windham.

* From late Sunday night through Tuesday morning

* The Upper Hudson River, Sacandaga River, Black River, Mohawk
River, Hoosic River, Deerfield River, West River and their
tributaries are at risk for flooding.

* The combination of runoff from snowmelt over the weekend and
rainfall Sunday afternoon into early Monday morning will
result in significant rises on rivers and their tributaries
with flooding possible.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
At 215 PM CDT, minor overland flooding was occurring due to snowmelt.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Wahpeton, Lisbon, Hankinson, Enderlin, Gwinner, Milnor and
Lidgerwood.

This includes Interstate 29 between mile markers 0 and 48.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Excessive runoff will cause flooding of small creeks and streams,
country roads, farmland, and other low lying spots.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 4 PM Sunday to 5 PM EDT
Monday.

* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 kt. Gusts to 35 kt possible Sunday
night.

* SEAS...5 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and or seas of 6 ft or greater are expected to produce hazardous
wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

* At 213 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Todd Mission,
or 7 miles northwest of Pinehurst, moving northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and nickel size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...

Instruction:
A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

If on or near Lake Conroe, get away from the water and move indoors
or inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 15 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now!  Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.
Alert:
Southerly winds will increase across the area tonight. In the
mountains, strong winds will begin after midnight tonight. In the
Valley and Plateau, winds will increase after sunrise. Winds will
diminish Sunday evening.

Warning, which is in effect from midnight tonight to 8 PM EDT
Sunday.

* WINDS...South 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 60 mph.

* TIMING...From midnight through Sunday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Damaging winds will blow down trees and power lines.
Widespread power outages are expected. Travel will be
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph and/or
gusts of 58 mph or stronger can be expected at times.  Winds of
these magnitudes can cause property damage and power outages.
Motorists should use caution...especially those in high profile
vehicles.

* TIMING...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree
limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
Instruction:

40 to 57 mph are expected or occurring. Winds this strong can
make driving difficult...especially for high profile vehicles.
Use extra caution.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Jacksonville has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from noon Sunday to 4 PM EDT
Monday.

* WINDS AND SEAS...Sunday, South winds increasing to 20 to 25
knots. Seas building to 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9
feet. Sunday night, Southwest winds 20 to 25 knots becoming west
in the morning. Seas 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9
feet. Monday, West northwest winds 20 to 25 knots becoming
northwest 15 to 20 knots. Seas 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas
up to 9 feet subsiding to 3 to 5 feet with occasional seas up to
6 feet in the afternoon.

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Monday.

limits, and no longer appears capable of producing a tornado.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has extended the

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Alamance County in central North Carolina...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 615 PM EDT

* At 259 PM EDT, local law enforcement officials reported flash
flooding occurring. A portion of Johnson Road in Durham County
remains closed due to flooding. Additionally, the Eno River in
Hillsboro has risen above flood stage, with subsequent rises
occurring along the Eno River eastward into Durham County.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Burlington, Graham, Hillsborough, Carrboro,
Mebane, Elon College, Rougemont and Gibsonville.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many roads
and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When encountering
flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
At 302 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Morganton,
moving east at 25 mph.

HAZARD...70 mph wind gusts and ping pong ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
considerable tree damage. Wind damage is also likely to
mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings.

Locations impacted include...
Morganton, Valdese, Gamewell, Cajah's Mountain, Drexel, Connelly
Springs, Rutherford College, Glen Alpine, Lake Rhodhiss and Oak Hill.
Instruction:
Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

Large hail can cause major property damage, especially to vehicles.
Strong winds may blow down a few trees and power lines. Seek shelter
inside an interior room.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.
Alert:

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southwestern Moore County in central North Carolina...
Northeastern Richmond County in central North Carolina...

* Until 345 PM EDT

* At 301 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles northwest
of Hoffman, or 11 miles northeast of Rockingham, moving northeast
at 25 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Southern Pines, Carthage, Pinehurst, Aberdeen, Whispering Pines,
Pinebluff, Ellerbe, Foxfire, Taylortown and Norman.
Instruction:
Straight line winds can blow down trees, power lines, and damage
mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.

Alert:
Scattered to numerous snow showers have developed across south
central and southeast Wyoming this afternoon. This activity will
persist for the next several hours. The heaviest showers will be
accompanied by visibilities as low as one half mile and possibly
slick road conditions. Those traveling across southeast Wyoming
today should be prepared for rapidly changing weather and road
conditions. If you encounter inclement weather, slow down and
allow extra time to reach your destination.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 8 AM to 8 PM EDT Sunday.

* WINDS...Northeast 15 to 25 knots with gusts up to 30 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...Waves 3 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory is issued when waves of 4 feet or more are
expected or wind speeds reach 21 to 33 knots which may produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should stay in port
during these conditions.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Topeka has issued a Freeze
Warning, which is in effect from 3 AM to 9 AM CDT Sunday.

* TEMPERATURES...Are expected to fall into the upper 20s to low
30s during the early morning hours on Sunday. There is some
uncertainty in how far east these freezing temperatures will
spread, which will depend heavily on how fast clouds and winds
can lessen before sunrise.

* IMPACTS...Sub-freezing temperatures will cause damage to
plants. Outdoor plants will need to be covered or brought
indoors.
Instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are highly
likely. These conditions will kill crops and other sensitive
vegetation.

strong can make driving difficult...especially for high profile
vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
At 253 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 11
miles north of Rockingham, moving northeast at 25 mph. A Severe
Thunderstorm Warning may be needed if this storm continues to
strengthen.

Nickel size hail, heavy downpours, and wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph
will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Southern Pines, Carthage, Pinehurst, Aberdeen, Whispering Pines,
Pinebluff, Ellerbe, Foxfire, Taylortown and Norman.
Instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.
Alert:
At 153 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located north of Lake
Conroe Dam. A new storm, 8 miles east of New Waverly, or 11 miles
northeast of Willis, has also developed, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

Instruction:
A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Continuous cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Move indoors immediately. Lightning is one of nature's leading
killers. Remember, if you can hear thunder, you are close enough to
be struck by lightning.

If on or near area lakes, get away from the water and move indoors
or inside a vehicle. remember, lightning can strike out to 15 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now!  Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.
Alert:
Strong northeast winds will develop Sunday on the lake causing a
seiche to develop. This will result in high water levels on the
western end of Lake Erie. Higher than normal water levels may cause
lakeshore flooding Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a Lakeshore
Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday morning through
Sunday afternoon.

* LAKE SHORE FLOODING...A northeasterly flow Sunday may cause
higher than normal water levels on the western basin of Lake
Erie. This may result in flooding along the lakeshore. The
combination of rising water levels and waves may result in the
flooding of the lakeshore.

* TIMING...Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon

* IMPACTS...Flooding along the immediate lakeshore and beach and
shoreline erosion may be possible. Rising water levels in
marinas and waterways into the lake could submerge dockage and
shoreline structures.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Watch is issued when conditions are favorable
for lakeshore flooding to develop. Residents on or near the shore
should begin to take action to protect property. Listen for later
statements or warnings.
Alert:
* TIMING...Through 1 AM CDT Sunday.

* WINDS...Sustained north to northwest winds at 25 to 35 MPH with
gusts as high as 45 MPH.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. High profile vehicles will see more difficult driving
conditions on east and west oriented roadways. Any boaters
heading out on area lakes will see choppy conditions.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult...especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
At 253 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 5 miles west of
Morganton, or near Glen Alpine, moving east at 25 mph.

HAZARD...70 mph wind gusts and ping pong ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
considerable tree damage. Wind damage is also likely to
mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings.

Locations impacted include...
Morganton, Valdese, Gamewell, Icard, Cajah's Mountain, Drexel,
Connelly Springs, Rutherford College, Glen Alpine and Lake Rhodhiss.
Instruction:
Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

Large hail can cause major property damage, especially to vehicles.
Strong winds may blow down a few trees and power lines. Seek shelter
inside an interior room.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

Therefore, the warning will be allowed to expire.

northeastern Texas.

Alert:
* TEMPERATURE...Lows tonight are forecast in the lower to middle
30s. Valleys and outlying areas may briefly drop below
freezing, especially in southern Illinois and southeast
Missouri.

* IMPACTS...Scattered to widespread frost is expected to develop
overnight and last through early Monday morning. This may damage
or kill tender young blooms and early season vegetation if
protective measures are not taken. Bring out door plants indoors
or cover them with some type of protective layer.

Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 20 to 30 kt with gusts up to 45 kt.
Seas 4 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots,
or seas 5 feet or greater, are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased...but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.

and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.
Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 10 to 20 kt with gusts up to 40 kt.
Waves 3 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots,
or seas 5 feet or greater, are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
At 438 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Hide-A-Way
Hills, moving northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to trees and power lines.

Locations impacted include...
Lancaster, Logan, Nelsonville, Bremen, Hide-A-Way Hills, Murray City,
Sugar Grove, Rushville, West Rushville, Hideaway Hills, Haydenville,
North Berne, Enterprise, Union Furnace, Rockbridge, Oreville and
Carbon Hill.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

To report severe weather, go to our website at weather.gov/iln and
submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.
Alert:
At 439 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located over Wilkesboro, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
North Wilkesboro...
Wilkesboro...
Ronda...
Mulberry...
and Buck.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

Alert:
Paint Rock River NEAR Woodville affecting Jackson...Madison and
Marshall Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
the Paint Rock River NEAR Woodville.
* until Tuesday evening.
* At 3 PM Sunday the stage was 13.4 feet and rising.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor Flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above Flood Stage by midnight tonight and
crest near 16.5 FEET BY early tomorrow evening. The river will fall
below Flood Stage by early Tuesday afternoon.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flood waters affect mostly bottomland along
the river...including low lying farm and pasturelands.
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.3 feet
on Feb 20 2019.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not attempt to drive through a flooded road. The
depth of water is not always obvious. As little as two feet of water
will carry most cars away. Also, the road bed may be washed out under
the water, and you could be stranded or trapped. Additional
information is available at http://water.weather.gov. Once there,
click on the Tennessee Valley to view local river information.

* Locations impacted include...

Beach, Palm Springs, North Palm Beach, Lake Park, Haverhill, Cloud
Lake, Palm Beach International Airport, Port Of Palm Beach, Golden
Lakes, Gun Club Estates, Schall Circle and Royal Palm Estates.
Instruction:
Funnel clouds occasionally touch down and produce tornadoes or
waterspouts. Move indoors and stay away from windows.

To report severe weather, contact your nearest law enforcement
agency. You can also share your report with NWS Miami on Facebook and
Twitter.

Alert:
At 428 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Lake George, or near Pierson, moving north at 35 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Pierson, Lake George, Seville and Bakerstown.
Instruction:
If on or near Lake George, get out of the water and move indoors or
inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 10 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now! Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

was located near Bucyrus, moving northeast at 55 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without

to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Bucyrus, Galion, Crestline, New Washington, Chatfield, Tiro, North
Robinson and Sulpher Springs.
Instruction:

floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

National Weather Service or your local nearest law enforcement agency
who will send your report. This act may save lives of others in the
path of dangerous weather.

Alert:
Strong and gusty offshore flow and elevated seas will continue
for the remainder of the afternoon. Winds and seas will begin to
decrease later this afternoon and decrease further this evening as
high pressure starts to build in from the west.
* WINDS...20 to 25 knots with gusts to near 30 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...2 to 4 feet within 20 nm, 4 to 7 feet beyond 20
nm.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

A tornado watch is in effect. Thunderstorms can produce tornadoes
suddenly, sometimes with little or no warning. Be alert for rapidly
changing weather conditions and be ready to act quickly if severe
weather is observed or a warning is issued.

Report damage directly to the Charleston National Weather Service at
1-888-383-2024 when it is safe to do so. You can also email your
report to nws.charlestonsc@noaa.gov.

Alert:
At 417 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Morral, or 7 miles north of Marion, moving northeast
at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and golf ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Marion, Bucyrus, Galion, Crestline, New Washington, Morral,
Chatfield, Nevada, Caledonia, Tiro, North Robinson, Oceola, Sulpher
Springs and Iberia.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

If a tornado or other severe weather is spotted, report it to the
National Weather Service or your local nearest law enforcement agency
who will send your report. This act may save lives of others in the
path of dangerous weather.

40 to 57 mph are expected, or are occurring. Winds this strong
can make driving difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Use extra caution.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Lincoln has issued a Frost
Advisory, which is in effect from 1 AM to 8 AM CDT Monday.

* TEMPERATURE...Low temperatures are expected to fall into the
lower 30s over southeast Illinois on Monday morning. As a
result, widespread front will be possible over the region.

* IMPACTS...Widespread frost is expected to develop shortly after
midnight tonight, and last through the early morning hours.
This may damage or kill tender young blooms and early season
vegetation if protective measures are not taken.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
Alert:
* LAKE SHORE FLOODING...Northeast winds of 20 to 30 knots will
cause higher than normal water levels on the western basin of
Lake Erie. Water levels were near 80 inches above low water
datum and had started to drop. This will result in minor
flooding and shoreline erosion along the lakeshore. Shifting
winds will allow levels to continue dropping into the evening
and levels will likely drop below 60 inches by 10pm.


* TIMING...Through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Flooding along the immediate lakeshore and beach and
shoreline erosion may be possible. Rising water levels in
marinas and waterways into the lake could submerge docks and
shoreline structures.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Warning is issued when flooding is occurring or
imminent along the lake. Residents on or near the shore in the
warned area should take immediate action to protect life and
property.

Instruction:
A Gale Warning means sustained winds or frequent gusts of 34 to
47 kt are expected or occurring. Operating a vessel in gale
conditions requires experience and properly equipped vessels. It
is highly recommended that mariners without the proper experience
seek safe harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means that sustained wind speeds or
frequent gusts of 25 to 33 kt and/or seas of 5 ft or higher are
expected or occurring, and hazardous to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in these conditions.

can strike out to 10 miles from the parent thunderstorm. If you can

Alert:
At 349 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 4 miles south of Morganton, or 4 miles southeast of Glen
Alpine, moving northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This dangerous storm will be near...
Glen Alpine around 350 PM EDT.
Morganton, Drexel, Valdese, Rutherford College and Connelly
Springs around 400 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by this dangerous storm include Oak Hill.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for the Little Tallahatchie Canal.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Little Tallahatchie Canal at Etta near New Albany
* until Monday April 15.
* At 2 PM Sunday the stage was 25.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring AND Minor flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 26.0 feet on Sunday April 14.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* The river rose above flood stage Sunday April 14 and will continue
rising to near 26.0 feet by Sunday April 14. The river will fall
below flood stage Monday April 15.
* At 26.0 feet...County Highway 47 near Mud Creek and Mill Creek has
6 to 12 inches of water over it. Several thousand acres of crop
land are flooded.

www.weather.gov and click near Memphis on the map, then select Rivers
and Lakes.

latest river information.

Large hail and damaging winds and continuous cloud to ground
lightning is occurring with this storm. Move indoors immediately.
Lightning is one of nature's leading killers. Remember, if you can
hear thunder, you are close enough to be struck by lightning.

Alert:
The Flood Watch continues for

* All of Vermont excluding Grand Isle, and Franklin, Clinton,
Essex, and St. Lawrence counties in Northern New York.

* From 11 PM EDT this evening through Tuesday morning.

* Abnormally warm temperatures on Saturday produced significant
snow melt bringing rivers close to bank full early Sunday
morning. A moisture- laden frontal system will bring widespread
rainfall this evening through Monday morning with rainfall
amounts from 0.75 to 1.25 inches expected. The combination of
rain and snow melt will potentially cause main stem river
flooding on the Ausable, Missisquoi, Passumpsic, Otter Creek,
Winooski, Lamoille, and possibly the Mad river. Sharp river
rises are likely beginning tonight. Most main stem rivers are
expected to crest during the day Monday based on current
indications.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the weekend and
into Monday.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
Strong onshore wind with gusts to gales will continue through this
afternoon eventually veering to northwest as low pressure departs to
the east. Significant wave heights will approach 12 feet over the
central open waters of Lake Huron and near the tip of the Thumb
while max waves exceed 15 feet at times, including the exposed
nearshore waters between Port Austina and Harbor Beach tonight into
early Monday. Gale warnings remain in effect and are expected to be
replaced by small craft advisories running through much of Monday
upon their expiration. Light wind through midweek.
The Small Craft Advisory is now in effect until 11 PM EDT this
evening.

sustained winds up to 22 knots from the northeast with gusts
up to 25 knots. The largest expected significant waves will
be 5 feet with a potential maximum wave height of 7 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 3 PM EDT Sunday
with the largest waves expected around 3 PM EDT Sunday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.

occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

* Tornado Warning for...
Southeastern McDowell County in western North Carolina...
Northeastern Rutherford County in western North Carolina...
Southern Burke County in western North Carolina...

* Until 400 PM EDT.

* At 333 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 11 miles northeast of Rutherfordton, or 10 miles north
of Bostic, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This dangerous storm will be near...
Salem, South Mountains State Park and Glen Alpine around 350 PM
EDT.
Morganton, Drexel, Valdese, Rutherford College and Connelly
Springs around 400 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by this dangerous thunderstorm include
Sunshine, Thermal City, Oak Hill, Dysartsville and Union Mills.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.
Alert:
Gusty southerly to southwesterly winds around a strong surface
low associated with large upper storm system will affect the
region through early this evening. Gusty northwest winds are
possible across high elevations focused across the northern
mountains late tonight into Monday morning.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued
a Wind Advisory, which is in effect until 10 PM EDT this evening.

* LOCATIONS...The Piedmont and Foothills of the Carolinas and
northeast Georgia.

* HAZARDS...Strong wind gusts.

* TIMING...Through 10 PM EDT this evening.

* WINDS...South 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects. Tree
limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your favorite source of
weather information for the latest updates. Additional details
can be found at www.weather.gov/gsp.

Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may

Instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.

Please report damaging winds by calling the National Weather
Service toll free at...1...800...2 6 7...8 1 0 1. Leave a message
with your observation and the specific location where it
occurred. You can also post your report to National Weather
Service Greenville Spartanburg Facebook or tweet your report
using hashtag nwsgsp.

profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

can be found at www.weather.gov/gsp.

Alert:

moving northeast at 45 mph.

STORM HAZARDS INCLUDE...
Winds to 40 mph...
Pea size hail...

Locations impacted include...
Springfield, Beavercreek, Huber Heights, Fairborn, Xenia, Yellow
Springs, Wright-Patterson Afb, Northridge, Enon, Riverside, North
Hampton, Tremont City, Donnelsville, Clifton, Green Meadows, Hustead,
Oldtown, Dialton, Medway and Springfield Municipal Airport.

This includes I-70 in Ohio between mile markers 42 and 59.

weather.gov/iln and submit your report via social media, when you can
do so safely.

information.

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

information.

properly equipped vessels. It is highly recommended that mariners
without the proper experience seek safe harbor prior to the onset

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Eastern McDowell County in western North Carolina...
Northeastern Rutherford County in western North Carolina...
Southwestern Caldwell County in western North Carolina...
Northwestern Cleveland County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...
Burke County in western North Carolina...

* Until 415 PM EDT.

* At 331 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles southeast
of Marion, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to trees and power lines.

* Locations impacted include...
Morganton, Marion, Drexel, Glen Alpine, Lake James State Park,
Table Rock, South Mountains State Park, Lake James, Nebo and
Thermal City.
Instruction:
Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

Scattered trees and power lines will be blown down in the warned
area. Seek shelter inside an interior room.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...

east central Georgia.

Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.
Alert:
At 327 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Westfield, moving northeast at 45 mph. While the
storm has shown signs of weakening rotation, reintensification is
possible.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Stuart...
Francisco...
Collinstown...
Patrick Springs...
and Critz.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 6 inches.

* WHERE...Portions of Northern Lower Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 4 AM EDT Monday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Blowing and drifting snow will occur into
this evening, especially near the Lake Huron coastline. Travel
could be very difficult as snow is expected to be wet/heavy
which is more difficult to drive in.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.
Alert:
* WHAT...Snow. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 4 inches.

* WHERE...Portions of Northern Lower Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 2 AM EDT Monday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Snow is
expected to be wet/heavy and thus tends to make roads more
greasy and difficult to drive on.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Louisville has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northwestern Nelson County in central Kentucky...
Northeastern Hardin County in central Kentucky...
Bullitt County in central Kentucky...

* Until 400 PM EDT.

* At 328 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near
Elizabethtown, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Elizabethtown, Shepherdsville, Pioneer Village, Radcliff, Mount
Washington, Lebanon Junction, Hebron Estates, Fox Chase, Bardstown
Junction and Hobbs.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.
Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...Sustained east northeast wind near 30 mph
with higher gusts will continue through late afternoon along the
western shoreline of Lake Erie. Although wind speed will begin
to diminish after 4 PM, continued onshore flow from the
northeast will support an ongoing flooding threat, especially
from Luna Pier to Maumee Bay. Winds will decrease and veer to
the north this evening, which will allow the lake levels to
decrease.

* Impacts...The combination of high water and wave action will
support flooding along the coast line and beach erosion.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Warning means that flooding is occurring or
imminent along the lake. Residents on or near the shore in the
warned area should be alert for rising water...and take
appropriate action to protect life and property.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety
Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...East to northeast wind will gust up to 35
mph today over western Lake Erie. The strong wind will lead to
rising water levels and elevated wave action through early
evening. The winds will back to the north this evening,
allowing water levels to decrease.

* Impacts...High water levels and ongoing rainfall may support
some flooding in and around Gibraltar.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds will
generate flooding of low areas along the lakeshore.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org
Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...Northeast winds will gust over 40 MPH at
times on Saginaw Bay late this afternoon into tonight. This will
drive water into the bay, thus raising lake levels. The winds
will back to the north overnight before weakening early Monday
morning, allowing the water levels to decrease.

* Impacts...The combination of rising water and waves will cause
flooding along the shoreline of Saginaw Bay. Beach erosion is
likely and some damage to structures near the shore are
possible.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Warning means that flooding is occurring or
imminent along the lake. Residents on or near the shore in the
warned area should be alert for rising water...and take
appropriate action to protect life and property.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org
Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...Northeast wind will continue to
strengthen today, peaking near 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph
this evening. Wind will then switch gradually to the north
overnight and remain strong into Monday morning. These winds
will lead to very high waves as well as a general increase in
the lake water level.

* Impacts...The high waves and rising water level will lead to
significant beach erosion in some areas and localized
lakeshore flooding from this afternoon into tonight before
gradually improving on Monday morning.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds will
generate flooding of low areas along the lakeshore.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org

The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Alert:
At 324 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Connersville,
moving northeast at 55 mph.

An NWS cooperative observer in Alpine Indiana reported quarter sized
hail recently with this storm.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Trained weather spotters.

IMPACT...Minor hail damage to vehicles is possible. Expect wind
damage to trees and power lines.

Locations impacted include...
Richmond, Connersville, Centerville, Cambridge City, Liberty, Dublin,
Salem, Waterloo, Abington, Brownsville, East Germantown, Spring
Grove, Boston, Mount Auburn, Whitewater, Richmond Municipal Airport,
Dunlapsville, Whitewater State Park, Goodwins Corner and Mettel
Field.

This includes the following Interstates...
I-70 in Indiana between mile markers 139 and 156.
I-70 in Ohio near mile marker 0.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.
Alert:
The National Weather Service has issued a Flood Warning for the Obion
River.
The National Weather Service in Memphis TN has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the Obion River near Obion
* from Tuesday April 16 until Tuesday April 16.
* At 2 PM Sunday the stage was...31.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 34.0 feet on Tuesday April 16.
* Flood stage is 34.0 feet.
At 34.0 feet, Farm land near the river is flooded..
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

A followup Flood Statement will be issued later today.

For graphical river and flood information...please go to
www.weather.gov and click near Memphis on the map, then select Rivers
and Lakes.

Do not drive through flooded areas...turn around don't drown.

Stay tuned to your weather radio and your local news media for the
latest river information.
Alert:
* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.

* WINDS...34 to 47 knots within the Gale Warning.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and a properly equipped vessel. Recreational boaters
should seek safe harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Little Tallahatchie Canal.
The National Weather Service in Memphis TN has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the Little Tallahatchie Canal at Etta near New Albany
* until later tonight Sunday April 14.
* At 2 PM Sunday the stage was...25.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
At 25.0 feet, Extensive crop land flooding is occurring, mainly
between State Highway 30 and County Highway 46. Water is beginning to
cover the unpaved portion of Union County Highway 47 near Mud Creek..

Alert:
* Wind: South to southwest 15 to 20 knots with gusts to 25 knots
late today and tonight becoming west Monday.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots over
the rivers of eastern Virginia are expected to produce hazardous
boating conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.

* At 2 PM Sunday the stage was...28.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring AND Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 31.0 feet on Saturday April 20.
* Flood stage is 28.0 feet.
* The river rose above flood stage  and will continue rising to near
31.0 feet by Saturday April 20. The river will fall below flood
stage Friday April 26.
At 31.0 feet, In Tennessee, Nix road is flooded. Major sections of
Four Mile Road are flooded. Snyder Bluff and northern Sam Taylor
Roads are flooding. Sunk Lake Road is covered north of Bee Lake.
Fields on Morgan Point are flooding..
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

A followup Flood Statement will be issued later today.

For graphical river and flood information...please go to
www.weather.gov and click near Memphis on the map, then select Rivers
and Lakes.

Do not drive through flooded areas...turn around don't drown.

Stay tuned to your weather radio and your local news media for the
latest river information.

* TIMING...Strongest winds occurring late this afternoon and
evening, and then strengthening further on Monday.

* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power
lines. Widespread power outages are possible. Travel could be
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph for
more an hour, or wind gusts of 46 to 57 mph for any duration are
expected. Winds this strong can make driving difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Alert:
At 321 PM EDT...a strong thunderstorm was near Owensboro, or 7 miles
southwest of Abbeville...moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...40 to 50 mph wind...frequent cloud to ground lightning
and heavy rain.

IMPACT...Expect minor damage to tree limbs and blowing around of
light...unsecured objects. Heavy rain may cause temporary
street flooding especially in poor drainage areas.

Some locations in the path of this storm include
Abbeville, Rochelle, Union, Five Points, Cedar Creek, Antioch Church
and Owensboro.
Instruction:
People outdoors should seek shelter immediately. If you can hear
thunder...you are close enough to be struck by lightning. Motorists
should slow down and be prepared for possible loss of control due to
hydroplaning.

Alert:
At 322 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Rutherfordton, moving northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This dangerous storm will remain over mainly rural areas of central
Rutherford County, including the following locations... Thermal City,
Green Hill and Union Mills.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

At 320 PM EDT...National Weather Service doppler radar indicated a
strong thunderstorm near Lowery, or 11 miles southwest of Soperton...
moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...40 to 50 mph wind and enhanced risk of a brief tornado.

IMPACT...While winds should result in minor damage to tree limbs
and blowing around of light...unsecured objects...this
storm has also exhibited localized rotation. A brief
tornado could quickly form.

Some locations in the path of this storm include
Soperton, Adrian, Lothair, Covena, Orland, Rockledge, Orianna,
Norristown, Barnhill, Lowery, Blackville, Zaidee and Gillis Springs.
Instruction:
People outdoors should seek shelter immediately.

A tornado watch remains in effect. Continue to monitor NOAA Weather
Radio...weather.gov or other media outlets for further statements or
possible warnings on these storms.

possible.

current forecasts.

* WINDS AND SEAS...Southwest winds 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to 30
kt tonight through Monday morning. West to northwest winds 15 to
25 kt with gusts up to 40 kt Monday afternoon through Monday
night. Seas 2 to 4 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

* Until 345 PM EDT.

* At 317 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Dexter, or 10
miles southwest of Dublin, moving northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and an enhanced risk of a tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Dublin, East Dublin, Dexter, Dudley, Lovett, Harlow, Tuckers
Crossroad and Brewton.
Instruction:
A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM EDT for central and
east central Georgia.

Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

If you see wind damage...hail or flooding...wait until the storm has
passed...and then call the National Weather Service toll free
at 1 8 6 6 7 6 3 4 4 6 6 or tweet us your report at NWSATLANTA.

Alert:
THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (TCEQ)...HAS ISSUED AN
OZONE ACTION DAY FOR THE HOUSTON...GALVESTON...AND BRAZORIA AREAS FOR
MONDAY APRIL 15TH.

ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BE FAVORABLE FOR PRODUCING
HIGH LEVELS OF OZONE POLLUTION IN THE HOUSTON...GALVESTON AND
SURROUNDING AREAS ON MONDAY. YOU CAN HELP PREVENT OZONE POLLUTION BY
SHARING A RIDE...WALKING...RIDING A BICYCLE...TAKING YOUR LUNCH TO
WORK...AVOIDING DRIVE THROUGH LANES...CONSERVING ENERGY AND KEEPING YOUR
VEHICLE PROPERLY TUNED.

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON OZONE:

OZONE: THE FACTS (WWW.TCEQ.TEXAS.GOV/AIRQUALITY/MONOPS/OZONEFACTS.HTML)

Alert:
Weak isolated thunderstorms are lifting through portions of the
area this afternoon. These storms will be capable of producing a

Instruction:

Alert:
Isolated thunderstorms are lifting through portions of the
advisory area. These storms will be capable of producing locally
heavy snow through about 5 PM. Combined with wind gusts up to 30
mph, visibility will occasionally fall as low as 1/4 of a mile.
Additional snow accumulation up to 2 inches will be possible
during this time. Roads will become snow-covered during intervals
of heavy snow. Motorists are advised to expect rapid fluctuations
in weather and road conditions.

Alert:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height 5 to 8 feet. High risk of rip
currents continues through late tonight.

* Timing...Through late tonight.

There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.

A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.
Instruction:

* TIMING...Through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...Surf height 3 to 5 feet.

There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties

signs.

calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.

Instruction:
The combination of gusty winds and saturated soil conditions will
cause scattered trees and power lines to fall. Seek shelter inside an
interior room.
Alert:
For the Lower Humboldt, including Battle Mountain, Minor flooding is
occurring and is expected to continue.

...Minor flooding is expected to continue along the Humboldt River near
Battle Mountain through Sunday before dropping below minor flood stage
Monday or Monday night...

FLD    OBSERVED         FORECAST 7AM
LOCATION            STG   STG DAY  TIME    Mon    Tue    Wed

Lower Humboldt
Battle Mountain   9.5    9.5 Sun 11 AM    9.5    9.4    9.4
Instruction:

Alert:
A strong storm system moving across the region will produce
gusty winds at times today. Wind gusts of 40-45 mph could blow
down a few trees and cause isolated power outages. The winds are
expected to settle down by tonight.
The National Weather Service in Nashville has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect until 7 PM CDT this evening.

* WHERE...The Upper Cumberland and surrounding areas. This
includes most areas east of Interstate 65.

* WINDS...South to southwest winds around 20 mph with gusts of
40-45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Few trees or limbs may blow down. Isolated power
outages. Loose objects will be blown down or scattered.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds over 40 mph are expected. Winds
this strong may blow down a few trees or tree limbs and cause
isolated power outages. Driving may also become difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
A strong storm system moving across the region will produce
gusty winds at times today. Wind gusts of 40-45 mph could blow
down a few trees and cause isolated power outages. The winds are
expected to settle down by tonight.
* WHERE...The Upper Cumberland and surrounding areas. This
includes most areas east of Interstate 65.

* WINDS...South to southwest winds around 20 mph with gusts of
40-45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Few trees or limbs may blow down. Isolated power
outages. Loose objects will be blown down or scattered.

A Wind Advisory means that winds over 40 mph are expected. Winds
this strong may blow down a few trees or tree limbs and cause
isolated power outages. Driving may also become difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
At 256 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Nebo, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Pilot Mountain...
Boonville...
Nebo...
Pilot Mountain State Park...
and Level Cross.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Eastern Rush County in central Indiana...
Northern Decatur County in central Indiana...

* Until 330 PM EDT.

* At 255 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Greensburg,
or 16 miles northwest of Batesville, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Greensburg, Rushville, Adams, Milroy, Glenwood, Clarksburg, New
Salem, Sandusky and Moscow.

This includes Interstate 74 between mile markers 126 and 137.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.
Alert:
At 252 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking heavy showers along a line
extending from near Christmas to Jetty Park. Movement was north at
35 mph. Heavy showers were also located over southeastern Volusia
county.

Wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible with these showers.

Locations impacted include...
Port Orange, Titusville, New Smyrna Beach, Edgewater and Cocoa.
Instruction:
Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these showers and may
lead to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through
flooded roadways.
Alert:
The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
At 253 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Hamilton Branch State Park, or 18 miles northwest of
Evans, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This dangerous storm will be near...
McCormick and Mccormick County Airport around 305 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include Double
Branches, Parksville, Whitetown, Plum Branch, Hawe Creek Campground,
New Hope, Knox Scout Reservation, Cherokee Boat Ramp, Woodlawn and
Clay Hill Campground.
Instruction:

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
At 250 PM EDT, a confirmed tornado was located 8 miles east of
Moultrie, moving northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornado will be near...
Adel, Sparks and Lenox around 305 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include Reed
Bingham State Park, Cook Co A/P, Cool Spring, Staunton, Pineboro,
Ellenton, Berlin, Barneyville, Laconte and Flat Ford.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a
basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.
Alert:
Very warm temperatures and rainfall will have river levels on
the rise over the next few days. Low pressure tracking near the
Canadian border is expected to bring up to an 1 inch of rain
through Tuesday morning. The rain combined with snowmelt could
lead to minor river flooding.
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of Maine and northern New Hampshire, including the
following areas, in Maine, Androscoggin, Central Somerset,
Kennebec, Northern Franklin, Northern Oxford, Southern
Franklin, Southern Oxford, and Southern Somerset. In northern
New Hampshire, Northern Carroll, Northern Coos, Northern
Grafton, Southern Carroll, Southern Coos, and Southern
Grafton.

* From Monday morning through Tuesday morning

* Rainfall and snowmelt may lead to minor river flooding.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
The areas affected include...
Coastal waters from Altamaha Sound to Fernandina Beach FL out 20
NM...
Coastal waters from Fernandina Beach to St. Augustine FL out 20
NM...

At 249 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated a shower, capable of producing
winds to around 30 knots. This shower was located near Amelia City,
or 32 nm south of St. Simons Island, moving northeast at 25 knots.
Instruction:
Mariners can expect gusty winds to around 30 knots, locally higher
waves, and lightning strikes. Boaters should seek safe harbor
immediately until this storm passes.
Alert:
Poteau River near Panama affecting Le Flore County.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Poteau River near Panama.
* until Monday morning, or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 1:30 PM Sunday, the stage was 28.50 feet.
* Flood stage is 29.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The Poteau River near Panama is expected to rise above
flood stage this evening and continue to rise to near 29.2 feet by
Monday before dawn. The river is expected to fall below flood stage
early Monday morning.
* Impact...At 29.0 feet, minor agricultural flooding occurs.
Instruction:

Alert:
Mississinewa River...Wabash River...White River...


.Lowland flooding began on the Wabash River late this Sunday
morning at Riverton in southwest Indiana.  Lowland flooding will
develop this week along much of the rest of the river as well as on
the White River south of Indianapolis.  Brief flooding on
the Mississinewa in the vicinity of Ridgeville is
expected today.  Smaller rivers and creeks may also go
into flood briefly through Sunday night.  Significant flooding is
not expected on any central and southern Indiana area rivers.

Rainfall from two separate storm systems is the cause of the
flooding.  System number one was this past Thursday night and
Friday morning with up to 1.75 inches, heaviest from southwestern
Indiana to north central Indiana.  System two, currently moving
through, brought as much as 1.70 inches of rain through 1 PM EDT,
heaviest from southwest Indiana to the Indianapolis area.  Up to
three tenths of an inch more of rain is expected between 1 PM and
when it ends Sunday evening.

Dry weather is forecast for Monday and Tuesday, a negligible amount
of rain Wednesday morning, then potentially substantial rainfall
Wednesday night through Thursday night and lighter amounts
continuing into Friday night.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Petersburg.
* from Monday afternoon to Monday April 22.
* At  1:30 PM Sunday the stage was 13.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 18.6 feet by Saturday afternoon.  It will fall
below flood stage by Monday April 22.
* At 19.0 feet...Low bottomlands flood and flooding begins on higher
bottomlands.  State Road 257 may begin to flood if Shoals gage
reading is over 17 feet.  Private levees may be overtopped in many
cases.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Mount Carmel.
* from Tuesday evening to Monday April 22.
* At 12:45 PM Sunday the stage was 15.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday evening and continue
to rise to near 19.6 feet by Sunday April 21.  It will fall below
flood stage by Monday April 22.
* At 20.0 feet...River is bankfull in all locations.  All oil field
production ceases with the exception of pumping units on
substructures.  Access to these are by boat only.  Agricultural
losses increase dramatically.  Farmers move livestock to higher
ground.  City of Mount Carmel leaves flood gates B and C in year
round.

through, brought as much as 1.70 inches of rain through 1 PM EDT,

three tenths of an inch more of rain is expected between 1 PM and
when it ends Sunday evening.

Dry weather is forecast for Monday and Tuesday, a negligible amount
of rain Wednesday morning, then potentially substantial rainfall
Wednesday night through Thursday night and lighter amounts
continuing into Friday night.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Edwardsport.
* from Tuesday morning to Sunday April 21.
* At  1:00 PM Sunday the stage was 12.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 18.2 feet by Thursday afternoon.  It will fall
below flood stage by Sunday April 21.
* At 18.0 feet...Old Vincennes Road and State Road 358 in Daviess
County and Schaefer Road in Knox County are impassable.  High water
affects agricultural bottomlands.  During agricultural season this
level is of concern to farmers on the unprotected areas along the
river.  High water affects river cabins.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
Mississinewa River...Wabash River...White River...


.Lowland flooding began on the Wabash River late this Sunday
morning at Riverton in southwest Indiana.  Lowland flooding will
develop this week along much of the rest of the river as well as on
the White River south of Indianapolis.  Brief flooding on
the Mississinewa in the vicinity of Ridgeville is
expected today.  Smaller rivers and creeks may also go
into flood briefly through Sunday night.  Significant flooding is
not expected on any central and southern Indiana area rivers.

Rainfall from two separate storm systems is the cause of the
flooding.  System number one was this past Thursday night and
Friday morning with up to 1.75 inches, heaviest from southwestern
Indiana to north central Indiana.  System two, currently moving
through, brought as much as 1.70 inches of rain through 1 PM EDT,
heaviest from southwest Indiana to the Indianapolis area.  Up to
three tenths of an inch more of rain is expected between 1 PM and
when it ends Sunday evening.

Dry weather is forecast for Monday and Tuesday, a negligible amount
of rain Wednesday morning, then potentially substantial rainfall
Wednesday night through Thursday night and lighter amounts
continuing into Friday night.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Elliston.
* from Monday afternoon to Saturday morning.
* At  9:00 AM Sunday the stage was 15.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 21.2 feet by Wednesday afternoon.  It will fall
below flood stage by Friday evening.
* At 21.0 feet...Eastern portion of CR 100 S in Greene County floods
leading to Plummer. Flooding covers all low bottomlands.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

click on rivers and lakes.

Alert:
Barton River At Coventry
The Flood Warning continues for
The Barton River At Coventry.
* At  2:30 PM Sunday the stage was 8.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 8.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Impact...At 8.0 feet...Maple Street and River Road between Orleans
and Coventry Station will flood. There will be extensive field and
lowland flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in BLACKSBURG has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Southeastern Surry County in northwestern North Carolina...
Central Yadkin County in northwestern North Carolina...

* Until 315 PM EDT

* At 245 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located over Brooks Crossroads, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* Locations impacted include...
Fairview...
Yadkinville...
Pilot Mountain...
Boonville...
and Nebo.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Alert:
At 245 PM EDT, a confirmed tornado was located near Moultrie, moving
northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornado will be near...
Adel, Sparks and Lenox around 305 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by this tornadic thunderstorm include Reed
Bingham State Park, Cook Co A/P, Cool Spring, Staunton, Pineboro,
Ellenton, Autreyville, Berlin, Barneyville and Flat Ford.
Instruction:
To repeat, a tornado is on the ground. TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a
basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in
a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect
yourself from flying debris.

Alert:
A storm system will move through NorCal Monday into early
Tuesday. Snow is expected to begin over the Sierra during the
late morning hours Monday and increase in intensity during the
afternoon. Snow will diminish Tuesday morning.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on difficult travel conditions,
including during the afternoon commute on Monday. Total snow
accumulations of 6 to 10 inches, with localized amounts over a
foot, are expected.

* WHERE...Western Plumas County/Lassen Park and West Slope
Northern Sierra Nevada including Interstate 80 over Donner
Pass, Highway 50 over Echo Summit and Highway 88 over Carson
Pass.

* WHEN...11 AM Monday to 11 AM Tuesday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Be prepared for snow covered
roads and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.
The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...Wind and or wave conditions will be hazardous
to small craft.
Instruction:
During a Small Craft Advisory, inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in
hazardous conditions.

* WAVES...Building 1 to 2 feet.

* TIMING...The strongest winds will be this afternoon, then
again behind a cold front after midnight.

create hazardous conditions for small craft.
Instruction:
Mariners on Lake Moultrie should use extra caution since strong
winds and rough waves can overturn small craft.
