Alert:
Mississinewa River...

.Lowland flooding will be developing this Sunday afternoon in
the vicinity of Ridgeville on the Mississinewa River as a result
of rainfall overnight and during the day today.  Significant
flooding is not expected.

Rain will be coming to an end tonight followed by dry weather for a
couple days.  More rain later this week may bring a return to the
flooding.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the Mississinewa River near Ridgeville.
* until Monday morning.
* At 2:00 PM Sunday the stage was 10.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by this afternoon and continue to
rise to near 10.9 feet by this evening.  It will fall below flood
stage by late tonight.
* At 11.0 feet...Lowland agricultural flooding along CR 100 W just
north of the river.  High water affecting a small portion of River
Road just east of SR 1 and north of the river.  Water is within a
few feet vertically of the approaches to SR 1 bridge in western
Randolph county.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Cowleech Fork Sabine River at Greenville.
* At 1245 PM Sunday the stage was 14.46 feet.
* Flood stage is 14 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and is forecast to end Sunday
afternoon.
* Forecast...The river has crested and will continue to recede and
fall below flood stage by Sunday afternoon.
* At 14 feet, Minor out of bank flooding will occur along the river
reach.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.
Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Stay tuned to NOAA All Hazards Radio for the latest river forecasts.

driving difficult, especially for high profile vehicles. Use

Alert:
At 220 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 7 miles south of
Pickens, or near Norris, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Minor hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind
damage to trees and power lines.

Locations impacted include...
Easley, Pickens, Central, Liberty, Norris, Six Mile, Rosman, Jocassee
Gorges, Dupont State Forest and Table Rock State Park.
Instruction:
Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

Scattered trees and power lines will be blown down in the warned
area. Seek shelter inside an interior room.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

Craft Advisory, which is in effect until 6 PM CDT this evening.

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free

building.

mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

This thunderstorm is capable of producing all types of severe weather
including extremely large hail, destructive straight line winds and
tornadoes. Move quickly to a safe shelter, such as an interior room,
a bathroom or closet or basement.

snow will end between 1 pm and 2 pm with little additional
accumulation.

surfaces.

Illinois will exit the region early this afternoon. Snow has ended
over all but portions of Bureau and Putnam Counties, where light
snow will end between 1 pm and 2 pm with little additional
accumulation.
Light snow will end early this afternoon with little additional
accumulation. Rising temperatures will melt most of the snow
accumulations on paved surfaces.
Instruction:

Alert:
The fast moving late season storm system that brought a swath
heavy wet snow across portions of west central and northwest
Illinois will exit the region early this afternoon. Snow has ended
over all but portions of Bureau and Putnam Counties, where light
snow will end between 1 pm and 2 pm with little additional
accumulation.
Light snow will end between 1 pm and 2 pm this afternoon with
little additional accumulation. Rising temperatures will melt most
of the snow accumulations on paved surfaces by 3 pm.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in BLACKSBURG has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
North central Surry County in northwestern North Carolina...
Southeastern Carroll County in southwestern Virginia...
Southwestern Patrick County in southwestern Virginia...

* Until 215 PM EDT

* At 151 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Mountain Park, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* Locations impacted include...
Mount Airy...
Flat Rock...
Dobson...
Ararat...
and Cana.
Instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Lakeshore Flood Warning, which is in effect until 8 PM EDT
Monday. The Lakeshore Flood Advisory is no longer in effect.

* Lakeshore Flooding...Sustained east northeast wind near 30 mph
with higher gusts will continue through mid afternoon along the
western shoreline of Lake Erie. Although wind speed will begin
to diminish by 4 PM, continued onshore flow from the northeast
will support an ongoing flooding threat, especially from Luna
Pier to Maumee Bay.

* Impacts...At 130 PM water levels at Toledo, Fermi, and Gibraltar
were 82, 72, and 68 inches above chart datum respectively.
Additional rises will be possible through 4 PM before wind
begins to turn northerly and weaken. The greatest flooding
potential will be between Luna Pier and the Ohio border.
Instruction:
To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org

A Lakeshore Flood Warning means that flooding is occurring or
imminent along the lake. Residents on or near the shore in the
warned area should be alert for rising water...and take
appropriate action to protect life and property.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety
Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...Northeast wind will continue to
strengthen today, peaking near 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph
this evening. Wind will then switch gradually to the north
overnight and remain strong into Monday morning. These winds
will lead to very high waves as well as a general increase in
the lake water level.

* Impacts...The high waves and rising water level will lead to
significant beach erosion in some areas and localized
lakeshore flooding from this afternoon into tonight before
gradually improving on Monday morning.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds will
generate flooding of low areas along the lakeshore.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org
Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...Although water levels at Essexville have
plateaued in the short term, northeast winds up to 35 mph with
higher gusts are still forecast to develop and persist from 4 PM
through midnight. The persistent onshore flow and elevated
waves will result in flooding along the immediate lakeshore.


* Impacts...The water level at Essexville was 52 inches above
chart datum at 130 PM and is expected to begin steadily
increasing no later than 5 PM. The water level is then forecast
to exceed 60 inches during the evening with a low potential to
reach 70 inches before wind begins to weaken and turn northerly
after midnight. The increased water level, along with high wave
action, will result in flooding of the lakeshore and may damage
suceptible structures along the shoreline.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Warning means that flooding is occurring or
imminent along the lake. Residents on or near the shore in the
warned area should be alert for rising water...and take
appropriate action to protect life and property.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org

Instruction:

Alert:
* Lakeshore Flooding...East to northeast wind will gust up to 35
mph today over western Lake Erie. The strong wind will lead to
rising water levels and elevated wave action through early
afternoon. The water level will then peak during mid-afternoon
as the wind direction becomes northerly.

* Impacts...The water level will peak near 70 inches above chart
datum along the Wayne County shoreline in and near Gibraltar
during mid afternoon, decreasing thereafter as winds turn
northerly and weaken after 4 PM.
Instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds will
generate flooding of low areas along the lakeshore.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit www.weather.gov/safety

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org

The National Weather Service in Tallahassee has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Apalachee Bay or Coastal Waters From Keaton Beach to Ochlockonee
River Fl out to 20 Nm...
Coastal Waters From  Ochlockonee River to Apalachicola FL out to 20
Nm...

Waters from Mexico Beach to Apalachicola FL from 20 to 60 NM...
Waters from Suwannee River to Apalachicola FL from 20 to 60 NM...

* Until 315 PM EDT/215 PM CDT/.

* At 148 PM EDT/1248 PM CDT/, severe thunderstorms capable of
producing waterspouts were located along a line extending from 8 nm
northwest of C Tower to 17 nm south of S Tower to 60 nm south of
Empire Mica Wreck, moving northeast at 40 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can quickly form and capsize boats...damage
vessels...and create suddenly higher waves. Make sure all
on board are in a secure location and wearing life
jackets. Expect wind gusts in excess of 34
knots...suddenly higher waves...frequent lightning...and
heavy downpours. Make sure all on board are wearing life
jackets.

* Locations impacted include...
Buckeye Reef, O Tower, K Tower, S Tower, V Tower, Apalachicola, C
Tower, St George Island and Marker 24 Barge.
Instruction:
Move to safe harbor until hazardous weather passes.

Frequent lightning is occurring with these storms. If caught on the
open water stay below deck if possible, keep away from ungrounded
metal objects.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northwestern Moore County in central North Carolina...
Southeastern Randolph County in central North Carolina...
Northwestern Lee County in central North Carolina...
Southwestern Chatham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 230 PM EDT

* At 148 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 7 miles southeast
of Biscoe, or 12 miles east of Troy, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Siler City, Goldston, Robbins, Seven Lakes, Cumnock, Harpers
Crossroads, Highfalls, Coleridge, Eagle Springs and Hasty.
Instruction:
Straight line winds can blow down trees, power lines, and damage
mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

This thunderstorm is capable of producing all types of severe weather
including extremely large hail, destructive straight line winds and
tornadoes. Move quickly to a safe shelter such as an interior room, a
bathroom, closet or basement.
Alert:
At 146 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from 20 miles west of Crawfordville to 14 miles north of
Carrabelle to 11 miles north of Eastpoint, moving east at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
East Camp, Jewel Fire Tower, Poplar Camp and Smith Creek.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Continuous cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms.
Move indoors immediately. Lightning is one of nature's leading
killers. Remember, if you can hear thunder, you are close enough to
be struck by lightning.
Alert:
The Severe Thunderstorm Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden
Counties
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County


Rainfall totals tonight into Monday could range from 0.75 to 1.25
inches. Warm temperatures over Northern New England this weekend will
result in snow melt of an existing snow pack. The combination of
rainfall tonight into Monday and snow melt could result in sharp rises
on the lower Connecticut River through Tuesday. The lower Connecticut
River is vulnerable to river gauges potentially reaching and exceeding
flood stage levels late Monday night around and after Midnight at
Montague and Northampton, then later Tuesday afternoon/evening at
Thompsonville, Hartford and Middle Haddam. Therefore a river flood
watch has been issued for the lower Connecticut River.
The National Weather Service in Boston/Norton, MA has issued a
* Flood Watch for
The Connecticut River At Thompsonville
* from Tuesday evening to late Tuesday night.
* At 12:30 PM Sunday the stage was 12.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is possible.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Forecast...Flood stage may be reached by Tuesday evening.
* Impact...At 15.0 feet...Lowland flooding will begin along the
Connecticut River near Thompsonville.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Observed river stages are courtesy of the U.S.
Geological Survey and other cooperating agencies. Please stay tuned
to NOAA Weather Radio or your local television or radio stations for
the latest information on this river flood event.

The National Weather Service in Boston/Norton, MA has issued a
* Flood Watch for
The Connecticut River At Hartford
* from Tuesday afternoon until further notice.
* At 12:30 PM Sunday the stage was 11.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is possible.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Forecast...Flood stage may be reached by Tuesday early afternoon.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Flooding of low lying areas below Hartford
is expected, especially in areas that are outside of levee
protection. Flooding also affects low lying areas upstream of
Hartford, including a portion of Windsor where the Farmington River
empties into the Connecticut River. Further downstream flooding is
expected in low lying sections along the Connecticut River from
Wethersfield and Glastonbury downstream through Cromwell,
Middletown and Portland. Boating interests should prepare for swift
river flows.

* Wind...Southwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 35 mph.

* Humidity...Around 10 percent.

* Fuels...Mostly dry, but mixed with some greening of new fuels
in areas.

* Impacts...Any fires that develop can spread rapidly. Outdoor
burning is discouraged.

are imminent or already occurring. These conditions can create
rapid wildfire growth.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has issued a

* Flood Advisory for Minor Flooding in Poor Drainage Areas for...
Rain and Snowmelt in...
Southeastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 945 PM EDT.

* At 350 PM EDT, local law enforcement reported rain and snowmelt
causing minor flooding in Bridgewater. Overflowing poor drainage
areas will result in minor flooding that has affected Packard Road
and could impact Route 1 this evening.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Bridgewater.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-
5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You may also contact
local law enforcement.

Big Blue River near Blue Rapids affecting Marshall County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At  2:15 PM Monday the stage was 40.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 41.3 feet by
Friday early afternoon. Additional rises may be possible
thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

Stay tuned to later developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio
and local media.

Alert:
The Flood Watch continues for

* All of Vermont except Grand Isle, Bennington and Windham
counties

* Through Tuesday morning.

* The combination of rain and snow melt will continue to cause
river flooding on area waterways. Sharp river rises have already
occurred, and most main stem rivers are expected to crest later
this afternoon and evening before receding overnight.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the weekend and
into Monday.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.

The National Weather Service in Grand Forks has extended the

* Flood Warning for...
Snowmelt in...
Southwestern Marshall County in northwestern Minnesota...
Western Clay County in northwestern Minnesota...
Western Norman County in northwestern Minnesota...
Western Polk County in northwestern Minnesota...
Eastern Cass County in southeastern North Dakota...
Eastern Traill County in southeastern North Dakota...

* Until 300 PM CDT Thursday.

* At 238 PM CDT, emergency management reported overland flooding was
occurring due to snowmelt.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Fargo, Moorhead, West Fargo, East Grand Forks, Crookston, Dilworth
and Horace.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 29 between mile markers 49 and 111, and between mile
markers 114 and 122.
Interstate 94 in North Dakota between mile markers 337 and 352.
Interstate 94 in Minnesota between mile markers 1 and 16.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Excessive runoff from snowmelt will cause flooding of small creeks
and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low lying spots.

Alert:
* WINDS...Northeast 15 to 25 knots becoming west and decreasing
this evening.

* WAVES...5 to 8 feet subsiding to 2 to 4 feet tonight.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory is issued when waves of 4 feet or more are
expected or wind speeds reach 21 to 33 knots which may produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should stay in port
during these conditions.
Alert:
An area of high pressure will build into the southern
Appalachians overnight producing clear sky, light wind, and chilly
temperatures. Areas of frost are expected by early Tuesday
morning.
The National Weather Service in Morristown has issued a Frost
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 AM to 8 AM EDT Tuesday.

* TEMPERATURES...As low as 35.

* TIMING...From midnight through 8 am Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation that
is left unprotected.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be damaged or killed if left
unprotected.

Alert:
* WINDS...West winds 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 40 kt.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means sustained winds or frequent gusts of 34 to
47 kt are expected or occurring. Operating a vessel in gale
conditions requires experience and properly equipped vessels. It
is highly recommended that mariners without the proper experience
seek safe harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
* WINDS...West 15 to 30 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.

* TIMING...Through 2 AM EDT Tuesday with the strongest winds
through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. Scattered power outages are expected.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory is issued when sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph,
or gusts of 46 to 57 mph, are expected or occurring. Winds this
strong can make driving difficult, especially for high profile
vehicles, in open areas, and on elevated roads and bridges. Use
extra caution.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Northeastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 315 PM EDT Tuesday.

* At 318 PM EDT, river gauge reports at Washburn indicated a river
level of 15.27 feet which is above flood stage.  Ice jams in place
near Washburn and Crouseville and continued river rises will cause
low land flooding in the warned area.

The combination of pre-existing ice jams and continued snowmelt will
result in a slow rise of river levels through at least Wednesday or
until the ice jam releases.  Those residents who are impacted by
flooding in Washburn, Wade and Crouseville along the Aroostook River
should closely watch the river levels over the coming days due to
the increased flood threat.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Crouseville, Washburn and Wade.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become
unstable and unsafe.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-
5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You may also contact
local law enforcement.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Grand Forks has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Snowmelt in...
Southwestern Marshall County in northwestern Minnesota...
Western Clay County in northwestern Minnesota...
Western Norman County in northwestern Minnesota...
Western Polk County in northwestern Minnesota...
Eastern Cass County in southeastern North Dakota...
Eastern Traill County in southeastern North Dakota...

* Until 300 PM CDT.

* At 225 PM CDT, overland flooding was occurring due to snowmelt.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Fargo, Moorhead, West Fargo, East Grand Forks, Crookston, Dilworth
and Horace.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 29 between mile markers 49 and 111, and between mile
markers 114 and 122.
Interstate 94 in North Dakota between mile markers 337 and 352.
Interstate 94 in Minnesota between mile markers 1 and 16.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Excessive runoff from snowmelt will cause flooding of small creeks
and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low lying spots.

Alert:
The areas affected include...
Boston Harbor...
Massachusetts Bay and Ipswich Bay...

At 322 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated an area of showers and
thunderstorms, capable of producing winds up to 25 to 30 knots. The
precipitation was located along a line extending from 11 nm
northwest of Lynn to 6 nm south of Patience Island, moving east at
30 knots.

Locations impacted include...
Eastern Point Ma, Mass Bay Buoy 44029, Boston Light, Sandy Bay,
Marblehead Neck, Broad Sound, Minot Light, Green Harbor, Ocean
Bluff-Brant Rock, Gurnet Point, Boston Harbor, Beverly Harbor, Boston
Buoy 44013, Ipswich Bay, Plymouth Light, Duxbury Pier Light, Essex
Bay and Scituate Harbor.
Instruction:

lightning strikes. Consider heading for safe harbor until these
storms pass.

Southwestern Caledonia County in northeastern Vermont...
Orange County in central Vermont...
Rutland County in southern Vermont...
Windsor County in southern Vermont...

* Until 900 PM EDT.

* At 305 PM EDT, emergency management officials reported flooding
ongoing across much of southern Vermont. There are numerous road
closures with a detailed listing found through VT 511. A large
area of southern Vermont recieved between one to three inches of
rain with another few tenths possible this afternoon. Many of the
smaller streams and tributaries are exceeding bank full and are
expected to crest in the next two to three hours.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Rutland, Chester, Woodstock, Braintree Hill, Bradford, Killington,
Rutland City, Rutland - Southern Vermont Airport, Pomfret,
Hartland, Ira, Fairlee, Mount Holly, Sharon, Washington,
Shrewsbury, Newbury, Danby, Williamstown and Bridgewater.

and are expected to crest this evening. Additional flood waters are
moving through the Wells River near Wells River, VT.

Alert:
A tightening pressure gradient between an exiting low pressure
system to the north and high pressure to the south will allow for
gusty northwest winds today across the northern mountains in
North Carolina.
* LOCATIONS...the northern mountains of North Carolina.

* HAZARDS...Very windy conditions.

* TIMING...Stronger gusts expected through the morning hours.

* WINDS...Northwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects.
Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may
result.
Instruction:

this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

can be found at www.weather.gov/gsp.

Instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now...or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures will
create favorable weather for rapid fire growth and spread. Avoid
activities that promote open flames and sparks.
Alert:
The Small Craft Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Alert:
At 137 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Coventry, or near Vernon, moving east at 30 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph will accompany this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Manchester, Glastonbury, Vernon, Mansfield, Windham, Plainfield,
Willimantic, Killingly, Ellington, Tolland, Coventry, Stafford,
Hebron, Putnam, Thompson, Brooklyn, Woodstock, Willington, Columbia
and Canterbury.
Instruction:
Get indoors when this storm approaches. Winds may be strong enough to
produce minor damage, such as a few downed branches.
Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
Otter Creek At Center Rutland
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

Alert:
* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.

* WINDS...34 to 47 knots within the Gale Warning.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and a properly equipped vessel. Recreational boaters
should seek safe harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Neches River Near Alto, Texas.
* until Wednesday evening...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 11:15 AM Monday The stage was 16.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 16 feet.
* Forecast...The river will fall below flood stage by Tuesday morning.
Also the Neches River near Alto crested near 17 feet during
yesterday, Sunday evening.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau...Thebes and New Madrid

.Recent heavy rainfall will cause river levels on the Mississippi River
to rise. Moderate flooding is expected to continue at Cape Girardeau and
Thebes with crests expected Thursday at both locations. The river
at New Madrid is expected to rise above minor flood stage Wednesday and
crest near 35.5 feet on Friday.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at New Madrid.
* from late Tuesday night to Wednesday April 24.
* At 12:00 PM Monday the stage was 32.4 feet.
* Flood Stage is 34.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by early Wednesday morning and
continue to rise to near 35.5 feet by Friday morning. The river
will fall below flood stage by early Wednesday, April 24.
* Impact...At 34.0 Feet...Minor flooding occurs affecting mainly
bottomland and surrounding low lying areas.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Baltimore MD/Washington has
issued a Frost Advisory, which is in effect from 2 AM to 9 AM EDT
Tuesday.

* TIMING...Through 5 PM this afternoon for the wind advisory. Late
tonight into early Tuesday morning for the frost advisory.

* TEMPERATURES...Falling to the mid 30s.

* WINDS...West 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines this afternoon. Scattered power outages are expected this
afternoon. Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation late
tonight.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

A Wind Advisory means that winds of 45 to 55 mph are expected.
Winds this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles.

Shelby Counties
Mississippi River at Helena affecting Lee...Phillips...Coahoma and
Tunica Counties
The Flood Advisory is extended for
the Mississippi River at Memphis
* until Sunday April 28.
* At 12 PM Monday the stage was 29.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 34.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 33.0 feet Sunday April 21.
* At 33.0 feet...In Memphis, Rivergate Drive could begin to flood
north of the rail yards. In Arkansas, settlement at Blue Lake is
flooded. Most all secondary roads east of the Arkansas Levee are
covered.

The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Tunica Riverpark
* until Sunday April 28.
* At 10 AM Monday the stage was 42.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring AND Minor flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 45.0 feet on Sunday April 21.
* Flood stage is 41.0 feet.
* The river is above flood stage and will continue rising to near
45.0 feet by Sunday April 21. The river will fall below flood stage
Sunday April 28.
* At 45.0 feet...In Mississippi, boat launch parking lot at Charlie's
Camp is covered. Campbell Road in is partly flooded. Northeast end
of Betty Lane is going under. Part of Bourbon Street is flooded.
Spoonbill Lane is going under water. Valley Lane is flooded in
Lakeview Camp. Road to houses south of Ship Island is being
covered.

The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Osceola
* until Saturday April 27.
* At 11 AM Monday the stage was 28.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring AND Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 32.0 feet on Saturday April 20.
* Flood stage is 28.0 feet.
* The river is above flood stage and will continue rising to near
32.0 feet by Saturday April 20. The river will fall below flood
stage Saturday April 27.
* At 32.0 feet...In Tennessee, Kirkpatrick and Snyder Bluff Roads are
flooding. Backwater has reached the west leg of Crutcher Lake Road
south of Keyes Point. Outbounds Road is covering up. South end of
Jim Fullen Road is flooded. River water is covering parts of
Ballard Slough Road and Ruleman Road. Fields and pastures west of
Herring Hill road are inundated. West end of Corona Road begins to
flood. In Arkansas, Sans Souci Road elevator floods.

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay.
* until Saturday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 7:00 AM Monday the stage was estimated at 3.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 4.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to flood stage this evening and flucuate
around flood stage for the next several days due to tidal effects.
* Impact...At stages near 5.0 feet...Water over lowest portions of
Goos Ferry Road. Cars should be moved to higher ground.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Minor flooding of Goos Ferry
Road will occur.
* Impact...At stages near 3.5 feet...Ponding of water on low spots
along Goos Ferry Road will occur.

* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.

Friday evening.

Alert:
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River Near Kinder
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Texas..

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Atchafalaya River At Morgan City.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 11:00 AM Monday the stage was 7.9 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 8.0 feet by early
Friday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At stages near 7.0 feet...Buildings at the foot of Ann
Street on the river side of the flood wall will flood as water
overtops the Rio Oil Company dock. Buildings on the river side of
the Berwick floodwall will flood. River traffic restrictions will
be strictly enforced. In addition, backwater flooding could
potentially impact portions areas around Lake Palourde and
Stephensville.
* Impact...At stages near 6.0 feet...Flood stage. The city dock will
be under water. Water will cover the lower end of Belleview Front
Street in Berwick. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger
river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly
enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 5.0 feet...Floodwall gates will be closed
to protect against higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected
by stronger river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be
strictly enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Action stage. Water will move
up the bank and across access roads below the city dock. Floodwall
gates should be closed by the 5 foot stage to protect against
higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger river
current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly enforced
by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Instruction:

Alert:
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River Near Kinder
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Texas..

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier.
* from Wednesday morning to Thursday evening...or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At  6:00 AM Monday the stage was 2.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 4.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to flood stage Wednesday morning and
fluctuate near flood near flood stage.
* Impact...At stages near 4.5 feet...Water covers portions of River
Road in north Lake Charles.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Minor marshland flooding
occurs. Flooding also begins on River Road in north Lake Charles.
Instruction:

Alert:
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River Near Kinder
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Texas..

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River Near Glenmora.
* until late Friday night...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:45 AM Monday the stage was 13.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Friday evening.
* Impact...At stages near 14.0 feet...Some roads upstream from
Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the community of
Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have two to three
feet of water over the road and are subject to being closed.
Flooding of forested areas near the river will also occur.
* Impact...At stages near 12.0 feet...When the river is rising and
the gauge reading is forecast to reach 12 feet or higher. Roads
upstream from Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the
community of Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have
water on them and are subject to being closed. Also, flooding of
forested areas near the river will occur.
Instruction:

Alert:
Mississippi River Near Arkansas City affecting Chicot...Desha...
Bolivar and Washington Counties
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Mississippi River Near Arkansas City
* from Tuesday afternoon to Sunday afternoon.
* At 11:00 AM Monday the stage was 36.8 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 37.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage Tuesday April 16th
and will continue to rise to near 37.2 feet by Thursday April 18th.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Mississippi River forecasts are based on rainfall that has occurred
and that which is forecast to occur over the next 48 hours.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Alert:
Pearl River Near Pearl River affecting St. Tammany...Hancock and
Pearl River Counties/Parishes
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Mississippi...

Pearl River Near Bogalusa affecting St. Tammany...Washington...
Hancock and Pearl River Counties/Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Bogalusa.
* Until further notice.
* At 11:00 AM Monday the stage was 18.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 20.5 feet by
Friday April 19 then begin falling.
* Impact...At 20.0 feet...Woodlands and crop acreage along the river
will be flooded. The Bogue Chitto Wildlife Management area will be
inundated with water in recreational camps and over access roads.
* Impact...At 18.5 feet...Woodlands and crop acreage along the river
will be flooded. The Bogue Chitto Wildlife Management area will be
inundated with water in recreational camps and over access roads.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Woodlands and crop acreage along the river
will be flooded.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Woodlands along the river and wildlife
management property will be flooded
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.
Alert:
Pearl River Near Pearl River affecting St. Tammany...Hancock and
Pearl River Counties/Parishes
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Mississippi...

Pearl River Near Bogalusa affecting St. Tammany...Washington...
Hancock and Pearl River Counties/Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Pearl River.
* Until further notice.
* At 11:00 AM Monday the stage was 12.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday April 17 and
continue to rise to near 15.5 feet by Sunday April 21.
* Impact...At 15.5 feet...Secondary roads to the river and throughout
Honey Island Swamp are inundated. Property in the vicinity of the
gage is flooded threatening about 20 homes along the left bank. The
Bogue Chitto National Wildlife Refuge will be closed to hunting at
the 15.5 foot stage.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Secondary roads to the river and throughout
Honey Island Swamp are inundated. Property in the vicinity of the
gage is flooded threatening about 20 homes along the left bank.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...The east and west channels of the river will
begin to merge. Honey Island Swamp trails will be under water as
inundation of the swamp begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 57.2 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 57.4 feet by
Sunday April 21 then begin falling.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Baton Rouge.
* Until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Monday the stage was 40.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 35.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 40.3 feet by
Monday April 22 then begin falling.
* Impact...At 40.0 feet...The grounds of the older part of Louisiana
State University's campus become soggy. This includes the area
around the Veterinary Medicine building, the Veterinary Medicine
Annex, the stadium and ball fields. The city of Baton Rouge and the
main LSU campus are protected by levees at this level.
* Impact...At 38.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 36.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 35.0 feet...River islands from Red River Landing
downstream to Baton Rouge will be inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Middle Haddam.
* from Tuesday evening until further notice...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 11:55 AM Monday the stage was 6.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by Tuesday evening.
The river is forecast to rise to 9.1 feet by Wednesday evening.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...Flooding closes most of Meadow Road, Route
17A, in the Gildersleeve section of Portland. Flooding impacts the
Middletown Marina and Meadow Farms. In Cromwell, portions of River
Road will be closed. In Rocky Hill, parts of Meadow Road will be
impassable for a time. Flooding continues along the river southward
through Essex.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
the Cuivre River at Old Monroe
* until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Monday the stage was 28.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue rising to near 28.2 feet by this
afternoon. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:
* Winds...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 55 mph.

* Timing...This afternoon and tonight. Strongest winds are
expected late this afternoon and this evening.

* Impacts...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. Isolated to Scattered power outages are possible. Travel
could be difficult especially for high profile vehicles.

* Location...Mohawk Valley, Capital District, Schoharie Valley,
eastern Catskills, mid Hudson Valley, Taconics, Berkshires and
northwestern Connecticut.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph are
expected, with gusts between 46 to 57 mph. Winds this strong are
capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

* At 11:00 AM Monday the stage was 21.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to a stage of 21.6 feet
by tomorrow morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Ouachita River At Columbia, Louisiana.
* from this morning until further notice...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 6:00 AM Monday The pool stage was 64.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 65 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage late this Monday morning and continue
to rise to near 65.5 feet by Tuesday evening. Additional rises
remain possible thereafter.
* Impact...at 65.0 feet...The Riverton recreational area floods and
must be closed. In addition, expect minor flooding of lowland river
bottoms.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Ouachita River At Felsenthal Lock and Dam, Arkansas.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:30 AM Monday The pool stage was 78.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 70 feet.
* Forecast...Little change through at least Tuesday evening.
* Impact...at 80.0 feet...Flooding of low lying areas in the
Felsenthal Wildlife Refuge will continue for at least another three
weeks.

the Ouachita River At Monroe, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.

* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 40 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 43.8 feet by this
Monday evening and then change little through at least Tuesday
evening.
* Impact...at 43.0 feet...The Bawcomville and Moon Lake recreational
areas flood and close.

Alert:
* WINDS...Becoming S and increasing to 15 to 25 kt today.

* WAVES...Short period SW waves building to 3 to 5 ft at 6
seconds, along with W to NW swell 6 to 8 ft at 13 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS...SW 10 to 20 kt shifting to W tonight.

* WAVES...Short period SW waves building to 5 to 7 ft at 7
seconds, along with W to NW swell 6 to 8 ft at 13 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous wave conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS...S to SW increasing to 15 to 25 kt with brief gusts up to
35 kt today, becoming W and easing to 10 to 20 kt this evening.

* WAVES...Short period SW waves building to 5 to 7 ft at 7
seconds, along with W to NW swell 6 to 8 ft at 13 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana..

Boeuf River Near Fort Necessity affecting Franklin Parish
The Flood Warning continues for
The Boeuf River Near Fort Necessity
* until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 55.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 50.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 55.5 feet
by tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At 55.0 feet...Several thousand acres of farm and
agricultural land are inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Wisconsin...

Fox River Near Berlin affecting Green Lake County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Fox River Near Berlin.
* At  9:00 AM Monday the stage was 13.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.3 feet by this
afternoon. The river will then slowly fall into next week.
* Impact...At 13.3 feet...There is minor flooding in the Berlin area
including in Riverside and Webster Street Parks in Berlin.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
Ouachita River At Camden affecting Calhoun and Ouachita Counties

Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D affecting Bradley...Calhoun and
Union Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:30 AM Monday the stage was 86.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 79.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 86.1 feet. Additional heavy
rain is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday, please be sure to monitor
future forecasts for any updates.
* Impacts at 85.0 feet...There may be some County roads along the
river flooded, requiring lengthy detours. River is high and swift,
boaters should be very cautious. Access to many oil and gas rigs
will be by boat only. Levee gates should be closed.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Cache River Near Patterson.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 9.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 9.5 feet by
Wednesday evening. Additional heavy rain is forecast on Wednesday
and Thursday, please be sure to monitor future forecasts for any
updates.
* Impacts at 10.0 feet...Pastureland and cropland not protected by
levees in Jackson and Woodruff counties affected. Water is over
portions of State Highway 37 and deep along the shoulders of State
Highway 18 near Grubbs. Water over portions of Woodruff County Road
775 north of State Highway 260.

Alert:
* WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 55 mph.

* TIMING...through Monday evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. Scattered power outages are possible.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph for
more an hour, or wind gusts of 46 to 57 mph for any duration are
expected. Winds this strong can make driving difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
SEE THE COASTAL WATERS FORECAST (CWFLOX) FOR MORE DETAILS.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous wind and sea
conditions will exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
Paint Rock River near Woodville affecting Jackson...Madison and
Marshall Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
the Paint Rock River near Woodville.
* until Tuesday evening.
* At 10 AM Monday the stage was 16.1 feet and rising.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor Flooding is occurring and Minor Flooding is forecast.
* Recent activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at
10 AM Monday was 16.1 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to 16.5 feet by
early this evening. The river will fall below Flood Stage late
tomorrow afternoon.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flood waters affect mostly bottomland along
the river...including low lying farm and pasturelands.
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.3 feet
on Feb 20 2019.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not attempt to drive through a flooded road. The
depth of water is not always obvious. As little as two feet of water
will carry most cars away. Also, the road bed may be washed out under
the water, and you could be stranded or trapped. Additional
information is available at http://water.weather.gov. Once there,
click on the Tennessee Valley to view local river information.
Alert:
Illinois River near Havana affecting Cass...Fulton and Mason
Counties
Illinois River at Beardstown affecting Brown...Cass...Morgan and
Schuyler Counties

.The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation, soil
moisture conditions, and forecast precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Illinois River near Havana.
* Until further notice.
* At 945 AM Monday the stage was 16.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 16.7 feet by
Saturday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, don't drown.

Additional river and weather information is available at
www.weather.gov/ilx.

The Flood Warning continues for
The White River At Clarendon.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 27.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 27.6 feet by
early Wednesday morning. Additional heavy rain is forecast on Wednesday
and Thursday, please be sure to monitor future forecasts for any
updates.
* Impacts at 28.0 feet...Flooding of cropland and timber is occurring.
Roads to homes and cabins in lower Maddox Bay area off Highway 146
south of Clarendon impassible.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Burlington has extended the

* Flood Warning for Small Streams for...
Rain and Snowmelt in...
Northwestern Orange County in central Vermont...
Central Addison County in central Vermont...
Washington County in central Vermont...

* Until 200 PM EDT.

* At 1149 AM EDT, flooding is still ongoing in Berlin, Waterbury,
and along the Mad River. Both the Mad and Dog rivers have crested
from the initial heavy rain last night but still may see rises as
showers move through until 200 PM. The Winooski at Waterbury is
also above flood stage and will continue to flood low lying areas
in Waterbury.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Barre, Montpelier, Plainfield, Waterbury Village, Websterville,
East Montpelier, Waitsfield, Berlin, Fayston, Middlesex, Barre
Town, Northfield Village, Warren, Duxbury, Northfield, Moretown,
Barre City, Waterbury, Roxbury and Williamstown.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low lying
spots.
Alert:
James River At Columbia
James River Near Stratford
James River At Ashton
James River Near Redfield
Turtle Creek At Redfield

.The following river forecasts include forecast precipitation through
the next 24 hours. Any additional future precipitation could affect
the forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The James River At Ashton.
* until further notice.
* At  9:45 AM Monday the stage was 19.3 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 21.5 feet by
Sunday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At 21.0 feet...The main east-west highway begins to flood on the
east bank of the river and the water overtops the bridge 2 miles
south and 1 mile east of Ashton.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Flood waters can be very dangerous. Never drive
across a flooded road. Turn around don't drown!

Stay tuned for further updates by listening to NOAA weather radio...
or your favorite local media.

For additional information...check out our web site at
www.weather.gov/abr...then left click on the Rivers and Lakes link.

The next scheduled statement will be issued Tuesday morning.

Alert:
Embarras River at Lawrenceville affecting Lawrence County

.The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation, soil
moisture conditions, and forecast precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Embarras River at Lawrenceville.
* Until late Wednesday night.
* At 945 AM Monday the stage was 30.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 30.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 31.2 feet by
early tomorrow morning. The river will fall below flood stage
Wednesday evening.
* Impact...At 30.0 feet...Minor agricultural flooding begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, don't drown.

Additional river and weather information is available at
www.weather.gov/ilx.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Observed river stages are courtesy of the U.S.
Geological Survey and other cooperating agencies. Please stay tuned
to NOAA Weather Radio or your local television or radio stations for
the latest information on this river flood event.

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Mississippi..

Yalobusha At Whaley affecting Carroll and Leflore Counties
Yazoo River At Yazoo City affecting Yazoo County
Big Sunflower River At Sunflower affecting Sunflower County
Big Sunflower River Near Anguilla affecting Sharkey County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Yalobusha At Whaley
* until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 22.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 23.0 feet
tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Minor flooding of lowland and agricultural
land is occurring.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Pendleton Oregon has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
A Dam Floodgate Release in...
Northwestern Umatilla County in northeastern Oregon...

* Until 830 AM PDT Tuesday.

* This is a continuation of the flood warning for the lower Mckay
Creek river. At 830 AM PDT, flooding continues below the Mckay
reservoir due to floodgate release. High water levels are expected
to continue through the day and overnight
Instruction:
Stay away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.

A Flood Warning means that flooding is imminent or occurring. All
interested parties should take necessary precautions immediately.

* Flood Advisory for
The Iroquois River at Iroquois, or from Near US-41 downstream to
confluence with Sugar Creek at Watseka.

* At 1000 AM Monday the stage was 15.3 feet.
* Action stage is 17.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 17.2 feet by Tuesday
evening.

April 17.

land begins.

Cherokee County Rescue mobilizes and sets up the flood control
center.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Vermillion River Near Wakonda.
* until further notice.
* At 07AM Monday the stage was estimated at 15.10 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.00 feet.
* Forecast...The river will crest near 17.0 feet by Tuesday April 23
then begin falling.
* At stages near 17.0 feet...Highway 19 south of Centerville is
flooded. Water reaches the bottom of the bridge on 302nd Street east
of Colfax Corner, and many of the levees will start to be overtopped
with approximately 25000 acres flooded between Davis and Vermillion.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not drive cars through flooded areas. the water
depth and road condition may be unsafe.

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Mississippi..

Tibbee Creek Near Tibbee affecting Clay County
Noxubee River At Macon affecting Noxubee County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Noxubee River At Macon
* until Thursday evening.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 31.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 31.3 feet this
afternoon.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Alert:
Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden
Counties
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County


The combination of recent rainfall locally and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin will bring sharp river
rises for the lower Connecticut River. River gauge readings along
the lower Connecticut River will reach and exceed flood stage levels
after Midnight tonight at Montague and Northampton, then during
Tuesday at Thompsonville, Hartford and Middle Haddam.
The National Weather Service in Boston/Norton, MA has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Connecticut River At Hartford.
* from late tonight until further notice...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 10:30 AM Monday the stage was 13.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by early tomorrow
and continue to rise to near 19.7 feet by Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 20.0 feet...Flooding is expected along the river in
portions of Wethersfield, Glastonbury, Rocky Hill and Cromwell. The
high waters and swift flows will disrupt some cross river ferry
services. Upstream of Hartford, flooding will continue to affect
portions of Windsor. Immediate river roads may become impassable in
all of these communities. Further downstream flooding will continue
to overspread sections of Portland, Middletown as well as Chester.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.
Alert:
Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden
Counties
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County


The combination of recent rainfall locally and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin will bring sharp river
rises for the lower Connecticut River. River gauge readings along

The National Weather Service in Boston/Norton, MA has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Connecticut River At Northampton.
* from late tonight to Wednesday morning...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At 11:00 AM Monday the stage was 108.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 112.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by early tomorrow
and continue to rise to near 113.1 feet by tomorrow early
afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage by early Wednesday
morning.
* Impact...At 113.0 feet...Minor flooding will affect portions of
Northampton in the vicinity of the Oxbow and Hadley along Aqua
Vitae Drive. Farming interests in Hatfield outside flood dike
protection will experience flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

* Flood stage is 28.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by tonight and
continue to rise to near 29.0 feet by tomorrow morning. The river
will fall below flood stage by tomorrow afternoon.
* Impact...At 29.0 feet...Flooding of low lying areas is expected
primarily from Montague downstream through Sunderland and Whately.

cancelled.
* At 10:55 AM Monday the stage was 6.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...Flooding closes most of Meadow Road, Route
17A, in the Gildersleeve section of Portland. Flooding impacts the
Middletown Marina and Meadow Farms. In Cromwell, portions of River
Road will be closed. In Rocky Hill, parts of Meadow Road will be
impassable for a time. Flooding continues along the river southward
through Essex.

* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage by tomorrow late
morning and continue to rise to near 15.5 feet by tomorrow evening.
The river will fall below flood stage by late Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flooding impacts low lying areas along the
Connecticut River from the Massachusetts towns of Agawam and
Longmeadow, through the northern Connecticut towns of Suffield and
Enfield.

..The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a flood warning
for the following rivers in New Hampshire...Vermont

Connecticut River Near Dalton affecting Coos and Essex Counties
The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a

* Flood warning for
the Connecticut River Near Dalton
* From this afternoon until further notice.
* At 11 AM the stage was 16.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Forecast to rise above flood stage this afternoon and
continue to rise to near 19.1 feet by tomorrow evening.
* Impact...At 17.5 feet...Lamoureux Road in Maidstone Vermont flooded.

* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flooded areas, it is impossible to know if the
road is safe for travel. Turn around, dont drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA weather radio...or
your favorite local media outlet.

.Recent heavy rains have caused significant rises along the river.

Alert:
Iroquois River near Foresman affecting Newton County
Sugar Creek at Milford affecting Iroquois County

The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation as well
as forecast precipitation 24-48 hours into the future.
