Otter Creek At Center Rutland

Passumpsic River at Passumpsic

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Vermont...
Barton River At Coventry
The Flood Warning continues for
The Winooski River At Waterbury.
* until Tuesday morning...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:45 AM Monday the stage was 419.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 419.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 420.3 feet by
Monday afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage after
midnight Tuesday.
* Impact...At 421.0 feet...Water will approach low lying parking lots
at the Waterbury State Office complex, and Rowe Field in Waterbury
will flood. Downstream in Richmond, Bridge Street at the Winooski
bridge near the Round Church will be inundated, and the Richmond
public park will flood. The river will be out of its banks from
Waterbury downstream through Richmond, with considerable field
flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

* until further notice.

* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will be nearly steady through this week
before beginning a slow fall.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

Alert:
* WINDS...West 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* TIMING...The strongest winds will begin late this afternoon and
continue into tonight.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. Scattered power outages are possible.

* LOCATION...Parts of Eastern Massachusetts and much of Rhode
Island.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph are
expected, with gusts between 46 to 57 mph. Winds this strong are
capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

kt. Seas 3 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

* At 9:15 AM Monday the stage was 20.5 feet and falling.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast: Fall to 20.3 feet Tuesday, then remain nearly steady.
* Impact: At 20.5 feet, water affects Mississippi Drive at Mulberry
Street.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an
alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.
Alert:
Updated flood information for the Mississippi River.

River forecasts include past precipitation and forecast rainfall for
the next 24 hours.

* Until further notice.

* Major flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.

Alert:

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Neches River Near Neches, Texas.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:30 AM Monday The stage was 13.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.7 feet by
Friday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...at 14.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding.  Move livestock and
equipment to higher ground away from the river.

Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
The Clear Boggy Creek near Caney

* until Tuesday morning...or until the warning is cancelled.

* At 9:30 AM Monday the stage was 26.5 feet.

* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.

* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.

* Forecast...A broad crest is occurring on the Clear Boggy Creek and
the creek is forecast to begin falling Monday afternoon. The Clear
Boggy Creek will fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning.

* Impact...At 27.0 feet...Creek levels rise to slightly above
bankfull stages in western Atoka County and the northeastern edge
of Bryan County. High stages on small feeder streams result in even
greater depths to mainstem bottomlands near their points of entry
into Clear Boggy Creek. Only croplands...pastures...and some
secondary rural roads are affected.
Instruction:

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Eagle Creek At Phalanx Station
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Never drive your car through flooded roadways. The water may be
deeper than it appears. Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to NOAA weather radio and other local media for further
details and updates.
Alert:
..The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a flood warning
for the following rivers in New Hampshire...Vermont

Connecticut River At West Lebanon affecting Grafton...Sullivan and
Windsor Counties
The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a

* Flood warning for
the Connecticut River At West Lebanon
* From this afternoon until late tonight.
* At 10 AM the stage was 21.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast to rise above flood stage by late this afternoon and
continue to rise to near 22.2 feet by this evening. The river will
fall below flood stage by this evening.
* Impact...At 22.0 feet...Water starts entering parking lot behind JC
Penny and Kmart..
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flooded areas, it is impossible to know if the
road is safe for travel. Turn around, dont drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA weather radio...or
your favorite local media outlet.
Alert:
Killbuck Creek Near Killbuck
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Killbuck Creek Near Killbuck
* from this evening to Wednesday morning.
* At 11 AM the stage was 14.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by this evening and rise to near
15.4 feet by late tonight. The river will fall below flood stage by
early Wednesday morning.
* At 15.0 feet...Several low lying roads in Holmes County including
Township Roads 91 and 92, and County Roads 621 and 622 are flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Never drive your car through flooded roadways. The water may be
deeper than it appears. Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to NOAA weather radio and other local media for further
details and updates.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
The East Cache Creek near Walters

* until Tuesday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.

* At 9:30 AM Monday the stage was 24.4 feet.

* Moderate flooding is occurring.

* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.

* Forecast...The East Cache Creek is cresting and will begin
falling early Monday afternoon. The East Cache Creek will fall
below flood stage mid Tuesday morning.

* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Valley-wide flooding of croplands...
pastures...and local roads occurs in southern Comanche County and
Cotton County and is accompanied by flood depths up to 3 feet with
swift currents.
Instruction:

Alert:
As much as 14 inches of snow has fallen overnight across the
higher elevations of the Salt and Wyoming Ranges above 9000 feet.
The snowfall has ended so the winter weather advisory has been
allowed to expire.
Instruction:

Alert:
Up to 3 to 4 inches of snow has fallen overnight. The snowfall
has ended so the winter weather advisory has been allowed to
expire.
Instruction:

Alert:
* Hickson...on the Red River...in Cass County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...North Dakota...

* Wahpeton...on the Red River ...in Wilkin and Richland Counties
* Fargo...on the Red River ...in Clay and Cass Counties
* Halstad...on the Red River ...in Norman and Traill Counties
* East Grand Forks...on the Red River ...in Polk and Grand Forks
Counties
* Oslo...on the Red River ...in Marshall...Polk...Grand Forks and
Walsh Counties
* Drayton...on the Red River ...in Kittson...Marshall...Pembina and
Walsh Counties
* Pembina...on the Red River ...in Kittson and Pembina Counties
* Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND) ...in Richland County

.Runoff from gradual snow melt across the region is still expected
to impact the mainstem Red River as temperatures remain above
freezing. A secondary, but smaller, crest and/or a slow decline in
water levels is expected over the next 7 days.

This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Pembina...on the Red River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:30 AM Monday the stage was 44.2 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 49.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 51.0 feet by
Monday mid-morning.  Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 50.0 feet, South end of Airport Road
closes.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Trinity River At Trinidad Affecting Henderson and Navarro Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trinity River At Trinidad.
* At 0900 AM Monday the stage was 32.25 feet.
* Flood stage is 33 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage by
Monday afternoon and crest near 37 feet by Wednesday morning. The
river should fall below flood stage by late Thursday afternoon.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.
Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Stay tuned to NOAA All Hazards Radio for the latest river forecasts.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
The Deep Red Creek near Randlett.

* until Tuesday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.

* At 9:30 AM Monday the stage was 22.5 feet.

* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.

* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.

* Forecast...The Deep Red Creek will continue rising and crest near
22.6 feet early Monday afternoon. The Deep Red Creek will fall
below flood stage late Tuesday morning.

* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Valley-wide flooding of croplands...
pastures...and local roads occurs and is accompanied by flood
depths up to 3 feet with swift currents.
Instruction:

Alert:

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
Pearl River Near Rockport affecting Copiah and Simpson Counties
Pearl River Near Monticello affecting Lawrence County
Pearl River Near Columbia affecting Marion County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Rockport
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Monday the stage was 27.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 28.0 feet this
evening.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.
Alert:
Pearl River Near Rockport affecting Copiah and Simpson Counties
Pearl River Near Monticello affecting Lawrence County
Pearl River Near Columbia affecting Marion County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Columbia
* from late Wednesday night until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Monday the stage was 13.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage early Thursday
morning and will continue to rise to near 17.5 feet Thursday
evening.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Low areas near the river begin to flood.
Water covers Old Highway 35 on the west side of the river.
* Impact...At 15.0 feet...Camp Lane Road south of columbia on the east
side of the river begins to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Pearl River Near Rockport affecting Copiah and Simpson Counties
Pearl River Near Monticello affecting Lawrence County
Pearl River Near Columbia affecting Marion County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Monticello
* until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Monday the stage was 22.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 24.0 feet
by Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Water appears in low areas in the extreme
eastern portion of the city of Monticello.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Mississippi..

Pearl River At Jackson affecting Hinds and Rankin Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River At Jackson
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 AM Monday the stage was 28.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 28.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 31.0 feet Friday
evening.
* Impact...At 31.0 feet...Water begins to impact approaches to
additional homes and businesses in the Byram area.
* Impact...At 30.0 feet...Water backs up into several creeks and
streams in the Jackson area. Water is under some homes near the
river in the Byram area.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Black Cypress Bayou At Jefferson, Texas.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:00 AM Monday The stage was 13.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13 feet.
* Forecast...The bayou will continue rising to near 14.0 feet by
Wednesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...at 15.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the White Oak Creek Near Talco, Texas.
* until Wednesday evening...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:15 AM Monday The stage was 15.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 16 feet.
* Forecast...The creek is expected to rise to near flood stage
Tuesday early afternoon.
* Impact...at 16.0 feet...Expect minor lowland flooding of creek
bottoms. Ranchers that may have cattle and equipment in the creek
bottoms should move them to higher ground.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
At 1055 AM EDT, the heavy rainfall from last nigth along with snow
melt over the weekend will countinue to cause flooding near
Tunbridge where Rt 110 is closed due to water over the roadway.
Flooding will also be possible along the Waits River through
Bradford.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
West Fairlee, Bradford, Tunbridge, Vershire, Corinth Corners, Topsham
Four Corners, Thetford Hill State Park, Thetford Center, Corinth,
Newbury, Topsham, Strafford, Newbury Village, Thetford, Fairlee,
Chelsea, Washington, Orange, Norwich and West Fairlee Center.
Instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low lying
spots.
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Sulphur River Near Talco, Texas.
* until Wednesday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:45 AM Monday The stage was 24.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 20 feet.
* Forecast...The Sulphur River will crest at 24.2 feet throughout this
Monday morning.  The river will then begin receding during this Monday
afternoon and then recede to below flood stage by Tuesday late
evening.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...Expect moderate flooding of lowland areas
with some secondary roadways closed. All cattle and equipment
nearby the river should be moved to higher ground.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
The heavy rain has ended and flood waters have receded, no longer
posing a threat to life or property. Please continue to heed any road
closures.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Small Craft Advisory has been allowed to expire.
Instruction:

Alert:
Wabash River...White River...

.Lowland flooding has developed and will continue to develop this
week along much of the Wabash River, as well as portions of the
White River south of Indianapolis.  Significant flooding is not
expected on any central and southern Indiana area rivers. Smaller
streams have crested and falling with main stem rivers still rising.

Two systems of rainfall brought 1 to as high as 3 inches of rain to
portions of central Indiana late last week and again this weekend.

Dry weather is forecast for Monday and Tuesday, a negligible amount
of rain on Wednesday, then potentially a substantial rainfall event
Thursday through Thursday night, with lighter amounts continuing
into Saturday.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Mount Carmel.
* from Tuesday morning to Monday April 22.
* At  8:45 AM Monday the stage was 16.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 19.8 feet by Friday evening.  It will fall below
flood stage by Monday April 22.
* At 20.0 feet...River is bankfull in all locations.  All oil field
production ceases with the exception of pumping units on
substructures.  Access to these are by boat only.  Agricultural
losses increase dramatically.  Farmers move livestock to higher
ground.  City of Mount Carmel leaves flood gates B and C in year
round.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Terre Haute.
* until Saturday afternoon.
* At 10:30 AM Monday the stage was 16.3 feet. This is 2.0 to 2.5 feet
higher than the observations from the old legacy gauge.
* Flood stage is 16.5 feet. This is 2.5 feet higher than flood stage
from the old legacy gauge.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by this afternoon and continue to
rise to near 18.7 feet by Wednesday evening.  It will fall below
flood stage by late Friday night.
* At 18.5 feet...Flooding of rural roads is in progress behind Honey
Creek Levee as a result of two unrepaired levee breaks.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Hutsonville Legacy Power Plant Site.
* until Monday April 22.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 18.4 feet Friday afternoon
and will fall below flood stage by Sunday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...Seep water occurs behind levees on Indiana side.
Hutson Creek begins to overflow from backwater.  Old Darwin Road
and a few rural roads in eastern Clark and Crawford counties in
Illinois are impassable.  Low agricultural land floods.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Wabash River at Covington.
* from late tonight to Thursday morning.
* At  9:45 AM Monday the stage was 13.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late tonight and continue to
rise to near 16.9 feet by Tuesday afternoon.  It will fall below
flood stage by Wednesday evening.
* At 17.5 feet...Some low agricultural fields flood.  Backyard flood
of cottages a short distance north of U.S. Highway 136.  High water
blocks land access to at least one residence.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Riverton.
* until Monday April 22.
* At 10:00 AM Monday the stage was 16.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 17.2 feet by late Friday night then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Sunday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...Extensive lowland flooding is in progress.  High
water surrounds many river cabins.  Access to most river cabins is
by boat only.  Levees begin to protect farmland.  Extensive
flooding of Leaverton Park occurs in Palestine, Illinois.
Instruction:

The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Edwardsport.
* until late Saturday night.
* At  7:00 AM Monday the stage was 15.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 18.0 feet by late Wednesday night
then begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Saturday
afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...Old Vincennes Road and State Road 358 in Daviess
County and Schaefer Road in Knox County are impassable.  High water
affects agricultural bottomlands.  During agricultural season this
level is of concern to farmers on the unprotected areas along the
river.  High water affects river cabins.

Two systems of rainfall brought 1 to as high as 3 inches of rain to
portions of central Indiana late last week and again this weekend.

Dry weather is forecast for Monday and Tuesday, a negligible amount
of rain on Wednesday, then potentially a substantial rainfall event
Thursday through Thursday night, with lighter amounts continuing
into Saturday.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Petersburg.
* until Monday April 22.
* At 10:30 AM Monday the stage was 14.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by this afternoon and continue to
rise to near 18.3 feet by Friday afternoon.  It will fall below
flood stage by Sunday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...Lowland flooding begins to flood several Pike County
roads.  Many of the following county roads begin to flood around
this level...east of SR 57 include CR 750N...CR 600N and CR 1000E.
Pike county road subject to flooding west of SR 57 include...CR 250
W...CR 400W...CR 675N...CR 700 N...CR  1000w...CR 900W...CR 700W
and CR 775W.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
The Beaver Creek near Electra.

* until Tuesday evening...or until the warning is cancelled.

* At 9:00 AM Monday the stage was 26.6 feet.

* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.

* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.

* Forecast...The Beaver Creek will continue rising slightly and crest
near 26.7 feet early Monday afternoon. The Beaver Creek will fall
below flood stage early Tuesday afternoon.

* Impact...At 27.0 feet...Widespread flood levels up to 3 feet in
depth cover farm and range lands...and may inundate some oil and
gas facilities...along and near the creek in southern Wilbarger
County and southwestern Wichita County.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Burlington has issued a

* Flood Warning for Small Streams for...
Rain and Snowmelt in...
Southwestern Caledonia County in northeastern Vermont...
Northeastern Orange County in central Vermont...
Northeastern Washington County in central Vermont...

* Until 445 PM EDT.

* At 1052 AM EDT, the Wells River in Wells River, VT is showing a
sharp rise and has gone into minor flood stage. We've received
reports that Depot Creek in Groton is overflowing its banks near
Groton. Flood waters will approach US Hwy 302 in Groton, South
Ryegate, and Wells River.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Wells River Village, Ryegate, Cabot, Marshfield Village, Groton
Village, Ricker State Park, Peacham, Groton, Marshfield, Cabot
Village, Newbury, Barnet, Topsham, Orange, Plainfield, Wells River,
South Ryegate, Boltonville, West Barnet and South Peacham.
Instruction:
Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become
unstable and unsafe.
Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River Near Blair.
* until Monday April 29.
* At  9:00 AM Monday the stage was 25.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.5 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 25.0 feet this afternoon.
* Impact...at 26.5 feet...Flooding is occurring in the Fort Calhoun
area.  This flooding affects several homes and includes County
Roads 34, 47 and 51.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...Minor flooding occurs at the Fort Calhoun
trailer park.
* Impact...at 23.5 feet...Flooding begins to occur at Wilson Island
State Park.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.
Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River At Omaha.
* until Monday April 29.
* At  9:30 AM Monday the stage was 26.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 29.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 26.5 feet this afternoon.
* Impact...at 28.0 feet...At this level most of the flood gates for
the city of Council Bluffs are closed.
* Impact...at 27.0 feet...NP Dodge Park, Freedom Park, Tom Hanafan
Park and Fontenelle Forest begin to flood.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...A casino parking lot begins to flood along
the Iowa side of the river.  In addition, Haworth Park located in
Bellevue begins to flood.
* Impact...at 21.0 feet...At this level the City of Council Bluffs
begins closing flood gates.
* Impact...at 19.0 feet...At this level, the City of Council Bluffs
begins to close drainage gates that discharge into the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.

Mississippi..

Big Black River At West affecting Attala and Holmes Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Black River At West
* until further notice.
* At  8:45 AM Monday the stage was 20.7 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue falling for the next 24 hours before
rising once again.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bayou Dorcheat At Lake Bistineau, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:00 AM Monday The pool stage was 144.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 142.5 feet.
* Forecast...After cresting through this Monday morning at 144.3
feet, the lake will recede to near 144.1 feet by Tuesday morning.
* Impact...at 144.0 feet...Most camps across the lake begin to flood.
Some homes will also face flooding especially homes that are not
stilted. Preparations for flooding should be rushed to completion.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

Alert:
Wabash River at New Harmony

.Runoff from recent rainfall will cause the Wabash River at New Harmony
to rise into minor flood stage. The river will reach flood stage
Tuesday afternoon and crest near 15.9 feet Saturday.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Wabash River at New Harmony.
* from Tuesday evening to Tuesday April 23.
* At  9:30 AM Monday the stage was 13.6 feet.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tomorrow evening and continue
to rise to near 15.9 feet by Saturday early afternoon. The river
will fall below flood stage by Tuesday, April 23.
* Impact...At 15.0 Feet...The river overflows low ground on the
Illinois side.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Alert:
Deep low pressure moves northeast into New England today, with
high pressure over the Gulf Coast states. The gradient between
these two systems will allow west to northwest winds to gust as
high as 45 to 55 mph today, especially in the higher elevations.
* Winds...West 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.

* Timing...Strongest gusts this morning into early afternoon.

* Impacts...Some weaker trees and limbs will be blown down.
Isolated power outages are possible. High profile vehicles
will have difficulty with the crosswinds along north to south
routes.

* Locations...From Southeast West Virginia to the foothills of
Virginia, and the North Carolina mountains.

* Hazards...Strong wind gusts.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory is issued when sustained winds are forecast to be
31 to 39 MPH or gusts will range between 46 and 57 MPH. Winds of
these magnitudes may cause minor property damage without extra
precautions. Motorists in high profile vehicles should use extra
caution until the winds subside.
Alert:
The Flood Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

Alert:
Kaskaskia River at Carlyle TW

.This Flood Warning is a result of releases from Carlyle Dam...
The Flood Warning continues for
the Kaskaskia River at Carlyle TW
* until Sunday morning.
* At  9:30 AM Monday the stage was 425.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 423.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to below flood stage by
late Saturday morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

Alert:
Swatara Creek At Harper Tavern
The Flood Warning continues for
The Swatara Creek At Harper Tavern.
* At 11 AM Monday the stage was 10.3 feet and rising.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river will crest near 10.8 feet by this afternoon. The river
will fall below flood stage tonight.
* At 10.0 feet...High water isolates several houses.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Never drive cars through flooded areas!! The water
may be too deep to allow safe passage. Most deaths that occur during
flooding are related to vehicles trying to cross flooded roadways.

An update to this product will be issued this afternoon.
Alert:

Counties

.The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation, soil
moisture conditions, and forecast precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for

* Until Friday evening.
* At 845 AM Monday the stage was 19.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 19.7 feet by
Wednesday afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage Friday
afternoon.
* Impact...At 19.7 feet...Mayflower Road...just north of U.S. Route
50...begins to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, don't drown.

Additional river and weather information is available at
www.weather.gov/ilx.

Alert:
Big Black River Near Bovina affecting Hinds and Warren Counties
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.
Alert:
Big Black River Near Bentonia affecting Madison and Yazoo Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Black River Near Bentonia.
* until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Monday the stage was 28.6 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 29.0 feet just
after midnight tonight.
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 29.0 feet
on Apr 15 2014.
* Impact...At 29.0 feet...Agricultural land along the river is
devastated by flood waters.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

the Meramec River near Arnold
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Monday the stage was 30.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to crest near 30.4 feet by tomorrow early
afternoon.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles

passage.

Alert:
Minor to moderate flooding continues along portions of the
Mississippi River.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Wabasha.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:15 AM Monday the stage was 13.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 13.0 feet
by Tuesday morning.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...The railroad underpass on Highway 60 may be
flooded. Flooding is also possible along Lawrence Boulevard and
Main Street East. Some businesses near the river may be flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Alert:
* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.

* WINDS...34 to 47 knots within the Gale Warning.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and a properly equipped vessel. Recreational boaters
should seek safe harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

.Overview...Snowmelt from last week's storm continues to cause a rise
in river levels, especially over the next few days as temperatures warm
significantly.  Another weather system this week will bring widespread
rainfall and will likely cause another rise, with several rivers
re-entering or increasing flood stages this week.

Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown and Nicollet Counties
Minnesota River at Henderson MN19 affecting Le Sueur...Scott and
Sibley Counties
Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver and Scott Counties
Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota...Hennepin and Scott
Counties
Crow River at Rockford affecting Hennepin and Wright Counties
Mississippi River at St. Paul affecting Dakota...Ramsey and
Washington Counties
Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota...
Washington and Pierce Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...Snowmelt from last week's storm continues to cause a rise
in river levels, especially over the next few days as temperatures warm
significantly.  Another weather system this week will bring widespread
rainfall and will likely cause another rise, with several rivers
re-entering or increasing flood stages this week.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River near Jordan.
* until further notice.
* At  8:45 AM Monday the stage was 26.8 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 28.0 feet by
Saturday early afternoon. Additional rises may be possible
thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.7 feet...The bridge at Scott County Road 9 and Carver
County Road 11/Jonathan Carver Parkway will be closed.
* Impact...At 25.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin to flood and private sanitary sewers may experience
problems.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.
Alert:
Cottonwood River at New Ulm affecting Brown County
Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County

Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...Snowmelt from last week's storm continues to cause a rise
in river levels, especially over the next few days as temperatures warm
significantly.  Another weather system this week will bring widespread
rainfall and will likely cause another rise, with several rivers
re-entering or increasing flood stages this week.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At Morton .
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 AM Monday the stage was 24.7 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 26.5 feet by
Sunday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Numerous roads flooded and impassable
between the Minnesota River and Redwood Falls.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Fleischer Rd flooded in North Redwood; storm
sewers closed off and bypass pumping begins.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in
North Redwood.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Water reaches flood mitigation culverts on
Riverside Road
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

The Redwood River near Redwood Falls.
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 AM Monday the stage was 6.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 8.8 feet by
Friday early afternoon. Additional rises may be possible
thereafter.
* Impact...At 8.5 feet...Swayback bridge in Redwood Falls overtopped.
* Impact...At 6.0 feet...Low lying areas, mainly farmland, and some
roads along the river begin to experience flooding; bottom of
Swayback bridge

.Overview...Snowmelt from last week's storm continues to cause a rise
in river levels, especially over the next few days as temperatures warm
significantly.  Another weather system this week will bring widespread
rainfall and will likely cause another rise, with several rivers
re-entering or increasing flood stages this week.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Montevideo.
* until further notice.
* At  8:00 AM Monday the stage was 16.8 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 19.0 feet by
Sunday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Sanitary sewers begin to be affected at this
level.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Storm sewers may need to be plugged to
prevent water from backing up into streets.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along the
river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.
Alert:
The Small Craft Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
* Enderlin...on the Maple River...in Cass and Ransom Counties

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in North
Dakota...

* Kindred...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass and Richland Counties
* West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Harwood...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Mapleton...on the Maple River ...in Cass County


.Snow melt runoff continues across the region as temperatures remain
above freezing. This extra water entering the river systems is still
expected to drive a secondary, but minor, rise and/or slow decline
in water levels over the next 7 days.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Kindred...on the Sheyenne River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:00 AM Monday the stage was 15.4 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 16.0 feet.
* Forecast...rise above Flood Stage by Tuesday mid-morning and
continue to rise to near 17.7 feet by Wednesday evening.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 18.0 feet, Portions of 55th St SE are
underwater.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:

Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Warm temperatures over the last few days have caused increased
snowmelt and have weakened the remaining river ice across
Northern Maine. Rainfall will continue through the day with an
additional half inch of rain expected by this evening. The rain
and snowmelt will continue to elevate small streams and creeks
across the Flood Watch area. Small river flooding is expected to
bring localized impacts to the region. River ice will continue to
move on the Aroostook and Saint John River systems over the next
36 hours. Ice jam flooding could be possible, especially in areas
that had pre-existing ice jams from this past winter.
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of Central Highlands Maine, Far Eastern Maine, and
Penobscot Valley Maine, including the following areas, in
Central Highlands Maine, Central Piscataquis and Southern
Piscataquis. In Far Eastern Maine, Northern Washington and
Southeast Aroostook. In Penobscot Valley Maine, Central
Penobscot.

* Through Tuesday morning.

* Rainfall and snowmelt may lead to localized small stream and
low lying land flooding. Low lying roads and small stream
crossings could become impassable due to flooding. Never drive
into a flooded road, turn around don't drown.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
Warm temperatures over the last few days have caused increased
snowmelt and have weakened the remaining river ice across
Northern Maine. Rainfall will continue through the day with an
additional half inch of rain expected by this evening. The rain
and snowmelt will continue to elevate small streams and creeks
across the Flood Watch area. Small river flooding is expected to
bring localized impacts to the region. River ice will continue to
move on the Aroostook and Saint John River systems over the next
36 hours. Ice jam flooding could be possible, especially in areas
that had pre-existing ice jams from this past winter.
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of Central Highlands Maine, Far Northern Maine, and
North Woods Maine, including the following areas, in Central
Highlands Maine, Northern Penobscot. In Far Northern Maine,
Northeast Aroostook and Northwest Aroostook. In North Woods
Maine, Northern Piscataquis and Northern Somerset.

* Through Tuesday morning.

* Rainfall and snowmelt may lead to ice jam flooding along the
Saint John and Aroostook Rivers. The highest threat areas for
flooding will be in regions that have pre-existing ice jams
from this past winter.

* A second flood threat will be localized small stream flooding
as excessive snowmelt and rainfall could cause low lying land
flooding. Low lying roads and small stream crossings could
become impassable due to flooding. Never drive into a flooded
road, turn around don't drown.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
* Sabin...on the South Branch Buffalo River...in Clay County
* Shelly...on the Marsh River...in Norman County
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County

.Snowmelt runoff continues across the region as temperatures remain
above freezing. The forecast continues to call for either minor
rises and/or slow declines in water levels over the next 7 days due
to this additional water entering the river systems.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Hallock...on the Two Rivers River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:00 AM Monday the stage was 803.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 802.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will rise to a crest near 805.9 feet sometime
Friday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 806.0 feet, Moderate Flood Stage. Storm
sewers start backing up. Storm sewer valve at T.H. 175 Bridge
closed. Lift Pump inspected.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County

.Snowmelt runoff continues across the region as temperatures remain
above freezing. The forecast continues to call for either minor
rises and/or slow declines in water levels over the next 7 days due
to this additional water entering the river systems.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Alvarado...on the Snake River.
* until late Thursday night...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:30 AM Monday the stage was 106.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 106.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will fall below Flood Stage Wednesday night.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 106.0 feet, Flood Warning Stage...
Minor.Storm sewer flood gates are closed.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

lead to minor flooding along the Trempealeau River near Dodge.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trempealeau River at Dodge.
* from late tonight to late Friday night...Or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At  8:45 AM Monday the stage was 7.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 9.8 feet by Thursday morning. The river will fall
below flood stage by Friday morning.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...The entrance road to the Trempealeau National
Wildlife Refuge is flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

the Neuse River At Smithfield.
* At 9:15 AM Monday the stage was 15.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.

tomorrow morning. The river will fall below flood stage Wednesday
morning.

and snow melt from overnight will continue to cause flooding.

Corinth, Newbury, Topsham, Strafford, Newbury Village, Thetford,
Fairlee, Chelsea, Washington, Orange, Norwich and West Fairlee
Center.

creeks and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low lying

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has issued a

* Flood Advisory for Minor Flooding in Poor Drainage Areas for...
An Ice Jam in...
Northeastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 330 PM EDT.

* At 937 AM EDT, gauge reports at Washburn indicated a river level
of 14.65 feet which is just above flood stage. There is potential
of minor low land flooding in the vicinity of the ice jam on the
Aroostook River.

Additional rainfall of one half of an inch is expected over the
area. The combination of a pre-existing ice jam, snowmelt and rain
will result in a continued slow rise of river levels through at
least Wednesday or until the ice jam releases.  Those residents who
are impacted by flooding in Washburn along the Aroostook River
should closely watch the river levels over the coming days due to
the increased flood threat.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

* At 924 AM EDT, gauge reports at Washburn indicated a river level
of 14.65 feet which is a just above flood stage. The potential of
minor low land flooding could be possible in the vicinity of the
ice jam on the Aroostook River.

Additional rainfall of one half of an inch is expected over the
area. The combination of a pre-existing ice jam, snowmelt and rain
will result in a continued slow rise of river levels through at
least Wednesday or until the ice jam releases.  Those residents who
are impacted by flooding in Washburn along the Aroostook River
should closely watch the river levels over the coming days due to
the increased flood threat.

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect until 7 AM EDT this morning.
The Gale Warning has been cancelled.

* WINDS AND SEAS...Northwest winds 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to
30 kt. Seas 2 to 4 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
* Winds...Areas of west winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph.
Isolated gusts to 55 to 60 mph.

* Timing...Strongest winds will be Tuesday afternoon and evening.

* Location...Near mountain ridgetops, through the passes, and
along desert slopes into adjacent desert areas. Strongest near
the passes and on some desert slopes.

* Visibility...In the deserts, visibility may be reduced at times
in blowing dust and sand.

* Impacts...Strong winds and reduced visibility will make for
hazardous travel conditions.

* Outlook...Winds decreasing and shifting to northerly Tuesday
night.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult...especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Instruction:

Alert:

Instruction:

the Currituck Sound are expected to produce hazardous boating
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels...should avoid navigating in
these conditions.

* Waves: 3 to 5 feet.

to produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.

* Seas...Steep around 10 feet at 12 seconds.

* Areas affected...Small craft advisory conditions are expected

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mfr/hazard
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that winds and seas will create a
potential hazard to smaller vessels and inexperienced mariners.

A Hazardous Seas Warning means very steep and hazardous sea
conditions are imminent or occurring. Recreational boaters should
remain in port, or take shelter until waves subside. Commercial
vessels should prepare for rough seas and consider remaining in
port or taking shelter in port until hazardous seas subside.

Alert:
Strong winds will redevelop Tuesday afternoon and combine with a
dry and very unstable atmosphere and above normal afternoon
temperatures. These forecast elements will create critical fire
weather conditions Tuesday afternoon and early evening across the
northeast and east central plains and the northeast highlands.
* AREA AND TIMING...The Northeast Highlands, the Northeast
Plains and the East Central Plains from noon to 8 PM MDT
Tuesday.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 10 to 15 percent Tuesday
afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
* Wahpeton...on the Red River ...in Wilkin and Richland Counties

* Fargo...on the Red River ...in Clay and Cass Counties

* East Grand Forks...on the Red River ...in Polk and Grand Forks
Counties

Walsh Counties
* Drayton...on the Red River ...in Kittson...Marshall...Pembina and
Walsh Counties
* Pembina...on the Red River ...in Kittson and Pembina Counties
* Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND) ...in Richland County

..Flooding continues along the Red River, and secondary rises are
expected, at some locations, due to additional snow and snowmelt from
last week's system, in addition to rain showers expected mid-week.

This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND).
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:15 PM Monday the stage was 16.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...
Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Moderate Flood Stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will rise to near 17.8 feet sometime
Thursday afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 18.0 feet, MAJOR FLOOD. Bridge near the
gage is inaccessible due to agricultural flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

conditions.

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...Northwest winds 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to
30 kt. Seas 6 to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow occurring. Plan on slippery road conditions.
Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches, with localized
amounts up to 8 inches, are expected.

* WHERE...Western Plumas County/Lassen Park and West Slope
Northern Sierra Nevada.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM Tuesday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for reduced visibilities at
times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Be prepared for snow covered
roads and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.
The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
A strengthening pressure gradient will lead to moderate to
strong southeast winds over the Gulf waters tonight through early
Tuesday morning. Strong gusty winds will affect the bays south of
Port Aransas by mid morning Tuesday and continue through the
afternoon. The Small Craft Advisory for the Gulf waters may need
to be extended for a period on Tuesday.
* WINDS...Southeast around 20 knots with gusts to 25 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...Seas building to 5 to 6 feet with occasional seas
to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.
Alert:
A strengthening pressure gradient will lead to moderate to
strong southeast winds over the Gulf waters tonight through early
Tuesday morning. Strong gusty winds will affect the bays south of
Port Aransas by mid morning Tuesday and continue through the
afternoon. The Small Craft Advisory for the Gulf waters may need
to be extended for a period on Tuesday.
* WINDS...Southeast 20 to 25 knots Tuesday morning.

* WAVES/SEAS...Bays becoming choppy to occasionally rough.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.
Alert:
* WAVES...West 6 to 8 feet at 7 seconds.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that hazardous wave conditions will
exist for small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

The Small Craft Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Alert:
The Small Craft Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Wabash River...White River...


.Lowland flooding has developed and will continue to develop this
week along much of the Wabash River, as well as portions of the
White River south of Indianapolis.  Significant flooding is not
expected on any central and southern Indiana area rivers. Smaller
streams have crested and falling with main stem rivers still rising.

Two systems of rainfall brought 1 to as high as 3 inches of rain to
portions of central Indiana late last week and again this weekend.

Dry weather is forecast for Monday and Tuesday, a negligible amount
of rain on Wednesday, then potentially a substantial rainfall event
Thursday through Thursday night, with lighter amounts continuing
into Saturday.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Hutsonville Legacy Power Plant Site.
* until Monday April 22.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 18.5 feet Friday evening and
will fall below flood stage by Sunday evening.
* At 18.0 feet...Seep water occurs behind levees on Indiana side.
Hutson Creek begins to overflow from backwater.  Old Darwin Road
and a few rural roads in eastern Clark and Crawford counties in
Illinois are impassable.  Low agricultural land floods.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Wabash River at Clinton.

* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to rise above flood stage Tuesday
evening, crest at 18.1 feet late Tuesday night, and then fall below
flood stage by Wednesday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...River road near Mecca and lowest areas of river park
at Clinton begin to flood.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Mount Carmel.
* from late Tuesday night to Monday April 22.
* At  8:45 PM Monday the stage was 17.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late Tuesday night and
continue to rise to near 19.7 feet by Friday afternoon.  It will
fall below flood stage by Sunday afternoon.
* At 20.0 feet...River is bankfull in all locations.  All oil field
production ceases with the exception of pumping units on
substructures.  Access to these are by boat only.  Agricultural
losses increase dramatically.  Farmers move livestock to higher
ground.  City of Mount Carmel leaves flood gates B and C in year
round.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

click on rivers and lakes.

Alert:
* Sabin...on the South Branch Buffalo River...in Clay County
* Shelly...on the Marsh River...in Norman County
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County

..Flooding continues along the Minnesota tributaries of the Red
River, and secondary rises are expected, at some locations, due to
additional snow and snowmelt from last week's system, in addition to
rain showers expected mid-week.

This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Dilworth...on the Buffalo River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:45 PM Monday the stage was 15.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will rise to near 19.5 feet sometime
Saturday afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 20.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

River, and secondary rises are expected, at some locations, due to
additional snow and snowmelt from last week's system, in addition to
rain showers expected mid-week.

This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Crookston...on the Red Lake River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:45 PM Monday the stage was 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Minor
flooding is forecast.
* Minor Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will rise to near 21.0 feet sometime
Friday morning then begin falling.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 23.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD STAGE.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks
