Alert:
Wabash River...

.The Wabash River is expected to briefly go slightly out of its banks
at Clinton Tuesday evening into Wednesday, then fall back below flood
stage by Wednesday afternoon.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the Wabash River at Clinton.
* from Tuesday evening to late Wednesday night.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...It is forecast to rise above flood stage Tuesday
evening, crest at 18.1 feet late Tuesday night and then fall below
flood stage by Wednesday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...River road near Mecca and lowest areas of river park
at Clinton begin to flood.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
Surface high pressure over the northern Gulf of Mexico and low
pressure deepening across the Central Plains will result in strong
southeast winds off the lower Texas coast beginning tonight.
Winds will also increase across the Laguna Madre by mid Tuesday
morning and will continue into the afternoon.
* WINDS...Southeast 20 to 25 knots.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 20 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners...especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
Surface high pressure over the northern Gulf of Mexico and low
pressure deepening across the Central Plains will result in strong
southeast winds off the lower Texas coast beginning tonight.
Winds will also increase across the Laguna Madre by mid Tuesday
morning and will continue into the afternoon.
* WINDS...Southeast winds around 20 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...5 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The winds this evening have decreased and fallen below advisory
criteria. Choppy conditions will continue to be an issue during
the overnight hours as winds look to remain breezy.
Instruction:

Alert:
The winds this evening have decreased and fallen below advisory
criteria. Choppy conditions will continue to be an issue during
the overnight hours as winds look to remain breezy.

Alert:
Fox River Near Berlin affecting Green Lake County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Fox River Near Berlin.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 13.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Monday morning.
* Impact...At 13.2 feet...There is minor flooding in the Berlin area
including in Riverside and Webster Street Parks in Berlin. This
level is about a 50 percent chance flood meaning there is a 50
percent chance in any given year of the river reaching this level.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on difficult travel conditions.
Total snow accumulations of 4 to 7 inches, are expected. The
heaviest snow is expected in hills above 1000 feet.

* WHERE...Upper Koyukuk Valley.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Wednesday. The heaviest snow is expected
from late tonight to late Tuesday night.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Look for reduced visibilities at times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause travel difficulties. The latest road conditions can be
obtained by calling 5 1 1.
Alert:

heaviest snow is expected in hills above 1000 feet from Manley
west.

* WHERE...Central Interior from Manley west.

* WHEN...6 PM Monday to 6 AM Wednesday. The heaviest snow is
expected from now through Tuesday afternoon. .

Hills above 1000 feet from Manley west can expect 4 to 7
inches of snow. Valleys from Manley west can expect 2-4 inches
of snow. East of Manley much lower amounts of snow and rain
will occur.

Alert:
Missouri River at St Joseph affecting Doniphan...Andrew and
Buchanan Counties.
Missouri River at Napoleon affecting Jackson...Lafayette and Ray
Counties.
Missouri River at Waverly affecting Carroll...Lafayette and Saline
Counties.
Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline
Counties.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River at Napoleon.
* until further notice.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 18.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 18.4 feet by
early Thursday morning then begin falling.
* At 17.0 feet...Low-lying areas unprotected by levees begin to
flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 18.9 feet by
Thursday evening then begin falling.
* At 19.0 feet...Backwater from the Missouri River floods property
along the Nodaway river at Nodaway, Missouri.
* At 17.0 feet...Lowland flooding upstream and downstream from St.
Joseph occurs.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River At Omaha.
* until Monday April 29.
* At  9:15 PM Monday the stage was 26.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 29.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 26.5 feet much of the
week.
* Impact...at 28.0 feet...At this level most of the flood gates for
the city of Council Bluffs are closed.
* Impact...at 27.0 feet...NP Dodge Park, Freedom Park, Tom Hanafan
Park and Fontenelle Forest begin to flood.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...A casino parking lot begins to flood along
the Iowa side of the river.  In addition, Haworth Park located in
Bellevue begins to flood.
* Impact...at 21.0 feet...At this level the City of Council Bluffs
begins closing flood gates.
* Impact...at 19.0 feet...At this level, the City of Council Bluffs
begins to close drainage gates that discharge into the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.
Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on difficult travel conditions.
Total snow accumulations of 4 to 7 inches, are expected. The
heaviest snow is expected in hills above 1000 feet.

* WHERE...Upper Koyukuk Valley.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM Wednesday. The heaviest snow is expected from
late tonight to late Tuesday night.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Look for reduced visibilities at times.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause travel difficulties. The latest road conditions can be
obtained by calling 5 1 1.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Plan on difficult travel conditions.
Total snow accumulations of 4 to 7 inches, are expected. The
heaviest snow is expected in hills above 1000 feet from Manley
west.

* WHERE...Central Interior from Manley west.

* WHEN...6 PM Monday to 6 AM Wednesday. The heaviest snow is
expected from now through Tuesday afternoon. .


* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Look for reduced visibilities at times.
Hills above 1000 feet from Manley west can expect 4 to 7 inches
of snow. Valleys from Manley west can expect 2-4 inches of snow.
East of Manley much lower amounts of snow and rain will occur.

stage Saturday April 27.

south of Keyes Point. Outbounds Road is covering up. South end of
Jim Fullen Road is flooded. River water is covering parts of
Ballard Slough Road and Ruleman Road. Fields and pastures west of
Herring Hill road are inundated. West end of Corona Road begins to
flood. In Arkansas, Sans Souci Road elevator floods.

Alert:
Lamoille River At Jeffersonville
The National Weather Service in Burlington has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Lamoille River At Jeffersonville.
* until late Tuesday night...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:15 PM Monday the stage was 450.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 450.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 450.5 feet by
early Tuesday. The river will fall below flood stage Tuesday
evening.
* Impact...At 450.0 feet...Water will rise to near the edge of Route
15 in Cambridge Village at the Wrong Way Bridge. There will be
widespread field flooding from Jeffersonville downstream through
Fairfax.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

* until further notice.
* At  9:00 PM Monday the stage was 30.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to crest near 30.4 feet by tomorrow morning.

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as

passage.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Swatara Creek Near Hershey.
* At 9 PM Monday the stage was 7.1 feet and falling.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river will crest near 7.2 feet by after midnight tonight. The
river will fall below flood stage early tomorrow morning.
* At 7.0 feet...The right, or north bank begins to overflow. Several
roadways upstream of the gage are affected by high water.

may be too deep to allow safe passage. Most deaths that occur during

Alert:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At 7:00 PM Monday the stage was 57.2 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 57.4 feet by
Saturday April 20 then begin falling after April 24.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Reserve.
* Until Sunday May 05.
* At 7:00 PM Monday the stage was 22.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 22.6 feet by
Monday April 22. The river will fall below flood stage Sunday
May 05.
* Impact...At 22.0 feet...Marine and industrial interests along the
river, upstream barge operators, and facilities are impacted.
Navigation will become difficult for smaller river craft. Safety
precautions for river traffic are urged.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.
Alert:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Baton Rouge.
* Until further notice.
* At 7:00 PM Monday the stage was 40.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 35.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 40.3 feet by
Sunday April 21 then begin falling after April 25.
* Impact...At 40.0 feet...The grounds of the older part of Louisiana
State University's campus become soggy. This includes the area
around the Veterinary Medicine building, the Veterinary Medicine
Annex, the stadium and ball fields. The city of Baton Rouge and the
main LSU campus are protected by levees at this level.
* Impact...At 38.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 36.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 35.0 feet...River islands from Red River Landing
downstream to Baton Rouge will be inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.
Alert:
Cuivre River at Old Monroe

.This Flood Warning is a result of backwater from  the Mississippi River...
The Flood Warning continues for
the Cuivre River at Old Monroe
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 PM Monday the stage was 28.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue falling to a stage of 27.3 feet
by Wednesday morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:
* TEMPERATURE...32 to 37 in valley locations.

* TIMING...Midnight tonight to 9 AM EDT.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation and
potted plants.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

Alert:
Pascagoula At Merrill affecting George...Greene and Jackson Counties.

.Recent heavy rains have caused significant rises along the river.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Pascagoula At Merrill
* From Thursday morning until further notice.
* At 8 PM Monday the stage was 16.2 feet.
* No flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22 feet.
* Forecast to rise above flood stage by Thursday morning and continue to rise
near 22.5 feet by Sunday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter.
* At 22 feet...Flood Stage. Water approaches homes in west Merrill.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...
Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather radio.
Alert:

Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Chickasawhay At Leakesville affecting George...Greene and Wayne Counties.

.Recent heavy rains have caused significant rises along the river.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Chickasawhay At Leakesville
* From after midnight tomorrow until further notice.
* At 8 PM Monday the stage was 19.1 feet.
* No flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 20 feet.
* Forecast to rise above flood stage by after midnight tomorrow and continue to
rise near 26 feet by Sunday morning. Additional rises are possible
thereafter.
* At 26 feet...Flooding at the highway bridge begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...
Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather radio.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a Frost
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 AM to 8 AM EDT Tuesday.

* TEMPERATURES...Lows in the mid 30s.

* IMPACTS...Sensitive plants left outdoors and unprotected may
be damaged.
Instruction:
Protect frost sensitive plants by bringing them indoors or
covering them with layers of newspapers or blankets.

Alert:
Wabash River at New Harmony

.The Wabash River at New Harmony is expected to rise above flood stage
by Wednesday morning and continue rising to a crest of 15.8 feet by
Saturday morning. The river is forecast to fall back below flood stage
next Tuesday April 23.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Wabash River at New Harmony.
* from late Tuesday night to Tuesday April 23.
* At  8:30 PM Monday the stage was 14.0 feet.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by early Wednesday morning and
continue to rise to near 15.8 feet by Saturday morning. The river
will fall below flood stage by early Tuesday morning April 23.
* Impact...At 15.0 Feet...The river overflows low ground on the
Illinois side.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

* Flood stage is 29 feet.
* The river will continue rising to near 34.5 feet by Friday morning then begin

higher ground. Old Ferry Road near the river begins to flood.

Alert:
* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
Westerly winds will decrease to 15 knots or less with waves of 1
to 3 feet.
Instruction:

Alert:
Big Muddy River near Murphysboro

.Minor flooding continues along the Big Muddy River near Murphysboro.
Water levels continue to rise, and the river is forecast to crest
near 25.1 feet Wednesday. The river is forecast to fall below flood
stage early next week.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Big Muddy River near Murphysboro.
* until Monday April 22.
* At  8:30 PM Monday the stage was 24.2 feet.
* Flood Stage is 22.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 25.1 feet by
Wednesday early afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage
Monday early afternoon April 22.
* Impact...At 24.0 Feet...Some minor flooding in S 3rd & Division /
Plum Street area.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/
Alert:
Updated flood information for the Mississippi River.

River forecasts include past precipitation and forecast rainfall for
the next 24 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Le Claire LD14.
* Until further notice.
* At  8:30 PM Monday the stage was 13.6 feet and steady.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast, Rise to 13.7 feet Tuesday evening, then begin falling.
* Impact, At  13.7 feet, Water affects East Harbor Drive in
Bettendorf.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an
alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.

Alert:
* Wind: West 15 to 20 knots with gusts to 25 knots.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots over
the rivers of eastern Virginia are expected to produce hazardous
boating conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels...should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.
Alert:
* Wind: West 20 to 25 knots with gusts 30 knots.

* Seas: 4 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots and/or
seas of 5 feet or greater over the coastal waters are expected to
produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

Instruction:

the Currituck Sound are expected to produce hazardous boating
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels...should avoid navigating in
these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

Alert:
* Wind: West 20 to 25 knots with gusts 30 knots.

* Waves: 3 to 5 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots and/or
waves of 4 feet or greater over the Chesapeake Bay are expected
to produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.
Alert:
River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trempealeau River at Dodge.
* from Tuesday morning to late Friday night...Or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At  7:45 PM Monday the stage was 7.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 9.8 feet by Thursday morning. The river will fall
below flood stage by Friday morning.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...The entrance road to the Trempealeau National
Wildlife Refuge is flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Dakota...

* Kindred...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass and Richland Counties

* Mapleton...on the Maple River ...in Cass County

.Flood continues along the North Dakota tributaries of the Red
River, and a secondary rise is expected due to additional snow and
snowmelt from last week's system, in addition to rain showers
expected mid-week.

This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Mapleton...on the Maple River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:15 PM Monday the stage was 17.3 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...rise above Flood Stage by Tuesday morning and
continue to rise to near 20.5 feet by Wednesday evening.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 21.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 40
kt. Seas 4 to 7 feet.
Instruction:

occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
* WINDS...West 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* TIMING...The strongest winds will continue into tonight.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects.
Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may
result.

* LOCATION...Coastal Massachusetts, including Cape Cod and
Islands.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph are
expected, with gusts between 46 to 57 mph. Winds this strong are
capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may
result.

* LOCATION...Northeast Connecticut, Northwest Rhode Island,
Central Massachusetts.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph are
expected, with gusts between 46 to 57 mph. Winds this strong are
capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph. Gusts
to 50 mph over the higher elevations.

* TIMING...The strongest winds will continue into tonight.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. Scattered power outages are possible.

* LOCATION...North Central Connecticut and Western Massachusetts.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph are
expected, with gusts between 46 to 57 mph. Winds this strong are
capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
Sugar Creek at Milford affecting Iroquois County
The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation as well
as forecast precipitation 24-48 hours into the future.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Sugar Creek at Milford, or from Near Milford downstream to
confluence with Iroquois River at Watseka.
* until late Tuesday night.
* At  800 PM Monday the stage was 15.8 feet.
* Action stage is 15.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...If you encounter a flooded roadway...turn around and
find an alternate route.

Additional information can be found at weather.gov/chicago.
Alert:
Embarras River at Lawrenceville affecting Lawrence County

.The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation, soil
moisture conditions, and forecast precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Embarras River at Lawrenceville.
* Until Wednesday evening.
* At  745 PM Monday the stage was 30.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 30.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 30.8 feet by
tomorrow morning. The river will fall below flood stage Wednesday
afternoon.
* Impact...At 30.0 feet...Minor agricultural flooding begins.

route. Turn around, don't drown.

www.weather.gov/ilx.
Alert:
..RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 12 PM TO 8 PM MDT
TUESDAY FOR THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS, NORTHEAST PLAINS AND EAST
CENTRAL PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITIES AND ABOVE
NORMAL TEMPERATURES...

Winds will continue to decrease this evening, and the threat of
fire weather conditions will diminish. Therefore, the Red Flag
warning along and east of the central mountain chain will be
allowed to expire at 8 PM this evening.

Strong winds will redevelop Tuesday afternoon and combine with a dry
and very unstable atmosphere and above normal afternoon
temperatures. These forecast elements will create critical fire
weather conditions Tuesday afternoon and early evening across the
northeast and east central plains and the northeast highlands.
* AREA AND TIMING...The Northeast Highlands, the Northeast Plains
and the East Central Plains from noon to 8 PM MDT Tuesday.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 10 to 15 percent Tuesday
afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.
Alert:
..RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 12 PM TO 8 PM MDT
TUESDAY FOR THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS, NORTHEAST PLAINS AND EAST
CENTRAL PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITIES AND ABOVE
NORMAL TEMPERATURES...

Winds will continue to decrease this evening, and the threat of

warning along and east of the central mountain chain will be
allowed to expire at 8 PM this evening.

Strong winds will redevelop Tuesday afternoon and combine with a dry
and very unstable atmosphere and above normal afternoon
temperatures. These forecast elements will create critical fire
weather conditions Tuesday afternoon and early evening across the
northeast and east central plains and the northeast highlands.
* AREA AND TIMING...The Northeast Highlands, the Northeast Plains
and the East Central Plains from noon to 8 PM MDT Tuesday.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 10 to 15 percent Tuesday
afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.

field of this Red Flag Warning.
Alert:
..RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 12 PM TO 8 PM MDT
TUESDAY FOR THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS, NORTHEAST PLAINS AND EAST
CENTRAL PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITIES AND ABOVE
NORMAL TEMPERATURES...

Winds will continue to decrease this evening, and the threat of
fire weather conditions will diminish. Therefore, the Red Flag
warning along and east of the central mountain chain will be
allowed to expire at 8 PM this evening.

Strong winds will redevelop Tuesday afternoon and combine with a dry
and very unstable atmosphere and above normal afternoon
temperatures. These forecast elements will create critical fire
weather conditions Tuesday afternoon and early evening across the
northeast and east central plains and the northeast highlands.
Winds will continue to weaken this evening, and the threat of
critical fire weather conditions will diminish. Therefore, the
Red Flag warning will be allowed to expire.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, do not drown.

histories--is available on the Web at...  www.weather.gov/desmoines.
Click on the Rivers and Lakes link.

Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...Snowmelt from last week's storm continues to cause a rise
in river levels, especially over the next few days as temperatures warm
significantly.  Another weather system this week will bring widespread
rainfall and will likely cause another rise, with several rivers
re-entering or increasing flood stages this week.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At Morton .
* until further notice.
* At  7:30 PM Monday the stage was 24.7 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 26.6 feet by
Monday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Numerous roads flooded and impassable
between the Minnesota River and Redwood Falls.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Fleischer Rd flooded in North Redwood; storm
sewers closed off and bypass pumping begins.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in
North Redwood.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Water reaches flood mitigation culverts on
Riverside Road
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:

* Until further notice.

* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue rising to near 8.1 feet by  2 PM
Tuesday ...Then begin falling.
* Impact...At 8.0 feet...Water reaches moderate flood stage. Water
surrounds several homes on Schroon River Road.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches
expected.

* WHERE...Butte, Georgetown Lake, Highway 12 Garrison to
Elliston, Homestake Pass, and MacDonald Pass.

* WHEN...From 4 AM to noon MDT Tuesday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions. A period
of moderate snow during the morning commute will cause
visibility down to a half mile at times. Snowfall rates near one
inch per hour are possible.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

The Hudson River At Troy.

* At  9 PM Monday the stage was...21.3 feet.

* Minor flooding is forecast.

Tuesday and forecast to continue to rise to near   21.6 feet around
8 AM Tuesday. The river is forecast to fall below flood stage after
2 PM Tuesday.
* Impact...At 21.5 feet...Minor flood stage. Water floods onto the
Mohawk Wharf in Village of Waterford.

Alert:
Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau...Thebes and New Madrid

.Recent heavy rainfall will cause river levels on the Mississippi River
to rise. Moderate flooding is expected to continue at Cape Girardeau and
Thebes with crests expected Thursday at both locations. The river
at New Madrid is expected to rise above minor flood stage Wednesday early
morning and crest near 35.5 feet on Friday.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Thebes
* until further notice.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 37.3 feet.
* Flood Stage is 33.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 38.1 feet by
Thursday early afternoon then begin falling.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Alert:
In the wake of yesterday's storm system, much colder air filtered
into the region today on the heels of gusty northwest winds.
Overnight and early Tuesday, Canadian high pressure will settle
over the region allowing winds to diminish. Dewpoints are dropping
into the 30s and will continue to fall overnight. This will allow
temperatures to fall into the lower to mid 30s in many locations
by late tonight.

With clearing skies, diminishing winds, moist ground from recent
rainfall, and the cold air mass, areas of frost are likely to
develop late tonight and early Tuesday morning across many parts
of the Virginia and North Carolina Piedmont. The most likely
locations for frost formation will be in valleys or low- lying
areas and rural sheltered locations. The frost could be sufficient
enough to kill sensitive vegetation and young crops that have
recently sprouted as well as budding and blooming plant, trees,
and flowers from the recent warm temperatures.

Precautions should be taken now to protect sensitive vegetation,
plants, and trees if at all possible. Potted house plants should
be brought indoors overnight to prevent them from being damaged or
killed.
The National Weather Service in Blacksburg has issued a Frost
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 AM to 9 AM EDT Tuesday.

* Temperatures...dropping into the lower to mid 30s...32 to 37 by
early Tuesday morning.

* Timing...coldest temperatures in the 4 AM to 8 AM time frame.

* Impacts...sensitive vegetation, plants, and budding or blooming
plants and trees could be damaged or killed from frost and/or a
light freeze.

* Locations...Virginia and North Carolina Piedmont and Foothills.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...Northwest winds 20 to 30 kt with gusts up to 40
kt. Seas 4 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.
Alert:
Neuse River At Kinston affecting Lenoir County
The Flood Warning extended for
The Neuse River At Kinston.
* from Tuesday afternoon until further notice.
* At 8 PM Monday the stage was 13.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by early tomorrow afternoon and
continue to rise to near 16.2 feet by Saturday evening. Additional
rises are possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flooding of the campground at the Nature
Center is expected. Water encroaches onto other properties along
the south side of the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive vehicles through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur
in automobiles when people try to drive through flooded areas.

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio...local
radio...media or cable TV.
Alert:
* Winds and Seas...Northeast to east winds to 25 kt.
Instruction:
means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots and/or seas 10 feet or
greater are expected to produce conditions hazardous to small
craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Another statement will be issued by Tuesday morning...or sooner if
conditions warrant.
Alert:
Rises continue along the Tombigbee River...but the river is cresting at
Lock and Dam. A Flood Warning remains in effect along the Tombigbee River.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Tombigbee River At Demopolis Lock and Dam.
* until Friday afternoon...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:15 PM Monday the stage was 67.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 68 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tonight and continue to rise
to near 71.3 feet by early Wednesday morning. The river will fall
below flood stage by early Friday morning.
* Impact...At 68 feet...Flooding of lowlands in the area occurs and
cattle should be moved to higher ground.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Another statement will be issued by Tuesday morning...or sooner if
conditions warrant.

* Flood stage is 101 feet.

* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 105 feet by

Alert:
Ohio River at Cairo

.Minor flooding continues along the Ohio River at Cairo. The river
will continue rising to 46.5 feet on Friday morning. Additional
rises are possible. The flood warning will contiue until further
notice.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Ohio River at Cairo
* until further notice.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 44.1 feet.
* Flood Stage is 40.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 46.5 feet by
early Friday morning then begin falling.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Alert:
White River At Augusta affecting White and Woodruff Counties

White River At Clarendon affecting Arkansas and Monroe Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River At Clarendon.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 27.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 27.6 feet by
early Wednesday morning.
* Impacts at 28.0 feet...Flooding of cropland and timber is occurring.
Roads to homes and cabins in lower Maddox Bay area off Highway 146
south of Clarendon impassible.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.

Alert:
Contentnea Creek Near Hookerton affecting Greene...Lenoir and Pitt
Counties
The Flood Warning extended for
The Contentnea Creek Near Hookerton.
* until Saturday afternoon.
* At 9 PM Monday the stage was 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.2 feet by
Thursday evening. The river is expected to fall below flood stage
Saturday morning.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...Minor flooding of low lying areas adjacent
to creek can be expected. Several homes threatened by water in
northwest Greene County near HWY 58.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive vehicles through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur
in automobiles when people try to drive through flooded areas.

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio...local
radio...media or cable TV.
Alert:
High pressure will continue to support good radiational cooling
conditions across the region with light winds and clear skies.
Frost will likely develop across much of the North Carolina
mountains and adjacent foothills later tonight as temperatures
fall into the mid 30s.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued
a Frost Advisory, which is in effect from 2 AM to 8 AM EDT
Tuesday.

* LOCATIONS...North Carolina mountains and adjacent foothills.

* TEMPERATURES...Lows in the mid 30s.

* TIMING...From 2 am to 8 am Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana......Texas..

Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River Near Kinder
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier
Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Atchafalaya River At Morgan City.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  7:00 PM Monday the stage was 7.7 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 7.7 feet.
* Impact...At stages near 7.0 feet...Buildings at the foot of Ann
Street on the river side of the flood wall will flood as water
overtops the Rio Oil Company dock. Buildings on the river side of
the Berwick floodwall will flood. River traffic restrictions will
be strictly enforced. In addition, backwater flooding could
potentially impact portions areas around Lake Palourde and
Stephensville.
* Impact...At stages near 6.0 feet...Flood stage. The city dock will
be under water. Water will cover the lower end of Belleview Front
Street in Berwick. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger
river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly
enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 5.0 feet...Floodwall gates will be closed
to protect against higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected
by stronger river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be
strictly enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Action stage. Water will move
up the bank and across access roads below the city dock. Floodwall
gates should be closed by the 5 foot stage to protect against
higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger river
current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly enforced
by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Instruction:

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Mississippi..

Noxubee River At Macon affecting Noxubee County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Noxubee River At Macon
* until Thursday evening.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 31.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue falling and will fall below
flood stage Thursday morning.
* Impact...At 31.0 feet...Agriculture flooding is occurring near the
river.
* Impact...At 28.0 feet...Farm land near the river begins to flood.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Low land near the river is flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Alert:
Otter Creek At Center Rutland
The Flood Warning continues for
The Otter Creek At Center Rutland.
* At  8:45 PM Monday the stage was 12.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 8.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Wednesday afternoon.
* Impact...At 12.0 feet...Homes and businesses will be flooded along
Dorr Drive and Park Street, and near the junction of Route 4 and
West Proctor Road in Rutland. There will be widespread inundation
of low lying roads from Clarendon downstream to Proctor, and Route
73 west of Brandon will flood. Portions of Route 7 in Rutland
County may be threatened by tributaries to Otter Creek.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

Big Sunflower River Near Anguilla affecting Sharkey County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Sunflower River At Sunflower
* until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Monday the stage was 25.2 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 25.3 feet
tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At 25.0 feet...Water begins to spread across farmland from
flooding at Jones Bayou. Widespread agricultural flooding is a
occurring in this area.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Farm roads to catfish ponds become
inundated.
* Impact...At 21.0 feet...Field west of river begins to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

evening.

* Impact...At 30.0 feet...Water backs up into several creeks and

river in the Byram area.
* Impact...At 29.0 feet...Farmland in southern Rankin County begins to
flood and water begins to affect home access near the river in the
Byram area.

occurring. Water begins to back up into several creeks and streams
in the Jackson area.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Roads near the river in Lefleurs Bluff State
Park begin to flood.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...The Jackson waste water treatment plant
loses its natural outflow and must initiate pumping.

Alert:
An area of high pressure will build into the southern
Appalachians overnight producing clear sky, light wind, and
chilly temperatures. Areas of frost are expected by early Tuesday
morning.
The National Weather Service in Morristown has issued a Frost
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 AM to 8 AM EDT Tuesday.

* TEMPERATURES...As low as 34.

* TIMING...From 2 am through 8 am Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation that
is left unprotected.
Instruction:
A Frost Advisory means that widespread frost is expected.
Sensitive outdoor plants may be damaged or killed if left
unprotected.

closures.

People with interests along the river should take the necessary precautions to
protect life and property from the flood waters.

Additional information is available on our website at weather.gov/ilm under the
"Rivers and Lakes" link.

The Great Pee Dee At Pee Dee.
* until further notice.
* At  8:00 PM Monday the stage was 21.49 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 23.3 feet by early Friday
afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Flooding will affect swamp and timberlands while also
disrupting logging operations. Operations will likely cease and equipment not
previously moved will remain trapped. Some farmland will have minor flooding
especially around Britton Neck.

Alert:
..The flood warning continues for the following rivers in Maine

Kennebec River At Skowhegan affecting Somerset County


...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in Maine
Kennebec River At Augusta affecting Kennebec County
The flood warning continues for
The Kennebec River At Augusta.
* from tomorrow late morning until Wednesday evening.
* At 8 PM Monday the stage was 9.3 feet and rising.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* The river is forecast to continue rising tonight and tomorrow. It
will go above flood stage Tuesday morning and crest near 13.4
feet Tuesday afternoon and evening. The river will then fall back
below flood stage during the day Wednesday.
* Impact...At 12.0 feet... water begins to flood the parking lot on
Front Street in Augusta.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...Water covers the dock at town landing in
Hallowell.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flooded areas, it is impossible to know if the
road is safe for travel. Turn around, dont drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA weather radio...or
your favorite local media outlet.

Alert:
Paint Rock River near Woodville affecting Jackson...Madison and
Marshall Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
the Paint Rock River near Woodville
* until Wednesday morning.
* At 7 PM Monday the stage was 16.5 feet and steady.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor Flooding is occurring and Minor Flooding is forecast.
* Recent activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at
7 PM Monday was 16.5 feet.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flood waters affect mostly bottomland along
the river...including low lying farm and pasturelands.
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.3 feet
on Feb 20 2019.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to
recognize flood dangers. If while driving you see water over a road,
turn around, don't drown! The water depth may be too great to allow
your vehicle to cross. Additional information is available at
http://water.weather.gov. Once there, click on the Tennessee Valley
to view local river information.

Alert:
Pearl River Near Bogalusa affecting St. Tammany...Washington...
Hancock and Pearl River Counties/Parishes

Pearl River Near Pearl River affecting St. Tammany...Hancock and
Pearl River Counties/Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Pearl River.
* Until further notice.
* At  7:00 PM Monday the stage was 13.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday April 17 and
continue to rise to near 15.5 feet by Sunday April 21.
* Impact...At 15.5 feet...Secondary roads to the river and throughout
Honey Island Swamp are inundated. Property in the vicinity of the
gage is flooded threatening about 20 homes along the left bank. The
Bogue Chitto National Wildlife Refuge will be closed to hunting at
the 15.5 foot stage.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Secondary roads to the river and throughout
Honey Island Swamp are inundated. Property in the vicinity of the
gage is flooded threatening about 20 homes along the left bank.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...The east and west channels of the river will
begin to merge. Honey Island Swamp trails will be under water as
inundation of the swamp begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

Alert:
Recent warm temperatures have caused increased snowmelt and
weakened the remaining river ice across Northern Maine. Showers
will persist overnight with up to an additional quarter inch of
rain expected. The rain and snowmelt will continue to elevate
small streams and creeks across the Flood Watch area. Small river
flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the region.
River ice will continue to move on the Aroostook and Saint John
River systems over the next 36 hours. Ice jam flooding could be
possible, especially in areas that had pre-existing ice jams from
this past winter.
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of Central Highlands Maine, Far Eastern Maine, and
Penobscot Valley Maine, including the following areas, in
Central Highlands Maine, Central Piscataquis and Southern
Piscataquis. In Far Eastern Maine, Northern Washington and
Southeast Aroostook. In Penobscot Valley Maine, Central
Penobscot.

* Through Tuesday afternoon

* Rainfall and snowmelt could lead to localized small stream and
lowland flooding. Many small streams are already at or near
bankfull. Low lying roads and small stream crossings could
become impassable due to flooding. Never drive into a flooded
road, turn around don't drown.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
Recent warm temperatures have caused increased snowmelt and
weakened the remaining river ice across Northern Maine. Showers
will persist overnight with up to an additional quarter inch of
rain expected. The rain and snowmelt will continue to elevate
small streams and creeks across the Flood Watch area. Small river
flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the region.
River ice will continue to move on the Aroostook and Saint John
River systems over the next 36 hours. Ice jam flooding could be
possible, especially in areas that had pre-existing ice jams from
this past winter.
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of Central Highlands Maine, Far Northern Maine, and
North Woods Maine, including the following areas, in Central
Highlands Maine, Northern Penobscot. In Far Northern Maine,
Northeast Aroostook and Northwest Aroostook. In North Woods
Maine, Northern Piscataquis and Northern Somerset.

* Through Tuesday afternoon

* Rainfall and snowmelt may lead to ice jam flooding along the
Saint John and Aroostook Rivers. The highest threat areas for
flooding will be in regions that have pre-existing ice jams
from this past winter.

* A second flood threat will be small stream flooding with many
small streams already at or near bankfull. This could lead to
flooding in lowland areas bordering the streams. Low lying
roads and small stream crossings could become impassable due
to flooding. Never drive into a flooded road, turn around
don't drown.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has extended the

* Flood Advisory for Minor Flooding in Poor Drainage Areas for...
Rain and Snowmelt in...
Southeastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 945 AM EDT Tuesday.

* At 808 PM EDT, local law enforcement reported that rain, snowmelt,
and release of ice on the Dead Brook continues to cause minor
flooding in Bridgewater. Overflowing water has resulted in the
closure of Packard Road. Minor flooding may also intermittently
occur on Route 1 where it crosses the brook through tonight and
Tuesday morning.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Bridgewater.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You
may also contact local law enforcement.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Chesapeake Bay from Smith Point to Little Creek VA...
Entrance to the Chesapeake Bay including the Chesapeake Bay Bridge
Tunnel...

* Until 1000 PM EDT.

* At 806 PM EDT, an area of strong wind was located over the central
and eastern portion of the Chesapeake Bay.

HAZARD...Wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Observations.

IMPACT...Small craft could be damaged in briefly higher winds and
suddenly higher waves.

* Locations impacted include...
Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel, New Point Comfort, Nassawadox Reef,
Wolf Trap, Crisfield, Thimble Shoals, Tangier Island, Tue Marshes
Light, Stingray Point, Onancock Inlet, Occohannock Reef, The Hump,
The Cell, Cabbage Patch, Longs Creek Inlet, Cape Charles Harbor,
Windmill Point, 1st Island Bay Bridge, Lower Bernard Island and
Rappahannock Range Light.
Instruction:
Move to safe harbor immediately as gusty winds and high waves are
expected.

floodgate releases. Bureau of Reclamation officials reported that
flow out of the dam will be at 2000 cfs overnight.  A new assessment
will be done on Tuesday morning and further adjustments may be made
at that time.

Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire
Counties

The combination of recent rainfall locally and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin will bring sharp river
rises for the lower Connecticut River. River gauge readings along
the lower Connecticut River will reach and exceed flood stage levels
after Midnight tonight at Montague and Northampton, then during
Tuesday at Thompsonville, Hartford and Middle Haddam.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Middle Haddam.
* from Tuesday evening until further notice...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At  7:55 PM Monday the stage was 6.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...Flooding closes most of Meadow Road, Route
17A, in the Gildersleeve section of Portland. Flooding impacts the
Middletown Marina and Meadow Farms. In Cromwell, portions of River
Road will be closed. In Rocky Hill, parts of Meadow Road will be
impassable for a time. Flooding continues along the river southward
through Essex.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.

and continue to rise to near 19.7 feet by Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 20.0 feet...Flooding is expected along the river in
portions of Wethersfield, Glastonbury, Rocky Hill and Cromwell. The
high waters and swift flows will disrupt some cross river ferry
services. Upstream of Hartford, flooding will continue to affect
portions of Windsor. Immediate river roads may become impassable in
all of these communities. Further downstream flooding will continue
to overspread sections of Portland, Middletown as well as Chester.

Alert:
* WINDS...Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph
will be possible for parts of San Bernardino and Inyo counties.

* TIMING...Winds will gradually increase Monday afternoon, and
begin gusting over 40 mph by Monday evening. Winds are
expected to begin subsiding Tuesday evening.

* IMPACTS...Driving may become difficult due to strong winds and
visibility could be reduced due to blowing dust especially
along I-15. Loose or unsecured items may be blown away or
strewn about.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means strong winds gusting over 40 mph can make
driving difficult...especially for high profile vehicles. Use
extra caution.

or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

cancelled the Gale Warning.

occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and a properly equipped vessel. Recreational boaters
should seek safe harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels...should
avoid navigating in these conditions.

Leavittsburg.

Alert:
near Fletcher affecting Buncombe and Henderson Counties

Heavy rainfall of 2-5 inches across Transylvania County during the
24-hour period ending the evening of April 14, 2019 caused
excessive runoff and resulted in significant rises in the
headwaters of the French Broad River and associated tributaries
including the Davidson and Little Rivers.  Those headwaters and
tributaries have crested and stream levels are quickly returning to
normal levels. The resultant floodwave has peaked along the middle
French Broad River from Horse Shoe to Fletcher to Bent Creek and
is now beginning to recede.  However, the French Broad River will
remain above Action/Advisory Stage through Tuesday morning,
resulting in nuisance inundation of adjacent low-lying areas
including farmland and boat access ramps. Therefore, the Flood
Advisory will continue through Tuesday morning.
The Flood Advisory continues for
the French Broad River Near Fletcher
* until Tuesday morning.
* The French Broad River near Fletcher crested at 10.22 feet
at 245 AM on April 15, 2019.
* At 07 PM Monday the stage was 10.1 feet and falling slowly.
* Action/Advisory Stage is 10.0 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 13.0 feet.
* FORECAST: The river will continue to fall slowly below Action/
Advisory Stage by Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS: At 10.0 feet: Action/Advisory Stage. The French Broad
River has exceeded bankfull at the gauge site. Isolated farmland
flooding is beginning across the French Broad River Valley from
Etowah downstream to Avery Creek upstream of the gauge site.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

A Flood Advisory for a river forecast point means that nuisance
flooding is expected to occur along the river when the river level is
forecast to be just below or at the official Minor Flood Stage.

Caution is urged when walking near river banks...keep children away
from drainage areas and culverts.

Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

page at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp

Please report high water...flooding and landslides to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free...1...8 0
0...2 6 7...8 1 0 1...or by posting on our Facebook page...or tweet
it using hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and
the specific location where it occurred.
Alert:
..at Blantyre affecting Henderson and Transylvania Counties

Heavy rainfall of 2-5 inches across Transylvania County during the
24-hour period ending the evening of April 14, 2019 caused
excessive runoff and resulted in significant rises in the
headwaters of the French Broad River and associated tributaries
including the Davidson and Little Rivers.  Those headwaters and
tributaries have crested and stream levels are quickly returning to
normal levels. The resultant floodwave has peaked along the Upper
French Broad River from Brevard to Etowah and Horse Shoe and is now
beginning to recede. Minor Flood Stage was not reached during this
flood event; therefore, more significant inundation of low-lying
areas adjacent to the river will not occur and the Flood Warning
has been cancelled.  However, the French Broad River will remain
above Action/Advisory Stage through Tuesday morning, resulting in
nusiance inundation of adjacent low-lying areas including
farmland and boat access ramps. Therefore, the Flood Warning has
been replaced by a Flood Advisory.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a
* Flood Advisory for
The French Broad River At Blantyre.
* until Tuesday morning.
* The French Broad River crested at 15.73 feet at 215 PM on April 15,
2019.
* At 06 PM Monday the stage was 15.7 feet and falling slowly.
* Action/Advisory Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 16.0 feet.
* FORECAST: The river will continue to fall gradually below Action/
Advisory Stage by 11 AM on Tuesday, April 16, 2019.
* IMPACTS: At 16.0 feet: Minor Flood Stage. Farmland flooding
continues on both sides of the French Broad River. Floodwaters
begin to impact boat access areas at Grove Bridge Rd. and Crab
Creek Rd.
* IMPACTS: At 15.0 feet: Action Stage.  Most farm fields are flooding
between the French Broad River and Brevard Rd. and between the
French Broad River and Pleasant Grove Rd.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

A Flood Advisory for a river forecast point means that nuisance
flooding is expected to occur along the river when the river level is
forecast to be just below or at the official Minor Flood Stage.

Caution is urged when walking near river banks...keep children away
from drainage areas, culverts, boat-access ramps, greenways, and
parks along the river.

Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

* Winds...South 20 to 30 kt, approaching gales at times through
this afternoon. Winds become west to southwest this evening and
diminish to 10 to 20 kt.

* Seas...West-northwest swell of 7 to 9 feet at 13 seconds
combining with steep to very steep wind waves to produce seas of
10 to 13 feet through this evening. Seas remain elevated at 9 to
10 ft late tonight into Tuesday, but transition back to mostly
west-northwest swell dominated.

* Areas affected...Conditions hazardous to small craft are
expected for all areas. The steepest seas and strongest winds
area expected beyond 2 to 3 nm from shore, except closer to
shore within the vicinity of Cape Blanco.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mfr/hazard
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that winds and seas will create a
potential hazard to smaller vessels and inexperienced mariners.

A Hazardous Seas Warning means very steep and hazardous sea
conditions are imminent or occurring. Recreational boaters should
remain in port, or take shelter until waves subside. Commercial
vessels should prepare for rough seas and consider remaining in
port or taking shelter in port until hazardous seas subside.

Alert:
Recent warm temperatures have caused increased snowmelt and
weakened the remaining river ice across Northern Maine. Showers
will persist early tonight with up to an additional quarter inch
of rain expected. The rain and snowmelt will continue to elevate
small streams and creeks across the Flood Watch area. Small river
flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the region.
River ice will continue to move on the Aroostook and Saint John
River systems over the next 36 hours. Ice jam flooding could be
possible, especially in areas that had pre-existing ice jams from
this past winter.
The Flood Watch is now in effect for

* Portions of Central Highlands Maine, Far Eastern Maine, and
Penobscot Valley Maine, including the following areas, in
Central Highlands Maine, Central Piscataquis and Southern
Piscataquis. In Far Eastern Maine, Northern Washington and
Southeast Aroostook. In Penobscot Valley Maine, Central
Penobscot.

* Through Tuesday afternoon.

* Rainfall and snowmelt could lead to localized small stream and
lowland flooding. Many small streams are already at or near
bankfull. Low lying roads and small stream crossings could
become impassable due to flooding. Never drive into a flooded
road, turn around don't drown.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
Recent warm temperatures have caused increased snowmelt and
weakened the remaining river ice across Northern Maine. Showers
will persist early tonight with up to an additional quarter inch
of rain expected. The rain and snowmelt will continue to elevate
small streams and creeks across the Flood Watch area. Small river
flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the region.
River ice will continue to move on the Aroostook and Saint John
River systems over the next 36 hours. Ice jam flooding could be
possible, especially in areas that had pre-existing ice jams from
this past winter.
The Flood Watch is now in effect for

* Portions of Central Highlands Maine, Far Northern Maine, and
North Woods Maine, including the following areas, in Central
Highlands Maine, Northern Penobscot. In Far Northern Maine,
Northeast Aroostook and Northwest Aroostook. In North Woods
Maine, Northern Piscataquis and Northern Somerset.

* Through Tuesday afternoon.

* Rainfall and snowmelt may lead to ice jam flooding along the
Saint John and Aroostook Rivers. The highest threat areas for
flooding will be in regions that have pre-existing ice jams
from this past winter.

* A second flood threat will be small stream flooding with many
small streams already at or near bankfull. This could lead to
flooding in lowland areas bordering the streams. Low lying
roads and small stream crossings could become impassable due to
flooding. Never drive into a flooded road, turn around don't
drown.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
