Alert:
A strengthening pressure gradient will lead to moderate to strong
southeast winds over the Gulf waters later this evening through
early Tuesday morning. Strong gusty winds will affect the bays
south of Port Aransas by mid morning Tuesday and continue through
the afternoon. The Small Craft Advisory for the Gulf waters may
need to be extended for a period on Tuesday.
The National Weather Service in Corpus Christi has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 10 PM this evening to
10 AM CDT Tuesday.

* WINDS...Southeast around 20 knots with gusts to 25 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...Seas building to 5 to 6 feet with occasional seas
to 8 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.

Tuesday.

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

into the mid and upper 30s by early Tuesday. Locations sheltered
by the wind will stand the best chance of seeing pockets of light

frost advisory is not needed at this time.

Alert:
* Winds...Areas of west winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph.
Isolated gusts to 60 mph, especially late Tuesday afternoon and
Tuesday evening.

* Timing...Winds will increase late this afternoon and this
evening, then the strongest winds will be Tuesday afternoon and
evening.

* Location...The strongest winds will be near mountain ridgetops
and along desert slopes into adjacent desert areas.

* Visibility...In the deserts, visibility will be reduced at
times in blowing dust and blowing sand.

* Impacts...Strong winds and reduced visibility will make for
hazardous travel conditions.

* Outlook...Winds shifting to the north late Tuesday night on the
coastal slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains with the
winds diminishing elsewhere.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult...especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Rock Island LD15.
* Until further notice.
* At  2:00 PM Monday the stage was 19.1 feet and steady.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* Forecast, Fall to 19.0 feet Tuesday morning.
* Impact, At  19.0 feet, Water affects Rock Islands Sunset Marina
parking lot and River Drive in Moline from the 2700 to 4800 block.
Davenports Le Claire Park is entirely underwater. Water affects
most of River Drive from Division to Federal. Water is also at the
base of the loading docks of the 2nd Street Post Office.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an
alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.

Alert:
..RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 12 PM TO 8 PM MDT TUESDAY FOR
THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS AND EASTERN PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS,
LOW HUMIDITIES AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...

Increasing winds aloft and a strengthening lee side trough will
cause breezy to windy conditions to continue across eastern New
Mexico through this evening. The atmosphere will also be dry and
very unstable while temperatures climb well above normal. This
classic set-up will lead to critical fire weather conditions
across the eastern highlands and plains this afternoon through
early evening. The pattern will repeat on Tuesday with even
stronger winds and thus, critical fire weather conditions will
return to the eastern plains Tuesday afternoon and early evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...Sandia, Manzano and Gallinas Mountains for the
remainder of this afternoon and early evening.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 15 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 7 to 12 percent late this
afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.
Alert:
..RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 12 PM TO 8 PM MDT TUESDAY FOR
THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS AND EASTERN PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS,
LOW HUMIDITIES AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...

Increasing winds aloft and a strengthening lee side trough will
cause breezy to windy conditions to continue across eastern New
Mexico through this evening. The atmosphere will also be dry and
very unstable while temperatures climb well above normal. This
classic set-up will lead to critical fire weather conditions
across the eastern highlands and plains this afternoon through
early evening. The pattern will repeat on Tuesday with even
stronger winds and thus, critical fire weather conditions will
return to the eastern plains Tuesday afternoon and early evening.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag
Warning...which is in effect from noon to 8 PM MDT Tuesday.

* AREA AND TIMING...The Northeast Highlands until 8 PM MDT this
evening and again noon to 8 PM MDT Tuesday.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest increasing to 15 to 30 mph with gusts
to 40 mph today and southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph
on Tuesday.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 7 to 12 percent late this
afternoon, then around 10 to 15 percent east of the Sangre de
Cristo Mountains Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.

Outdoor burning is not recommended.

Alert:
..RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 12 PM TO 8 PM MDT TUESDAY FOR
THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS AND EASTERN PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS,
LOW HUMIDITIES AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...

Increasing winds aloft and a strengthening lee side trough will
cause breezy to windy conditions to continue across eastern New
Mexico through this evening. The atmosphere will also be dry and
very unstable while temperatures climb well above normal. This
classic set-up will lead to critical fire weather conditions
across the eastern highlands and plains this afternoon through
early evening. The pattern will repeat on Tuesday with even
stronger winds and thus, critical fire weather conditions will
return to the eastern plains Tuesday afternoon and early evening.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag
Warning...which is in effect from noon to 8 PM MDT Tuesday. The
Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.

* AREA AND TIMING...The Northeast and East Central Plains for the
remainder of this afternoon and early evening, as well as
Tuesday afternoon and early evening.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 15 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph
today, and southwest at 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph
Tuesday.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 7 to 12 percent late today,
and 10 to 15 percent late Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.

northwestern Connecticut.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained winds of 31 to 39 mph are
expected, with gusts between 46 to 57 mph. Winds this strong are
capable of downing small tree limbs and branches, possibly
causing isolated power outages. Driving can also be difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:

Waves 2 to 4 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
Surface high pressure over the Northern Gulf of Mexico and low
pressure deepening across the Central Plains will result in strong
southeast winds off the lower Texas coast beginning tonight. Winds
will then increase across the Bay waters by mid-morning and
continue into the afternoon.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 10 PM this evening to
4 PM CDT Tuesday.

* WINDS...Southeast winds around 20 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...4 to 6 feet nearshore. 5 to 7 feet offshore.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

* Flood Advisory for Minor Flooding in Poor Drainage Areas for...

Southeastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 945 PM EDT.

causing minor flooding in Bridgewater. Overflowing poor drainage
areas will result in minor flooding that has affected Packard Road
and could impact Route 1 this evening.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Bridgewater.

deaths occur in vehicles.

at 1-800-909-

local law enforcement.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At  2:15 PM Monday the stage was 40.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 41.3 feet by
Friday early afternoon. Additional rises may be possible
thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

and local media.

Alert:
The Flood Watch continues for

* All of Vermont except Grand Isle, Bennington and Windham
counties

* Through Tuesday morning.

* The combination of rain and snow melt will continue to cause
river flooding on area waterways. Sharp river rises have already
occurred, and most main stem rivers are expected to crest later
this afternoon and evening before receding overnight.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the weekend and
into Monday.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.

Instruction:

Alert:
A tightening pressure gradient due to an upper level low passing
over central New Mexico will increase winds overnight tonight into
Wednesday, with peak winds occurring Wednesday afternoon. Strong
west-to-southwest winds will occur across southern New Mexico and
west Texas with the strongest winds along the International
Border. Wind speeds of 25-35 mph and gusts to 45 mph will be
possible. Some localized blowing dust may occur in the afternoon,
with low visibilities.
The National Weather Service in El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa has
issued a Wind Advisory, which is in effect from 2 PM to 11 PM MDT
Wednesday.

* AREA AFFECTED... Strongest winds will occur along the
International Border in Luna, Dona Ana, and southern Otero
Counties in New Mexico, along with El Paso and Hudspeth Counties
in far west Texas.

* TIMING...Gusty winds Wednesday morning will strength in the
afternoon, peaking around 5pm. Winds will slowly decrease
Wednesday night.

* WINDS...Sustained speeds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts of 45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Winds will make for difficult driving conditions,
especially for high-profile vehicles in cross winds. Loose
objects may blow about. Patchy blowing dust may cause localized
low visibility.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 35 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

* Impact, At  19.0 feet, Water affects Rock Islands Sunset Marina
parking lot and River Drive in Moline from the 2700 to 4800 block.
Davenports Le Claire Park is entirely underwater. Water affects
most of River Drive from Division to Federal. Water is also at the
base of the loading docks of the 2nd Street Post Office.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an
alternate route. Turn around, don't drown.

Alert:
Recent rain and warm temperatures have caused increased snowmelt
and weakened the remaining river ice across northern Maine.
Rivers will continue to rise over the next 12 to 24 hours due to
the recent snowmelt and rain in the Flood Watch area. Small river
flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the region.
Smaller rivers should crest this evening then begin to trend down
overnight into Wednesday. River ice will continue to move on the
Aroostook and Saint John River systems over the next 24 hours. Ice
jam flooding could be possible, especially in areas that had
pre-existing ice jams from this past winter.
The Flood Watch continues for

* A portion of Far Northern Maine, including the following
areas, Northeast Aroostook and Northwest Aroostook.

* Until 2 AM EDT Wednesday.

* Snowmelt may lead to ice jam flooding along the Saint John and
Aroostook Rivers. The highest threat areas for flooding will
be in regions that have pre-existing ice jams from this past
winter.

* A second flood threat will be small stream flooding with many
small streams already at or near bankfull. This could lead to
flooding in lowland areas bordering the streams. Low lying roads
and small stream crossings could become impassable due to
flooding. Never drive into a flooded road, turn around don't
drown. Small streams and rivers will crest this evening then
begin to trend down overnight into Wednesday.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Flash Flood Watch for portions of Arkansas, Louisiana, and
northeast Texas, including the following areas, in Arkansas,
Columbia, Lafayette, Nevada, and Union. In Louisiana,
Bienville, Bossier, Caddo, Claiborne, De Soto, Lincoln, Red
River, Union, and Webster. In northeast Texas, Harrison,
Marion, and Panola.

* From Wednesday evening through Thursday afternoon

* Showers and thunderstorms will increase in coverage across the
region on Wednesday night. With recent rainfall causing flash
flooding across this area, an additional two to three inches of
rainfall over a short period of time could cause additional
flash flood concerns.

* Heavy rainfall may lead to flooding of low-lying and poor
drainage areas, as well as flooding of rivers, creeks, and
streams.
Instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions may develop that lead
to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a very dangerous situation.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

Alert:
..Minor Coastal Flooding Possible...

.The risk of strong rip currents will persist through Thursday afternoon.
Be sure to swim near a lifeguard and stay away from rocks, piers and jetties
where the rip currents are particularly strong.

In addition, with increasing winds and seas, water levels will
become 1 to 1 1/2 feet above normal. Near times of high tide, minor
overwash of low lying coastal roads may occur. This includes
portions of the Bolivar Peninsula, Blue Water Highway and
Surfside.
The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston has issued a
High Rip Current Risk, which is in effect through Thursday
afternoon.

* HAZARDS...Strong rip currents, elevated surf and minor coastal flooding
on Gulf facing shores.

* TIMING...Through Thursday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can become life threatening to anyone entering the
surf and can even sweep the strongest swimmer out to sea. Minor coastal
flooding for a few hours before and after high tide could make travel
difficult along low lying coastal roads, particularly between Surfside
and the Bolivar Peninsula.
Instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore...which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins...
jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol...
flags and signs. Swim near a lifeguard.

If you become caught in a rip current...yell for help. Remain
calm...do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current...swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
At 222 PM CDT, emergency management reported snowmelt causing
flooding through the northern half of the Red River Valley.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Grand Forks, Thompson, Drayton, Pembina, Manvel, Reynolds and St.
Vincent.

This includes Interstate 29 between mile markers 123 and 217.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low lying spots.

afternoon between 15 and 25 mph with gusts to 40 mph. Winds
will diminish late this evening.

for high profile vehicles. This includes Highways 1 and 101,
and State Route 246. There will be local blowing sand along
the beaches.

cross winds.
Alert:
* WINDS AND TIMING...Northwest to north winds will strengthen
this afternoon between 15 and 30 mph with gusts between 40 and
50 mph. Strongest winds will occur across the wind prone
passes between Gaviota and Refugio in the afternoon and early
evening hours. Winds will then shift to the north to northeast
affecting the same areas but expanding across the hills above
and around Montecito this evening into the overnight hours.
There will be local gusts to 55 mph, especially around the
hills of Montecito. Winds will start to diminish some early
Wednesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. This includes Highways 101, 154 and
192...as well as the Gaviota and San Marcos Passes.
Instruction:
When driving, use extra caution. Be prepared for sudden gusty
cross winds.

through this evening. Local gusts to 55 mph will be possible
across western portion. Winds will diminish some late this
evening into early Wednesday morning.

Alert:

Alert:
A passing upper trough will result in strong winds across the
Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains Wednesday. Conditions should
improve late Wednesday evening as the system moves east.
The National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a High
Wind Warning, which is in effect from noon to 9 PM MDT Wednesday.
The High Wind Watch is no longer in effect.

* TIMING...Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening.

* WINDS...West 40 to 50 mph with gusts to 70 mph.

* IMPACTS...People driving high-profile vehicles should be very
cautious traveling in the mountains, particularly in a north
and south direction. Significant turbulence will be hazardous
for low flying light aircraft.
Instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has extended the

* Flood Warning for...
Northeastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 315 PM EDT Wednesday.

* At 219 PM EDT, river gauge reports at Washburn indicated a river
level of 16.64 feet which is above flood stage. Ice jams still
locked in place near Washburn and Crouseville along with continued
river rises will cause low land flooding in the warned area.

* The combination of pre-existing ice jams and continued snowmelt
will result in a continued slow rise of river levels through
Wednesday or until the ice jam releases.  In addition, brief rapid
rises are possible once the ice locked in place begins to break up
and move. Those residents who are impacted by flooding in
Washburn, Wade and Crouseville along the Aroostook River should
closely watch the river levels over the coming days due to the
increased flood threat.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Crouseville, Washburn and Wade.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-
5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You may also contact
local law enforcement.

A Flood Warning means that flooding is imminent or occurring. All
interested parties should take necessary precautions immediately.

above freezing at most locations. As a result, the winter weather
advisory will be allowed to expire at noon today. Precipitation
will slowly end from southwest to northeast this afternoon.

some elevated surfaces such as bridges and overpasses can still
have icy spots.

those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
The Gale Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots,
or seas 5 feet or greater, are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially
those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden

Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Connecticut...
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties

The combination of recent heavy rainfall and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin have caused river gauge
readings along the lower Connecticut River to reach and exceed flood
stage levels.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Northampton.
* until Wednesday morning...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  1:00 PM Tuesday the stage was 112.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 112.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 112.6 feet by
this evening. The river will fall below flood stage early tomorrow.
* Impact...At 113.0 feet...Minor flooding will affect portions of
Northampton in the vicinity of the Oxbow and Hadley along Aqua
Vitae Drive. Farming interests in Hatfield outside flood dike
protection will experience flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

cancelled.

* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.

* Impact...At 9.5 feet...Flooding closes most of Meadow Road, Route

Middletown Marina and Meadow Farms. In Cromwell, portions of River
Road will be closed. In Rocky Hill, parts of Meadow Road will be
impassable for a time. Flooding continues along the river southward
through Essex.

* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  1:16 PM Tuesday the stage was 17.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 19.9 feet by
tomorrow late morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 20.0 feet...Flooding is expected along the river in
portions of Wethersfield, Glastonbury, Rocky Hill and Cromwell. The
high waters and swift flows will disrupt some cross river ferry
services. Upstream of Hartford, flooding will continue to affect
portions of Windsor. Immediate river roads may become impassable in
all of these communities. Further downstream flooding will continue
to overspread sections of Portland, Middletown as well as Chester.

Alert:
A fast moving storm system will bring primarily rain to
elevations below 5500 feet and snow to elevations above 5500 feet
through this afternoon and into early this evening. Snow could mix
in with the rain at lower elevations in the heavier bursts of
precipitation, but no accumulations are expected. Snow
accumulations above 5500 feet of 1 to 3 inches are possible,
especially on grassy surfaces. Road surfaces could become slick
due to slushy snow, especially at higher elevations like Kings
Hill Pass.
Instruction:

River...Tallahatchie River...Tombigbee River.

the Coldwater River at Marks
* until Thursday April 18.
* At 11 AM Tuesday the stage was 39.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring AND Minor flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 39.5 feet on Wednesday April 17.
* Flood stage is 39.0 feet.
* The river rose above flood stage Monday April 15 and will continue
rising to near 39.5 feet by Wednesday April 17. The river will fall
below flood stage Thursday April 18.
* At 39.5 feet...Flooding is occurring around Marks and in low-lying
farm land in Quitman County.

conditions warrant.

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

Barton River At Coventry
The Flood Warning continues for
The Otter Creek At Center Rutland.
* At 11:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 10.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 8.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
late Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 11.0 feet...Water will come near homes and businesses in
Rutland along Otter Creek on Dorr Drive and Park Street, and along
the confluence of Otter Creek and the Clarendon River at West
Proctor Road and Rte 4. Low lying roads in Clarendon and
Wallingford will flood. Downstream in Proctor and Pittsford,
numerous roads will be inundated, and Route 73 west of Brandon will
flood. Route 7 may be threatened by tributaries to Otter Creek in
Rutland County.

warrant.

For graphical river and flood information...please go to
www.weather.gov and click near Memphis on the map, then select Rivers
and Lakes.

Do not drive through flooded areas...turn around don't drown.

Stay tuned to your weather radio and your local news media for the
latest river information.
Alert:
James River At Huron
James River Near Forestburg
James River At Mitchell
James River Near Scotland
James River Above Yankton
Firesteel Creek Near Mount Vernon
Lake Francis Case At Chamberlain
Missouri River At Niobrara
Missouri River At Springfield
West Fork Vermillion River Near Parker
East Fork Vermillion River Near Parker
Vermillion River Near Davis
Vermillion River Near Wakonda

.The following river forecasts include forecast precipitation through
tonight. Any additional future rains could affect the crest
forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The James River At Mitchell.
* until further notice.
* At 10AM Tuesday the stage was 22.18 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 17.00 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 24.7 feet by
Thursday April 25. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At stages near 25.0 feet...Water reaches the bottom of the bridge
on 257th Street at the gauge, and Highway 42 east of Ethan will be
flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not drive cars through flooded areas. the water
depth and road condition may be unsafe.

Additional information is available at

http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=fsd

Stay tuned for further updates by listening to NOAA weather radio...
or your local radio and TV stations.

The next scheduled statement will be issued tomorrow morning.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Vermillion River Near Davis.
* until further notice.
* At 07AM Tuesday the stage was estimated at 11.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.00 feet.
* Forecast...the river will crest near 14.0 feet on Sunday April 21.
* At stages near 14.5 feet...The higher banks and levees get
overtopped, and flooding of some rural roads south of Davis begins.
Also 280th Street between 459th and 460th Avenue is flooded.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Vermillion River Near Wakonda.
* until further notice.
* At 07AM Tuesday the stage was estimated at 13.40 feet.
* Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.00 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday April 16 and crest
near 17.1 feet by Tuesday April 23.
* At stages near 17.0 feet...Highway 19 south of Centerville is
flooded. Water reaches the bottom of the bridge on 302nd Street east
of Colfax Corner, and many of the levees will start to be overtopped
with approximately 25000 acres flooded between Davis and Vermillion.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Alert:
Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and West
Baton Rouge Parishes
Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 57.2 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 57.5 feet by
Monday April 22 then begin falling.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.
Alert:
Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and West
Baton Rouge Parishes
Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Baton Rouge.
* Until Friday May 10.
* At  8:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 40.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 35.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 40.3 feet by
Tuesday April 23. The river will fall below flood stage Friday May
10.
* Impact...At 40.0 feet...The grounds of the older part of Louisiana
State University's campus become soggy. This includes the area
around the Veterinary Medicine building, the Veterinary Medicine
Annex, the stadium and ball fields. The city of Baton Rouge and the
main LSU campus are protected by levees at this level.
* Impact...At 38.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 36.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
* Impact...At 35.0 feet...River islands from Red River Landing
downstream to Baton Rouge will be inundated.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Reserve.
* Until Thursday May 02.
* At 10:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 22.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 22.5 feet by
Tuesday April 23. The river will fall below flood stage Thursday
May 02.
* Impact...At 22.0 feet...Marine and industrial interests along the
river, upstream barge operators, and facilities are impacted.
Navigation will become difficult for smaller river craft. Safety
precautions for river traffic are urged.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Alert:
Mississippi River at Cape Girardeau...Thebes and New Madrid

.Recent heavy rainfall will cause river levels on the Mississippi River
to rise. Moderate flooding is expected to continue at Cape Girardeau and
Thebes with crests expected Thursday at both locations. The river
at New Madrid is expected to rise above minor flood stage Wednesday morning
and crest near 35.5 feet on Friday.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Mississippi River at Thebes
* until further notice.
* At 11:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 37.4 feet.
* Flood Stage is 33.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 38.0 feet by
Thursday evening.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

continue to rise to near 35.5 feet by Friday morning.

Alert:
John Day River at Service Creek affecting Wheeler County
The Flood Warning continues for
The John Day River at Service Creek.
* until Tuesday April 23.
* At 8:30 AM Tuesday, the stage was 9.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.5 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage Friday afternoon and
continue to rise to near 13.7 feet Sunday. The river is
expected to fall below flood stage Tuesday or Wednesday of next
week.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton

Big Sioux River near Estelline

The Big Sioux River near Estelline.
* until further notice.
* At 11AM Tuesday the stage was 1645.50 feet.
* Flood stage is 1644.00 feet.
* At stages near 1644 feet...Significant flooding of crop and pasture
land begins.

* until further notice.
* At 10AM Tuesday the stage was 13.74 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.00 feet.
* Forecast...The river will crest near 14.8 feet by Saturday April 20
then begin falling.
* At stages near 15.0 feet...Some homes in Dell Rapids and Renner are
flooded, and the Jaycee Camp between Baltic and Renner is also
flooded.

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier.
* from this evening to Thursday evening...or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At  6:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 3.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 4.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will flucuate around 4 feet for the next several
days due to tidal effects.
* Impact...At stages near 4.5 feet...Water covers portions of River
Road in north Lake Charles.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Minor marshland flooding
occurs. Flooding also begins on River Road in north Lake Charles.

Alert:
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
Calcasieu River Near Kinder
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Texas..

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Atchafalaya River At Morgan City.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 7.8 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 7.3 feet
by tomorrow morning.
* Impact...At stages near 7.0 feet...Buildings at the foot of Ann
Street on the river side of the flood wall will flood as water
overtops the Rio Oil Company dock. Buildings on the river side of
the Berwick floodwall will flood. River traffic restrictions will
be strictly enforced. In addition, backwater flooding could
potentially impact portions areas around Lake Palourde and
Stephensville.
* Impact...At stages near 6.0 feet...Flood stage. The city dock will
be under water. Water will cover the lower end of Belleview Front
Street in Berwick. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger
river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly
enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 5.0 feet...Floodwall gates will be closed
to protect against higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected
by stronger river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be
strictly enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Action stage. Water will move
up the bank and across access roads below the city dock. Floodwall
gates should be closed by the 5 foot stage to protect against
higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger river
current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly enforced
by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Instruction:

Alert:
Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River Near Salt Water Barrier
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City

* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Thursday before midnight.
* Impact...At stages near 15.0 feet...Moderate flooding will occur
with several access roads to the river flooded.

the river will occur.

banks on both sides of the river.

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River Near Glenmora.
* until late Friday night...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 13.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Friday evening.
* Impact...At stages near 12.0 feet...When the river is rising and
the gauge reading is forecast to reach 12 feet or higher. Roads
upstream from Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the
community of Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have
water on them and are subject to being closed. Also, flooding of
forested areas near the river will occur.

Alert:
Mississippi River At Aitkin affecting Aitkin and Crow Wing Counties
Mississippi River at Fort Ripley affecting Crow Wing and Morrison
Counties

.Recent snowfall has been followed by warmer temperatures. The result
has been melting snow running off into rivers and keeping river
levels hovering just below flood stage. River levels will rise to
minor flood stage by Wednesday morning and continue steadily rising
due to runoff from melting snow and precipitation expected on
Wednesday and Thursday. There is a chance for the Mississippi at
Aitkin to rise to Moderate Flood stage this weekend.
The National Weather Service in Duluth has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Mississippi River at Fort Ripley.
* from Wednesday morning until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 9.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tomorrow morning and continue
to rise to near 11.0 feet by Monday evening. additional rises are
possible thereafter.
* At 11.0 feet...This will cause minor flooding of rural areas near
Fort Ripley..
This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.7 feet on Apr 28 1975.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio for further updates...

For the most recent river information go to our web page at
www.weather.gov/dlh
and visit the AHPS/River information section for complete details.

Turn around, don't drown. Don't drive through flooded areas.
Alert:
Mississippi River At Aitkin affecting Aitkin and Crow Wing Counties
Mississippi River at Fort Ripley affecting Crow Wing and Morrison
Counties

.Recent snowfall has been followed by warmer temperatures. The result
has been melting snow running off into rivers and keeping river
levels hovering just below flood stage. River levels will rise to
minor flood stage by Wednesday morning and continue steadily rising
due to runoff from melting snow and precipitation expected on
Wednesday and Thursday. There is a chance for the Mississippi at
Aitkin to rise to Moderate Flood stage this weekend.
The National Weather Service in Duluth has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Mississippi River At Aitkin.
* from Wednesday morning until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 12.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tomorrow morning and continue
to rise to near 15.8 feet by Tuesday morning. additional rises are
possible thereafter.
* At 15.0 feet...A few homes become surrounded by water in the
Cedarbrook neighborhood near Eagle Rd. The Aitkin city park becomes
flooded..
This crest compares to a previous crest of 17.7 feet on Apr 28 2001.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio for further updates...

and visit the AHPS/River information section for complete details.

Saturday afternoon. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At 21.0 feet...The main east-west highway begins to flood on the
east bank of the river and the water overtops the bridge 2 miles
south and 1 mile east of Ashton.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Flood waters can be very dangerous. Never drive
across a flooded road. Turn around don't drown!

Stay tuned for further updates by listening to NOAA weather radio...
or your favorite local media.

For additional information...check out our web site at
www.weather.gov/abr...then left click on the Rivers and Lakes link.

The next scheduled statement will be issued on Wednesday.

James River At Ashton
James River Near Redfield

the next 24 hours. Any additional future precipitation could affect
the forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The James River At Columbia.
* until further notice.
* At 10:15 AM Tuesday the stage was 18.6 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain steady for the next several days,
then will slowly begin to fall.
* At 18.5 feet...The water reaches the bottom of the bridge at the
gauging location on Brown County 16..

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
* WINDS...West 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 55 mph.

* TIMING...Through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...Difficult driving conditions, especially for larger
vehicles traveling along roads with crosswinds. Light,
unsecured objects may become airborne. Minor tree damage
possible.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained wind speeds of between
30 and 40 mph are expected, or wind gusts of between 40 and
58 mph. Winds this strong can make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. In addition, strong winds over desert
areas could result in briefly lowered visibilities to well under
a mile at times in blowing dust or blowing sand. Use extra
caution.
Alert:
* WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.

* TIMING...This afternoon and evening.

* IMPACTS...Difficult driving conditions, especially for larger
vehicles traveling along roads with crosswinds. Light,

58 mph. Winds this strong can make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. In addition, strong winds over desert

caution.

* Halstad...on the Red River ...in Norman and Traill Counties
* East Grand Forks...on the Red River ...in Polk and Grand Forks
Counties
* Oslo...on the Red River ...in Marshall...Polk...Grand Forks and
Walsh Counties
* Drayton...on the Red River ...in Kittson...Marshall...Pembina and
Walsh Counties
* Pembina...on the Red River ...in Kittson and Pembina Counties
* Abercrombie...on the Wild Rice River (ND) ...in Richland County


.Runoff from snowmelt is expected to wrap up today as any remaining
snow will be melted by warm temperatures today. However, rain is
expected across the region late tonight and through the day
Wednesday. The combination of the remainder of the snowmelt and
upcoming rainfall is driving a secondary rise and/or slow decline in
water levels in regional rivers. This current forecast
incorporates the rainfall forecast for the next 48 hours.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Halstad...on the Red River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 38.0 feet.
* Major flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Major
flooding is forecast.
* Major Flood Stage is 37.5 feet.
* Forecast...the river will continue to fall to a stage of 37.5 feet
by Wednesday mid-morning.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 38.0 feet, US Highway 75 closure installed
on the south side of the Halstad ring dike.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not attempt to drive through a flooded road. The
depth of water is not always obvious. As little as two feet of water
will carry most cars away. Also, the road bed may be washed out under
the water, and you could be stranded or trapped. Additional
information is available at http://water.weather.gov. Once there,
click on the Tennessee Valley to view local river information.

Counties.

.Recent heavy rains have caused significant rises along the river.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Tombigbee River Near Leroy
* until further notice.
* At 10 AM Tuesday the stage was 25.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 24 feet.
* The river will continue rising to near 26.6 feet by Friday morning.
Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At 24 feet...Flooding of low lying farm and pasturelands begins. Cattle in
low lying areas should be moved to higher ground.

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather radio.

* Flood stage is 29 feet.
* The river will continue rising to near 34.5 feet by Friday morning then begin
falling by early Saturday morning.

Alert:
Black River At Black Rock affecting Independence...Jackson and
Lawrence Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Cache River Near Patterson.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 9.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 10.0 feet by
Sunday morning.
* Impacts at 10.0 feet...Pastureland and cropland not protected by
levees in Jackson and Woodruff counties affected. Water is over
portions of State Highway 37 and deep along the shoulders of State
Highway 18 near Grubbs. Water over portions of Woodruff County Road
775 north of State Highway 260.

Alert:
White River At Augusta affecting White and Woodruff Counties

White River At Clarendon affecting Arkansas and Monroe Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 24 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River At Clarendon.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 27.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain elevated through the remainder of
the week with the rain chances in the forecast.
* Impacts at 26.0 feet...River flows in many side channels and creates
islands between the river and sloughs and creeks. Flooding of cropland
and timber is occurring. Portions of the National Wildlife Refuge
downstream of Clarendon flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.
Alert:
Southerly winds will gradually strengthen with building seas
tonight and Thursday.
The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston has issued a
Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 7 PM this evening
to 7 AM CDT Thursday.

* WINDS...south and southeast winds 15 to 20 knots with gusts
near 25 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...4 to 6 feet nearshore and 5 to 8 feet offshore.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots...
and/or seas 7 feet or higher...are expected to produce hazardous
conditions for small craft. Inexperienced boaters...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northwest 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to 25 kt.

* SEAS...8 to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northwest 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to 25 kt.

* SEAS...6 to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS...Northwest around 20 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* SEAS...6 to 9 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

A Dam Floodgate Release in...
Northwestern Umatilla County in northeastern Oregon...

* Until 830 PM PDT Tuesday.

* At 818 AM PDT, reporting gauges indicate a flow of around 1700 cfs
which is still capable of producing minor flooding along the lower
Mckay Creek.

interested parties should take necessary precautions immediately.

* Until further notice.
* At 10 AM Tuesday the stage was 8.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue rising to near 8.1 feet by  2 PM
Tuesday ...Then begin falling.
* Impact...At 8.0 feet...Water reaches moderate flood stage. Water
surrounds several homes on Schroon River Road.

Alert:
Trinity River At Trinidad Affecting Henderson and Navarro Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trinity River At Trinidad.
* At 1000 AM Tuesday the stage was 34.22 feet.
* Flood stage is 33 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to a crest near 35 feet
by Wednesday after midnight. The river should fall below flood
stage Thursday after midnight.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.
Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.
Stay tuned to NOAA All Hazards Radio for the latest river forecasts.

find an alternate route.

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 10 to 20 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.
Seas 4 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that sustained wind speeds or
frequent gusts of 25 to 33 kt and/or seas of 5 ft or higher are
expected or occurring, and hazardous to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 15 to 20 kt with gusts up to 25 kt.
Ocean seas 3 to 5 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that sustained wind speeds or
frequent gusts of 25 to 33 kt and/or seas of 5 ft or higher are
expected or occurring, and hazardous to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
* EVENT...Southerly winds will increase to around 15-20 mph with
higher gusts, mainly over western sections of the region.

* TIMING...11 AM this morning through 6 PM this evening.

* IMPACT...Rough chop will make for hazardous boating conditions
on open area waterways.
Instruction:
A Lake Wind Advisory indicates that winds will cause rough chop
on area lakes. Small boats will be especially prone to capsizing.
Alert:
Iroquois River near Foresman affecting Newton County

The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation as well
as forecast precipitation 24-48 hours into the future.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Iroquois River near Foresman, or from Near I-65 east of Foresman
downstream to near US-41 north of Kentland.
* until Wednesday afternoon.
* At  945 AM Tuesday the stage was 15.7 feet.
* Action stage is 15.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 15.7 feet through this afternoon.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

find an alternate route.

Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River Near Blair.
* until Monday April 29.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 24.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.5 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 24.9 feet this afternoon.
* Impact...at 26.5 feet...Flooding is occurring in the Fort Calhoun
area.  This flooding affects several homes and includes County
Roads 34, 47 and 51.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...Minor flooding occurs at the Fort Calhoun
trailer park.
* Impact...at 23.5 feet...Flooding begins to occur at Wilson Island
State Park.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.
Alert:
Chickasawhay River At Enterprise affecting Clarke County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Chickasawhay River At Enterprise
* until Wednesday morning.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 25.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river has crested and will fall below
flood stage tonight.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.
Alert:
Missouri River Near Blair affecting Harrison and Washington
Counties.

Missouri River At Omaha affecting Pottawattamie...Douglas and Sarpy
Counties.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Missouri River At Omaha.
* until Monday April 29.
* At  9:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 26.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 29.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 26.4 feet this afternoon.
* Impact...at 28.0 feet...At this level most of the flood gates for
the city of Council Bluffs are closed.
* Impact...at 27.0 feet...NP Dodge Park, Freedom Park, Tom Hanafan
Park and Fontenelle Forest begin to flood.
* Impact...at 25.0 feet...A casino parking lot begins to flood along
the Iowa side of the river.  In addition, Haworth Park located in
Bellevue begins to flood.
* Impact...at 21.0 feet...At this level the City of Council Bluffs
begins closing flood gates.
* Impact...at 19.0 feet...At this level, the City of Council Bluffs
begins to close drainage gates that discharge into the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through areas where water covers the road.  The
water depth may be too great to allow your vehicle to pass safely.
Turn around...don't drown!

Stay tuned to the latest developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio...or a local media outlet.
Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for
the Meramec River near Arnold
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 30.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to continue rising to near 30.3 feet by this
afternoon. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

Alert:
Big Muddy River near Murphysboro

.Minor flooding continues along the Big Muddy River near Murphysboro.
Water levels continue to rise and the river is forecast to crest
near 25.0 feet on Thursday morning. The river is forecast to fall
below flood stage early next week.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Big Muddy River near Murphysboro.
* until Monday evening.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 24.4 feet.
* Flood Stage is 22.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 25.0 feet by Thursday morning.
The river will fall below flood stage Monday afternoon.
* Impact...At 24.0 Feet...Some minor flooding in S 3rd & Division /
Plum Street area.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Alert:
Wolf River near Shiocton affecting Outagamie...Shawano and Waupaca
Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wolf River near Shiocton.
* At  7:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 11.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...the river will continue rising to near 12.3 feet by
early Sunday morning then begin falling.
* Impacts at 11.5 feet. There is minor flooding at the city park
along with lowland and adjacent agricultural land.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Persons with interests along this river need to prepare for flooding.
Stay tuned for further updates on this flooding situation.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
Kaskaskia River at Carlyle TW

.This Flood Warning is a result of releases from Carlyle Dam...
The Flood Warning continues for
the Kaskaskia River at Carlyle TW
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 425.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 423.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river will continue to fall to a stage of 425.8 feet by
tomorrow morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
Alert:
Kankakee River at Shelby affecting Lake and Newton Counties

The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation as well
as forecast precipitation 24-48 hours into the future.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Kankakee River at Shelby, or from Near I-65 and De Motte
downstream to IL/IN state line.
* until Saturday afternoon.
* At  845 AM Tuesday the stage was 9.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 9.3 feet by early
Wednesday. The river will fall below flood stage Saturday morning.
* Impact...At 9.0 feet...Lowland agricultural flooding begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...If you encounter a flooded roadway...turn around and
find an alternate route.
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Bayou D'Arbonne At Lake D'Arbonne near Farmerville, Louisiana.
* until late Thursday night...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 8:45 AM Tuesday The pool stage was 83.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 83 feet.
* Forecast...The lake will continue to fall to below flood pool stage by
Thursday morning.
* Impact...at 84.0 feet...Expect significant flooding of several
secondary roadways that will result in several residents being
cutoff from major highways. Several low are homes will be in danger
of flooding and homeowners should take steps to protect property.
Nearly all camps will suffer from flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

Alert:
Black River At Jonesville L&D affecting Catahoula and Concordia
Parishes
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Black River At Jonesville L&D
* from Saturday morning until further notice.
* At  5:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 49.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 50.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is expected to rise to near flood stage
Saturday morning
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 49.6 feet
on Jan 24 2016.
* Impact...At 50.0 feet...Highway 124 south near the town of Larto
starts to flood. Backwater flooding begins in unprotected areas on
right bank.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Forecasts are based on rainfall that has occurred and that which is
forecast to occur. Routine 24 hours of forecast rainfall is used for
all rivers  except for those in the Tombigbee River System which
includes Tibbee Creek,  Luxapallila Creek, Noxubee River,and the
Tombigbee River mainstem where a routine of 48 hours of additional
rainfall is used.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.
Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Little River Of Louisiana Near Rochelle.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 8:30 AM Tuesday The stage was 34.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 32 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 35.5 feet by
early Wednesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...at 35.0 feet...Expect considerable lowland flooding of
hunting camps.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when

Alert:
French Broad River At Blantyre affecting Henderson and Transylvania
Counties

River levels continue to slowly recede following the recent heavy
rainfall. No further flooding is expected at this time.
The Flood Advisory has expired for
The French Broad River At Blantyre
* At 10 AM Tuesday the stage was 15.1 feet and falling.
* Action Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 16.0 feet.
* FORECAST: The river crested below Minor Flood Stage at 15.7 feet.
The river will continue to fall to 12.2 feet by Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS: At 15.0 feet: Action Stage.  Most farm fields are flooding
between the French Broad River and Brevard Rd. and between the
French Broad River and Pleasant Grove Rd..
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

A Flood Advisory for a river forecast point means that nuisance
flooding is expected to occur along the river when the river level is
forecast to be just below or at the official flood stage.

Caution is urged when walking near river banks...keep children away
from drainage areas and culverts.
Alert:
Missouri River at St Joseph affecting Doniphan...Andrew and
Buchanan Counties.

Missouri River at Napoleon affecting Jackson...Lafayette and Ray
Counties.

Missouri River at Waverly affecting Carroll...Lafayette and Saline
Counties.

Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline
Counties.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River At Miami.
* until further notice.
* At  8:50 AM Tuesday the stage was 19.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 19.5 feet by
Saturday morning.
* At 18.0 feet...Low-lying rural areas outside of levees begin to
flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

Alert:
Strong onshore flow has subsided over the Gulf waters this
morning. But southeast flow will increase to strong levels in
bays south of Port Aransas late morning and this afternoon.
Southeast winds will ranged from 15 to 20 knots. Seas will ranged
from 4 to 6 feet. Mariners operating in small craft should
exercise caution.
Instruction:

Alert:
Strong onshore flow has subsided over the Gulf waters this
morning. But southeast flow will increase to strong levels in
bays south of Port Aransas late morning and this afternoon.
* WINDS...Southeast 20 to 25 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...Bays becoming choppy to occasionally rough.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Ouachita River At Columbia, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 6:00 AM Tuesday The pool stage was 65.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 65 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 66.0 feet by
Friday evening.  Additional rises remain possible thereafter.
* Impact...at 67.0 feet...The Columbia Lock and Dam recreational area
floods and must be closed. In addition, expect moderate to severe
flooding of lowland river bottoms between and near levee systems.
Secure boats and private boat launches for high water.  Expect high
water to continue through at least the first week of May.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

Alert:
Minor to moderate flooding continues along the Mississippi
River.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Guttenberg Dam 10.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 17.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 17.5 feet
by Wednesday morning.
* Impact...At 15.5 feet...The water is over Marina Road.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .
Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Mississippi..

Noxubee River At Macon affecting Noxubee County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Noxubee River At Macon
* until Thursday evening.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 30.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue falling and will fall below
flood stage Thursday morning.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Pearl River Near Columbia affecting Marion County

The Pearl River Near Columbia
* from Thursday afternoon until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Tuesday the stage was 14.8 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage early Thursday
afternoon and will continue to rise to near 17.5 feet early Friday
afternoon.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Low areas near the river begin to flood.
Water covers Old Highway 35 on the west side of the river.

side of the river begins to flood.

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
