Alert:
Wabash River...White River...

.Lowland flooding has developed and will continue to develop this
week along much of the Wabash River, as well as portions of the
White River south of Bowling Green.  Significant flooding is not
expected on any central and southern Indiana area rivers.

A potentially substantial rainfall event is expected
Thursday through Thursday night, with lighter amounts continuing
into Saturday. This rain will likely lead to renewed flooding in
areas where flooding has ended and is expected to lead to more
severe flooding than is currently ongoing.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Hutsonville Legacy Power Plant Site.
* until late Sunday night.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 18.2 feet Friday morning and
will fall below flood stage by Sunday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...Seep water occurs behind levees on Indiana side.
Hutson Creek begins to overflow from backwater.  Old Darwin Road
and a few rural roads in eastern Clark and Crawford counties in
Illinois are impassable.  Low agricultural land floods.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
Wabash River...White River...

.Lowland flooding has developed and will continue to develop this
week along much of the Wabash River, as well as portions of the
White River south of Bowling Green.  Significant flooding is not
expected on any central and southern Indiana area rivers.

A potentially substantial rainfall event is expected
Thursday through Thursday night, with lighter amounts continuing
into Saturday. This rain will likely lead to renewed flooding in
areas where flooding has ended and is expected to lead to more
severe flooding than is currently ongoing.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Covington.
* until Thursday morning.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 16.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 16.9 feet by this evening then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Wednesday evening.
* At 17.5 feet...Some low agricultural fields flood.  Backyard flood
of cottages a short distance north of U.S. Highway 136.  High water
blocks land access to at least one residence.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Montezuma.
* until Friday evening.
* At  9:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 16.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 17.2 feet by Wednesday morning then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Friday morning.
* At 18.0 feet...Montezuma agricultural levee is overtopped.  Fourteen
hundred acres of low bottomlands flood.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

click on rivers and lakes.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Mount Carmel.
* from Wednesday evening to late Saturday night.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 17.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday evening and continue
to rise to near 19.1 feet by late Friday night.  It will fall below
flood stage by Saturday afternoon.
* At 18.4 feet...Pumping started at Mt. Carmel.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and

conditions.

click on rivers and lakes.

The Wabash River at Lafayette.

* At  9:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 11.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 11.6 feet by this afternoon then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Wednesday morning.
* At 12.0 feet...High water affects a few low river cabins and county
roads.

The White River at Petersburg.
* until Saturday evening.
* At  9:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 16.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 17.7 feet by Thursday morning then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Saturday morning.
* At 18.0 feet...Lowland flooding begins to flood several Pike County
roads.  Many of the following county roads begin to flood around
this level...east of SR 57 include CR 750N...CR 600N and CR 1000E.
Pike county road subject to flooding west of SR 57 include...CR 250
W...CR 400W...CR 675N...CR 700 N...CR  1000w...CR 900W...CR 700W
and CR 775W.

The White River at Edwardsport.
* until Saturday morning.
* At  7:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 16.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 17.6 feet by Wednesday morning then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Friday evening.
* At 17.5 feet...Flooding closes Old Vincennes Road.  High water
crosses SR 358 on the Daviess County side just west of the levee.
Flooding begins to affect higher bottomlands.  Residential property
of river cabins begins to flood.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Terre Haute.
* until Saturday morning.
* At  9:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 17.4 feet. This is 2.0 to 2.5
feet higher than the observations from the old legacy gauge.
* Flood stage is 16.5 feet. This is 2.5 feet higher than flood stage
from the old legacy gauge.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 18.2 feet by Wednesday evening then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Friday evening.
* At 18.5 feet...Lowest river cabins across from the Wabash Generating
Station begin to flood. Flooding of agricultural land along U.S. 63
north of Terre Haute, west bank of river and in southwest Vigo
County occurs. County roads flood in southwest Vigo County. The
wetland projects between U.S. 40 and I-70 begin to slowly fill.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Hazleton.
* until Sunday afternoon.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 18.4 feet late Thursday night
and will fall below flood stage by late Saturday night.
* At 18.0 feet...Floodwaters cover much low ground in agricultural
season.  Low lying oil fields...Pottsville Road and possibly a few
other low rural roads flood.  High water isolates Pottstown, a
river cabin community.

Alert:
Wabash River...White River...

The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Riverton.
* until late Sunday night.
* At 10:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 16.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 17.0 feet by Friday evening then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Sunday afternoon.
* At 18.0 feet...Extensive lowland flooding is in progress.  High
water surrounds many river cabins.  Access to most river cabins is
by boat only.  Levees begin to protect farmland.  Extensive
flooding of Leaverton Park occurs in Palestine, Illinois.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:
Winds are diminishing. Occasional gusts to 20 knots may linger
into the afternoon.
Instruction:

Alert:
Fox River Near Berlin affecting Green Lake County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Fox River Near Berlin.
* At  8:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 13.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage
early Monday morning.
* Impact...At 13.2 feet...There is minor flooding in the Berlin area
including in Riverside and Webster Street Parks in Berlin.
Instruction:

Alert:

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv
Alert:
Cottonwood River at New Ulm affecting Brown County
Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County
Crow River at Rockford affecting Hennepin and Wright Counties
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...Wisconsin..
Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Chippewa...Lac qui Parle
and Yellow Medicine Counties
Minnesota River At Morton  affecting Renville County
Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown and Nicollet Counties
Minnesota River at Henderson MN19 affecting Le Sueur...Scott and
Sibley Counties
Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver and Scott Counties
Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota...Hennepin and Scott
Counties
Mississippi River at St. Paul affecting Dakota...Ramsey and
Washington Counties
Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota...
Washington and Pierce Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...Snowmelt continues from last week's weather system,
with area rivers generally falling but expected to rise with another
system this week. Forecast rainfall amounts have fallen a bit since
yesterday, which bodes well for area rivers as flood levels will remain
lower as a result.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Montevideo.
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 16.7 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 19.4 feet by
Sunday evening then begin falling.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Sanitary sewers begin to be affected at this
level.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Storm sewers may need to be plugged to
prevent water from backing up into streets.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along the
river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Redwood River near Redwood Falls.
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 6.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 8.6 feet by
Friday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 8.5 feet...Swayback bridge in Redwood Falls overtopped.
* Impact...At 6.0 feet...Low lying areas, mainly farmland, and some
roads along the river begin to experience flooding; bottom of
Swayback bridge

* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 28.0 feet by
Sunday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 26.7 feet...The bridge at Scott County Road 9 and Carver
County Road 11/Jonathan Carver Parkway will be closed.
* Impact...At 25.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin to flood and private sanitary sewers may experience
problems.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at St. Paul.
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 14.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 15.6 feet by
Monday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Portions of the Lilydale park area begin to
experience flooding.
* Impact...At 13.3 feet...Water begins to encroach on Water St.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.
Alert:
Cottonwood River at New Ulm affecting Brown County
Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County

Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...Snowmelt continues from last week's weather system,
with area rivers generally falling but expected to rise with another
system this week. Forecast rainfall amounts have fallen a bit since

lower as a result.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Savage.
* until further notice.
* Flood stage is 702.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is forecast to have a maximum value of 708.4
feet Tuesday morning.
* Impact...At 705.0 feet...Flood waters begin to impact the park road
at Fort Snelling State Park.
* Impact...At 702.0 feet...Barge loading stops at Port Cargill, and
other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact
Black Dog Road in Burnsville.
* Impact...At 700.0 feet...Flood waters begin to cover trails at Fort
Snelling State Park as well as low parts on the Bloomington Ferry
Bridge trail just east of US 169.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.
Alert:
Cottonwood River at New Ulm affecting Brown County
Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County
Crow River at Rockford affecting Hennepin and Wright Counties
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota...Wisconsin..
Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Chippewa...Lac qui Parle
and Yellow Medicine Counties
Minnesota River At Morton  affecting Renville County
Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown and Nicollet Counties
Minnesota River at Henderson MN19 affecting Le Sueur...Scott and
Sibley Counties
Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver and Scott Counties
Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota...Hennepin and Scott
Counties
Mississippi River at St. Paul affecting Dakota...Ramsey and
Washington Counties
Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota...
Washington and Pierce Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview...Snowmelt continues from last week's weather system,
with area rivers generally falling but expected to rise with another
system this week. Forecast rainfall amounts have fallen a bit since
yesterday, which bodes well for area rivers as flood levels will remain
lower as a result.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At New Ulm.
* until further notice.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 802.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 800.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 804.3 feet by
early Tuesday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 796.0 feet...Water impacts park land and boat launch
access road is closed.
* Impact...At 795.0 feet...Water begins to impact the access roads in
the floodplain.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

with area rivers generally falling but expected to rise with another

The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Henderson MN19.
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 733.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 732.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 734.0 feet by
Friday evening then begin falling.
* Impact...At 733.7 feet...The floodwall gates will be closed when
Henderson reaches 733.7 and the river is still rising at Mankato.
* Impact...At 733.5 feet...Highway 93 may be closed between Henderson
and Hwy 169.
* Impact...At 732.5 feet...Water begins encroaching on highway 19 east
of Henderson.
* Impact...At 732.0 feet...Water begins impacting residences and
agricultural buildings north and south of Henderson.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

for the latest information concerning this flood event.

.Overview...Snowmelt continues from last week's weather system,
with area rivers generally falling but expected to rise with another

lower as a result.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At Morton .
* until further notice.
* At  8:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 24.9 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 26.8 feet by
early Tuesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Numerous roads flooded and impassable
between the Minnesota River and Redwood Falls.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Fleischer Rd flooded in North Redwood; storm
sewers closed off and bypass pumping begins.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in
North Redwood.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Water reaches flood mitigation culverts on
Riverside Road
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.
Alert:
* Sabin...on the South Branch Buffalo River...in Clay County
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Shelly...on the Marsh River ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County


.Runoff from snowmelt is expected to wrap up today as any remaining
snow will be melted by warm temperatures today. However, rain is
expected across the region late tonight and through the day
Wednesday. The combination of the remainder of the snowmelt and
upcoming rainfall is driving a secondary rise and/or slow decline in
water levels in regional rivers. This current forecast
incorporates the rainfall forecast for the next 48 hours.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Sabin...on the South Branch Buffalo River.
* from Wednesday evening to Monday afternoon...or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 11.1 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...rise above Flood Stage by Wednesday night and continue
to rise to near 13.5 feet by early Friday morning. The river will
fall below Flood Stage by Sunday mid-morning.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 14.0 feet, Agricultural flooding begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
Recent warm temperatures have caused increased snowmelt and
weakened the remaining river ice across northern Maine. Rivers
will continue to rise over the next 12 to 24 hours due to the
recent snowmelt and rain in the Flood Watch area. Small river
flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the region
today. Smaller rivers will crest this morning and begin to trend
down tonight into Wednesday. River ice will continue to move on
the Aroostook and Saint John River systems over the next 24 hours.
Ice jam flooding could be possible, especially in areas that had
pre-existing ice jams from this past winter.
The Flood Watch continues for

* A portion of Far Northern Maine, including the following
areas, Northeast Aroostook and Northwest Aroostook.

* Through late tonight.

* Snowmelt may lead to ice jam flooding along the Saint John and
Aroostook Rivers. The highest threat areas for flooding will be
in regions that have pre-existing ice jams from this past
winter.

* A second flood threat will be small stream flooding with many
small streams already at or near bankfull. This could lead to
flooding in lowland areas bordering the streams. Low lying
roads and small stream crossings could become impassable due
to flooding. Never drive into a flooded road, turn around
don't drown. Small streams and rivers will crest this morning
and begin to trend down over the next day.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.
Alert:
* Sabin...on the South Branch Buffalo River...in Clay County
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County

* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County

and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks
Alert:
* Sabin...on the South Branch Buffalo River...in Clay County
* Alvarado...on the Snake River...in Marshall County

...The flood warning continues for these river locations in
Minnesota...

* Hawley...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Dilworth...on the Buffalo River ...in Clay County
* Hendrum...on the Wild Rice River (MN) ...in Norman County
* Shelly...on the Marsh River ...in Norman County
* Climax...on the Sandhill River ...in Polk County
* Crookston...on the Red Lake River ...in Polk County
* Hallock...on the Two Rivers River ...in Kittson County


.Runoff from snowmelt is expected to wrap up today as any remaining
snow will be melted by warm temperatures today. However, rain is
expected across the region late tonight and through the day
Wednesday. The combination of the remainder of the snowmelt and
upcoming rainfall is driving a secondary rise and/or slow decline in
water levels in regional rivers. This current forecast
incorporates the rainfall forecast for the next 48 hours.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Hawley...on the Buffalo River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 8.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and during the next 7 days...Moderate
flooding is forecast.
* Moderate Flood Stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...the river will rise to a crest near 9.5 feet sometime
Thursday mid-morning then begin falling.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 10.0 feet, Bankfull Stage.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River At Edinburg
* until further notice.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 21.2 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 22.0 feet by early
tomorrow afternoon.
* Impact...At 21.0 feet...Minor over bank flooding continues in areas
south of the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 24 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

Alert:
Surface high pressure across the northern Gulf combined with
lower pressure inland will support a tighter pressure gradient,
stronger southeast to south winds, and elevated seas today through
late Wednesday.
* WINDS...Southeast winds around 20 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...5 to 7 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has issued a

* Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Snowmelt in...
East central Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 1015 PM EDT Tuesday.

* At 1020 AM EDT, emergency management reported snowmelt causing
small stream flooding in Island Falls.  MDOT has closed Route 2 in
Island Falls at the Dyer Brook bridge due to flooding caused by
ice and snowmelt.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Island Falls.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-
5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You may also contact
local law enforcement.

A Flood Advisory means river or stream flows are elevated, or ponding
of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.

Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

Dakota...

* Kindred...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass and Richland Counties
* West Fargo Diversion...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Harwood...on the Sheyenne River ...in Cass County
* Mapleton...on the Maple River ...in Cass County


.Runoff from snowmelt is expected to wrap up today as any remaining
snow will be melted by warm temperatures today. However, rain is
expected across the region late tonight and through the day
Wednesday. The combination of the remainder of the snowmelt and
upcoming rainfall is driving a secondary rise and/or slow decline in
water levels in regional rivers. This current forecast
incorporates the rainfall forecast for the next 48 hours.


This forecast is for a 7-day period...the highest stage
indicated may not reflect the crest for this event.

Forecasts are updated daily and stage values will change
as new weather and river information is used.

River forecasts use 24 hours of forecast precipitation
between April 1st and October 1st, and 48 hours otherwise.
However, depending on the situation, they may include
precipitation expected through the next 72 hours.
The Flood Warning continues for...
* ...Mapleton...on the Maple River.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  8:15 AM Tuesday the stage was 17.5 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 18.0 feet.
* Forecast...rise above Flood Stage by Tuesday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 20.5 feet by Thursday evening.
* Impact Statement(s) - At 21.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

* Enderlin...on the Maple River...in Cass and Ransom Counties

Alert:
The Small Craft Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 10 to 15 kt with gusts up to 25
kt. Seas 3 to 6 feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
Neuse River At Kinston affecting Lenoir County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Neuse River At Kinston.
* from this afternoon until further notice.
* At  9 AM Tuesday the stage was 13.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by this afternoon and continue to
rise to near 16.3 feet by early Sunday morning. Additional rises
are possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flooding of the campground at the Nature
Center is expected. Water encroaches onto other properties along
the south side of the river.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive vehicles through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur
in automobiles when people try to drive through flooded areas.

Stay tuned to developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio...local
radio...media or cable TV.
Alert:
Ouachita River At Camden affecting Calhoun and Ouachita Counties

Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D affecting Bradley...Calhoun and
Union Counties


River forecasts are based on current conditions and rainfall
forecasted to occur over the next 48 hours. During periods of
flooding...Evening forecasts are reissued with updated rainfall
forecasts.

Observed and forecasted stage data plots are available on our
Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service web page at...
www.weather.gov/lzk
Under the Current Conditions section...Select River and Lakes AHPS.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 8:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 86.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 79.0 feet.
* Forecast...With an additional round of heavy rainfall expected
on Wednesday, the river will remain elevated through the week.
* Impacts at 85.0 feet...There may be some County roads along the
river flooded, requiring lengthy detours. River is high and swift,
boaters should be very cautious. Access to many oil and gas rigs
will be by boat only. Levee gates should be closed.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Remember to Turn Around...Don't Drown
Do not drive cars through flooded areas.

Everyone with property or other interest along streams and rivers
should remain alert to changing weather forecasts. Should conditions
change...Look for river forecasts or Flood Warnings for use in making
informed decisions to protect life and property.

Alert:
* WINDS AND SEAS...West winds 20 to 25 kt with gusts up to 35
kt. Waves Around 2 feet.
Instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

Alert:
Big Sioux River AT Watertown
Big Sioux River Near Castlewood

.The following river forecasts include forecast precipitation through
the next 24 hours. Any additional future precipitation could affect
the forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Sioux River Near Castlewood.
* until further notice.
* At 8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 10.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 12.3 feet by
Wednesday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At 11.7 feet...Significant amounts of pasture and other
agricultural land will be flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Flood waters can be very dangerous. Never drive
across a flooded road. Turn around don't drown!

Stay tuned for further updates by listening to NOAA weather radio...
or your favorite local media.

For additional information...check out our web site at
www.weather.gov/abr...then left click on the Rivers and Lakes link.

The next scheduled statement will be issued on Wednesday.

Alert:
The Winter Weather Advisory has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WINDS...Sustained west to northwest 20 to 30 mph, with gusts
near 55 mph.

* TIMING...West to northwest winds will be strongest late this
afternoon into this evening.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds may blow down limbs, trees, and power
lines. A few power outages are possible. Highways affected
include, but are not limited to Highway 14 and Highway 58 below
Tehachapi Pass, including the town of Mojave.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that wind gusts of 45 to 57 mph are
expected. Wind gusts this strong can make driving difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
Snowmelt and periods of rain will result in higher water levels
along the Black River near Black River Falls.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The National Weather Service in La Crosse WI has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Black River at Black River Falls.
* from Wednesday afternoon to late Thursday night.
* At  7:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 44.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 47.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday and continue to rise
to near 47.4 feet by Wednesday evening. The river will fall below
flood stage by Thursday morning.
* Impact...At 47.0 feet...Some rural roads may begin to flood
including county Highway VV downstream near the La Crosse County
line.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



If you live in a threatened area, be alert for high or rising water,
and be ready to move to higher ground if necessary.

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Stay tuned to your favorite source of weather information, including
NOAA Weather Radio, for later statements.

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has extended the

* Flood Advisory for Minor Flooding in Poor Drainage Areas for...
An Ice Jam in...
Eastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 1015 AM EDT Wednesday.

* At 959 AM EDT, local law enforcement reported an ice jam causing
minor flooding in Fort Fairfield on the Russell Road. Overflowing
poor drainage areas will result in minor flooding. Flooding is
expected to continue in this area until the ice jam above Tinker
Dam releases.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Fort Fairfield.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You
may also contact local law enforcement.

A Flood Advisory means river or stream flows are elevated, or ponding
of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
Alert:
Snowmelt and periods of rain will result in higher water levels
along the Trempealeau River near Dodge through the weekend.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Trempealeau River at Dodge.
* from Wednesday afternoon to Saturday morning...Or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At  8:45 AM Tuesday the stage was 7.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday and continue to rise
to near 9.6 feet by Thursday evening. The river will fall below
flood stage by Friday.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...The entrance road to the Trempealeau National
Wildlife Refuge is flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Eastern Aroostook County in northern Maine...

* Until 115 PM EDT.

* At 955 AM EDT, local law enforcement reported an ice jam causing
minor flooding in Fort Fairfield on the Russell Road. Overflowing

expected to continue in this area until the ice jam above Tinker
Dam releases.

Alert:
Wabash River at New Harmony

.The Wabash River at New Harmony is expected to rise above flood stage
by Wednesday morning and continue rising to a crest of 15.3 feet by
Thursday afternoon. It is forecast to fall below flood stage on
Sunday afternoon.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Wabash River at New Harmony.
* from late tonight to Sunday evening.
* At  8:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 14.2 feet.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Wednesday morning and the crest
near 15.3 feet by Thursday afternoon. The river will fall below flood
stage on Sunday afternoon.
* Impact...At 15.0 Feet...The river overflows low ground on the
Illinois side.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

Alert:
Embarras River at Lawrenceville affecting Lawrence County

.The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation, soil
moisture conditions, and forecast precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Embarras River at Lawrenceville.
* Until late tonight.
* At 745 AM Tuesday the stage was 30.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 30.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
tonight.
* Impact...At 30.0 feet...Minor agricultural flooding begins.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, don't drown.

www.weather.gov/ilx.

* At  9:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 21.66 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 22.8 feet by early Thursday

James River At Richmond Westham affecting Chesterfield...City of
Richmond and Henrico Counties
For the Lower James Basin...including Richmond Westham...Minor
flooding is forecast.
The National Weather Service in Wakefield Va has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The James River At Richmond Westham.
* until this evening...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 07:30 AM Tuesday the stage was 11.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to rise this morning to near
12.1 by early Tuesday afternoon.  The river will then fall below
flood stage by late Tuesday afternoon.
* At 12.0 feet...Flood stage. Minor flooding along both banks, no
damage at this level.
This river level is comparable to a previous crest of 12.2 feet on
Apr 22 2015.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Please use extreme caution if venturing near riverbanks. Move to
higher ground immediately should rising water threaten your safety.

www.weather.gov/akq.  Click on the Rivers and Lakes icon beneath the
point and click forecast map.

Alert:
West northwest winds will strengthen Tuesday afternoon into the
evening. Gusts are expected to reach 25 knots over the outer
waters, with a brief period of gusts above 21 knots possible over
portions of the inner waters as well.
* Winds...West northwest gusting 20 to 25 knots over the outer
waters. Brief gusts above 21 knots possible over the inner
waters during late afternoon and early evening hours.

* Waves/Seas...Peaking at 7 to 8 FT over the outer waters, and 6
FT over the inner waters.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
Paint Rock River near Woodville affecting Jackson...Madison and
Marshall Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
the Paint Rock River near Woodville.
* until this afternoon.
* At 6 AM Tuesday the stage was 15.6 feet and falling.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Recent activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at
6 AM Tuesday was 16.5 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below Flood Stage by
this morning.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Flood waters affect mostly bottomland along
the river...including low lying farm and pasturelands.
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.3 feet
on Feb 20 2019.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not attempt to drive through a flooded road. The
depth of water is not always obvious. As little as two feet of water
will carry most cars away. Also, the road bed may be washed out under
the water, and you could be stranded or trapped. Additional
information is available at http://water.weather.gov. Once there,
click on the Tennessee Valley to view local river information.

Alert:
Strong southwest winds will redevelop late this morning
persisting through the afternoon, combining with a dry and very
unstable atmosphere and above normal afternoon temperatures. These
forecast elements will create critical fire weather conditions
this afternoon through the early evening across the northeast and
east central plains and the northeast highlands.
* AREA AND TIMING...The Northeast Highlands, the Northeast Plains
and the East Central Plains from noon to 8 PM MDT.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping to 10 to 15 percent this afternoon,
with single digit humidity likely in the East Central Plains.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
Instruction:
Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the
field of this Red Flag Warning.

* GENERAL SEAS...6 to 8 ft through Thursday night.

Wisconsin River At Portage affecting Columbia County
The National Weather Service in Milwaukee/sullivan has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Wisconsin River At Portage.
* At 10:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 15.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 17.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tomorrow afternoon and
continue to rise to near 18.5 feet by early Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 18.5 feet...Floodwaters affect River Shores Road about
3 miles upstream of Portage in the Town of Lewiston and River Oaks
Road about 7 miles downstream of Portage in the Town of Dekorra in
Columbia County. Water over Levee Rd, Wood St, and Tritz Rd. There
is widespread flooding of roads in the Blackhawk Park Area
including West Lake Road...Blackhawk Road and Wood Street. The
Blackhawk Park area is on the south side of the river about 3 miles
south of Portage.

Alert:
..The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota..
Mississippi River At Aitkin affecting Aitkin and Crow Wing
Counties
Mississippi River at Fort Ripley affecting Crow Wing and Morrison
Counties

.Recent snowfall has been followed by warmer temperatures. The result
has been melting snow running off into rivers and keeping river
levels hovering just below flood stage. River levels will rise to
minor flood stage today and continue steadily rising
due to runoff from melting snow and precipitation expected
today and into Thursday.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Aitkin.
* At  9:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 13.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 14.6 feet by
Sunday morning then begin falling.
* At 15.0 feet...A few homes become surrounded by water in the
Cedarbrook neighborhood near Eagle Rd. The Aitkin city park becomes
flooded..
This crest compares to a previous crest of 14.6 feet on May 14 2014.

Alert:
* WHAT...Waves 3 to 6 feet expected.

* WHERE...Black River to Ontonagon MI and Saxon Harbor WI to
Black River MI.

* WHEN...From 8 PM EDT /7 PM CDT/ this evening to 6 PM EDT /5 PM
CDT/ Thursday.

* IMPACTS...Conditions will be hazardous to small craft.

* WIND AND WAVES DURING THE SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY...Expect
sustained winds of up to 28 knots from the north, with gusts
up to 32 knots. The largest expected significant waves will be
5 feet with a maximum wave height of up to 8 feet possible.

* TIMING...The maximum winds are expected around 8 AM EDT
Thursday with the largest waves expected around 5 AM EDT
Thursday.
Instruction:
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels, should avoid navigating in hazardous conditions.

Alert:
Mississippi River at Wabasha affecting Wabasha and Buffalo Counties
Mississippi River at Winona affecting Winona...Buffalo and
Trempealeau Counties
Mississippi River at La Crosse affecting Houston...La Crosse and
Vernon Counties
Mississippi River at Guttenberg Dam 10 affecting Clayton and Grant
Counties

.Additional snowmelt and forecast rainfall is expected to push river
levels higher into next week.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for The Mississippi River at Winona.

* At  9:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 13.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river is expected to crest in the 15.5-16.5 foot
range around April 24th or 25th.
* Impact...At 16.0 feet...Lock and Dam 5A goes out of operation.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you live in a threatened area, be alert for high or rising water,
and be ready to move to higher ground if necessary.

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Stay tuned to your favorite source of weather information, including
NOAA Weather Radio, for later statements.

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

Alert:
Strengthening low pressure over North Texas will lead to strong
onshore flow developing over the Gulf waters of the Middle Texas
coast this evening and overnight. Strong flow will continue until
a cold front pushes through late in the night. Seas will build in
response to the strong winds.
* WINDS...Southeast 20 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...building to 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas to 9
feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.
Alert:
Strengthening low pressure over North Texas will lead to strong
onshore flow developing over the Gulf waters of the Middle Texas
coast this evening and overnight. Strong flow will continue until
a cold front pushes through late in the night. Seas will build in
response to the strong winds.

Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 10 PM this evening to
3 AM CDT Thursday.

Alert:
Winds will increase and seas will build ahead of an approaching
storm system.

Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 5 PM this afternoon
to 6 AM CDT Thursday.

* WINDS...increasing to 15 to 25 knots and gusty.

* WAVES/SEAS...building to 4 to 6 feet nearshore and 6 to 8 feet
offshore with occasional seas up to 7 feet nearshore and 10 feet
offshore.

A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots...and/or
seas 7 feet or higher...are expected to produce hazardous conditions
for small craft. Inexperienced boaters...especially those operating
smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
At 1022 AM CDT, am area of strong thunderstorms were clustered from
near Henderson to Northfield, or 26 miles north of Mankato, moving
northeast at 35 mph.

Dime size hail and torrential rain are possible with this area
of storms.

Locations impacted include...
Mankato, Faribault, Northfield, Burnsville, Lakeville, Apple Valley,
Shakopee, Savage, Prior Lake, Hastings, Rosemount and Farmington.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 35 between mile markers 50 and 80.
U.S. Highway 14 between mile markers 123 and 125.
U.S. Highway 169 between mile markers 57 and 84.

Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm, and may cause
localized urban flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.
Instruction:

Alert:
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden
Counties
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County

The combination of recent heavy rainfall and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin have caused river gauge
readings along the lower Connecticut River to reach and exceed flood
stage levels.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Northampton.
* until late tonight...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 11:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 112.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 112.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 112.6 feet by
this afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage tonight.
* Impact...At 113.0 feet...Minor flooding will affect portions of
Northampton in the vicinity of the Oxbow and Hadley along Aqua
Vitae Drive. Farming interests in Hatfield outside flood dike
protection will experience flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

Counties

The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Hartford.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:46 AM Wednesday the stage was 19.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 20.1 feet by late
this afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 20.0 feet...Flooding is expected along the river in
portions of Wethersfield, Glastonbury, Rocky Hill and Cromwell. The
high waters and swift flows will disrupt some cross river ferry
services. Upstream of Hartford, flooding will continue to affect
portions of Windsor. Immediate river roads may become impassable in
all of these communities. Further downstream flooding will continue
to overspread sections of Portland, Middletown as well as Chester.

in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.
Alert:
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden
Counties
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County

The combination of recent heavy rainfall and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin have caused river gauge
readings along the lower Connecticut River to reach and exceed flood
stage levels.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Middle Haddam.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:55 AM Wednesday the stage was 8.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 9.2 feet by after
midnight tonight.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...Flooding closes most of Meadow Road, Route
17A, in the Gildersleeve section of Portland. Flooding impacts the
Middletown Marina and Meadow Farms. In Cromwell, portions of River
Road will be closed. In Rocky Hill, parts of Meadow Road will be
impassable for a time. Flooding continues along the river southward
through Essex.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

The Big Sioux River near Canton.
* until further notice.
* At 10AM Wednesday the stage was 1238.66 feet.
* Flood stage is 1235.00 feet.
* At stages near 1238 feet...Nearly all crop and pasture land in the
1/2 mile wide flood plain will be inundated.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not drive cars through flooded areas. the water
depth and road condition may be unsafe.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Sioux River At Sioux Falls I-90.
* until further notice.
* At 10AM Wednesday the stage was 15.31 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.00 feet.
* Forecast...The river will crest near 16.1 feet by Sunday April 21
then begin falling.
* At stages near 17.0 feet...Flooding begins to affect roads, homes,
and businesses in Renner.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Do not drive cars through flooded areas. the water
depth and road condition may be unsafe.

Minnesota...Wisconsin..

and Yellow Medicine Counties

Renville and Yellow Medicine Counties

Counties

Sibley Counties

Counties

Washington Counties
Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota...
Washington and Pierce Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview... The last of the melting snow in the upper basin will
combine with fairly widespread rainfall over the next 24 hours to
increase river levels, with runoff from the precipitation flowing
into area rivers and streams over the coming days.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Savage.
* until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 706.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 702.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 709.1 feet by
early Wednesday morning. Additional rises may be possible
thereafter.
* Impact...At 710.0 feet...Protection of city sanitary sewers may be
necessary.
* Impact...At 705.0 feet...Flood waters begin to impact the park road
at Fort Snelling State Park.
* Impact...At 702.0 feet...Barge loading stops at Port Cargill, and
other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact
Black Dog Road in Burnsville.
* Impact...At 700.0 feet...Flood waters begin to cover trails at Fort
Snelling State Park as well as low parts on the Bloomington Ferry
Bridge trail just east of US 169.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At Morton .
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 25.1 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 21.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 27.5 feet by
Monday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Numerous roads flooded and impassable
between the Minnesota River and Redwood Falls.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Fleischer Rd flooded in North Redwood; storm
sewers closed off and bypass pumping begins.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in
North Redwood.
* Impact...At 19.0 feet...Water reaches flood mitigation culverts on
Riverside Road

The Flood Warning continues for

* At 10:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 16.9 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 19.8 feet by
Sunday evening then begin falling.
* Impact...At 18.0 feet...Sanitary sewers begin to be affected at this
level.
* Impact...At 17.0 feet...Storm sewers may need to be plugged to
prevent water from backing up into streets.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along the
river.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Granite Falls HWY 212.
* from Thursday afternoon until further notice.
* At  9:15 AM Wednesday the stage was 887.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 888.5 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by tomorrow early afternoon and
continue to rise to near 890.9 feet by Monday morning.
* Impact...At 891.6 feet...Flood waters begin to flow into the natural
diversion that starts upstream of Granite Falls...and flows around
the western and southern sections of the city. NAVD88
* Impact...At 891.5 feet...Flood waters begin to affect Highway 67
southeast of town. NAVD88
* Impact...At 889.5 feet...Flood waters begin to top the controlling
bank at Highway 212. NAVD88
* Impact...At 888.5 feet...Flood waters begin to encroach the alley
way along the river at the foot bridge. NAVD88

Minnesota River at Mankato affecting Blue Earth and Nicollet
Counties
Minnesota River at Henderson MN19 affecting Le Sueur...Scott and
Sibley Counties
Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver and Scott Counties
Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota...Hennepin and Scott
Counties
Mississippi River at St. Paul affecting Dakota...Ramsey and
Washington Counties
Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota...
Washington and Pierce Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County

.Overview... The last of the melting snow in the upper basin will
combine with fairly widespread rainfall over the next 24 hours to
increase river levels, with runoff from the precipitation flowing
into area rivers and streams over the coming days.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River At New Ulm.
* until further notice.
* At  9:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 802.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 800.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 805.9 feet by
Wednesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 796.0 feet...Water impacts park land and boat launch
access road is closed.
* Impact...At 795.0 feet...Water begins to impact the access roads in
the floodplain.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

.Overview... The last of the melting snow in the upper basin will
combine with fairly widespread rainfall over the next 24 hours to
increase river levels, with runoff from the precipitation flowing
into area rivers and streams over the coming days.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River near Jordan.
* until further notice.
* At  9:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 27.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 25.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 29.0 feet by
Tuesday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 29.5 feet...Highway 41 at Chaska may close when the
river reaches this stage.
* Impact...At 26.7 feet...The bridge at Scott County Road 9 and Carver
County Road 11/Jonathan Carver Parkway will be closed.
* Impact...At 25.0 feet...Low lying areas and some roads along the
river begin to flood and private sanitary sewers may experience
problems.

.Overview... The last of the melting snow in the upper basin will
combine with fairly widespread rainfall over the next 24 hours to
increase river levels, with runoff from the precipitation flowing
into area rivers and streams over the coming days.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Redwood River near Redwood Falls.
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 6.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 9.0 feet by
Saturday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 8.5 feet...Swayback bridge in Redwood Falls overtopped.
* Impact...At 6.0 feet...Low lying areas, mainly farmland, and some
roads along the river begin to experience flooding; bottom of
Swayback bridge

.Overview... The last of the melting snow in the upper basin will
combine with fairly widespread rainfall over the next 24 hours to
increase river levels, with runoff from the precipitation flowing
into area rivers and streams over the coming days.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Minnesota River at Henderson MN19.
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 733.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 732.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 734.8 feet by
Monday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 733.7 feet...The floodwall gates will be closed when
Henderson reaches 733.7 and the river is still rising at Mankato.
* Impact...At 733.5 feet...Highway 93 may be closed between Henderson
and Hwy 169.
* Impact...At 732.5 feet...Water begins encroaching on highway 19 east
of Henderson.
* Impact...At 732.0 feet...Water begins impacting residences and
agricultural buildings north and south of Henderson.

Alert:
Surface high pressure across the North Gulf combined with lower
pressure inland will support a tighter pressure gradient, with
elevated winds and seas through Thursday morning..
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 10 PM this evening to
6 AM CDT Thursday.

* WINDS...Southeast to south 15 to 25 knots

* WAVES/SEAS...5 to 7 feet nearshore, 6 to 9 feet offshore.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
Minnesota River at Granite Falls HWY 212 affecting Chippewa...
Renville and Yellow Medicine Counties
Minnesota River at Mankato affecting Blue Earth and Nicollet
Counties


.This river forecast is based on snowmelt upstream as well as widespread
rainfall over the course of Wednesday & Thursday, resulting in gradual
runoff into area rivers.
The National Weather Service in Chanhassen has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Minnesota River at Mankato.
* from Friday afternoon until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 21.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Friday early afternoon and
continue to rise to near 23.0 feet by Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 24.5 feet...HWY 99 east of St Peter closed (estimated
level for spring floods)
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

Alert:
The Flood Warning continues for the Coldwater River...Tallahatchie
River.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Tallahatchie River near Lambert
* from Thursday April 18 until Saturday April 20.
* At 9 AM Wednesday the stage was 31.7 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Maximum forecast stage of 32.5 feet on Friday April 19.
* Flood stage is 32.0 feet.
* Forecast to rise above flood stage by Thursday April 18 and
continue to rise to near 32.5 feet by Friday April 19.The river
will fall below flood stage by Saturday April 20.
* At 32.0 feet...Low-lying farmland in northern Quitman County is
flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

A followup Flood Statement will be issued later today.

For graphical river and flood information...please go to
www.weather.gov and click near Memphis on the map, then select Rivers
and Lakes.

Do not drive through flooded areas...turn around don't drown.

Stay tuned to your weather radio and your local news media for the
latest river information.

Alert:
Turtle Creek At Redfield

.The following river forecasts include forecast precipitation through
the next 24 hours. Any additional future precipitation could affect
the forecasts.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Turtle Creek At Redfield.
* until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 8.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Major flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 17.4 feet by
Saturday evening. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* At 18.0 feet...The spillway at Lake Redfield is running nearly full
and is threatened by the high water.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Flood waters can be very dangerous. Never drive
across a flooded road. Turn around don't drown!

Stay tuned for further updates by listening to NOAA weather radio...
or your favorite local media.

For additional information...check out our web site at
www.weather.gov/abr...then left click on the Rivers and Lakes link.

The next scheduled statement will be issued Thursday morning.
Alert:
Kankakee River at Shelby affecting Lake and Newton Counties

The following forecasts are based on observed precipitation as well
as forecast precipitation 24-48 hours into the future.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Kankakee River at Shelby, or from near I-65 and De Motte
downstream to IL/IN state line.
* until Saturday evening.
* At  945 AM Wednesday the stage was 9.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 9.5 feet by
Thursday afternoon. The river will fall below flood stage Saturday
afternoon.
* Impact...At 10.0 feet...County Road 1200W/Range Line Road is
threatened north of the river. Wildwood Estates and Sumava Resorts
begin to experience some flooding.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...If you encounter a flooded roadway...turn around and
find an alternate route.

Alert:
Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Eel River...Flatrock
River...Wabash River...White River...


.With rivers already elevated and ground remaining saturated
forecast rainfall will extend flooding or create new flooding across
a large portion of western and southern Indiana.
The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Spencer.
* from Friday evening until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 12.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Friday evening and continue to
rise to near 17.6 feet by late Sunday night. Additional rises are
possible thereafter.
* At 17.5 feet...Lowest portions of Trails 1 and 7 flood in McCormicks
Creek State Park.  Extensive backwater in Rattlesnake, Fall,
McCormicks, Limestone, Big, and Bean Blossom Creeks with overflow
flooding crops or hay.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
Alert:

.With rivers already elevated and ground remaining saturated
forecast rainfall will extend flooding or create new flooding across
a large portion of western and southern Indiana.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Montezuma.
* until Friday April 26.
* At  9:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 16.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 19.3 feet by Sunday afternoon then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Thursday April 25.
* At 20.0 feet...Park in southern Montezuma begins to flood.  Higher
bottomlands begin to flood.  Water backs up most local tributaries.
River water is at the top of some private levees.  Lowest county
roads begin to flood.  Parke CR 75 W begins to flood.
Instruction:

Alert:
Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Eel River...Flatrock
River...Wabash River...White River...


.With rivers already elevated and ground remaining saturated
forecast rainfall will extend flooding or create new flooding across
a large portion of western and southern Indiana.
The Flood Warning continues for
The East Fork White River near Rivervale.
* from Sunday afternoon to Saturday April 27.
* At 10:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 14.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Sunday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 23.9 feet by Tuesday evening.  It will fall below
flood stage by Friday April 26.
* At 25.0 feet...During the late March 2008 flood, the Bedford Times
reported the following County Roads still under water; River Road,
entire Road; Bartlettsville Road, by the bridge and in the bottoms;
Judah-Logan Road, by the bridge; Logan Bottoms, the gravel part;
Donica Church Road, between Logan Bottom and the hill; Peerless
Road, by Mica Metals; Little Salt Creek Run; Stumphole Bridge Road,
near Indiana State Road 450; Huron-Williams Road; Lawrenceport
Road; Rivervale Road and Earl Road.

.With rivers already elevated and ground remaining saturated
forecast rainfall will extend flooding or create new flooding across
a large portion of western and southern Indiana.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Terre Haute.
* until Friday April 26.
* At 10:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 17.5 feet. This is 2.0 to 2.5
feet higher than the observations from the old legacy gauge.
* Flood stage is 16.5 feet. This is 2.5 feet higher than flood stage
from the old legacy gauge.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 20.2 feet by late Sunday night then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Friday April 26.
* At 20.5 feet...Residential property of about 50 river cabins begin
to flood.  North Lake and Izaak Walton Areas near West Terre Haute
begin to flood.  Flooding closes more county roads.  Lowland
agricultural flooding is in progress.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

Alert:
Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Eel River...Flatrock
River...Wabash River...White River...


.With rivers already elevated and ground remaining saturated
forecast rainfall will extend flooding or create new flooding across
a large portion of western and southern Indiana.
The Flood Warning continues for
The East Fork White River near Bedford.
* from Monday evening to Friday April 26.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to rise above flood stage Monday evening,
crest at 21.4 feet Wednesday April 24, and then fall below flood
stage by Friday April 26.
* At 21.2 feet...At this level during December 2013 backwater reached
the tailwater of Lake Monroe as Salt Creek stopped falling.  The
crest of the river followed 2 days later and reached 27.6 feet at
Bedford and caused Salt Creek to rise nearly 6 feet at the
tailwater of Monroe Lake.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

click on rivers and lakes.

.With rivers already elevated and ground remaining saturated
forecast rainfall will extend flooding or create new flooding across
a large portion of western and southern Indiana.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Vincennes.
* from late Thursday night until further notice.
* At 10:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 15.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late Thursday night and
continue to rise to near 17.4 feet by late Friday night.
* At 17.0 feet...Considerable agricultural flooding extends from just
north of the junction of Illinois 33 with Business 50 to the St.
Francesville, Illinois area.  River Road from Lincoln Memorial
Bridge to Billett Rd is impassable.  Extensive seep water forms
behind Illinois levees extending from Russellville to U.S. Highway
50.  Flooding of agricultural land begins in Knox County Indiana
west of the railroad extending for the Oaktown area to the north
side of Vincennes.  Extensive flooding of Small Creek.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

The Wabash River at Lafayette.
* until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 10.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 11.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Friday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 14.0 feet by late Saturday night.

impassable.  Tapawingo Park in West Lafayette begins to flood.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

bank. Lowell Public Access site is open but ramp is totally

tonight. Any additional future rains could affect the crest
forecasts.
