The Lake Francis Case At Chamberlain.
* until further notice.
* At 09AM Wednesday the stage was 65.32 feet.
* Flood stage is 65.00 feet.

the gauge will begin flooding, and water reaches the top of the boat
ramp near Buryanek camp ground.

Alert:
The flood warning continues for
the Black Cypress Bayou At Jefferson, Texas.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:00 AM Wednesday The stage was 13.4 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13 feet.
* Forecast...The bayou will continue rising to near 13.5 feet by
Saturday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...at 13.0 feet...Lowland flooding will affect mainly timber
resources.

walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

Alert:
* WINDS...Southeast 10 to 20 knots this afternoon veering to the
south and increasing to 15 to 25 knots tonight. Winds becoming
west at 10 to 20 knots on Thursday.


* WAVES...building to 3 to 6 feet tonight and continuing into
Thursday morning.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that winds or waves are expected to
produce hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels should
avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
Wabash River at New Harmony

.Rivel levels are expected to rise along the Wabash River due to heavy
rainfall over the next 48 hours. Minor flooding is forecast to develop at
New Harmony later this afternoon with a crest around 18.0 feet later next
week. Fluctuations to the forecast are possible depending on how much
rain falls over the basin and points upstream.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Wabash River at New Harmony.
* until further notice.
* At  9:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 14.8 feet.
* Flood Stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by this evening and continue to
rise to near 18.0 feet by Thursday April 25th.
* Impact...At 19.0 Feet...Harmonie State Park is closed. Surrounding
bottomland is flooded.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

a total of 3 to 5 inches.

* WHERE...West of North Pole.

* WHEN...Until 1 PM today.

obtained by calling 5 1 1.

Alert:
Pearl River Near Pearl River affecting St. Tammany...Hancock and
Pearl River Counties/Parishes
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...Mississippi...

Pearl River Near Bogalusa affecting St. Tammany...Washington...
Hancock and Pearl River Counties/Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Pearl River Near Pearl River.
* Until further notice.
* At  9:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 14.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to rise to near 15.5 feet by
Thursday April 25 then begin falling.
* Impact...At 15.5 feet...Secondary roads to the river and throughout
Honey Island Swamp are inundated. Property in the vicinity of the
gage is flooded threatening about 20 homes along the left bank. The
Bogue Chitto National Wildlife Refuge will be closed to hunting at
the 15.5 foot stage.
* Impact...At 14.0 feet...Secondary roads to the river and throughout
Honey Island Swamp are inundated. Property in the vicinity of the
gage is flooded threatening about 20 homes along the left bank.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

the Bayou Dorcheat At Lake Bistineau, Louisiana.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 9:00 AM Wednesday The stage was 143.6 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood pool stage is 142.5 feet.
* Forecast...The lake will remain near 143.6 feet through Thursday
morning.
* Impact...at 144.0 feet...Most camps across the lake begin to flood.
Some homes will also face flooding especially homes that are not
stilted. Preparations for flooding should be rushed to completion.

walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

* Wind Gusts...Up to 30 knots.
Instruction:

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
At 950 AM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Ohiowa, or 32
miles south of York, moving east at 30 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Milligan and Ohiowa.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Black River At Jonesville L&D affecting Catahoula and Concordia
Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Black River At Jonesville L&D
* from Sunday evening until further notice.
* At  7:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 49.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 50.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is expected to rise to near flood stage Sunday
evening.
* Flood history...This crest compares to a previous crest of 49.6 feet
on Jan 24 2016.
* Impact...At 50.0 feet...Highway 124 south near the town of Larto
starts to flood. Backwater flooding begins in unprotected areas on
right bank.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Forecasts are based on rainfall that has occurred and that which is
forecast to occur. Routine 48 hours of forecast rainfall is used for
all rivers  except for those in the Tombigbee River System which
includes Tibbee Creek, Luxapallila Creek, Noxubee River, and the
Tombigbee River mainstem where a routine of 48 hours of additional
rainfall is used.

https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

10 PM.

The National Weather Service in Grand Forks, ND has issued a
new Flood Warning for...
* ...Twin Valley...on the Wild Rice River (MN)
* from Thursday afternoon to Monday afternoon.
* At  8:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 8.5 feet.
* Minor Flood Stage is 10.0 feet.
* For the next 7 days...Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...rise above Flood Stage by Thursday afternoon and
continue to rise to near 10.5 feet by Friday morning. The river
will fall below Flood Stage by Sunday.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...turn around, don't drown...

- Don't travel through flooded areas!

- Persons in the warned area need to take steps to protect life
and property. If necessary, move to a higher and safer location.

- Persons living in the Red River Basin should monitor river
levels while the river is in, or near, flood.

For more information...go to the AHPS/River section
on our web page at:      www.weather.gov/grandforks

Alert:
Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Flatrock River...White
River...Wabash River...Eel River...

.Lowland flooding will develop along rivers in central and southern
Indiana. Significant flooding is not expected. Flooding will affect
some local and state roads...low agricultural land and some river
parks.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River near Centerton.
* from Saturday morning to Monday afternoon.
* At 10:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 6.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Saturday morning and continue
to rise to near 13.0 feet by Sunday morning.  It will fall below
flood stage by late Sunday night.
* At 12.4 feet...Road just north of Blue Bluff Bridge has about six
inches of water on it.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

* At 13.2 feet...Lowland flooding in progress along Driftwood River in
northern Bartholomew County on April 6, 2011. Double Y Saddle Club
area flooded.  At least 6 inches of water flowing over CR 950N to
Club. Water is less than one foot away from CR 330W just south of
its intersection with Ohio Ridge Rd. CR 500N west of CR 250W is
flooded blocking vehicular access to residences near the river
bank. Lowell Public Access site is open but ramp is totally
flooded. Water close to one residence at Shelby CR 1000S and CR
900W.

Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Flatrock River...White
River...Wabash River...Eel River...

.Lowland flooding will develop along rivers in central and southern
Indiana. Significant flooding is not expected. Flooding will affect
some local and state roads...low agricultural land and some river
parks.
The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River at Anderson.
* from Friday afternoon to late Saturday night.
* At 10:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 6.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Friday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 11.0 feet by late Friday night.  It will fall below
flood stage by Saturday afternoon.
* At 11.0 feet...Flood waters inundate Edgewater Park.  Water
approaches Grand Avenue east of Broadway Street Bridge.
Instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

* At  9:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 15.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by late Thursday night and
continue to rise to near 17.4 feet by late Friday night.
* At 17.0 feet...Considerable agricultural flooding extends from just
north of the junction of Illinois 33 with Business 50 to the St.
Francesville, Illinois area.  River Road from Lincoln Memorial
Bridge to Billett Rd is impassable.  Extensive seep water forms
behind Illinois levees extending from Russellville to U.S. Highway
50.  Flooding of agricultural land begins in Knox County Indiana
west of the railroad extending for the Oaktown area to the north
side of Vincennes.  Extensive flooding of Small Creek.

The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the East Fork White River near Bedford.
* from Monday evening to Friday April 26.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Forecast...It is forecast to rise above flood stage Monday evening,
crest at 21.4 feet Wednesday April 24 and then fall below flood
stage by Friday April 26.
* At 21.2 feet...At this level during December 2013 backwater reached
the tailwater of Lake Monroe as Salt Creek stopped falling.  The
crest of the river followed 2 days later and reached 27.6 feet at
Bedford and caused Salt Creek to rise nearly 6 feet at the
tailwater of Monroe Lake.

Alert:
Wisconsin River at Castle Rock Dam affecting Adams and Juneau
Counties

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you live in a threatened area, be alert for high or rising water,
and be ready to move to higher ground if necessary.

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Stay tuned to your favorite source of weather information, including
NOAA Weather Radio, for later statements.

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

Big Blue River near Blue Rapids affecting Marshall County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Blue River near Blue Rapids.
* until further notice.
* At 9:15 AM Wednesday the stage was 41.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 41.2 feet by
early Friday morning. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Minor lowland flooding occurs from
Marysville to Tuttle Creek Lake.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Do not drive into flooded areas. Shallow flowing
water can wash a car from the roadway. Also, the roadbed may be
washed out under the water.

Stay tuned to later developments by listening to NOAA Weather Radio
and local media.

Alert:
Noxubee River At Macon affecting Noxubee County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Noxubee River At Macon
* until further notice.
* At 9:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 30.3 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 26.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 30.8 feet just
after midnight tonight.
* Impact...At 30.0 feet...Farm land near the river begins to flood.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 48 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Counties.

Counties.

Missouri River At Miami affecting Carroll...Chariton and Saline

The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River at Waverly.
* until Friday May 10.
* At  8:30 AM Wednesday the stage was 21.6 feet.
* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 21.7 feet by
Tuesday April 23rd. The river will fall below flood stage
Thursday May 9th.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive through flowing water. Nearly half of all flood
fatalities are vehicle related. As little as 6 inches of water may
cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Two feet of water will
carry most vehicles away.This product along with additional weather
and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

Alert:

issued a Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from noon to
6 PM EDT Thursday.

* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
Moist air flowing over cold waters of Lake Michigan was producing areas
of dense fog near Lake Michigan. Remain alert for rapidly falling
visibilities, and use caution if driving near the Lake this
morning.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Milwaukee/Sullivan has issued a
Dense Fog Advisory...which is in effect until noon CDT today.

* VISIBILITY: 1 mile or less.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.
Alert:

Alert:
A cold front brought 2 to 3 inches of snow last night to parts of
the Fairbanks area. The snow fell in a narrow band with the
heaviest snow falling over the west side of town. Areas east of
Fairbanks, such as North Pole, only received light dusting. Any
snowfall in the Fairbanks area will taper off by late morning.
Please use caution when traveling this morning as roadways may be
slippery.
Instruction:

Alert:

Ong, or 33 miles southeast of Hastings, moving east at 30 mph.

Penny size hail will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Geneva, Shickley, Davenport, Milligan, Bruning, Ohiowa, Carleton, Ong
and Strang.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Chicago has issued a Dense Fog
Advisory, which is in effect until 3 PM CDT this afternoon.

* VISIBILITY...Under one half mile.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.
Alert:
The storm which prompted the warning has weakened below severe
limits, and has exited the warned area. Therefore, the warning will
be allowed to expire.  However small hail and gusty winds are still
possible with this thunderstorm.
Instruction:

Alert:
* WINDS...West 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.

* TIMING...Noon today through 7 PM this evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds and rough waves on area lakes will
create hazardous conditions for small craft.
Instruction:
Boaters should use extreme caution if venturing onto Fort Peck
Lake. For your personal safety, avoid the open waters. Stay close
to shore or around protected areas.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Glasgow has issued a Dense Fog
Advisory, which is in effect until 10 AM MDT this morning.

* VISIBILITIES...A quarter mile or less.

* TIMING...Now through 10 AM.

* IMPACTS...Dense fog will create hazardous driving conditions.
Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.

There is also a Lake Wind Advisory in effect for Fort Peck lake.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one quarter mile. If driving, slow down, use
your low beam headlights, and leave plenty of distance ahead of
you.

Alert:
Tallahala Creek At Laurel affecting Jones County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Tallahala Creek At Laurel
* until Saturday afternoon.
* At 8:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 13.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 15.5 feet just
after midnight tonight.
* Impact...At 15.0 feet...Agricultural and lowland flooding is
becoming more widespread along and near the creek.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 48ours. Rainfall
amounts greater than forecast may take the rivers higher.


Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected tonight between 8 and
10 PM.

Big Black River At West affecting Attala and Holmes Counties
Big Black River Near Bentonia affecting Madison and Yazoo Counties
Big Black River Near Bovina affecting Hinds and Warren Counties
The Flood Warning continues for
The Big Black River Near Bentonia
* until further notice.
* At  8:15 AM Wednesday the stage was 28.9 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue falling through tomorrow morning
and then will rise below current levels.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Please note that forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has
occurred along with forecast rainfall for the next 48 hours. River
forecasts in the Tombigbee River Basin have an additional 48 hours of
rainfall added. Rainfall amounts greater than forecast may take the
rivers higher.

Alert:
At 854 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Clay Center, or 16 miles east of Hastings, moving east at 35 mph.

Penny size hail will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Sutton, Harvard, Clay Center, Grafton and Saronville.
Instruction:

Alert:
Light to at times moderate burst of snow over some mountain passes
will lead to slippery roads this morning as road surfaces remain
near or slightly below freezing. As the morning wears on and
temperatures warm, road surfaces are expected to become primarily
wet despite any additional snowfall. Motorist are urged to allow
additional travel time this morning given the potential for some
slippery spots. Be prepared for changing road conditions over a
short distances, especially over mountain passes.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Green Bay has issued a Dense Fog
Advisory, which is in effect until 3 AM CDT Thursday.

* VISIBILITY...1 mile or less, occasionally less than a quarter
mile. Satellite imagery shows dense fog is lifting north and
will overspread the nearshore waters of Door County later this
morning. Fog may dissipate some from afternoon rain showers, but
is expected to redevelop this evening.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
A passing upper level disturbance will combine with a deep low
pressure system to the northeast to produce windy conditions
across southern New Mexico and Texas today. The strongest winds
will occur this afternoon. Wind speeds of 25-35 mph and gusts to
45 mph are expected. Some localized blowing dust may occur in the
afternoon, with low visibilities.
* AREA AFFECTED... Strongest winds will occur along the southern
portions of Luna, Dona Ana, and southern Otero Counties in New
Mexico, along with El Paso and Hudspeth Counties in far west
Texas.

* TIMING...Gusty winds this morning will strength in the
afternoon, peaking around 5pm. Winds will slowly decrease
Wednesday night.

* WINDS...Sustained speeds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts of 45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Winds will make for difficult driving conditions,
especially for high-profile vehicles in cross winds. Loose
objects may blow about. Patchy blowing dust may cause
localized low visibility.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Milwaukee/Sullivan has issued a
Dense Fog Advisory...which is in effect until noon CDT today.

* TIMING...Through midday.

* VISIBILITY...1/4 mile or less.

* IMPACTS...Reduced visibility.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one quarter mile. If driving...slow down...
use your headlights...and leave plenty of distance ahead of you.

Alert:
At 811 AM CDT, a strong thunderstorm was located over Revere, or 23
miles northeast of Slayton, moving northeast at 30 mph.

Nickel size hail is possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Walnut Grove, Lamberton, Wabasso, Lucan, Clements, Revere, Seaforth
and Wanda.

This includes the following highways...
U.S. Highway 14 between mile markers 50 and 63.
U.S. Highway 71 between mile markers 60 and 68.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
Instruction:

Alert:
An area of dense fog along the St. Lawrence River from Alexandria
Bay to Ogdensburg New York will continue through mid morning,
reducing visibility to a quarter mile or less at times. Motorists
should use extreme caution while traveling in this area. Slow
down, and leave plenty of room between you and the car in front of
you.
Instruction:

* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 22.7 feet by early Friday
morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 23.0 feet...Flooding will affect swamp and timberlands while also
disrupting logging operations. Operations will likely cease and equipment not
previously moved will remain trapped. Some farmland will have minor flooding
especially around Britton Neck.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

People with interests along the river should take the necessary precautions to
protect life and property from the flood waters.

Additional information is available on our website at weather.gov/ilm under the
"Rivers and Lakes" link.

17 miles southwest of New Ulm, moving northeast at 20 mph.

Nickel size hail is possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
New Ulm, Madelia, Courtland, Hanska, La Salle, Sveadahl, Grogan and
Searles.

This includes U.S. Highway 14 near mile marker 99.

Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

Instruction:

Alert:
Snow is falling this morning over the greater Anchorage area
through the Matanuska Valley. Accumulations of up to 2 inches are
expected along the Anchorage Hillside and Eagle River, with little
to no accumulation from Midtown west. Up to 4 inches of snow are
possible in the Matanuska Valley. There is a potential for slick
surfaces, and travel conditions may become difficult. The snow is
expected to switch over to rain around noon today. Temperatures
will climb into the lower to mid 40s this afternoon.

For current road conditions dial 5-1-1 or visit www.511.alaska.gov
Instruction:

The Flood Warning continues for

* until Saturday afternoon...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  5:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 47.4 feet.
* Flood stage is 47.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 50.2 feet by

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you live in a threatened area, be alert for high or rising water,
and be ready to move to higher ground if necessary.

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

NOAA Weather Radio, for later statements.

Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire
Counties

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Massachusetts...Connecticut...
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire
Counties
Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hartford and Hampden
Counties
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex
Counties
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County

The combination of recent heavy rainfall and snow melt across the
upper reaches of the Connecticut River basin have caused river gauge
readings along the lower Connecticut River to reach and exceed flood
stage levels.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Connecticut River At Middle Haddam.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  4:55 AM Wednesday the stage was 8.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 7.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 9.2 feet by after
midnight tonight.
* Impact...At 9.5 feet...Flooding closes most of Meadow Road, Route
17A, in the Gildersleeve section of Portland. Flooding impacts the
Middletown Marina and Meadow Farms. In Cromwell, portions of River
Road will be closed. In Rocky Hill, parts of Meadow Road will be
impassable for a time. Flooding continues along the river southward
through Essex.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...A Flood Statement providing the latest information
in this flood event will be issued within the next 8 hours, or
earlier if needed.

Safety Message...Do not allow children to play near swollen rivers,
streams or culverts. Swiftly moving water can pose an imminent threat
to life.

and/or steep waves are expected to produce hazardous wave
conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

Alert:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 6 inches
is anticipated.

* WHERE...Sangre de Cristo Mountains Above 11000 Feet, Pikes Peak
Above 11000 Feet, and Wet Mountains Above 10000 Feet.

* WHEN...Until 9 PM MDT this evening.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The
hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening
commute.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

Alert:
Locally dense fog will occur across parts of northern Michigan
this morning. Dense fog is most likely near Lake Huron, as well as
over the higher elevations of northern lower Michigan. Dense fog
will reduce visibilities to a quarter mile or less, making travel
more difficult. The fog will gradually burn off after 9 am.

Use low-beam headlights if you encounter dense fog. Slow down and
leave extra space between yourself and vehicles around you. Use
extra caution near school bus stops.
Instruction:

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Portland has issued a Small Craft
Advisory for rough bar, which is in effect from 3 PM this
afternoon to 6 PM PDT this evening. A Small Craft Advisory for
rough bar has also been issued from 3 AM to 6 AM PDT Thursday.

* IN THE MAIN CHANNEL...

* GENERAL SEAS...near 7 ft today through Thursday.

* FIRST EBB...Around 4 am today. Seas near 10 ft, with breakers
likely.

* SECOND EBB...Around 415 pm today. Seas near 10 ft with
breakers possible.

* THIRD EBB...Strong ebb around 445 am Thursday. Seas 11 ft with
breakers likely.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for rough bar means that wave conditions
are expected to be hazardous to small craft in or near harbor
entrances.

Alert:
Fox River Near Berlin affecting Green Lake County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Fox River Near Berlin.
* At  3:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 13.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 13.4 feet by
Saturday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 13.3 feet...There is minor flooding in the Berlin area
including in Riverside and Webster Street Parks in Berlin.
Instruction:

Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternate
route. Turn around, don't drown.

Additional river and weather information is available at
www.weather.gov/ilx.

Alert:
..WIND ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT THIS AFTERNOON UNTIL EARLY THIS
EVENING FOR THE EDDY COUNTY PLAINS...SOUTHERN LEA COUNTY...REEVES
COUNTY...THE UPPER TRANS PECOS...EASTERN CULBERSON COUNTY AND THE
VAN HORN AREA...THE DAVIS MOUNTAINS AND FOOTHILLS...CHINATI
MOUNTAINS...AND MARFA PLATEAU...

.A passing upper trough will result in high winds across the
Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains today. Strong winds are also
anticipated across portions of Southeast New Mexico southward to
the Davis Mountains and Marfa Plateau. Conditions will begin to
improve this evening as the system moves east.
* TIMING...This afternoon through this evening.

* WINDS...West 40 to 50 mph with gusts to 70 mph.

* IMPACTS...People driving high-profile vehicles should be very
cautious traveling in the mountains, particularly in a north
and south direction. Significant turbulence will be hazardous
for low flying light aircraft.
Instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.
Alert:
..WIND ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT THIS AFTERNOON UNTIL EARLY THIS
EVENING FOR THE EDDY COUNTY PLAINS...SOUTHERN LEA COUNTY...REEVES
COUNTY...THE UPPER TRANS PECOS...EASTERN CULBERSON COUNTY AND THE
VAN HORN AREA...THE DAVIS MOUNTAINS AND FOOTHILLS...CHINATI
MOUNTAINS...AND MARFA PLATEAU...

.A passing upper trough will result in high winds across the
Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains today. Strong winds are also
anticipated across portions of Southeast New Mexico southward to
the Davis Mountains and Marfa Plateau. Conditions will begin to
improve this evening as the system moves east.
* TIMING...This afternoon through early this evening.

* WINDS...West 30 to 40 mph with gusts 50 to 55 mph.

* IMPACTS...Secure lawn furniture, garbage cans, or other objects
which could be blown about by the wind.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
A broad area of fog has formed across the Finger Lakes into the
southern tier of New York this morning with isolated spots
experiencing patchy dense fog. If traveling this morning be aware
that visibilities may be reduced to a half mile or less over very
short distances. Use extra caution when driving, and set
headlights to low beam when driving through fog. The fog is
expected to lift and mix out by 9 am this morning.
Instruction:

Alert:
Localized dense fog has developed early this morning, especially
along the New York Thruway in Chautauqua and southern Erie
counties, as well as the lower spots in Genesee, Livingston,
Wyoming, and Ontario counties. Light winds combined with recent
rainfall should allow for fog to persist through sunrise and the
morning commute. Morning commuters should be prepared for rapidly
reduced visibilities below one quarter of a mile at times.
Instruction:

Alert:
River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River at Winona.
* until further notice...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At  3:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 13.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Impact...At 13.0 feet...Prairie Island Park begins to flood. Pumping
operations are underway by the city of Winona, and dike patrols are
started.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

precipitation.

Alert:
Strong northwest winds with gusts up to 40 to 50 mph will follow
a Pacific cold front this afternoon into the early evening,
thanks to an upper low crossing New Mexico today. This will cause
potentially hazardous crosswinds for U.S. Highways 64 and 491
starting by 3pm and lasting through 8pm.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 3 PM this afternoon to 8 PM MDT
this evening.

* LOCATION...Northwest Plateau, including Farmington to Shiprock.

* WINDS...Northwest sustained 25 to 35 mph with gusts of 40 to 50
mph.

* TIMING...Winds will begin to strengthen by 3pm MDT, peaking by
6pm MDT, tapering off by 8pm MDT.

* VISIBILITY...No visibility reductions are expected due to wind.

* LOCAL IMPACTS...Crosswinds will create potentially hazardous
travel for high profile vehicles along U.S. Highways 64 and 491.
Instruction:
Motorists should exercise caution while travelling. Sudden gusts
of wind may cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Extra
attention should be given to cross winds.
Alert:
River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.

Alert:
Strengthening low pressure over North Texas will lead to
strong onshore flow developing in deep waters this evening and
overnight. Strong flow will continue until a cold front pushes
through late in the night. Seas will build in response to the
strong winds.
The National Weather Service in Corpus Christi has issued a Small
Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 9 PM this evening to 5 AM
CDT Thursday.

* WINDS...Southeast 20 to 25 knots.

* WAVES/SEAS...building to 6 to 8 feet with occasional seas to 10
feet.
Instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 7 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions. Mariners should pay close
attention to the marine forecast...and consider wind and sea
conditions in planning.

Alert:
A storm over Arizona will cross New Mexico today with sufficient
moisture and instability to generate snow over the Sangre de
Cristo Mountains. Highest amounts will be above 9500 feet where
snowfall will meet and exceed winter weather advisory criteria. A
wind shift to the northeast later today into tonight may produce
a few inches of snow on the east slopes.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 8 inches
expected, locally higher amounts around 10 inches on the highest
peaks.

* WHERE...Northern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet including
Red River and Southern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet.

* WHEN...From 6 AM this morning to midnight MDT tonight.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
Instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by
calling 5 1 1 or 1-800-432-4269.

Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

Alert:
At 403 AM EDT, emergency management reported snowmelt causing small
stream flooding in Island Falls. MDOT has closed Route 2 in Island
Falls at the Dyer Brook bridge due to flooding caused by ice and
snowmelt.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Island Falls.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

A Flood Advisory means river or stream flows are elevated, or ponding
of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
Alert:

Light.

It is possible that the Dense Fog Advisory may eventually need to
be extended south later tonight.
Instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

flooding caused by ice and snowmelt.

deaths occur in vehicles.

Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
At 339 AM EDT, the river gauge at Washburn indicated a water level
of 17.13 feet, which is moderate flood stage.  Ice jams still locked
in place near Washburn and Crouseville along with continued river
rises will cause low land flooding in the warned area. Low lying
structures on Gardner Creek Road may begin to flood today.

The combination of pre-existing ice jams and continued snowmelt will
result in a continued slow rise of river levels through this
afternoon or until the ice jam releases.  In addition, brief rapid
rises are possible once the ice locked in place begins to break up
and move. Those residents who are impacted by flooding in Washburn,
Wade and Crouseville along the Aroostook River should closely watch
the river levels over the coming days due to the increased flood
threat.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Crouseville, Washburn and Wade.
Instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

To report flooding, contact the National Weather Service in Caribou
at 1-800-909-5970 or visit https://inws.ncep.noaa.gov/report. You
may also contact local law enforcement.

Alert:
Recent rainfall and snowmelt have weakened the remaining river
ice across northern Maine. Rivers will continue to rise today due
to the recent snowmelt and rain in the Flood Watch area. Small
river flooding is expected to bring localized impacts to the
region. Smaller rivers should begin to slowly trend down today.
River ice will continue to move on the Aroostook and Saint John
River systems today. Ice jam flooding is possible, especially in
areas that had pre-existing ice jams from this past winter.
The Flood Watch is now in effect for

* A portion of Far Northern Maine, including the following
areas, Northeast Aroostook and Northwest Aroostook.

* Through this afternoon.

* Recent rainfall and snowmelt may lead to ice jam flooding along
the Saint John and Aroostook Rivers. The highest threat areas
for flooding will be in regions that have pre-existing ice jams
from this past winter.

* A second flood threat will be small stream flooding with many
small streams already at or near bankfull. This could lead to
flooding in lowland areas bordering the streams. Low lying roads
and small stream crossings could become impassable due to
flooding. Never drive into a flooded road, turn around don't
drown. Small streams and rivers will begin to trend down today.
Instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.

Thursday.

* WAVES...building to 3 to 6 feet.
Instruction:

produce hazardous conditions to small craft. Inexperienced
mariners...especially those operating smaller vessels should
avoid navigating in these conditions.

Alert:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has expanded the

* Flash Flood Watch to include portions of north central
Louisiana and Texas, including the following areas, in north
central Louisiana, Jackson and Ouachita. In Texas, Gregg,
Nacogdoches, Rusk, and Shelby.

* From this evening through Thursday evening

* Showers and thunderstorms will increase in coverage across the
region on Wednesday night. With recent rainfall causing flash
flooding across this area, an additional two to three inches
of rainfall over a short period of time could cause additional
flash flood concerns.

* Heavy rainfall may lead to flooding of low-lying and poor
drainage areas, as well as flooding of rivers, creeks, and
streams.
Instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions may develop that lead
to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a very dangerous situation.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...

If you live or travel near streams and rivers seek higher ground
immediately at first signs of rising water. Obey all road closure
signs, they are there for your safety. Do not attempt to drive
through flooded areas, most flood deaths occur in automobiles. Turn
around, don't drown!

Stay tuned to developments by listening to noaa weather radio, or by
visiting our web site at: weather.gov.

Alert:
A cold front is passing through Fairbanks this evening. This is
bringing gusty west winds, cooler temperatures, and scattered
rain and snow showers.

After 10 PM tonight, the scattered showers will change to snow.
By early Wednesday morning, the snow showers will become more
widespread, before tapering off late Wednesday morning. In valley
locations the snow will melt soon after hitting the ground. In
the hills, between one and 2 inches of snow is possible tonight
and Wednesday morning.
Instruction:

Alert:
A passing storm system, across central New Mexico, will
tighten pressure gradients and mix down strong winds from above,
to increase surface winds overnight tonight through Wednesday.
The strongest winds are expect to develop in the afternoon hours
on Wednesday. Strong west and southwest winds will blow across
southern New Mexico and west Texas with the strongest winds along
the International Border. Wind speeds of 25-35 mph and gusts to 45
mph will be possible. Some localized blowing dust may occur in
the afternoon, with low visibilities.
* AREA AFFECTED... Strongest winds will occur along the southern
portions of Luna, Dona Ana, and southern Otero Counties in New
Mexico, along with El Paso and Hudspeth Counties in far west
Texas.

* TIMING...Gusty winds Wednesday morning will strength in the
afternoon, peaking around 5pm. Winds will slowly decrease
Wednesday night.

* WINDS...Sustained speeds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts of 45 mph.

* IMPACTS...Winds will make for difficult driving conditions,
especially for high-profile vehicles in cross winds. Loose
objects may blow about. Patchy blowing dust may cause
localized low visibility.
Instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 mph are expected. Winds
this strong can make driving difficult, especially for high
profile vehicles. Use extra caution.
Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

anticipated.

* WHERE...Northern and southern Sangre de Cristo mountains above

cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

Alert:

gusts between 40 and 50 mph. The strongest winds will occur
across the wind prone passes between Gaviota and Refugio. Winds
will then shift to the north to northeast affecting the same
areas but expanding across the hills above and around Montecito
this evening into the overnight hours. There will be local gusts
to 55 mph, especially around the hills of Montecito. Winds will
start to diminish some early Wednesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. This includes Highways 101, 154 and
192...as well as the Gaviota and San Marcos Passes.
Instruction:

cross winds.

58 mph. Winds this strong can make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. In addition, strong winds over desert

caution.

Alert:
At 846 PM PDT/846 PM MST/, Doppler radar indicated that rain had
ended in the Lake Havasu City area. However, another area of rain
will affect the city between 9 and 10 PM MST. Amounts will be light,
but the additional rain could cause brief rises in already flowing
washes.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Lake Havasu City, Three Dunes Campground, Desert Hills, Black Meadow
Landing Campground and Cattail Cove State Park.
Instruction:
In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Find an alternate route.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Vicksburg
* until Friday May 03.
* At 10:00 PM Tuesday the stage was 45.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 43.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 46.5 feet
Saturday April 20.
* Impact...At 46.5 feet...Portions of Highway 465, Eagle Lake Road and

water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Mississippi River forecasts are based on rainfall that has occurred
and that which is forecast to occur over the next 48 hours.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected between 8 and 10 AM.
Alert:
Bolivar and Washington Counties

Mississippi River Near Greenville affecting Chicot...East
Carroll...Issaquena and Washington Counties

Mississippi River At Vicksburg affecting Madison...Tensas...
Claiborne...Jefferson and Warren Counties/Parishes]

Mississippi River At Natchez affecting Concordia...Adams and
Wilkinson Counties/Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Natchez
* until Wednesday May 08.
* At 10:00 PM Tuesday the stage was 53.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 54.0 feet Sunday
April 21.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River Near Arkansas City
* until Sunday morning.
* At 10:00 PM Tuesday the stage was 37.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 37.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 37.5 feet
Wednesday April 17.
* Impact...At 37.0 feet...The low silt plain in front of arkansas city
inside the levee system begins to flood along with widespread
bottomland flooding at huntington point mississippi.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Mississippi River forecasts are based on rainfall that has occurred
and that which is forecast to occur over the next 48 hours.

Alert:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Instruction:
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
Alert:
At 843 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain was tapering off
along Oatman Highway just south of Golden Valley. The highway was
already flooded and closed between mile markers 39 and 40, and it is
possible that the water will flow down the Sacramento Wash and reach
Oatman Topock Highway just north of Interstate 40 tonight.
Instruction:
Please report flooding to your local law enforcement agency when you
can do so safely.

A Flash Flood Warning means that flooding is imminent or occurring.
If you are in the warned area move to higher ground immediately.
Residents living along streams and creeks should take immediate
precautions to protect life and property.
Alert:
The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northern Yuma County in northeastern Colorado...

* Until 1030 PM MDT.

* At 944 PM MDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from 7 miles east of Lone Star to 8 miles northeast of
Eckley, moving northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Clarkville and Wauneta.

This includes Highway 385 between mile markers 257 and 269.
Instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.
Alert:
The Flood Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Turn around, don't drown. Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility
vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep to allow
for safe passage. As little as one foot of water on the road can move
most vehicles off the road.


Additional information is available at:
weather.gov/Pendleton
Alert:
The storm which prompted the warning has weakened below severe
limits, and has exited the warned area. Therefore, the warning will
be allowed to expire.

However, a Severe Thunderstorm Warning still remains in effect for
northwestern Yuma County until 945 PM MDT.
Instruction:

Alert:
..The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana..

Black River At Jonesville L&D affecting Catahoula and Concordia
Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Black River At Jonesville L&D
* from Saturday morning until further notice.
* At  5:00 AM Tuesday the stage was 49.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 50.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river is expected to rise to near flood stage
Saturday morning.
* Impact...At 50.0 feet...Highway 124 south near the town of Larto
starts to flood. Backwater flooding begins in unprotected areas on
right bank.
Instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive or walk through areas where water covers roadway! The
water may be deeper than it appears. Remember...Turn around, don't
drown!

Forecasts are based on rainfall that has occurred and that which is
forecast to occur. Routine 24 hours of forecast rainfall is used for
all rivers  except for those in the Tombigbee River System which
includes Tibbee Creek,  Luxapallila Creek, Noxubee River,and the
Tombigbee River mainstem where a routine of 48 hours of additional
rainfall is used.

Additional information is available at:
https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=JAN

The next regularly scheduled update is expected between 8 and 10 AM.
